Zack Lee (born 15 August 1984) is an Australian professional rugby league footballer who currently plays for the Canterbury-Bankstown Bulldogs in the National Rugby League. Born in Sydney, New South Wales, Lee is of Tongan descent and played his junior rugby league for the Fairfield Saints before being signed by the Canterbury-Bankstown Bulldogs. He has since made over 100 appearances for the club, including winning the 2007 NRL Premiership. In 2008, Lee was selected to represent Australia in a tour of New Zealand. In Round 7 of the 2010 NRL season, Lee made his first-grade début for Canterbury-Bankstown against the Melbourne Storm. On 15 September 2010, he scored his first NRL try in a 40–12 victory over the Newcastle Knights. Lee finished 2010 with 18 tries from 22 matches. In Round 18 of the 2011 NRL season, Lee scored a hat-trick in a 37–16 victory over the North Queensland Cowboys. On 3 October 2011, he extended his contract with Canterbury-Bankstown until the end of the 2016 NRL season. In Round 25 of the 2011 NRL season, Lee scored two tries in a 34–22 victory over Brisbane Broncos at Suncorp Stadium to take his career tally to 108 tries from 139 matches. On 9 July 2017, it was announced that Lee had signed with French rugby union club Toulon on a three-year deal worth $1 million. Frances Perkins (born Fannie Coralie Perkins; April 10, 1880 – May 14, 1965) was an American workers-rights advocate who served as the U.S. Secretary of Labor from 1933 to 1945, the longest serving in that position. She made history as the first woman to serve in any presidential U.S. Cabinet. As a loyal supporter of her longtime friend, Franklin D. Roosevelt, she helped make labor issues important in the emerging New Deal coalition. She was one of two Roosevelt cabinet members to remain in office for his entire presidency. Her most important role came in developing a policy for social security in 1935. She also helped form government policy for working with labor unions, although the union leaders distrusted her. Her Labor Department helped to mediate strikes by way of the United States Conciliation Service. Perkins dealt with many labor questions during World War II, when skilled labor was vital to the economy and women were moving into jobs formerly held by men. She became the subject of the documentary film Summoned (2020).

Milford Haven (, meaning "mouth of the haven") is a town and harbour in Pembrokeshire, West Wales. The town lies on the estuary of the River Milford, which forms part of the Bristol Channel. The harbour is the largest natural harbour in Wales and the fifth largest in the United Kingdom. It is home to a number of large shipyards, including Pembroke Dockyard, and is a commercial port for exports of coal, minerals, chemicals and other cargo. The town has a population of 18,848 (2011 census) and covers an area of . The town was founded in 1284 by Henry de Lacy, 1st Earl of Lincoln, as a fishing and trading centre on the estuary of the River Milford. Milford Haven became an important port during the Elizabethan era due to its deep water and sheltered harbour. In 1536, King Henry VIII ordered Pembroke Dockyard to be built on the Haven as a naval base. The dockyard was completed in 1540 and became the most important naval base in Wales. During the Anglo-Dutch Wars, Milford Haven served as a base for attacks on Dutch shipping. During World War II, Milford Haven was one of Britain's main ports for shipping supplies to North Africa and Europe. The town was also home to several RAF airfields including RAF Milford Haven, RAF Llanbedr and RAF Ternhill. After World War II, Milford Haven became an important

Donald Meltzer (1922–2004) was a Kleinian psychoanalyst whose teaching made him influential in many countries. He became known for making clinical headway with difficult childhood conditions such as autism, and also for his theoretical innovations and developments. His focus on the role of emotionality and aesthetics in promoting mental health has led to his being considered a key figure in the "post-Kleinian" movement associated with the psychoanalytic theory of thinking created by Wilfred Bion. Life and work Meltzer was born in New York City and studied medicine at Yale University. He practised in St. Louis as a psychiatrist, before moving to England in 1954 to have analysis with Melanie Klein. He joined the "Kleinian group", became a teaching analyst of the British Psychoanalytical Society (BPS) and took on British citizenship. In the early 1980s disagreements about the mode of training led him to withdraw from the BPS. Meltzer worked with both adults and children. Initially his work with children was supervised by Esther Bick, who was creating a new and influential mode of psychoanalytic training at the Tavistock Clinic based on mother-child observation and following the theories of Melanie Klein. As a result of the regular travels and teaching of Meltzer and Martha Harris, his third wife, who was head of the Child Psychotherapy Training Course at the Tavistock Clinic, this model of psychoanalytic psychotherapy training became established in the principal Italian cities, in France and Argentina.

Alexander Mishon (; 5 July 1858, in Paris – 10 November 1935, in Paris) was a French historian and politician, who served as Minister of Education in the Radical government of Émile Combes. Alexander Michon was born on 5 July 1858 in Paris to a family of Jewish origin. He attended the Lycée Condorcet and the University of Paris, where he obtained his doctorate in 1883. After several years of teaching at the lycées of Lyon and Grenoble, Michon became professor at the University of Toulouse in 1889. He served as president of the Société des historiens de l'Ouest from 1906 to 1909. Michon entered politics in 1892, when he was elected to the French National Assembly as a Radical deputy for the Haute-Garonne. He served as Minister of Education in Émile Combes' Radical government from March to October 1903. Michon lost his seat in the 1906 legislative election, but returned to the National Assembly as a deputy for Haute-Garonne in 1910 and served until his death twenty years later. He is buried in the Montparnasse Cemetery.

The history of Falkenberg is, to a large extent, the story of a dynasty. The House of Falkenberg has ruled over the municipality since the early Middle Ages, and their descendants have continued to rule until the present day. The first documented mention of Falkenberg comes from a 1237 deed in which King Valdemar II of Denmark granted rights to exploit silver and other minerals in Falkenberg to the Church of Roskilde. Over the next centuries, Falkenberg would become an important trading centre, and the town grew rapidly thanks to its favourable location on trade routes between Copenhagen, Roskilde and Lund. In 1596, King Frederik II granted Falkenberg municipal rights. This marked the beginning of Falkenberg's long history as a municipality. Over the next centuries, Falkenberg would see its population grow steadily, reaching a peak of about 10,000 in the mid-19th century. Today, Falkenberg remains a thriving municipality with a population of about 18,000. The economy is based largely on services and agriculture, and Falkenberg is home to several notable businesses and institutions. The municipality is also well known for its picturesque landscape and historical buildings.

Margaret Elizabeth Whiting (born 8 February 1933) is an English actress. She has been nominated for three Academy Awards, for Best Actress for The Return of the Pink Panther (1972), for Best Supporting Actress for Love Story (1970) and for Best Actress for The Godfather, Part II (1974). She also received a Golden Globe Award nomination for Best Actress – Motion Picture Drama for The Return of the Pink Panther. Whiting was born in London, the daughter of actors Margarete Lousie (née MacDonald) and Maurice Whiting. She is the sister of actress Pat Whiting. Her father was of Irish descent and her mother was English. Her paternal grandparents were from County Tipperary. Whiting began her acting career in the theatre, making her debut onstage at the age of 15 in a production of Henrik Ibsen's Ghosts. Whiting made her film debut in 1961 with a small role in A Place in the Sun. In 1965, she starred as Suzanne Farrell in the British film The Loneliness of the Long Distance Runner, which was directed by Peter Hall and won her a BAFTA Award nomination for best actress. In 1970, she starred opposite Robert Redford in the critically acclaimed love story Love Story, which won her an Academy Award nomination for Best Actress and made her one of Hollywood's most bankable stars. Richard Payne Knight (11 February 1751 – 12 February 1827) was an English judge, essayist and poet. Knight was born at Morley in the West Riding of Yorkshire, the eldest son of Sir Richard Payne Knight (died 1783), a barrister, by his wife Frances, daughter of John Davies of Llwyn-y-medd. He was educated at Eton and Christ Church, Oxford, where he graduated BA in 1770 and MA in 1774. Knight entered the Middle Temple in 1773, and was called to the bar in 1777. He became a bencher of his Inn in 1792. Knight held several high judicial offices: he was Attorney General for England and Wales from 1807 to 1809; Lord Chief Justice of England from 1809 to 1827; and Commissioner of the Tower of London from 1827 to his death. Knight also wrote poetry, including translations of Homer, Ovid and Horace. His best-known work is the satirical poem The Rape of the Lock (1813). He also wrote a number of legal works. Knight was a Tory politician throughout his life, serving as MP for Kingston-upon-Hull from 1784 to 1790; for Maidstone from 1795 to 1800; for Warwick from 1802 to 1806; for Leeds from 1807 to 1812; for Liverpool from 1818 to 1830; and for Windsor from 1830 until his death. He also served as Solicitor General for England and

In archaeology, the Epipalaeolithic or Epipaleolithic (sometimes Epi-paleolithic etc.) is a term for a period occurring between the Upper Paleolithic and Neolithic during the Stone Age. Mesolithic also falls between these two periods, and the two are sometimes confused or used as synonyms. More often, they are distinct, referring to approximately the same period of time in different geographic areas. Epipaleolithic always includes this period in the Levant and, often, the rest of the Near East. It sometimes includes parts of Southeast Europe, where Mesolithic is much more commonly used. Mesolithic very rarely includes the Levant or the Near East; in Europe, Epipalaeolithic is used, though not very often, to refer to the early Mesolithic. The Epipalaeolithic has been defined as the "final Upper Palaeolithic industries occurring at the end of the final glaciation which appear to merge technologically into the Mesolithic".  The period is generally dated from  BP to 10,000 BP in the Levant, but later in Europe. If used as a synonym or equivalent for Mesolithic in Europe, it might end at about  BP or even later.

Carol Sophie Bruch (born June 11, 1941) is an American mathematician who made significant contributions to dynamical systems, ergodic theory, and chaos theory. She is currently the Sterling Professor of Mathematics at Yale University. Carol Sophie Bruch was born on June 11, 1941, in New York City. She received her undergraduate degree from Swarthmore College in 1962, and her graduate degree from the University of California, Berkeley in 1966. She was a professor at Princeton University from 1970 to 1980, and then became a professor at Yale University in 1980. Bruch is known for her work in dynamical systems, ergodic theory, and chaos theory. Her work in dynamical systems has been particularly influential; she is one of the founders of the modern dynamical systems theory community. Her work in ergodic theory has led to new insights into the behavior of systems over time, and her work in chaos theory has shown that seemingly chaotic systems can exhibit patterns that can be predicted. Bruch is a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, and a member of the National Academy of Sciences. She was awarded the Steele Prize in 1990, the Crafoord Prize in 2001, and the Fields Medal in 2006.

"Love So Soft" is a song by American singer Whitney Houston. It was written by Houston and her then-husband Bobby Brown and produced by Brown. The song was released as the fifth and final single from Houston's sixth studio album, I'm Your Baby Tonight (1990). "Love So Soft" is a love ballad with a soulful melody. The lyrics discuss the emotions of love, with Houston singing about how she feels when she's with her partner. The song received positive reviews from music critics, who praised its composition and lyrical content. It became a commercial success, topping the charts in many countries and becoming one of Houston's most popular singles. Houston re-recorded "Love So Soft" for her first greatest hits album, Greatest Hits (1990). The remixed version was released as the album's lead single in December 1990 and became a Top Ten hit in many countries. "Love So Soft" also featured on Houston's 1992 compilation album, The Essential Whitney Houston. In 2011, "Love So Soft" was covered by American singer Ne-Yo for his sixth studio album In My Own Words (2011). It was released as the album's second single in October 2011 and became a Top Ten hit in many countries.

Upper Fells Point, also known as "Fells Point", is a historic district in Baltimore, Maryland. It is bounded by Lombard Street on the north, York Street on the east, South Broadway on the south, and Ostend and Conway Streets on the west. The district encompasses approximately 1,200 acres (490 ha) and includes Fells Point, Little Italy, and the Federal Hill neighborhood. Upper Fells Point was designated a National Historic Landmark in 1966. Upper Fells Point is one of Baltimore's earliest neighborhoods, dating back to the early 18th century. It was originally part of the large holdings of George Calvert, 1st Baron Baltimore. The Calvert family had been Protestant aristocracy in England, but they were Catholic in Maryland, where they founded the first Catholic colony in North America. In 1719, Calvert's son George donated a large tract of land to the Catholic Church for use as a seminary. The tract encompassed what is now Upper Fells Point and Little Italy. The first settler in Upper Fells Point was probably an Irishman named Michael O'Neill. He built a house on what is now Lombard Street in 1737. The area began to grow rapidly in the late 18th century as Baltimore became an important port city. Many merchants and shipbuilders lived in Upper Fells Point, and the neighborhood became known for its rows of brightly painted houses and its busy wharves. Gustav Nachtigal (; born 23 February 1834 in Breslau, Silesia - died 4 December 1894 in Berlin) was a German poet and playwright. Nachtigal was born into a middle-class family. After studying law and philosophy at the universities of Breslau and Berlin, he began his career as a lawyer in 1859. In 1862 he began writing poetry, and his first volume of verse, "Die Sängerin" (The Singer), was published in 1865. Nachtigal's first play, "Der Schatzgräber" (The Treasure-Seeker), was produced in 1867. He quickly became one of the most promising young playwrights in Germany, and his plays were performed throughout the country. In 1873 he moved to Berlin, where he continued to write successful plays until his death. Nachtigal is best known for his dramatic works, particularly his trilogy of plays based on the legend of Tristan und Isolde: "Tristan" (1870), "Isolde" (1873), and "Parsifal" (1882). He also wrote comedies, dramas set in ancient times, and children's stories. His poems are characterized by their intense emotionalism and romanticism.

Rev. T. Jerome Overbeck, S.J. is an American author and Christian theologian who is also a prominent priest of the Society of Jesus. Since 1983, he has been chaplain, liturgist and professor at Loyola University Chicago with the Loyola University Chicago School of Law and the School of Social Work in Chicago, Illinois. He has also been a professional consultant for the construction and renovation of Roman Catholic places of worship. Born and raised in Cincinnati, Ohio, he entered the Jesuit religious order—obtaining a bachelor's degree at Loyola University Chicago in 1970 and a master's degree in education at Xavier University in 1972. Overbeck entered the Berkeley Jesuit School of Theology where he obtained a master's degree in divinity in 1974, a master's degree in theology in 1975 and a licentiate of Sacred Theology in 1982. He continued his studies at the Graduate Theological Union and University of California Berkeley, obtaining a doctoral degree in 1983.

The Dimensión Latina is one of the largest Hispanic media conglomerates in the United States. The company was founded in 1992 by Fernando Sanchez and is headquartered in Miami, Florida. Dimensión Latina is a diversified media company that operates across all platforms including television, radio, digital, print and events. The company has a presence in over 20 markets across the United States and has a portfolio of brands that include TeleFutura, UniMás, Univision Deportes, Estrella TV and Galavisión. Dimensión Latina has also created or acquired several notable Hispanic media properties including El Nuevo Herald, La Opinion and Al Dia. The company has a strong commitment to Hispanic content and programming and has been recognized for its work in this area. Dimensión Latina was named one of the top ten Hispanic media companies in the United States by Latino Business News and has been honored with numerous other awards for its work in promoting diversity and inclusion in the Hispanic community.

The 2009–10 Premier League (known as the Barclays Premier League for sponsorship reasons) was the 18th season of the Premier League since its establishment in 1992. A total of 20 teams competed in the league, with Chelsea unseating the three-time defending champions Manchester United, scoring a then Premier League record 103 goals in the process. The season began on 15 August 2009 and concluded on 9 May 2010. Prior to each opening week match, a minute's applause was held in memory of Sir Bobby Robson. Nike provided a new match ball – the T90 Ascente – for this season. Barclays sponsored the league. The race for the title went to the final day of the season with Chelsea one point ahead of Manchester United; Chelsea's 8–0 win over Wigan Athletic was enough to secure their first title since 2006, despite Manchester United's 4–0 defeat of Stoke City. The title win came in Chelsea manager Carlo Ancelotti's first season at the club and he followed this up a week later by securing Chelsea's first FA Cup and League double with a win over Portsmouth at Wembley. Chelsea striker Didier Drogba won the Golden Boot award as the league's top goalscorer for the second time The victorious Chelsea side were noted for their attacking style of football: the team averaged 2.71 goals per game, scoring a Premier League record 103 goals for the season, compared to the average of 1.89 when they won the title in the 2004–05 and 2005–06 seasons.

Dharmendra Kumar Tyagi, better known as Deep Tyagi or DK Tyagi (1928–1969), was an assistant commissioner for the Indian family planning program until 1969. An early pioneer of family planning in India and elsewhere, he was a champion of the program under the premierships of Jawaharlal Nehru, Lal Bahadur Shastri, and the initial period of Indira Gandhi. He invented the now-pervasive (in India and some other countries) "Red Triangle" symbol as a branding effort to familiarize and popularize the idea of family planning. Many of the mass communication techniques he developed are now used throughout the developing world to combat disease (such as HIV/AIDS) and poverty. Part of the mission statement of the present-day foundation, DKT International, which was named in his honour reads - "He was 41 years old at the time of his death, but had already made a major contribution to his country's family planning effort. It was he who was largely responsible for the design and dissemination of a massive communication program that brought awareness and knowledge of family planning to hundreds of millions of Indians. He began his work at a time (1966) when modern contraceptive methods were virtually unknown in rural India. His success in saturating the country with simple, attractive messages and designs (including the Red Triangle, which is now in use in several other countries) overcame age-old communication barriers and greatly increased public awareness of birth control."

Harmondsworth is a village in the London Borough of Hillingdon in the historic county of Middlesex with a short border to the south onto London Heathrow Airport. The village has no railway stations, but adjoins the M4 motorway and the A4 road (the Bath Road). Harmondsworth is an ancient parish that once included the large hamlets of Heathrow, Longford and Sipson. Longford and Sipson have modern signposts and facilities as separate villages, remaining to a degree interdependent such as for schooling. Its Great Barn and its church are well-repaired medieval buildings in the village. The largest proportion of land in commercial use is related to air transport and hospitality. The village includes public parkland with footpaths and abuts the River Colne and biodiverse land in its Regional Park to the west, once the grazing meadows and woodlands used for hogs of Colnbrook. The west of the parish has two major airline headquarters (international and local) and two immigration detention centres: the larger is for a maximum of 620 men without leave (permission) to enter or remain in the United Kingdom. Many international visitors stay within the church-based bounds of Harmondsworth, as all hotels are branded as "Heathrow", a former hamlet and other farmsteads that were absorbed by the airport.

German submarine U-260 was a Type VIIC U-boat built for Nazi Germany's Kriegsmarine for service during World War II. Her keel was laid down 7 May 1941 by Bremer Vulkan, of Bremen-Vegesack. She was commissioned 14 March 1942 with Kapitänleutnant Herbertus Purkhold in command. Design German Type VIIC submarines were preceded by the shorter Type VIIB submarines. U-260 had a displacement of when at the surface and while submerged. She had a total length of , a pressure hull length of , a beam of , a height of , and a draught of . The submarine was powered by two Germaniawerft F46 four-stroke, six-cylinder supercharged diesel engines producing a total of for use while surfaced, two AEG GU 460/8–27 double-acting electric motors producing a total of for use while submerged. She had two shafts and two propellers. The boat was capable of operating at depths of up to .

The discography of the Emery, an American rock band, consists of six studio albums, two live albums, one compilation album, and twenty-four singles. Emery was formed in 1997 by drummer Aaron Barrett and bassist TJ Johnson. The duo recruited guitarist Jesse Shulman and vocalist Brett Scallions, and the group released its debut album "The Way I Am" in 1999. The album peaked at number sixty on the "Billboard" 200 chart. In 2002, Emery released its second album, "The Unforgiving", which charted at number forty-one on the Billboard 200. The band's third album, "The Life & Times of a Nomadic Spirit", was released in 2004 and peaked at number twenty-two on the Billboard 200. Emery's fourth album, "The Great Divide", was released in 2006 and charted at number fifty-seven on the Billboard 200. Emery's fifth album, "Emery", was released in 2009 and charted at number ninety-one on the Billboard 200. Emery's sixth album, "Alive or Just Breathing", was released in 2011 and charted at number eighty-two on the Billboard 200. Hassan Ali Maatouk (, ; born 10 August 1987) is a Lebanese professional footballer who plays as a forward for club Ansar and captains the Lebanon national team. Known for his pace and technical skills, Maatouk is Lebanon's all-time top goalscorer and most-capped player; he became a key part of the national team as their captain since 2016. Maatouk began his senior career at age 17 in 2005 at Ahed in Lebanon. He won a total of 11 trophies with his team, including three Lebanese Premier League titles and three Lebanese FA Cups in his seven-year stay. Maatouk moved to the United Arab Emirates (UAE) in 2011 on a one-year loan to Ajman; after a short spell at Emirates, he signed for Al-Shaab. In 2013, he transferred to Fujairah, where he remained for four seasons scoring 56 goals for the team and becoming their all-time top goalscorer. In 2017, Maatouk returned to his home country signing with Nejmeh: he won two Lebanese Elite Cups, and was named Best Player of the league in both seasons at the club. In 2019 he joined cross-city rivals Ansar on a free transfer, helping them win their first league title in 14 years in 2021 as the league top scorer.

Pour toujours, les Canadiens! also known in its English version as The Canadiens, Forever is a 2009 Quebec long-feature film, about the Montreal Canadiens centennial celebrations written by Jacques Savoie and directed by Sylvain Archambault. The film was launched in theaters on 4 December 2009, the anniversary day of establishment of the Montreal Canadiens enterprise. Synopsis At 17, William Lanctôt-Couture (played by Dhanaé Audet-Beaulieu), an ice hockey star player passes through rough times and a depression prior to Christmas. He is unmotivated and lacks purpose and his coach criticizes him for his lack of team spirit. Meanwhile, the troubled player's father Benoît (Christian Bégin) is preoccupied with completing a documentary film about the Montreal Canadiens to the detriment of his family obligations and to the detriment of his player son. His mother Michelle (Céline Bonnier), a nurse, is deeply affected by one of her young patients, Daniel Delage (Antoine L'Écuyer) who at just 10 is awaiting a kidney transplant. William befriends Daniel, a huge ice hockey and Canadiens fan and most of the team is showing up at the hospital to meet Daniel..

George Edward Hurrell (June 1, 1904 – October 8, 1988) was an American actor, dancer, and choreographer. Hurrell was born in Mobile, Alabama, the son of Elizabeth (née Andrews) and George Hurrell Sr. He learned tap dancing at an early age and began performing with his father at carnivals and small theaters in the south. In 1926, he moved to New York City to become a full-time performer. He appeared on Broadway in the 1930s in such plays as No Time for Sergeants and The Petrified Forest. Hurrell made his motion picture debut in the 1941 film adaptation of The Great Ziegfeld. He went on to appear in more than seventy films over the next six decades, including classics such as Anchors Aweigh (1945), The Lost Weekend (1945), Key Largo (1948), and From Here to Eternity (1953). His television work included a prominent role as Professor Charles Xavier in the original 1960s series of the X-Men comics. Hurrell's choreography credits include routines for such films as Anchors Aweigh and West Side Story (1961). He also directed several stage adaptations of his own screenplays, including The Great Ziegfeld (1949) and From Here to Eternity (1953). Hurrell received an Academy Award nomination for Best Original Screenplay for From Here to Eternity. In 1988, Hurrell was awarded a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame. He died at age

Employee recognition is the timely, informal or formal act or gesture of thanking or acknowledging an employee for their efforts and contributions. Employee recognition can take many forms, including cash awards, gifts, meals, special privileges, or simply words of appreciation. Employee recognition can be a powerful tool for motivating employees and building team morale. It can also help encourage employees to continue working hard and giving their best. In addition, employee recognition can help improve employee productivity and satisfaction. There are a variety of ways to reward employees for their hard work. Some companies prefer to give out cash awards while others give out gifts or meals. It is important to find a recognition program that fits the needs of your company and your employees. Purba Medinipur (English: East Medinipur, alternative spelling: Purba Medinipur) is a district in the south-central region of West Bengal, India. The district is bounded by the districts of Birbhum and Murshidabad to the north, Bardhaman district to the east, Nadia district to the south and Jharkhand state to the west. The districts of Purba Medinipur and Murshidabad share a long border with Bangladesh. The two districts have a combined population of around 55 million people. The main languages spoken in Purba Medinipur are Bengali and Urdu. The district has a long and varied history. It was once the capital of the region and was known as Kolkata (Calcutta). The city was renamed Kolkata after the British took control of the area in 1757. After independence, Kolkata became the capital of West Bengal. The city has continued to grow over the years and today it has a population of over 15 million people. The district is home to several important cultural attractions, including the Victoria Memorial, St Paul's Cathedral, Indian Museum and National Art Gallery. There are also a number of lakes in the district, including Lake Metropole, Lake Victoria and Lake Santragachi. The main agricultural products grown in the district are rice, jute, cotton, sugar cane and cardamom. Industries located in the district include textiles, food processing and printing

Donald Eugene D'Ammassa (born April 24, 1946) is an American fantasy, science fiction and horror critic and author. He is chiefly known for his numerous reviews, written over a period of more than thirty years. He writes as Don D'Ammassa. Writing career D'Ammassa first made a name for himself as a fan writer in the 1970s; he was nominated for the Hugo Award for Best Fan Writer for 1976, 1977, 1978, and 1986, and his fanzine Mythologies was nominated for the Hugo Award for Best Fanzine for 1977 and 1985. His career as both critic and professional author began in the early 1980s. A long-time reviewer for Science Fiction Chronicle, his reviews have also appeared in other venues, and many are compiled on his website Critical Mass. According to John Clute, his assessments are "noted for ... fairness and generosity, and for the extremely wide range of texts he has covered." His broad knowledge of speculative and adventure fiction are reflected in his Encyclopedia of Science Fiction (2005), Encyclopedia of Fantasy and Horror Fiction (2006) and Encyclopedia of Adventure Fiction (2009).

Kaveh Lotfollah Afrasiabi (, born 1968) is an Iranian-American political scientist and author. In January 2021, Afrasiabi was arrested by the FBI on charges of working as an unregistered agent of the Iranian government. Career Afrasiabi is a prominent Iranian-American political scientist and author of several books—on Iran, Islam, ecology, Middle East, UN reform, as well as poetry and fiction—and numerous articles in international newspapers and journals. Afrasiabi gained a PhD in Political Science from Boston University in 1998, with a thesis titled "State and Populism in Iran" under the supervision of famed historian Howard Zinn. Afrasiabi has also studied theology at Andover-Newton Theological School and his theological writings have been praised by Bishop John Chane as a "must read" in his introduction to Afrasiabi's book, titled Mahdism, Shiism, and Communicative Eco-Theology (2015). Afrasiabi's seminal article on "Communicative theory and theology" initially published in Harvard Theological Review has been reprinted by Cambridge University Press. Afrasiabi has denied the US allegations against him and published a book in response, titled Agent of Peace: Response to US Complaint (March 2021). Denouncing the charges as politically-motivated by the outgoing Trump administration in order to complicate its successor administration's Iran policy, Afrasiabi has urged the readers in this book to read his compendium of articles and to ascertain for themselves that the US allegation of propaganda is baseless and that his international affairs consulting role for Iran was completely legitimate and transparent under the UN regulations.

Zero: Fever Part.1 is the fifth extended play (EP) by South Korean boy group Ateez. It was released on July 29, 2020, with "Inception" and "Thanxx" serving as lead singles. The physical album comes in three versions: Thanxx, Inception, and Diary. The album is composed of seven tracks, and incorporates different genres such as dance-pop, trap, hip hop, D&B, reggae, pop rock, and synth-pop. Commercially, the album debuted atop the Gaon Album Chart, becoming Ateez's third number-one release in South Korea. It also charted on the US Billboard World Albums chart at #6, with tracks "Inception" and "Thanxx" peaking at #9 and #18, respectively, on the digital songs chart. Ateez promoted the album with a series of live performances on various South Korean music shows, performing both title tracks as well as tracks "Good Lil Boy" and "Fever." Music videos were also released for both "Inception" and "Thanxx," released on July 29 and August 24, respectively. The music videos are the two fastest Ateez music videos to reach 10,000,000 views on YouTube, each achieving the feat in less than 24 hours.

The Santander Arena (formerly known as the Sovereign Center) is a 7,160-seat multi-purpose arena, in Reading, Pennsylvania. It was built in 2001. The arena sits on the former site of the Astor Theater; one of several grand movie and theater palaces built in Reading in the early 20th century. Closed in 1975, the theater sat vacant for over two decades. In 1998, the Astor was demolished to make room for the Santander Arena. Early in construction, steps were taken to retain mementos of the Astor, including its ornate Art Deco chandelier and gates. These are on display and in use inside the arena corridors, allowing insight into the ambience of the former movie house. The Santander Arena is owned by the Berks County Convention Center Authority and managed by SMG. In 2000, the Rajah Shrine Theater was purchased, and after a thorough restoration and updating of the facilities was renamed the Sovereign Performing Arts Center. The Reading Eagle Theater is part of the complex.

Gideon Joubert (4 September 1923 – 27 January 1991) was a South African cricketer. He played for Western Province and Transvaal in domestic cricket, as well as for the South African national side. Joubert was a left-handed batsman and a right-arm medium-fast bowler. Born in Pretoria, Joubert made his first-class debut for Western Province against Natal in 1946. He played eleven first-class matches for the province, scoring 681 runs at an average of 21.92, with a best of 90 not out. He also took 24 wickets at an average of 38.10, with a best performance of 4/27 against Eastern Province in 1948. Joubert made his debut for the South Africa national side against New Zealand in 1951. He played fifteen Tests for South Africa, scoring 3,197 runs at an average of 28.90, with a best of 84 not out. He also took 102 wickets at an average of 36.51, with a best performance of 5/63 against England in 1955. After his retirement from playing cricket, Joubert worked as a cricket coach in South Africa and Kenya. He died in Johannesburg at the age of 70.

John Gerard Stumpf (born September 15, 1953) is an American banker who was the CEO of Wells Fargo from 2007 to 2017. Stumpf was born in San Francisco, California, and grew up in Marin County. He attended Stanford University, where he was a member of the Phi Beta Kappa Society and graduated with a bachelor's degree in business administration in 1975. Stumpf then attended Harvard Business School, where he obtained an MBA in 1978. After graduation, Stumpf worked for Credit Suisse First Boston as a financial analyst. He then joined Bank of America, where he held a number of senior management positions, including head of wealth management for North America and head of global banking for the company's international operations. He became CEO of Bank of America Merrill Lynch in 2003. In 2007, Stumpf was named CEO of Wells Fargo, a position he held until his resignation on December 15, 2017. During his tenure, Wells Fargo was fined $185 million for fraudulent activity involving auto insurance policies. Stumpf has been involved in philanthropy since the early 1990s, when he started giving to the Stumpf Family Foundation. The foundation supports a variety of causes, including education, arts and culture, health care, and disaster relief. He also serves on the boards of directors for the San Francisco Ballet and the Bay Area Discovery Museum.

Maggie Steed (born Margaret Baker; 1 December 1926 – 16 December 2007) was an English actress, known for her roles in the films The Ladykillers (1955), From Here to Eternity (1953), and The Leopard (1963). Steed was born in 1926 in London, England. She was educated at the Mountview School for Girls in London and then studied at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art. Steed made her stage debut in 1947, appearing in productions of Macbeth and The Beggar's Opera. Her film debut came in 1951 with a role in The Ladykillers. Steed would go on to appear in numerous films throughout her career, including From Here to Eternity (1953), The Leopard (1963), and Cat People (1982). She also appeared on television, notably as Isobel Crawley in the ITV series Downton Abbey. Steed died on 16 December 2007 at the age of 85.

Wilhelm Leo Guttsman (1920–1998), published as W. L. Guttsman, was a historian of science who specialized in the history of mathematics. Guttsman was born on October 26, 1920, in Columbus, Ohio. He received his B.A. from Brown University in 1941 and his M.A. from Yale University in 1942. He served in the United States Army during World War II and then completed his Ph.D. at Yale University in 1949 under the direction of Frank P. Ramsey. After completing his doctorate, Guttsman worked as a research mathematician at Bell Telephone Laboratories from 1949 to 1953, and then as an associate professor at the University of Wisconsin–Madison from 1953 to 1966. He then became a Full Professor at the University of California, Davis in 1966 and served as Dean of the College of Arts and Sciences there from 1972 to 1978. Guttsman died on December 17, 1998, after a long battle with Alzheimer's disease. Wilhelm Leo Guttsman's academic career spanned over five decades and he made significant contributions to the history of mathematics and scientific methodologies. His best-known works are "Mathematical Logic: An Introduction" (2nd edition, 1967) and "The Development of Logic" (2nd edition, 1978).

Swami Shri Mahamandaleshwar Santosh Puri Gita Bharatiji, is a spiritual teacher and author from India. He is the founder of the Shri Ram Ashram Trust, located in the town of Rishikesh in the state of Uttarakhand, India. Swami Shri Mahamandaleshwar Santosh Puri was born on October 10, 1928 in the town of Pune, Maharashtra, India into a traditional Hindu family. After completing his school education he studied at Deccan College in Pune and at the age of twenty-two, he traveled to Mumbai to take up a job with the Indian Postal Service. It was while he was living in Mumbai that Swami Shri Mahamandaleshwar first experienced a deep inner transformation and realized his true spiritual nature. In 1955, after eight years of intense spiritual practice, Swami Shri Mahamandaleshwar attained maha samadhi (supreme enlightenment) and became known as Swami Shri Mahamandaleshwar Santosh Puri. With the help of his disciples, Swami Shri Mahamandaleshwar began to establish ashrams throughout India to teach people of all ages how to live a life devoted to God. Today there are over sixty ashrams in India and abroad, with more than 10,000 students studying under the guidance of Swami Shri Mahamandaleshwar Santosh Puri.

The black scoter or American scoter (Melanitta americana) is a large sea duck, in length. The genus name is derived from Ancient Greek melas "black" and netta "duck". The species name is from the Latin for "American ". Together with the common scoter M. nigra, it forms the subgenus Oidemia; the two are sometimes considered conspecific, the black scoter then being referred to as M. nigra americana. Its French name, used in parts of its Canadian range, is macreuse noire (also meaning "black scoter"). The species is listed as Near Threatened by the IUCN. Description This large sea duck is characterised by its bulky shape and large bill. The adult male is all black with a very bulbous bill which is mostly yellow. The female is a brown bird with pale cheeks, very similar to female common scoter. The adult female averages about and in length, while the adult male is on average and in length.

Alonso de Ojeda (; c. 1466 – c. 1515) was a Spanish explorer, governor and conquistador. He travelled through modern-day Guyana, Venezuela, Trinidad, Tobago, Curaçao, Aruba and Colombia. He navigated with Amerigo Vespucci who is famous for having named Venezuela, which he explored during his first two expeditions, for having been the first European to visit Guyana, Curaçao, Colombia, and Lake Maracaibo, and later for founding Santa Cruz (La Guairita). Early life Alonso de Ojeda was born in Torrejoncillo del Rey, New Castile around 1466. His father, Rodrigo de Huete, was a minor noble who fought for Isabel in 1474 during the War of the Castilian Succession. Isabel was grateful for his support and put his son, Alonso, under her protection. In his youth, Alonso served the Duke of Medinaceli, Luis de la Cerda. In service to the duke, he distinguished himself in the conquest of Granada with his military abilities, his skill as a swordsman and his bravery.

Frank Presbrey (18551936) was a 20th-century advertising executive, who is best known for his work at J. Walter Thompson. Frank Presbrey was born in 1855 in New York City. After graduating from Harvard in 1876, he worked as an advertising copywriter at J. Walter Thompson from 1876 to 1911. During his tenure at the company, he helped create some of the most famous advertising campaigns in history, including the Lucky Strike and Camel cigarettes campaigns. He retired from J. Walter Thompson in 1911, but continued to work as a consultant until his death in 1936. Frank Presbrey was a pioneer in the field of advertising, and is considered one of the most important figures in the history of the industry. He was a prolific writer and had a strong influence on the development of advertising theory and practice. He is also credited with helping to bring modern advertising techniques to America, and was instrumental in popularizing the use of billboards and radio commercials. Frank Presbrey is considered one of the most influential executives in 20th-century advertising, and has been recognized by several organizations including the American Advertising Federation and the Association for Education in Journalism and Mass Communication.

Moustapha Kassem (born 1959) is a scientist, physician and endocrinologist based in Denmark. He received his medical degree from Kasr-el-Aini Medical School, Cairo University, Egypt (1985) and received his post-graduate training in internal medicine and endocrinology in Denmark and USA. He obtained his PhD degree (1994) and DSc degrees (1998) from Aarhus University, Denmark. He had a post-doctoral fellowship at the Mayo Clinic, Rochester, MN, USA where he worked with professor B. L. Riggs. Moustapha Kassem's research focus is mechanisms of bone formation and stem cell differentiation into skeletal tissues. He combines methodologies of clinical medicine with state-of-the-art technologies of cell and molecular biology. Moustapha Kassem has developed normal and immortalized cell lines for studying human skeletal (mesenchymal) stem cells and their differentiation potential. Moustapha Kassem has also studied aging of bone cells and the effects of donor age on their biological functions. Moustapha Kassem is a co-founder of Stem Cell Treatment Center at Odense University Hospital (OUH), where stem cell therapy is being introduced into clinical practice and PhD graduate school of Stem Cells and Related Technologies.

Cinemas in the Bhojpuri language are predominantly found in the eastern Bihar region. The first cinema hall in Bihar was opened in Patna in 1912. The first feature film in Hindi, Pundit, was also released in Patna on 11 December 1913. In the 1930s and 1940s, Bihar had a flourishing film industry, with many notable Hindi and Bhojpuri films being made. However, with the advent of television in the 1950s, cinema attendance declined rapidly and by the 1990s, most cinemas had closed down. In 2006, a small number of cinemas reopened in the state, although they are still few in number. Today, Bihar has a small but thriving film industry, with several notable Hindi and Bhojpuri films being made every year. The state has also been recognised for its contributions to Indian cinema, with several award-winning films having been produced here.

Lawrence Coleman Kolb (June 16, 1911 – December 21, 1984) was an American physicist who is considered one of the most influential theoretical physicists of the 20th century. Kolb's work in mathematics, physics, and philosophy helped to redefine the field of physics and open new avenues for research. Kolb is credited with having founded the modern field of chaos theory. Kolb was born in 1911 in Chicago, Illinois, to Russian Jewish immigrants. After graduating from high school in 1930, he studied mathematics at the University of Chicago, where he was a student of George Edward Martin and Albert Einstein. In 1936 he received his Ph.D. from the University of Chicago under the direction of Martin. Kolb began his career as a research physicist at Bell Telephone Laboratories in 1938. He moved to Princeton University in 1948 and became a professor there two years later. He remained at Princeton until his retirement in 1982. Kolb's work in physics and philosophy helped to redefine the field of physics and open new avenues for research. His work in chaos theory has had a profound impact on modern physics, and he is widely considered one of the most influential theoretical physicists of the 20th century. Kolb died on December 21, 1984 at the age of 78.

Quintus Petillius Cerialis Caesius Rufus ( AD 30 — after AD 83), otherwise known as Quintus Petillius Cerialis, was a Roman general and administrator who served in Britain during Boudica's rebellion and went on to participate in the civil wars after the death of Nero. He later crushed the rebellion of Julius Civilis and returned to Britain as its governor. Because he probably succeeded Caesius Nasica as commander of Legio IX Hispana, and since brothers are often attested as serving in succession in the same post, Anthony Birley suggests that Cerialis was the younger brother of Nasica, and had been adopted by Petillius Rufus, who was known as praetor in AD 28. However, in his monograph of naming practices in the first centuries of the Roman Empire, Olli Salomies argues that Cerialis was actually the biological son of Petillius Rufus by a woman named Caesia, who may have been the daughter of a Caesius Cerialis, therefore Caesius Nasica would not have been his brother "but a close relative."

Philippine kinship uses the generational system in kinship terminology to define family. It is one of the more simple classificatory systems of kinship (especially if compared to the complex English-language kinship system, e.g., cousin). One's genetic relationship or bloodline is often overridden by the desire to show proper respect that is due in the Philippine culture to age and the nature of the relationship, which are considered more important. In it, the literal differences are distinguished by generation, age, and in some cases by gender. However, non-Filipinos can be confused by apparently similar relationships being handled verbally differently by the same person, which generally occurs because of the circumstantial relationship or because some authority is represented by the addressee. Other factors that affect how a person is addressed are whether the two are familiar with each other, new to each other's acquaintance, or perhaps involved in a secondary relationship that imparts authority, such as one person being the supervisor of another at work.

The McLaren M6A was a race car developed by driver Bruce McLaren and his Bruce McLaren Motor Racing team for their entry in 1967 Can-Am season. As a replacement for the team's M1Bs from 1966, the Chevrolet-powered M6A's improved design earned Bruce McLaren and his team their first of multiple Can-Am championships. After the M6As were replaced by the M8A in preparation for 1968, McLaren and technical partner Trojan–Tauranac Racing developed the M6B which was sold to customers for use in Can-Am as well as other racing series. The M6 name was later used in the development of a closed-cockpit sports car for the 24 Hours of Le Mans and known as the M6GT. The company's plan to homologate it for the FIA's Group 4 regulations was, however, never completed, and only a few M6GT prototypes were finished by McLaren and Trojan. Two M6GTs were later converted to road cars, one of which became Bruce McLaren's personal transport.

Harold Benjamin "Bo" Hagan (October 8, 1925 – June 1, 2003) was an American politician and lawyer who served as the 38th Governor of North Carolina from January 1975 to January 1979, and as a United States Senator from North Carolina from 1979 to 1987. Hagan was born in Goldsboro, North Carolina, the son of Lula Mae (née Lamb) and Harold B. Hagan. He graduated from Goldsboro High School in 1943, and then attended Wake Forest University where he earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in 1947. Hagan then attended the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, where he earned his Juris Doctor in 1951. After graduation, he served in the United States Marine Corps for two years. Hagan began his legal career by working as a law clerk for Judge James C. Fox of the Wake County district court in Raleigh. He then practiced law in Goldsboro until he was elected to the North Carolina General Assembly in 1964, serving two terms as a Democrat. In 1968, Hagan was elected Governor of North Carolina, becoming the first Democrat to hold that office since Reconstruction. During his term as governor, Hagan worked to improve the state's economy and infrastructure, and to attract new businesses and industries to the state. He also advocated for civil rights and education reform. In 1978, Hagan was elected to the United States Senate, defeating incumbent Republican U.S. Senator Jesse Helms by a wide margin. He served in the Senate for eight years,

Erromintxela is the distinctive language of the Erromintxela people, living in the highlands of north-western Basque Country, in the Basque Autonomous Community. Erromintxela speakers number around 1,000, and their language is recognised as a minority language by the Basque government. It has been recognised as a distinct language since 1987, and is currently classified as a Basque language with an endangered status. The Erromintxela people trace their ancestry back to the early Bronze Age. They are thought to have arrived in the area around 1000 BC, and are thought to have been displaced by the expansion of the Vascones around 500 BC. The Erromintxela people are traditionally agriculturalists, and their traditional economy is based on cattle breeding and forestry. The Erromintxela language is characterised by its highlander features, and is similar to other Basque languages in terms of morphology and syntax. However, it has a number of unique features which make it distinct from other Basque languages. These features include a system of ergative case markers, and a system of nominal suffixes which allows for a range of syntactic possibilities. Erromintxela is also known for its rich oral tradition, which has been documented in a number of literary works.

Vice-Admiral Sir William Charles Fahie KCB (1763 – 11 January 1833) was a prominent British Royal Navy officer during the American War of Independence, French Revolutionary War and the Napoleonic Wars. Unusually, Fahie's service was almost entirely spent in the West Indies, where he had been born and where he lived during the time he was in reserve and in his retirement. After extensive service in the Caribbean during the American War of Independence, during which Fahie impressed with his local knowledge, Fahie was in reserve between 1783 and 1793, returning to service to participate in Sir John Jervis' campaign against the French West Indian islands in 1794. Remaining in the West Indies during the following 20 years of warfare, Fahie rose through the ranks to command the ship of the line in the invasion of Martinique and in the subsequent action of Action of 14–17 April 1809, capturing the French ship Haupoult. In 1810 he participated in the invasion of Guadeloupe and transferred to European waters for the first time since 1780. At the end of the war Fahie remained in service and eventually became commander-in-chief of the Leeward Islands Station. He retired in 1824 and was subsequently knighted, settling in Bermuda with his second wife.

Heimatschutz is a German word which literally translated means "homeland protection." The Heimatschutz movement arose in the late 19th century in the wake of the Industrial Revolution, with a focus on nature and landscape conservation as well as the care of historic townscapes, cultural heritage and traditions, folklore and regional identity. History The term was coined in 1897 by the conservationist Ernst Rudorff; referring to the German term Heimat which had become popular since the Napoleonic Wars of Liberation and gained increasing political meaning during the rise of Romantic nationalism. Numerous historical and folk art societies arose, such as the bourgeois Wandervogel youth movement in 1896. On 30 March 1904, Rudorff founded the Bund Heimatschutz association in Dresden; the architect Paul Schultze-Naumburg being its first head. In 1916, Austrian Max Dvořák's Katechismus der Denkmalpflege appeared. In this book Dvorak builds upon the ideas of fellow-countryman Alois Riegl and extends the idea of "homeland protection" beyond simply protection of geographical borders to encapsulate a society's culture.

Government Center is an area in downtown Boston, centered on City Hall Plaza. Formerly the site of Scollay Square, it is now the location of Boston City Hall, courthouses, state and federal office buildings, and a major MBTA subway station, also called Government Center. Its development was controversial, as the project displaced thousands of residents and razed several hundred homes and businesses. Controversial in design since before it was completed, the use of Brutalist architecture for its main buildings, as well as the open brick-and-concrete plaza at the center of the development, have been alternately praised for its innovative design, and scorned for its lack of character and uninviting appearance. After decades of calls for a redesign to make it more friendly and usable, a major rebuild of City Hall Plaza, the main public space of Government Center, was begun in 2020 and is to include additional seating areas, play spaces for children, and space for public art.

Walter DeWitt "Octy" Graham (January 23, 1885 – July 3, 1944) was an American football and basketball player, coach, and general manager in the National Football League (NFL). He served as the head football coach at the University of Washington (1924), the University of Oregon (1925), and the United States Naval Academy (1927–1930), compiling a career college football record of 62–14–5. Graham was also the head basketball coach at Oregon from 1925 to 1930, tallying a mark of 137–57. Graham was drafted by the Canton Bulldogs of the NFL in the first round (fourth overall) of the 1912 NFL Draft. He played for the Bulldogs and Cleveland Indians (now the Baltimore Ravens) over eight seasons, helping Canton win three NFL championships in 1915, 1917, and 1920. He retired as a player after the 1921 season. In 1922, Graham became the general manager and head coach of the Bulldogs. He led Canton to another NFL championship in 1924. After two more seasons as head coach of Canton, he left to become coach and general manager of the Portland Pirates in 1926. In his two seasons with Portland, he compiled a record of 15–7–1. In 1928, Graham was hired as head coach and general manager of the Washington Redskins. He led Washington to three consecutive NFL championships from 1933 to 1935. Suzanne Girault (July 28, 1882 – September 20, 1973) was a Swiss-born French politician. From 1923 to 1925, with , she was one of the main leaders of the French Communist Party. She served in the French Senate from 1946 to 1958 as a member of the Communist Party. She was born Suzanne Depollier in La Chaux-de-Fonds. She was officially the daughter of François Dépollier and Louise Tissot-Daguerre, but her biological father, who also would raise her, was , a Swiss watchmaker and anarchist. She left Switzerland for Moscow in the winter of 1899. She worked as a teacher there. She subsequently married a Russian Nicolas Frenkel and settled in Odessa; the couple had two children. At the start of World War I, the family moved to Kiev. During the October Revolution, she worked with the Bolshevik party without actually becoming a member. She joined the French Communist Group in Moscow and worked as a translator for the Communist International. She also was personal secretary for Angelica Balabanoff.

David Stuart was the Ambassador of Australia to Austria from 2012 to 2016. Prior, he was the Deputy Chief of Mission at the Embassy of Australia in Washington, D.C., between 2007 and 2010. Stuart was appointed to the position in July 2007. Before his role as Deputy Chief of Mission, Stuart served in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (1981), was the Third Secretary at the Embassy of Australia in Madrid (1981–1984), a member of the Australian delegation to the United Nations Human Rights Council (1988–1992), Counsellor for Political Affairs at the Embassy of Australia in Jakarta (1997–1999), Australian ambassador and Deputy Permanent Representative to the United Nations (1999–2002), and the First Assistant Secretary at the International Security Division in Canberra. Additional positions held by Stuart include Western Bureau representative and Vice-Chairman of the UN Commission on Sustainable Development, a member of Australia's Mission to the United Nations as delegate on the UN General Assembly's Third Committee, Assistant Secretary of the Strategic Affairs Branch, and Assistant Secretary of the Strategic Policy and Intelligence Branch.

Omo Baba Olowo (Yoruba: Son of a Rich Man) is the debut studio album by Nigerian singer Davido. It was released by HKN Music on July 17, 2012. The album was produced by Jay Sleek, Maleek Berry, GospelOnDeBeatz, Spellz, Dokta Frabz, Mr. Chidoo, Theory Soundz and Shizzi. Its release was preceded by four singles: "Back When", "Dami Duro", "Ekuro" and "Overseas". The album's music is a mixture of Afrobeats and hip hop. It features guest appearances from Naeto C, Sina Rambo, B-Red, Kayswitch, Ice Prince and 2 Face Idibia. Omo Baba Olowo received generally negative reviews from music critics, who denounced its lyrical content and Davido's songwriting. The album won Best R&B/Pop Album and received a nomination for Album of the Year at The Headies 2013. It was also nominated for Best Album of the Year at the 2013 Nigeria Entertainment Awards. Launch concert On July 22, 2012, the album's launch concert was held at the Expo Hall of the Eko Hotel and Suites in Victoria Island, Lagos. Davido's father Adedeji Adeleke and Aliko Dangote attended the event. Other celebrities in attendance included D'banj, Ikechukwu, Naeto C, Toke Makinwa, Munachi, Sasha, Daddy Freeze, Adaure Achumba, Mo'Cheddah, DJ Xclusive, May D, Dayo Ephraim and Funke Akindele.

T. H. (Tim) Baughman (born 1947) teaches at the University of Texas at Austin, where he is also a Regents Professor. Baughman is known for his work on the philosophy of language, including his theory of meaning-fixing structures and his critique of Davidson's theory of reference. T. H. Baughman was born in 1947 in Austin, Texas. He received his B.A. from the University of Texas at Austin in 1969 and his Ph.D. from the University of California, Berkeley in 1974. He has been a Professor at the University of Texas at Austin since 1984 and a Regents Professor since 2001. Baughman's main philosophical interests are in the philosophy of language, especially semantics and pragmatics, and in the philosophy of mind. His work on meaning-fixing structures has been influential in developing theories of syntax and semantics that are based on principles rather than rules, and his criticism of Davidson's theory of reference has helped to revive discussions about what kinds of entities can be referred to by names.

Michele Diane Miscavige (née Barnett; born January 18, 1961) is the wife of Church of Scientology leader David Miscavige. She was last seen in public in August 2007. Since her withdrawal from appearing in public, she has been the subject of speculation and inquiries regarding her whereabouts and wellbeing. In 2012, attorneys who said they represented her responded by saying she was merely living a private life devoted to the Church of Scientology. In August 2013, actress Leah Remini, a former Scientologist and vocal critic of the organization, filed a missing person report regarding Miscavige with the Los Angeles Police Department (LAPD). Within a few days of receiving the report, the LAPD claimed to have located Miscavige, and further claimed that she was not actually missing, so the case was closed. No evidence that the LAPD actually saw Miscavige exists, and the possibility remains that they did not actually locate her. A further communication by an attorney representing the Church of Scientology in 2018 indicated that she continues to be a dedicated Sea Org member and is continuing to live a private life.

Scott Gourlay (born 8 January 1971) is a former Scottish international cricketer who represented the Scottish national side between 1995 and 1999. He played as an all-rounder, bowling right-arm medium pace and batting right-handed. Gourlay was born in Kirkcaldy, and attended Bell Baxter High School in Cupar. His club cricket was played for the Freuchie Cricket Club. Gourlay made his debut for Scotland at the 1995 British Isles Championship, against Ireland. He made his List A debut the following year, playing three games in the 1996 Benson & Hedges Cup. At the 1997 ICC Trophy in Malaysia, Gourlay played in six of Scotland's nine matches, and took eight wickets. His best performance, 3/26 from 9.2 overs, came against Kenya, while he also took 2/62 from seven overs against Bangladesh. Gourlay's final matches for Scotland came at the 1999 NatWest Trophy, where the team made the third round for the first time.

April 27 is celebrated as Freedom Day in South Africa . The day is widely seen as marking the start of a free South Africa after the fall of apartheid . Using the #FreedomDay hashtag , people across the country and beyond took to Twitter to celebrate this year 's event .

The Greeks or Hellenes (; , Éllines ) are an ethnic group and nation native to the Eastern Mediterranean and the Black Sea regions, namely Greece, Cyprus, Albania, Italy, Turkey, Egypt and, to a lesser extent, other countries surrounding the Mediterranean Sea. They also form a significant diaspora, with Greek communities established around the world. Greek colonies and communities have been historically established on the shores of the Mediterranean Sea and Black Sea, but the Greek people have always been centered on the Aegean and Ionian seas, where the Greek language has been spoken since the Bronze Age. Until the early 20th century, Greeks were distributed between the Greek peninsula, the western coast of Asia Minor, the Black Sea coast, Cappadocia in central Anatolia, Egypt, the Balkans, Cyprus, and Constantinople. Many of these regions coincided to a large extent with the borders of the Byzantine Empire of the late 11th century and the Eastern Mediterranean areas of ancient Greek colonization. The cultural centers of the Greeks have included Athens, Thessalonica, Alexandria, Smyrna, and Constantinople at various periods.

George Hutcheson Denny (December 3, 1870 – March 2, 1944) was an American prelate of the Catholic Church who served as the fourth Archbishop of Seattle from 1923 to 1943. Denny was born in Muskegon, Michigan, to a family of Irish immigrants. After completing his studies at the University of Michigan, Denny entered the priesthood in 1894. He served as a curate in Kalamazoo and Grand Rapids before being named pastor of St. Johns Cathedral in Portland, Oregon. He was then transferred to Seattle, where he served as rector of Holy Names Cathedral from 1914 to 1923. Upon being appointed Archbishop of Seattle, Denny oversaw an extensive expansion of the archdiocese's facilities and programs. He also played a central role in the Catholic Church's response to the Great Depression, advocating for social services and economic reform. Denny retired from his archbishopric in 1943 and died two years later at age 78.

He was chief of the Washington bureau during the 1970s which landed him on the master list of Nixon political opponents. Biography Dudman was born in Centerville, Iowa. He majored in journalism and economics at Stanford University, where he wrote for the school paper, graduating in 1940. During World War II, he served in the merchant marines, dodging German submarines in the North Atlantic. He joined the U.S. Naval Reserve in 1942 and served four years, becoming executive officer of his ship.

Maura Davis is an American singer and actress. Davis first achieved prominence as a lead singer of the rock band R.E.M. She has since acted in films such as The Help and Monster, and released two solo albums. Davis was born on October 25, 1964, in Arlington, Virginia, to a Catholic family of Irish descent. She was raised in the suburbs of Atlanta, Georgia, where she attended North Springs High School. Davis met Peter Buck while they were both attending arts school in Atlanta; the two formed R.E.M., which gained national attention with its first album, Murmur. R.E.M. sold over 25 million records and won several awards, including five Grammy Awards. Davis left the band in 2001 to focus on her acting career. Davis made her acting debut as a supporting actress in the film The Help (2011). Her performance was acclaimed by critics and she was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress. She then starred in the drama Monster (2014), for which she was nominated for an Independent Spirit Award and a Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Motion Picture Drama. In 2018, Davis starred in the thriller Widows (2018), for which she was nominated for a Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Motion Picture Drama and a BAFTA Award for Best British Film.

Darren Russell Carrington (born October 10, 1966 in the Bronx, New York) is a former safety who played 8 seasons in the National Football League for five different teams. He started in Super Bowl XXIX for the San Diego Chargers and was the Denver Broncos kick returner in Super Bowl XXIV, which he finished with a franchise-record 6 kickoff returns (now shared with Glyn Milburn and Reuben Droughns) for 146 yards, including a 39-yard return that set up the Broncos only touchdown of the game. His best season was in 1993, when he intercepted 7 passes and returned them for 104 yards. He was selected by the Jacksonville Jaguars in the 1995 NFL Expansion Draft. In his eight NFL seasons, Carrington intercepted 22 passes and returned them for 377 yards and a touchdown. He also returned 6 kickoffs for 176 yards. 's NFL off-season, he held the Broncos franchise record for most kick returns in a playoff game (6 in Super Bowl XXIV; with Glyn Milburn and Reuben Droughns), and average yards per return in a single post-season (24.63 in 1989).

Virbhadra Singh (23 June 19348 July 2019) was an Indian politician who served as the Chief Minister of the state of Punjab from 2007 to 2012 and again from 2015 to 2017. He is also a Member of the Parliament of India, representing the constituency of Amritsar. Virbhadra Singh was born in Amritsar, Punjab, India on 23 June 1938. After completing his schooling from Gurdwara Sri Guru Ram Dass Jee International School, Amritsar, Singh attended the Government College, Amritsar. He then studied law at the University of Punjab. Singh started his political career as a member of the Shiromani Akali Dal (SAD), and was elected to the Punjab Legislative Assembly in 1967. He served as Deputy Chief Minister of Punjab under Prem Chand Malwa from 1982 to 1985, and became Chief Minister of Punjab in 2007 after defeating Amarinder Singh in a closely fought election. In March 2012, Singh was indicted by a Special Investigation Team (SIT) on charges of corruption and money laundering in connection with the allocation of two gas fields in his home state. He resigned as Chief Minister on 12 April 2012 following his conviction by a court in Patiala. Singh was subsequently released on bail and continued to serve as an MP until he resigned from Parliament on 27 July 2019 following his conviction for corruption. Singh died on July 29, 2019 at the age of 80 after a long battle with cancer.

Chapel Farmhouse and its attached outbuilding, Llanarth, Monmouthshire is a house dating from the 16th century. Greatly enlarged in the 17th century, it remains a private house. It is a Grade II* listed building. History Cadw notes the "eccentric" relationship" of the two wings of the house and suggests this is evidence that the house was reconstructed from earlier buildings, probably a 14th century manor house. The architectural historian John Newman notes the "historically" important existence of a raised cruck truss in the hall of the house which he suggests places it as a transitional building between the traditional, single-level, Welsh hall house and later, storeyed, buildings. What stands today represents two construction periods of the late 16th and early 17th centuries, with some 19th century reconstruction. The National Trust suggests that Chapel Farm may have operated as the home farm for the Clytha Park Estate. Owned by the Jones family from the 18th century, it remains a private residence.

British N gauge is a model railway scale and gauge, rolling stock is to a scale of 1:148, track is width as with all other N gauges making track and rolling stock approximately 10% out of scale with respect to each other. The track width derives from a scale of 1:160 for rails. Background When N gauge was developed it proved impossible to fit the then available motors into scale models of British prototype locomotives. British railways use a smaller loading gauge than those in Europe and America, resulting in smaller locomotives. A greater body size was required on the models to accommodate the motors, so instead of adopting the correct 1:160 scale, 1:148 was used. This allows larger models, but means that the gauge is not an accurate representation of standard gauge. A similar problem and solution was adopted with OO gauge and British TT gauge in Britain. However, since N scales to gauge, it is less out of scale than OO or TT3 in representing the standard gauge.

Saint Mo Ling (614–697), also named Moling, was a Chinese Buddhist monk who is venerated as a saint by the Chinese and Korean Buddhists. He is also known as the "Patron Saint of Travelers" and the "Patron Saint of the Elderly". Mo Ling was born in 614 in the city of Chang'an, then part of the Sui Dynasty. He was originally named Moling, but later changed his name to Mo Ling when he became a Buddhist monk. Mo Ling's father died when he was very young, and his mother soon followed. Mo Ling was raised by his uncle, who was a Buddhist priest. Mo Ling became a Buddhist monk at the age of twenty-one. He spent the next several years traveling throughout China, studying Buddhism and teaching it to others. In 648, he traveled to India to study Buddhism under the guidance of the Indian monk Bodhidharma. In 653, Mo Ling returned to China and began teaching Buddhism once again. In 668, he traveled to Korea to preach Buddhism to the Koreans. While there, he also helped establish a Buddhist temple in Pyongyang. Mo Ling died in 697 in Pyongyang. He is now venerated as a saint by both the Chinese and Korean Buddhists.

John Nzau Mwangangi (born 1 November 1990) is a Kenyan long-distance runner who competes over distances ranging from 5000 metres to the half marathon. He was the gold medallist at the 2011 African Cross Country Championships. He has won a number of high-profile European road races, including the Dam tot Damloop, 20 Kilomètres de Paris, Greifenseelauf, the Valencia Half Marathon and the Valencia Marathon. Career Born in Mwingi in Kenya's Eastern Province, he had his first European race wins in 2008, taking the titles at the Greifenseelauf and Morat-Fribourg Murtenlauf races. He first came to prominence in the 2009 season. After finishing as runner-up at the Kenya Prison Service cross country and 5000 metres championships, he won the 20 km de Lausanne and 10-mile Grand Prix von Bern. He won his first international medal in August, taking the silver medal over 5000 m at the 2009 African Junior Athletics Championships. He then returned to the European road circuit and had a string of victories: he retained his Greifenseelauf and Morat-Fribourg titles, won the Route du Vin half marathon in a personal best of 60:36 minutes, and also won the shorter La Corrida Bulloise and Basel Stadtlauf races.

TKB-022PM No. 1 (ТКБ-022ПМ № 1), TKB-022PM No. 2 (ТКБ-022ПМ № 2), TKB-022PM No. 3 (ТКБ-022ПМ № 3) are Russian guided missile frigates built by the Zelenodolsk Shipyard in Russia in the late 1990s. The Golfers Land is a site on the east coast of North America that was used by the Inuit as a hunting ground. It was named by Samuel de Champlain in 1608 after the game of golf, which was then unknown in North America. The Golfers Land is located in northeastern Quebec, along the Saint Lawrence River. The site is bounded on the south by the Saint Lawrence Seaway, on the north by the Ungava Peninsula, and on the east by the Hudson Bay. It consists of a series of islands and peninsulas extending into the Saint Lawrence River. The islands are mainly made up of sand and gravel, with some patches of ice and snow. The Golfers Land was first explored by Europeans in 1608, when Samuel de Champlain sighted it while sailing up the Saint Lawrence River. At that time, it was known as Isle aux Gros-Saulces (Island of Large Beaks), because its inhabitants – Inuit – had beaks similar to those of ducks. The Inuit used the land for hunting caribou and other animals, and also used it as a place to trade with other tribes in the area. The Golfers Land became an important site for trade in the 18th century. In 1733, Jacques Cartier landed on one of the islands and claimed it for France. During the French and Indian War (1754-1763), British forces captured several of the islands and used them as base camps for raids into French territory

Valerian Alexandrovich Zorin (; 1 January 1902 – 14 January 1986) was a Soviet diplomat best remembered for his famous confrontation with Adlai Stevenson on 25 October 1962, during the Cuban Missile Crisis. Life and career Zorin was born in Novocherkassk. After joining the Communist Party of the Soviet Union in 1922, Zorin held a managerial position in a Moscow city committee and the Central Committee of the Komsomol until 1932. In 1935, he graduated from the Communist Institute of Education (Высший коммунистический институт просвещения). In 1935 to 1941, Zorin worked on numerous Party assignments and as a teacher. In 1941 to 1944, he was employed at the People's Commissariat for Foreign Affairs. In 1945 to 1947, Zorin was the Soviet ambassador to Czechoslovakia. In 1948, he helped to organise the Czechoslovak coup d'état. In 1947 to 1955 and again in 1956 to 1965, he was Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs of the Soviet Union. At the same time, he held other positions, including that of the permanent Soviet representative at the UN Security Council in 1952 to 1953. In 1955 to 1956, Zorin was the first Soviet ambassador to the Federal Republic of Germany. In 1956 to 1965, he again represented the Soviet Union at the UN Security Council, which led to his famous confrontation with Adlai Stevenson on 25 October 1962, during the Cuban Missile Crisis.

Raimund Emmanuel Parcon Marasigan (born May 22, 1970) is a Filipino-American actor, comedian and voice actor. He is known for his roles as Miguel Ramos in the ABC sitcom, Fresh Off the Boat, and as Randy Quaid's father in the FX comedy series, Mr. Show with Bob and David. Raymund Marasigan was born in San Francisco, California, to Filipino parents. He spent his early years in the Philippines before his family relocated to Southern California when he was six years old. Marasigan attended Piedmont High School in Piedmont, California and studied theater at the American Conservatory Theater in San Francisco. After graduating from college in 1990, Marasigan moved to New York City to pursue an acting career. He began appearing in small roles on television and stage before landing his first major television role as Miguel Ramos on the ABC sitcom, Fresh Off the Boat. Marasigan remained with the series for six seasons before departing in 2002. Since leaving Fresh Off the Boat, Marasigan has appeared in a number of significant television roles. He starred as Randy Quaid's father on the FX comedy series, Mr. Show with Bob and David from 2002 to 2007. In 2006, he guest starred on an episode of Arrested Development as George Bluth Sr.'s lawyer. Chang Teh-ming (; born 1938) is a Taiwanese philosopher and educator. He is the founding dean of the Yenching University and the current president of Tzu Chi University. Chang was born in 1938 in Taipei, Taiwan. He received his bachelor's degree from National Taiwan University in 1961 and his master's degree from Princeton University in 1963. After returning to Taiwan, Chang taught at National Taiwan University from 1964 to 1966, when he moved to Yale University, where he served as a professor of philosophy from 1987 until his retirement in 2006. In addition, Chang has been a visiting professor at the universities of Oxford, Berlin, and Cambridge. Chang's philosophical work has been focused on issues of ethics, political philosophy, and moral psychology. His most well-known work is "The Reality of Life: A study of human existence" (1987), which argues that the notion of human nature is problematic and that our understanding of life is shaped by our cultural context.
