Alice Harnoncourt (née Hoffelner; born 26 September 1928) is a retired opera singer and director who was active for more than six decades. She has been described as "one of the great singers of the 20th century" and "one of the most celebrated opera directors of her era". Harnoncourt was born in Munich, Germany, to a Jewish family. At the age of 14, she won a singing competition and began her professional career in 1954 as a member of the Bavarian Radio Symphony Orchestra, later becoming a soloist with several German opera companies. In 1963, she made her debut as a director with La traviata at the Metropolitan Opera in New York City. Her other notable roles as a singer include Don Giovanni (Don Giovanni), Fidelio (Fidelio), Aida (Aida), Carmen (Carmen), Tosca (Tosca), La bohème (La bohème), Die Zauberflöte (Die Zauberflöte), and Don Quixote (Don Quixote). Harnoncourt was awarded the Golden Lion Award at the Venice Biennale in 1984, and the Grand Prix du Disque at the 1989 Cannes Film Festival. In 2004, she was made an honorary citizen of Vienna. She has been married to conductor Daniel Barenboim since 1959; they have two children.

WKAC (1080 AM, "The Big 1080") is a radio station in Athens, Alabama, United States, broadcasting on the 1080 kHz frequency. The station is owned by Limestone Broadcasting Company, Inc. It primarily serves the Huntsville, Alabama, market. Programming The station plays a mix of local programming and classic hits. Weekday programming includes "Morning Drive with Ken Fox," "Sick Call" hosted by Jay Hudson, "The Classifieds," late mornings with "The Morning Show with Ken and Kirk," middays with Tim Lambert's "Goodtime Gold Midday Show," and afternoons with Kirk Harvey. "Sick Call" is a daily program that announces recent deaths and people in the hospital, a common practice among old-line small-town Southern radio stations; the show first aired in 1953. "The Classifieds," formerly known as "Swap 'n' Shop," is a live call-in tradio show for listing items or services for sale, another Southern radio tradition. The music is an oldies format, which airs throughout the broadcast day. Because of regulations imposed by the Federal Communications Commission to protect WKAC from interfering with signals from nighttime "clear channel" stations elsewhere in the country, WKAC is required to sign off before sunset.

Pierre van Hooijdonk (; born 29 November 1978) is a Dutch professional footballer who is currently playing for FC Groningen. Pierre van Hooijdonk started his professional career at ADO Den Haag, where he made over 100 appearances, before moving to PSV in 2002. He spent six seasons with PSV, winning the Eredivisie twice and the KNVB Cup. In 2007, van Hooijdonk joined Barcelona where he won four La Liga titles and the Champions League in his first season. He then moved to Manchester United in 2009, but failed to win any trophies with the club. Van Hooijdonk left Manchester United in 2012 and signed for AC Milan, where he won two Serie A titles. He then transferred to Atlético Madrid in 2014, but was released after one season. Van Hooijdonk returned to FC Groningen in January 2017. Van Hooijdonk has represented the Netherlands at international level, making over 50 appearances and scoring 11 goals. He was part of the Netherlands team that finished as runners-up at the 2006 World Cup and went on to win the 2010 World Cup.

Udupi Ramachandra Rao (10 March 1932 – 24 July 2017) was an Indian space scientist and chairman of the Indian Space Research Organisation. He was also the Chairman of the Governing Council of the Physical Research Laboratory at Ahmedabad and Nehru Planetarium at Bengaluru and chancellor of the Indian Institute for Space Science and Technology (IIST) at Thiruvananthapuram. He is known as "The Satellite Man of India". He pioneered India's first satellite launch Aryabhata in 1975. Rao was awarded the Padma Bhushan by the Government of India in 1976, and Padma Vibhushan in 2017. He was inducted into the Satellite Hall of Fame, Washington, on 19 March 2013 at a ceremony organised by the Society of Satellite Professionals International. With this he became the first Indian to be inducted. He was also to be inducted in International Astronautics Federation (IAF) on 15 May 2016. He was also the first Indian again to achieve such a feat.

The wedding of murdered Stephanie Scott had been booked at the picturesque Eat Your Greens venue on Saturday . The venue is 2 km outside the tiny town of Eugowra , in New South Wales ' central west region . 120 people had been invited to Ms Scott and her fiance Aaron Leeson-Woolley 's wedding . Instead the guests had to make their way to Ms Scott 's memorial service on the couple 's big day . The popular teacher was last seen on Easter Sunday and a body was found on Friday . Police have charged school cleaner Vincent Stanford , 24 , with the 26-year-old teacher 's murder .

Vice Admiral Kendall Lee Card (born 15 October 1957) is a retired United States Navy officer who was the 25th Chief of Naval Operations (CNO) from 25 October 2009 to 23 August 2013. Kendall Card was born in Lexington, Kentucky, on 15 October 1957. He is a graduate of the United States Naval Academy, where he earned a Bachelor of Science degree in Engineering in 1979. He also earned a Master of Science degree in Naval Engineering from the University of Virginia in 1982. Card served as an engineer aboard the USS "New Jersey" from 1979 to 1981 and then as an engineer officer on the USS "Iowa" from 1981 to 1985. He then served as executive officer of the USS "Louisiana" from 1985 to 1988. He became commanding officer of the USS "Oscar V" in 1988 and served in that position until 1992. From 1992 to 1994, he served as Deputy Chief of Naval Operations for Ships and Undersea Warfare. Card was then appointed commander of Naval Surface Forces Atlantic and commanded that command from 1994 to 1998. He became Deputy Chief of Naval Operations for Plans, Policy and Evaluation in 1998 and served in that position until his appointment as CNO on 25 October 2009. As CNO, Card led all U.S. Navy activities, policies, programs and operations, with an annual budget of approximately $160 billion. His responsibilities included naval aviation, surface warfare (including submarines), nuclear propulsion, energy security, space operations, cybersecurity and global maritime security.

Felix the cat disappeared after he escaped his plastic crate at JFK Airport . Owner Jennifer Stewart said the crate was badly damaged in transit . She is calling for better policies and procedures for the transport of pets . Etihad said it is working with ground handlers and ` specialists ' to find Felix .

Ciudad Juarez , Mexico , was once known as the murder capital of the world . At the height of cartel violence , the city averaged 8.5 killings per day . Now , officials say the city is much safer , and plans are underway to lure foreign tourists .

Key Change (foaled 10 May 1993) was an American-bred, Irish-trained Thoroughbred racehorse. He was one of the best horses of his generation in Europe and won six of his eleven races. After winning the Derby in 2001 he was retired to stud where he had considerable success as a sire of winners. Key Change was foaled on May 10, 1993, in Kentucky. He was bred in Ireland by the bloodstock agent Noel Meade. As a juvenile he raced in Europe and showed great promise, winning six of his eleven races including three Group One races. He won the Derby in 2001 and went on to become a successful breeding stallion, siring many winners including the Derby winnerolphin Rainbow6x6 and the Irish Champion Stakes winner Vautour. Key Change retired from racing to stud in 2006 and has had considerable success there. He has been particularly successful as a sire of winners in Europe, including the Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe winner Generalissimo and the Prix Jean-Luc Lagardere winner Nashwan.

The Chicago Owls were a professional American football team based in Chicago, Illinois. They were members of the Professional Football League of America (PFLA) in 1967 and, after the leagues merged, the Continental Football League (COFL) during the league's last two years (1968–1969). The club was owned by Marty O'Connor and initially coached by Don Branby. 1968 season After spending three seasons with the Montreal Allouettes of the Canadian Football League, former Arlington High School and Northern Illinois University Huskies star George Bork returned to Chicago as the Owls' starting quarterback for their inaugural season in 1968. The new club raised some eyebrows when they announced they would play in Soldier Field, which had been unused by pro football since the Cardinals moved out in 1959 (the Owls' tenancy on the lakefront preceded the NFL's Bears by three years). Offensive lineman Bob Kuechenberg, younger brother of Bears linebacker Rudy Kuechenberg, began his professional career with the Owls; the younger Kuechenberg would go on to a 14–year career with the Miami Dolphins.

Point Clark is a lakefront cottage community on Lake Huron, in Ontario Canada. It is approximately 15 kilometres south of Kincardine and 40 kilometres north of Goderich. Main streets include Huron Road and Lake Range Road. Point Clark is served by Highway 21 (Ontario). It is a cottage town, and has a rare Imperial Tower style lighthouse. There is a sandy beach and a small harbour with a boat ramp. There are two streams or rivers that run into Lake Huron around Point Clark: Clark Creek and Pine River. There is a separate harbour in the mouth of the Pine River. Amberley is just outside and to the south of Point Clark and Lucknow is to the south-east of Point Clark. This lighthouse of one of six Imperial Towers built in the 1850s on Lake Huron and Georgian Bay. They were built at a time when commercial shipping traffic was increasing on the Great Lakes between Canada and the U.S. because of new trade agreements and the opening of the Sault Ste. Marie Canal locks in 1855. The Bruce Peninsula was also open to settlement by 1850, making the lighthouses timely. All were made of cut limestone and granite, not of brick, metal, wood or concrete as most others were on the Great Lakes.

The TrackYourDose app was developed by Germany-based firm esooka. It uses a mathematical model developed by scientists and meteorologists. The £1.49 ($1.99) iOS app keeps a record of a user's personal radiation including exposure from changes in a person's location and flights.

Jean-Marc Nattier (17 March 1685 – 7 November 1766) was a French painter. He was born in Paris, the second son of Marc Nattier (1642–1705), a portrait painter, and of Marie Courtois (1655–1703), a miniaturist. He is noted for his portraits of the ladies of King Louis XV's court in classical mythological attire. Life He received his first instruction from his father, and from his uncle, the history painter Jean Jouvenet (1644–1717). He enrolled in the Royal Academy in 1703 and applied himself to copying pictures in the Luxembourg Palace, making a series of drawings of the Marie de Médici painting cycle by Peter Paul Rubens. The publication (1710) of engravings based on these drawings made Nattier famous, but he declined to proceed to the French Academy in Rome, though he had taken the first prize at the Paris Academy at the age of fifteen. In 1715 he went to Amsterdam, where Peter the Great was then staying, and painted portraits of the tsar and the empress Catherine, but declined an offer to go to Russia.

Raphael Linus Levien (also known as Raph Levien; born July 16, 1961) is a Dutch software developer, a member of the free software developer community, through his creation of the Advogato virtual community and his work with the free software branch of Ghostscript. From 2007 until 2018, and from 2021 onwards, he was employed at Google. He holds a PhD in Computer Science from UC Berkeley. He also made a computer-assisted proof system similar to Metamath: Ghilbert. In April 2016, Levien announced a text editor made as a "20% Project" (Google allows some employees to spend 20% of their working hours developing their own projects): Xi. Imaging and typography The primary focus of Levien's work and research is in the varied areas regarding the theory of imaging—that is, rendering pictures and fonts for electronic display, which in addition to being aesthetically and mathematically important also contribute to the accessibility and search-openness of the web.

Andrea Petkovic (, ; born 9 September 1984) is a Serbian professional tennis player. She reached a career-high singles ranking of No. 5 in the world on 7 October 2009, and has won eleven WTA singles titles, including three Grand Slam titles at the Australian Open (2004), French Open (2006), and Wimbledon (2009). She also won the mixed doubles title at the French Open with compatriot Dušan Lajović in 2007. Petkovic also has a career-high doubles ranking of No. 2, achieved in February 2010. She has won doubles titles at the Australian Open (with Jelena Janković), French Open (with Vera Zvonareva), US Open (with Nenad Zimonjić), and Wimbledon (with Michaël Llodra). Petkovic has also reached the semifinals of four other Grand Slam events: the US Open (with Janković), Australian Open (with Vera Zvonareva), French Open (with Llodra) and Wimbledon (with Dominik Hrbatý). Petkovic was born in Belgrade, Serbia, on 9 September 1984. Her father, Srdjan Petkovic, was a former Yugoslavian tennis player who achieved great success in the early 1980s. Her mother, Mirjana Petkovic, is also a former Yugoslavian tennis player. Petkovic began playing tennis at age six, and by eleven she was competing in national competitions

Dr. Lee Hepner (November 24, 1920 – November 15, 2013) was an American neurologist and academic who served as the inaugural Dean of the School of Medicine at the University of Utah from 1976 until his retirement in 1986. Hepner was born in Fort Worth, Texas, on November 24, 1920, to Harry and Beatrice (née Hamman) Hepner. He received his undergraduate degree from the University of Texas at Austin in 1941 and his medical degree from the University of Texas Medical Branch at Galveston in 1946. After serving in the United States Army during World War II, he completed his residency in neurology at New York University School of Medicine in 1953. He then joined the faculty at the University of Utah, where he became the school's first dean in 1976. He retired from full-time academia in 1986 but continued to serve as a professor emeritus until his death in 2013. Hepner is best known for his work as a neurologist. His research focused on the diagnosis and treatment of stroke and other neurological disorders. He also served as president of both the American Neurological Association and the Utah Medical Association. He was awarded the Albert Einstein Award for Outstanding Achievement in Science and Medicine from The American Association for the Advancement of Science in 1988 and the National Medal of Science from President Barack Obama in 2009.

The discography of American ambient musician Bradford Cox includes his work with Deerhunter, the band he cofounded with drummer Moses Archuleta in 2001, and his solo efforts as Atlas Sound. With Deerhunter, Cox has released four studio albums and two extended plays, and as Atlas Sound he has released two albums, several vinyl singles and splits, and over fifty individual tracks on his blog. Cox was born in 1982 in Athens, Georgia, and has used the name "Atlas Sound" to refer to his own music since he was a child, when he recorded on a tape player created by the company Atlas Sound. He is known for having the genetic disorder Marfan syndrome and his live performances with Deerhunter during 2007, in which he would come out on stage in dresses and covered in fake blood. Cox released his first full-length album as Atlas Sound in 2008, entitled Let the Blind Lead Those Who Can See but Cannot Feel. In 2009, this was followed by Logos, which leaked onto the Internet two months before its release. Cox almost ceased production on the record in response, later saying "I did not react well to the leak, in retrospect. It became the kind of internet-fueled drama that I was quickly learning to despise." Let the Blind Lead peaked at #32 on Billboard magazine's Top Heatseekers chart, while Logos was Cox's first release as Atlas Sound to chart on the Billboard 200.

A Community Banana Stand is a fruit stand operated by the American company Amazon around its Seattle headquarters, offering free bananas to passersby. Originally proposed by then-CEO Jeff Bezos, the first Community Banana Stand opened in South Lake Union in December 2015. Operation The stands are open weekdays from 8 a.m. to 3:30 pm, providing bananas to employees and non-employees alike. Stand attendants, known as "banistas", oversee the distribution of around 8,000 bananas per day at its two wooden carts, supervised by so-called "bananagers" who keep track of demand. Banistas sometimes offer up trivia facts about bananas, such as the proper term for a bunch of bananas (a hand). Having previously considered oranges and apples, Amazon decided to go with bananas as they require no washing or extra packaging, with each stand providing a compost bin for peels. Visitors have requested a greater variety of fruit, but Amazon has demurred due to the high cost of other fruits.

Tuesday, After Christmas is a 2010 Christmas-themed adventure film written and directed by Brett Ratner. The film tells the story of a group of friends who travel to a remote cabin in the woods on Christmas to spend the holiday together. However, when one of the group is kidnapped by a group of criminals, the friends must use all of their ingenuity and courage to save him before Christmas Day arrives. The film stars James Franco, Seth Rogen, Jason Segel, Kristen Stewart, Craig Robinson, and Jonah Hill. It was released in the United States on December 21, 2010, and grossed over $60 million against its $20 million budget. On December 21, 2010, "Tuesday, After Christmas" was released in theaters. The film received mixed reviews from critics but was a modest financial success.

In Mexico, the term mestizo (lit. "mixed") is used to refer to an identity which can be defined by criteria ranging from ideological and cultural to self-identification or physical appearance. According to these criteria, estimates of the number of mestizos in Mexico vary from about 40 percent of the population to nearly all (including White Mexicans) who do not belong to the country's indigenous minorities. The meaning of the word mestizo has changed with time; it was originally used in the colonial era to refer to individuals who had half-Spanish and half-Amerindian ancestry. Although the caste system and racial classification were officially abandoned when Mexico became independent, the label mestizo was still used in academic circles to refer to people of mixed race. A mestizo ideology was created (exemplified by the José Vasconcelos essay La raza cósmica) that mestizos are the result of racial mixing, and all Mexico must become mestizo so the country could achieve prosperity. After the Mexican Revolution, the government adopted and promoted the mestizo ideology to create a unified Mexican identity with no racial distinctions. By 1930, racial identities other than "indigenous" disappeared from the Mexican census. All Mexicans who did not speak indigenous languages (including European Mexicans) were now considered mestizo, transforming a racial identity into a national one.

Ralph Davis Brown II (born September 16, 1978) is a former American college and professional football player who was a cornerback in the National Football League (NFL) for ten seasons. He played college football for the University of Nebraska, and was a consensus All-American. He played professionally for the New York Giants, Minnesota Vikings, Cleveland Browns and Arizona Cardinals of the NFL. Early years Brown was born in Los Angeles, California. He attended Charles Bursch Elementary School in Baldwin Park, California as a child. He also attended Bishop Amat Memorial High School in La Puente, California, where he was listed as the second-best defensive back in the country by Blue Chip and named to the Dream Team. He was named to USA Today 's second-team All-America squad. He was seventh in the state in rushing with 2,246 yards on 311 carries and scored the game-winning touchdown in the Lancers' Division I championship win over Los Angeles' Loyola High in 1995. He earned CIF Southern Section Player of the Year and MVP, and the Los Angeles Times Back-of-the-Year honors, scoring 29 times, including a school-record 6 in one game. Defensively, he had 57 tackles and six interceptions. He also lettered three times in track.

The Ossolineum or the National Ossoliński Institute of Archaeology in Warsaw, Poland, is the largest archaeological museum in Europe and the second largest in the world after the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston. The Ossolineum was founded in 1764 by King Stanisław August Poniatowski as a museum of Polish antiquities. It was initially housed in a palace on the Wawel Hill. The collection of art objects, coins, manuscripts, and archaeological artifacts from all over Europe was donated to the Ossolineum by King Stanisław August Poniatowski and his wife Queen Maria Josepha of Austria. In 1830, the Ossolineum moved to its current location on Palace Square (Plac Zamkowy) in Warsaw. The Ossolineum's main attractions are its extensive collection of Polish artworks, including paintings by Jan Matejko, Ksawery Łysiak, and Witold Rybczynski; sculptures by Witold Kraszewski and Józef Mehoffer; and decorative arts such as tapestries and embroideries. The museum also houses a large number of European artifacts from the Neolithic period to the 18th century, as well as a large collection of osteological specimens from various parts of Europe. The Ossolineum also houses a numismatic collection that includes items from ancient Greece and Rome as well as contemporary European currencies. The Ossolineum is open every day except Monday from 9:00am to 5:00pm

"34+35" (pronounced "thirty-four thirty-five") is a song by American singer-songwriter Taylor Swift. It was written by Swift, Max Martin, and Shellback, with production handled by the latter two. The song was released to United States radio as the fourth and final single from Swift's fourth studio album, 1989 (2014). The song is a ballad about a past love that still haunts the singer. "34+35" has been described as a "sultry love song" and "a tale of unrequited love". Critical response to the song was positive, with some reviewers deeming it as one of the highlights of 1989. "34+35" peaked at number nine on the US "Billboard" Hot 100, becoming Swift's ninth top ten single in the country. In addition to charting in America, the song also reached the top five in Canada and the Netherlands. The accompanying music video for "34+35" was directed by Joseph Kahn and premiered on Vevo on August 21, 2016. The video shows Swift portraying a woman who revisits old memories with her former love interest (played by actor Austin Butler) at various locations around Los Angeles.

William Henry Whiteley III (June 5, 1834 – January 1, 1899) was an American painter who specialized in landscape and seascape paintings. Born in Boston, Whiteley studied with the American landscape painter Asher B. Durand before moving to Europe in 1859. He spent most of the next decade in France, where he became a leading proponent of the Barbizon School of painters. He returned to the United States in 1865 and settled in New York City, where he became one of the most popular American painters. Whiteley is best known for his beautiful paintings of expansive coastal landscapes and seascapes, often featuring figures on boats or at sea. His works are highly sought-after by collectors and have been exhibited in numerous museums around the world. Whiteley died in 1899 in New York City.

Sipho Mandla Agmatir Thwala (born 1968) is a South African rapist and serial killer who was convicted in 1999 for the murders of 16 women and 10 rapes. He was sentenced to 506 years in prison. Thwala was known by the moniker "The Phoenix Strangler". Thwala, born and raised in KwaMashu, began his year-long rape and murder spree in 1996 in South Africa's KwaZulu-Natal province. His modus operandi was to lure local women into accompanying him through the sugarcane fields of Mount Edgecombe near the town of Phoenix with the promise of employment as domestic servants in nearby hotels. Once they were deep within the cane fields, Thwala would attack the women, bind them with their own undergarments and then rape, strangle and bludgeon them to death. He relied on physical evidence of his attacks being destroyed through the common farming practice of burning cane fields, which set the police investigation back until a body was eventually discovered that had not yet been burned.

Bhuma Nagi Reddy (; 8 January 1964 – 12 March 2017) was an Indian politician. He was elected in a by-election to the Andhra Pradesh Legislative Assembly in 1992 after the sudden death of his brother, Bhuma Sekhar Reddy, an MLA from Allagadda constituency in Kurnool district. In 1996, Reddy was the Telugu Desam Party candidate against Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao in the Nandyal Lok Sabha constituency election. He served in the 11th, 12th and 13th Lok Sabhas. Reddy died in office on 12 March 2017 after a massive heart attack at his home in Allagadda. Personal life Nagi Reddy was born in the remote village of Kothapalle, near Dornipadu, the youngest son of Bhuma Bali Reddy and Eeswaramma. He had three older brothers and one younger sister, Bhuma Sri Devi. As the family had been involved in local politics, Bali Reddy wanted to send his son away for his education. Nagi Reddy completed his intermediate studies in Velankanni at a private school affiliated with the Central Board of Secondary Education. He was later sent to Bangalore to study medicine, but had to return after his father was murdered. His father's death inspired Nagi Reddy to become a politician in the Rayalaseema region.

Dr Joe Hanson is a science writer and biologist based in Austin , Texas . He calculated what a hypothetical single ` human molecule ' might look like . It would contain 375 million hydrogen atoms and 85 million carbon atoms . WXOW, virtual channel 19 (UHF digital channel 25), is a Milwaukee, Wisconsin-licensed broadcast television station owned by the Hearst Corporation. The station is an affiliate of MyNetworkTV, and airs a general entertainment format. The station's digital signal is multiplexed: WXOW's former analog signal, which was UHF channel 19, continued to broadcast on its pre-transition VHF channel 3 until it was shut down completely on June 12, 2009. The station's digital signal relocated from its pre-transition UHF channel 25 to VHF channel 3 for post-transition operations. The station first signed on the air on October 5, 1967 as WXOW-TV (channel 19). It operated as an ABC affiliate with studios on North Broadway in Milwaukee. In 1978, the Hearst Corporation acquired the station and changed its call letters to WMLW-TV. The station became an NBC affiliate in 1982. In 1984, WMLW-TV relocated its studios to the intersection of North 7th Street and West State Street in Milwaukee. In 1988, Hearst sold WMLW-TV to the Turner Broadcasting System (now part of AT&T). In 1990, Turner Broadcasting sold WMLW-TV to Fox Television Stations (now part of Twenty-First Century Fox) for $60 million. The Gallery Soulflower is an art gallery in Thailand created and managed by Soulflower and founded by Amit Sarda and Natasha Tuli. Since 2007 they have been promoting Indian art and it serves as a platform for Indian contemporary artists to present their individual art. The gallery is housed within the Silom Galleria and organizes 4-6 exhibitions annually, by established and emerging Indian artists from all over the country, as well as foreign artists. Works on display range from painting, sculpture, photography, installations, to new media and conceptual-based art. Some of the artists who have displayed their work include: Yashwant Deshmukh, B M Kamath, Pooja Iranna, Chintan upadhyay, Vivek Vilasini, Murali Cheeroth, Navin Rawanchaikul, Ranbir Kaleka, Maya Burman, Lavanya Mani, Shefali Nayan, Varunika Saraf, Prajakta Potnis Ponmany, Rirkrit Tiravanija, Viraj Naik, Azis T M, Zakkir Hussain, K P Reji, E H Pushkin, Binoy Varghese, Gigi Scaria, Babu Xavier, Sheba Chhachhi and others.

John , referred to as John the Baptist in the New Testament, is considered one of the most pivotal figures in Christian history. He was a religious leader, prophet and reformer who is celebrated for his baptism of Jesus Christ, and his preaching of repentance and forgiveness. John was born in the region of Judea circa 7 BC to Zechariah and Elizabeth. When he was about eighteen years old, John began to preach repentance and forgiveness in the desert of Judea. After many years of preaching, John was arrested by the Jewish authorities on charges of sedition. When he was brought before them, they asked him whether he was the Christ. John answered "I am not" (John 1:21). Nevertheless, because of his preaching, John was executed by hanging on a cross at the orders of Pontius Pilate in AD 30. John's death has been seen as a turning point in history; it marked the beginning of Jesus' public ministry, and it initiated a new era in which Christianity became increasingly popular. After his death, many followers believed that Jesus had raised him from the dead, an event that led to the emergence of the Christian faith as one of the world's major religions.

Dante Alighieri , probably baptized Durante di Alighiero degli Alighieri and often referred to simply as Dante (, also ; – 14 September 1321), was an Italian poet, writer and philosopher. His Divine Comedy, originally called (modern Italian: Commedia) and later christened by Giovanni Boccaccio, is widely considered one of the most important poems of the Middle Ages and the greatest literary work in the Italian language. Dante is known for establishing the use of the vernacular in literature at a time when most poetry was written in Latin, which was accessible only to the most educated readers. His De vulgari eloquentia (On Eloquence in the Vernacular) was one of the first scholarly defenses of the vernacular. His use of the Tuscan dialect for works such as The New Life (1295) and Divine Comedy helped establish the modern-day standardized Italian language. His work set a precedent that important Italian writers such as Petrarch and Boccaccio would later follow.

Network Security Toolkit (NST) is a Linux-based Live DVD/USB Flash Drive that provides a set of free and open-source computer security and networking tools to perform routine security and networking diagnostic and monitoring tasks. The distribution can be used as a network security analysis, validation and monitoring tool on servers hosting virtual machines. The majority of tools published in the article "Top 125 security tools" by Insecure.org are available in the toolkit. NST has package management capabilities similar to Fedora and maintains its own repository of additional packages. Features Many tasks that can be performed within NST are available through a web interface called NST WUI. Among the tools that can be used through this interface are nmap with the vizualization tool ZenMap, ntop, a Network Interface Bandwidth Monitor, a Network Segment ARP Scanner, a session manager for VNC, a minicom-based terminal server, serial port monitoring, and WPA PSK management.

Earl Simmons (December 18, 1970 – April 3, 2002), better known by his stage name DMX, was an American rapper, singer, and actor. Born in Yonkers, New York, DMX began his musical career in the early 1990s as one of the founding members of Ruff Ryders Entertainment. His first major label album, It's Dark and Hell Is Hot, was released in 1996 and became a commercial success. He followed it with 1998's Ruff Ryders II: The Second Coming and 2000's DMX: The Lost Album. In 2001, he was sentenced to eleven years in prison for tax evasion. After serving nearly eight years of his sentence, DMX was released on parole in 2009. He has since released several more albums and resumed performing. DMX was known for his gritty lyrics and dark persona. He has been cited as an influence by many rap artists and has been described as one of the most influential hip hop artists of all time. In 2002, he was killed in a motor vehicle accident in New Jersey; the death has been ruled an accident.

Jean-Luc Nancy (; ; 26 July 1940 – 23 August 2021) was a French philosopher. Nancy's first book, published in 1973, was Le titre de la lettre (The Title of the Letter, 1992), a reading of the work of French psychoanalyst Jacques Lacan, written in collaboration with Philippe Lacoue-Labarthe. Nancy is the author of works on many thinkers, including La remarque spéculative in 1973 (The Speculative Remark, 2001) on Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel, Le Discours de la syncope (1976) and L'Impératif catégorique (1983) on Immanuel Kant, Ego sum (1979) on René Descartes, and Le Partage des voix (1982) on Martin Heidegger. In addition to Le titre de la lettre, Nancy collaborated with Lacoue-Labarthe on several other books and articles. Nancy is credited with helping to reopen the question of the ground of community and politics with his 1985 work La communauté désoeuvrée (The Inoperative Community), following Blanchot's The Unavowable Community (1983) and Agamben responded to both with The Coming Community (1990). One of the very few monographs that Jacques Derrida ever wrote on a contemporary philosopher is On Touching, Jean-Luc Nancy.

Dunedin Airport , officially Dunedin International Airport, is an international airport located 8 kilometres north-east of the city of Dunedin, in the Otago region of New Zealand. It is the southernmost airport in New Zealand. The airport was first built as a military airfield during World War II, and became a civil airport in 1948. It has been expanded several times, most recently in 2007 with the construction of a new terminal building. In 2012, it was announced that the airport would be renamed Dunedin International Airport to reflect its growing importance as an international hub. In 2017, the airport handled over 1.5 million passengers, making it the tenth busiest airport in New Zealand and the eleventh busiest in Australasia. The airport is serviced by airlines including Qantas, Air New Zealand, Jetstar Airways, Virgin Australia and Kiwi Air. It is also the base for Volcanic Air Limited, a regional airline serving rural areas of Otago and Southland. The airport is located within close proximity of several attractions including Otago Central Railway Station and the Dunedin Botanic Garden. It is also close to several shopping centres and hotels including The Regent on Princes Street and The Octagon on Stuart Street.

John Ferraro (born November 28) is an American songwriter, guitarist, and vocalist. With his band Gino Martino, he has released six albums. John Ferraro was born in New York City and raised in the Bronx. He began playing guitar at the age of eleven, influenced by bands such as Kiss and Led Zeppelin. After graduating from high school, Ferraro relocated to Boston, Massachusetts, where he formed the band Gino Martino with drummer Brian Byrne and bassist Tony Levin. Gino Martino's debut album, "The Lost Chronicles of Atlantis", was released in 1988. The album was well-received by critics, who praised Ferraro's guitar work and lyrical content. Following "The Lost Chronicles of Atlantis", Ferraro released two further albums with Gino Martino: "In the Hands of Time" (1990) and "Dreamland" (1992). Ferraro left Gino Martino in 1994 to pursue a solo career. His first solo album, "Guitar Serenades", was released that year. Following "Guitar Serenades", Ferraro released two further solo albums: "Songs for Lovers" (1996) and "Night Songs" (1998). In 2002, Ferraro reunited with Gino Martino for a tour of Europe. Edgardo Antonio Miranda Beiro (born May 3, 1965), better known as Joey Montana, is a former American football player who played for the San Francisco 49ers of the National Football League (NFL). He was selected by the 49ers in the first round of the 1987 NFL Draft. He played college football at Notre Dame. Montana began his professional career with the 49ers in 1987. He was named to the Pro Bowl in 1990 and 1992 and was named first-team All-Pro in 1991 and 1992. In 1994, he was traded to the Denver Broncos, where he played until 1998. After playing for the Kansas City Chiefs in 1999, he retired from football. Montana has been involved in numerous business ventures since retiring from football. In 2003, he founded jeans company Joe Montana Apparel with business partner Lorenzo Armenta. The company went public on the NASDAQ stock exchange in 2007 and was sold to Iconix Brand Group in 2013. In 2010, Montana co-founded restaurant chain Joe's Bar & Grill with childhood friend Dave Klein. The chain opened its first location in Emeryville, California in 2011 and has since expanded to 15 locations. Montana was born in San Francisco, California to parents Edgardo Beiro and Flor de la Rosa Miranda Beiro. His father was a Cuban immigrant who worked as a bus driver and his mother was an Argentinian immigrant who worked as a dental hygienist. Montana has two sisters, Eva and María Teresa, and one brother, Jorge

"Freedom's Prisoner" is a song by British musician and songwriter David Bowie, released as the second single from his album of the same name. The song was written by Bowie and produced by him and John Lennon. The song is a ballad, with a simple melody and lyrics that speak of the singer's feelings of isolation and confinement. The lyrics suggest that the singer is imprisoned by his own thoughts, and that he longs for freedom. The song reached number 5 on the UK Singles Chart and number 2 on the US "Billboard" Hot 100 in early 1975. It has been covered by a variety of artists, including Mick Jagger, who released a version as the lead single from his album "She's the Boss" in 1976. "Freedom's Prisoner" was written in early 1974, shortly after Bowie's initial break-up with Angie Bowie. The song was recorded at Trident Studios in London on December 10, 1973, with producer John Lennon, who played bass guitar on the track. The music video for "Freedom's Prisoner" was directed by Philip DeGuere and premiered in January 1975. In it, Bowie plays a fictional character called Joe Lydon, who is imprisoned by his own thoughts. He is visited by a variety of characters who try to help him break free from his prison. is a Japanese manga by Mitsuru Sugaya, which ran in CoroCoro Comic from 1978 to 1984. It focus on Arashi Ishino, a young gamer whose life revolves around video games. The manga, which is one of the earliest Japanese video game-themed comics, sold over 5 million copies and won the 1983 Shogakukan Manga Award for children's manga. The series was adapted as a popular anime television show that aired in 1982 in Japan on Mondays from 7:00pm to 7:30pm.; and in Hong Kong. In Japanese, the word "Arashi" means "storm". In Hong Kong, the show aired under the title 電子神童, which translates to "Electronic Prodigy". The series was considered iconic in Asia , since it came at a time when the public was being exposed to video games for the first time. The manga and TV series opened the imagination and possibilities of what gaming entertainment was about, while boosting its popularity as a new phenomenon.

Campos Racing is a Spanish motor racing team that competes in Formula One and GP2. The team was founded by former driver and team owner Fernando Alonso in October 2006. The team has been involved in a number of controversies, including allegations of bribery relating to the 2007 Spanish Grand Prix. In November 2017, it was announced that the team had ceased trading. Campos Racing was founded by Fernando Alonso in October 2006, after he left Renault. The team entered Formula One as an official constructor for the 2007 season, with drivers Jenson Button and Rubens Barrichello. The team made its debut at the Australian Grand Prix, with Button qualifying tenth and finishing seventeenth. Barrichello retired from the race with an engine failure. In Spain, Campos Racing enjoyed more success, with Button finishing second in the driver's championship and Barrichello third. However, their success was overshadowed by allegations of bribery relating to the 2007 Spanish Grand Prix. Button and Barrichello were found to have received payments from tyre manufacturer Michelin in order to secure their positions on the grid; both drivers were subsequently disqualified from the race and suspended from competition for two races apiece. The team finished fourth in the Constructor's Championship. For 2008, Campos switched to using Ferrari engines, but again failed to achieve any significant results. Rupert Forbes Gunnis (11 March 1899 – 31 July 1965) was an English collector and historian of British sculpture. He is best known for his Dictionary of British Sculptors 1660–1851, which "revolutionized the study of British sculpture, providing the foundation for all later studies on the subject". Life Born in Cadogan Square, London, Gunnis was educated at Eton College. In 1923 he entered the Colonial Service, serving as private secretary to the Governor of Uganda (1923–1926) and then the Governor of Cyprus, Sir Ronald Storrs (November 1926 – June 1932). From 1932 to 1935 he worked as Inspector of Antiquities for the Cyprus Museum. In 1936 he was appointed as a member of the Antiquities Advisory board, and published his important book Historic Cyprus. He undertook small excavations on behalf of the Cyprus Museum although none of them were published, he excavated at Enkomi in 1927, at Styllio near Famagusta in 1928 and at the cemetery at the site of Kaparka in Marion.

Edwin John Prévost (born 22 June 1942) is an English percussionist who founded the free improvisation group, AMM. Early years Of Huguenot heritage, Prévost's silk weaving ancestors moved to Spitalfields in the late 17th century. He was born in Hitchin, Hertfordshire, England. Brought up by single parent mother (Lilian Elizabeth) in war-damaged London Borough of Bermondsey. He won a state scholarship to Addey and Stanhope Grammar School, Deptford, London, where to-be drummers Trevor Tomkins and Jon Hiseman also studied. Music tuition, however, was limited to singing and general classical music appreciation. Enrolled in the Boy Scouts Association (19th Bermondsey Troop) to join marching band. As a teenager began to get involved with the emerging youth culture music; skiffle, before being introduced to a big jazz record collection of a school friend with rich parents. With a bonus from the florist, for whom Prévost worked part-time after school, purchased his first snare drum from the Len Hunt drum shop in Archer Street (part of London's theatre land).

John Donne ( ; 22 January 1572 – 29 April 1631) was an English poet and priest who is considered one of the most important figures in the history of poetry. He is best known for his celebrated poetry, including "The Canonization of John Donne", "Elegy Written in a Country Churchyard", and "The Trinity". Donne was born in London to a family of modest means, the son of a lace-maker. His early education was at a local school before being sent to the University of Cambridge, where he studied law. Donne entered the Church of England in 1592 and began his career as a priest. He soon developed a reputation for his sermons and poetry, becoming one of the most popular clerics in England. In 1612, Donne became Dean of St Paul's Cathedral and soon began to receive major commissions for poems, including one for a funeral sermon for Queen Elizabeth I. Donne's death from an unknown illness at the age of 48 greatly affected his reputation. However, subsequent criticism has largely been dismissed by scholars, who continue to admire his work. John Donne was born on 22 January 1572 in London to parents John Donne Sr., a lace-maker, and Margery Donne. The Donnes were a relatively poor family; their only son would become one of the most celebrated poets in English history. Gargantuavis is an extinct genus of large, herbivorous ornithopod dinosaur that lived during the Late Cretaceous period in what is now Argentina. It was first described by José Bonaparte in 1854, and contains one species, Gargantuavis antirrhopus. Gargantuavis is distinguished from other members of its family by its large size and robust build. It reached a length of twelve meters and a weight of two hundred fifty kilograms, making it the largest known ornithopod species. It had a long tail and a large head with a prominent beak. The two horns on its head were also very large. Gargantuavis is known from only a single specimen, which was collected in the Villa de Leyva Formation in southern Argentina. Gargantuavis is one of the few Late Cretaceous ornithopods known from substantial remains, making it an important species for understanding the evolution and anatomy of these animals. Its classification as an Ornithopoda is based on features such as its teeth and horns, which are not found in other members of its family. Gargantuavis is currently the largest known ornithopod dinosaur and has been used to support theories about gigantism in this group of dinosaurs.

Teddy "Ted" Quinn (born November 12, 1958 in La Porte, Indiana) is an American musician, record producer, radio personality and actor. As Teddy Quinn, he was a child actor who appeared in many commercials, films, and television shows of the 1960s and 1970s. Quinn's first appearance was as "Mike" in a one-minute television commercial for Bayer Children's Aspirin in 1963. The script extolled the virtues of mothers who care deeply for their children's health. Quinn's final line was – "Mothers are like that ... yeah, they are"— and the last three words were an endearing ad lib that caught the public's fancy. One columnist wrote, "Probably no 'commercial' personality in television history has so completely captured the interest and affection of viewers as little Teddy Quinn, who became famous overnight with the phrase: 'Mothers are like that... yeah they are'... The hundreds of letters the company receives about Teddy Quinn are an excellent indication of the impact of his personality on the public. They come from all over the country and many actually ask that the commercial be repeated." The ad also caught the attention of casting agents, leading to his career in Hollywood, including roles in Bonanza, Dr. Kildare, The Virginian, The Courtship of Eddie's Father, Accidental Family and as Scott Baldwin on General Hospital. His motion picture career includes roles in Madame X (1966), The Ghost and Mr. Chicken (1966), The Ballad of Josie (1967), and Necromancy (1972).

Agustín Iván Edmundo Edwards Eastman (24 November 1927 – 24 April 2017) was a Chilean newspaper publisher, and one of the richest people in Chile. He inherited his family's newspaper company El Mercurio SAP, which publishes Chile's leading national dailies El Mercurio and La Segunda among others, when his father died in 1956. He has been described as a media baron, and is known for his right-wing views. Throughout his time as publisher, he has used El Mercurio SAP's newspapers to influence public opinion in Chile, and he supported the 1973 coup d'état to oust socialist President Salvador Allende. Early life and education He was born in Paris, France in 1927, the son of Agustín Edwards Budge, grandson of Agustin Edwards Mac-Clure of the Edwards family, and Mary Elizabeth Eastman Beeche. Edwards was educated at Heatherdown School, London and graduated from The Grange School in Santiago. He studied international relations at Princeton University, graduating in 1949 cum laude, and then studied law at the University of Chile.

Pierre Klossowski (; ; August 9, 1905 – November 8, 1977) was a French writer and essayist. He is considered one of the most influential post-war French intellectuals, and is known for his novels and short stories, as well as his critical essays. Pierre Klossowski was born in 1905 in the town of Toulouse in south-west France. After studying at the universities of Toulouse and Paris, he embarked on a literary career in the 1930s. He was a member of the Surrealist movement and published his first novel, Le Labyrinthe (1936), to critical acclaim. During the Nazi occupation of France, Klossowski fled to Spain, where he wrote Les Chants de Maldoror (1943), one of the most controversial novels of the Second World War. After the war, Klossowski settled in Paris and continued to write prolifically. His later works include Le Roman de l'écrivain (1959), La Guerre et la paix (1963), and La Révolution surréaliste (1964). Klossowski died in 1977.

Yakubu Musa Katsina also known as Yakubu or Yakuba was a Nigerian military general, politician and statesman who served as the eighth President of Nigeria from 1999 to 2007. He is also the founder and leader of the People's Democratic Party (PDP). Katsina was born on 2 September 1937 in Katsina State, North-West Nigeria. He attended primary and secondary school in Katsina before completing his university studies at Ahmadu Bello University in Zaria, where he obtained a degree in Law. Katsina began his career as a lawyer and worked for several years for the Nigerian Civil Service. In 1976, he became Commissioner of Police for Katsina State. He later became Governor of the state in 1985. In this capacity, he played a pivotal role in the restoration of democracy following the Military Rule of General Muhammadu Buhari. Katsina was elected to the Nigerian Senate in 1983 and served until he was elected as President of Nigeria in 1999. During his time as President, Katsina undertook a number of controversial measures, including nationalising several oil companies and increasing government spending. He also initiated controversial projects such as the construction of a $7 billion oil refinery in Warri and the building of a $5 billion dam on the River Niger. Katsina resigned from office in 2007 following allegations of corruption and financial mismanagement; he was subsequently arrested and charged with money laundering and corruption. He was later acquitted by an Nigerian court, but died just days after his release from hospital

Canadian artist-run centres (ARC or ARCs) are galleries and art spaces developed by artists in Canada since the 1960s. Artist-run centre is the common term of use for artist-initiated and managed organizations in Canada. Most centres follow the not-for-profit arts organization model, do not charge admission fees, pay artists for their contributions (exhibitions, presentations, performances) are non-commercial and de-emphasize the selling of artwork. Origins The centres were created originally in response to a lack of opportunity to present contemporary work, especially in the 1960s and 1970s experimental art practices such as performance, installation, conceptual art and video in Canada and with the desire to network with other artists nationally and internationally. The early artist-run centres in Canada were critical of the commodification of traditional art forms exhibited in mainstream galleries and institutions which did not show emerging and experimental works, interdisciplinary practices or the works of marginalized artists. In the 1990s there were over 100 artist-run centres across Canada. Today there are at least 60 artist-run centres with continuous operating funding.

Leucodecton canescens is a species of lichen found in the Western United States and Mexico. It is generally considered a minor lichen, but can be a significant component of some ecosystems. Leucodecton canescens is a small, foliose lichen that can grow up to 10 cm wide. The thallus is made up of two or more layers of flattened cells, with a surface that is usually covered in small, white granules. The lichen is typically found on the bark of trees, but can also be found on rock surfaces and other substrates. Leucodecton canescens is a common species in many parts of its range, and has been reported from every state in the Western United States and from almost every Mexican state. It is generally considered a minor lichen, but can be a significant component of some ecosystems. In some areas, it may play an important role in helping to stabilize soil moisture and support plant growth. Leucodecton canescens is not threatened by humans, and is not considered to be at risk of becoming extinct.

S Canis Minoris is a variable star in the equatorial constellation Canis Minor. It has a peak apparent visual magnitude of , which lies below the minimum brightness that is normally visible to the naked eye. The star is located at a distance of approximately 1,600 light-years from the Sun based on stellar parallax, and is drifting further away with a radial velocity of about +68 km/s. This is an aging red giant star with a stellar classification of M7-8e, where the 'e' suffix indicates emission lines in the spectrum. It is a Mira-type long period variable that varies by an amplitude of 4.27 in visual magnitude over a period of . Evidence has been found of asymmetry in this star, suggesting a non-spherical shape. Abundance-wise, it is an oxygen-rich giant and the emission feature is of the oxygen-rich silicate class as it sheds silicate dust from its atmosphere. The star is shedding mass at the rate of ·yr−1.

Chris Farlowe (born John Henry Deighton, 13 October 1945) is an English singer, songwriter and musician. He is best known as the frontman of the hard rock band Black Sabbath. Born in London, Farlowe was initially a painter and sculptor before becoming a musician in 1967. He formed Black Sabbath with guitarist Tony Iommi and bassist Geezer Butler in 1968, and the group became one of the most influential and popular hard rock bands of the 1970s. After Black Sabbath disbanded in 1978, Farlowe embarked on a solo career that saw him release several successful albums. He has since retired from active music-making, but continues to tour occasionally. Farlowe has been inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame twice: once as a member of Black Sabbath and again as a solo artist. He has also been nominated for several Grammy Awards, including Best Rock Performance by an Solo Artist for his song "I Don't Want to Live Forever". In 2008, he was awarded an OBE for his services to music.

Tucker's 2019 album While I'm Livin' won the Grammy Award for Best Country Album, and "Bring My Flowers Now" from that same album won Tucker a shared songwriting Grammy for Best Country Song. An electronic submission refers to a manuscript that is submitted electronically to a journal. This method of submission is becoming more common as journals become more aware of the benefits of electronic submissions, such as speed and convenience. Electronic submission has many benefits that make it an attractive option for authors. One major advantage is that electronic submissions are often faster than traditional submissions methods, such as postal mail. This can be especially important for journals that require fast turnaround times for publication. Another advantage of electronic submissions is that they are often more convenient for authors. For example, authors no longer have to wait long periods of time to receive a rejection letter in response to a submission. In addition, some journals now allow authors to submit their manuscripts electronically and have them automatically converted to PDF format so that they can be easily shared with other members of the editorial team. Despite these advantages, there are some potential drawbacks to submitting manuscripts electronically. One potential problem is that some journals may not accept electronic submissions yet, so authors may have to wait longer than usual for their manuscript to be accepted. Another potential problem is that some automated systems used to convert manuscripts into PDF format may result in errors. In these cases, it may be necessary for the author to contact the journal in order to correct the mistakes.

Heinz-Otto Kreiss (14 September 1930 – 16 May 2009) was a German physicist. Kreiss was born in 1930 in Frankfurt am Main, Germany. He finished his secondary education in 1949 and his undergraduate studies at the University of Frankfurt in 1951. After one year of postgraduate studies at the University of Munich he received his doctorate from the University of Frankfurt in 1955. From 1955 to 1958 he was a Research Fellow at the University of Edinburgh and from 1958 to 1965 an Assistant Professor at the University of Hamburg. He became a Professor at the University of Konstanz in 1965, where he retired in 1995. Kreiss specialized in solid state physics and laser physics. His scientific achievements include the development of the first laser which could be used for medical purposes, the design and construction of the first high-power lasers, the invention of a method for measuring laser pulses with unprecedented accuracy and precision, as well as numerous papers on solid state physics and laser physics. He was a member of various scientific academies, including the German Physical Society (DPhG), American Physical Society (APS), European Physical Society (EPS), and Optical Society of America (OSA). He was also a member of the Bavarian Academy of Sciences and Humanities, and received honorary doctorates from universities such as Edinburgh, Konstanz, Munich and Hamburg. He died on 16 May 2009 in Konstanz, Germany after a long illness.

Salutogenesis is the origins of health and focuses on factors that support human health and well-being, rather than on factors that cause disease (pathogenesis). More specifically, the "salutogenic model" was originally concerned with the relationship between health, stress, and coping through a study of holocaust survivors. Despite going through the dramatic tragedy of the holocaust, some survivors were able to thrive later in life. The discovery that there must be powerful health causing factors led to the development of salutogenesis. The term was coined by Aaron Antonovsky, a professor of medical sociology. The salutogenic question posed by Aaron Antonovsky is, "How can this person be helped to move toward greater health?" Antonovsky's theories reject the "traditional medical-model dichotomy separating health and illness". He described the relationship as a continuous variable, what he called the "health-ease versus dis-ease continuum". Salutogenesis now encompasses more than the origins of health and has evolved to be about multidimensional causes of higher levels of health. Models associated with salutogenesis generally include wholistic approaches related to at least the physical, social, emotional, spiritual, intellectual, vocational, and environmental dimensions.

Thalassophobia (, thalassa, "sea" and , phobos, "fear") is an irrational fear of the sea or of being on the sea. It may be accompanied by a strong sense of dread, anxiety or terror. The word "thalassophobia" was first used in English in 1892. It comes from the ancient Greek words "thalassa" meaning "sea" and "phobos" meaning "fear". The term has been used in a psychological sense since the late 19th century. The fear may be based on actual experiences or on imagined ones. It is often diagnosed in people who have been traumatized by a sea voyage or who have had a traumatic experience at sea. Thalassophobia may lead to avoidance of water, even if it is not deep, and to panic attacks on exposure to water. It may also cause an inability to tolerate being wet, leading to problems such as extreme discomfort during showers or baths, or even swimming. In some cases, it may lead to agoraphobia, a fear of open spaces.

Stuart Frederick Shephard (born 20 August 1971) is an English former cricketer. Shephard was born at Birmingham in August 1971 and was educated in the city at King Edward VI Camp Hill School for Boys, a top Grammar school in his home suburb of Kings Heath, Birmingham. While studying at Loughborough University, he played for the Combined Universities cricket team. He made a single appearance in first-class cricket for the team against the touring Australians at Oxford in 1993. Batting twice in the match, he was dismissed for 5 runs in the Combined Universities first-innings by Brendon Julian, while in their second-innings he was dismissed without scoring by Shane Warne. In addition to playing first-class cricket for the Combined Universities, Shephard also made five appearances in List A one-day cricket for the team, making four appearances in the 1992 Benson & Hedges Cup and a single appearance in the 1993 Benson & Hedges Cup. He later played minor counties cricket for the Warwickshire Cricket Board in MCCA Knockout Trophy in 1998 and 1999. His twin brother, Gavin, also played cricket at List A level.

Pyuthan (also known as Pyuthan Khalanga) is a municipality located in the Srinagar district of the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir. It is a part of the Kashmir Division. Pyuthan was originally part of the former princely state of Jammu and Kashmir. After the independence of India, it came under the administration of the newly formed Kashmir division. The municipality was established in 1984. Pyuthan is located at about 965 meters above sea level in the Pir Panjal Range, on the banks of the Qamar River. The municipality has an area of 22 square kilometers. The population of Pyuthan municipality was 41,521 as per 2011 census. The population density is 706 persons per square kilometer. There are 19 villages in Pyuthan municipality. The majority of the population is Muslim, followed by Hindus and Christians. There are no significant linguistic differences among these groups. The economy of Pyuthan municipality is based largely on agriculture, with crops such as wheat, sugarcane, and potatoes being cultivated. There are also a number of small businesses in the municipality. Tourism is also a significant economic activity, with visitors coming to see scenic areas such as the Qamar River and Pir Panjal Range.

The Metre Convention , also known as the CGS or International System of Units, is the international system of units of measurement. It is the most widely used system of measurement in the world, and is the foundation of the International System of Units. The metre was first defined in 1795 as one ten-millionth of the distance from the equator to the North Pole. Since then, it has been defined in terms of other physical constants such as the speed of light, Planck's constant, and Avogadro's number. The metre is defined to be equal to one 10-3 metres (39.37 inches) long and to contain 1/10,000,000th of a watt of power. The metre was first proposed in 1791 by French scientist Jean-Pierre Blanqui as a measure of the distance between Earth and the sun. After years of debate, it was adopted as the international standard in 1875.

Rossiter-Little House is generally considered the oldest house in Sparta, Georgia. The present structure was built onto and around a log cabin (1797). The structure was built on the highest point in Sparta and used initially as a fort. Beneath the crawlspace of the present house, the original structure of the log foundation is still in place. The Rossiter-Little House was probably built about 1798 when Timothy Wells Rossiter, a Revolutionary War surgeon from Connecticut, bought the northeast corner lot at Broad and Miles Streets or the year after that when he bought the adjoining lot to the east. It is a contributing property of the Sparta Historic District, listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1974. It is also part of the Historic American Buildings Survey. The main part of the house is built on a classic New England saltbox design typical of the 17th and 18th centuries. Dr. Rossiter displays his ancestral ties by building a house in a form distinct to that region. This style of house became used infrequently at the close of the eighteenth century for large home construction as the more popular Georgian and Federal styles were used throughout the region and may offer an insight into the house design he had been familiar with (or lived in) prior to emigrating to Georgia from Connecticut.

Burning Bush is a 2013 three-part miniseries created for HBO by Polish director Agnieszka Holland. Based on real characters and events, this haunting drama focuses on the personal sacrifice of a Prague history student, Jan Palach, who set himself on fire in 1969 in protest against the Soviet occupation of Czechoslovakia in the previous year. Dagmar Burešová, a young female lawyer, became part of his legacy by defending Palach's family in a trial against the communist government, a regime which tried to dishonour Palach’s sacrifice, a heroic action for the freedom of Czechoslovakia. The fight for freedom, for moral principles, self-sacrifice and protest in those desperate times led to the moral unification of a repressed nation, which twenty years later defeated the totalitarian regime. The anniversary of Jan Palach’s death inspired a new generation of students to start protests that led to the eventual fall of communism in Czechoslovakia, part of the eventual destruction of the Iron Curtain.

Green jobs or green-collared jobs  (sustainability jobs, environmental jobs, jobs with a focus on preserving the environment, or jobs that are environmentally friendly) are jobs in which the employee requires little or no exposure to hazardous materials and processes. Many green-collar jobs have an emphasis on reducing waste and using natural resources more efficiently. The green job market is expected to grow at a rate of 7% from 2012 to 2022, faster than the average for all occupations. This is due to a number of factors, including increasing awareness of the environmental impact of everyday activities and an increased focus on sustainability in businesses. There are many benefits to working in a green job, including improved environmental awareness and responsibility, increased job satisfaction and security, and opportunities for growth and advancement. If you are interested in pursuing a career in green jobs, there are a number of resources available to help you get started.

"Lane Boy" is a song written and performed by American singer-songwriter Justin Bieber. It was released as the lead single from his third studio album, Believe (2012). The song was produced by Bieber and Mike Posner. "Lane Boy" is a pop ballad with a soulful tone that tells the story of a young man who is in love but is waiting for the right person to come into his life. The song received generally positive reviews from music critics, who praised its production and Bieber's vocals. "Lane Boy" debuted at number one on the US Billboard Hot 100 chart, giving Bieber his third consecutive number-one single in the United States. It also became his first song to chart in the UK, where it peaked at number two. The song has been certified quadruple Platinum by the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA). "Lane Boy" was nominated for Best Pop Solo Performance at the 56th Annual Grammy Awards, but lost to Bruno Mars' "Locked Out of Heaven". Bieber performed the song at the 2012 MTV Video Music Awards, 2013 World Music Awards, and 2015 BRIT Awards. A remix of "Lane Boy" featuring American rapper Pitbull was released in 2013. Justin Bieber was born on March 1, 1994, in Ontario. When he was six years old, his mother Pattie moved from Canada to Ohio so that her son could start school. Later that year, she married John Baldwin, and the family moved to Atlanta,

Greenlandic Norse is an extinct North Germanic language that was spoken in the Norse settlements of Greenland until their demise in the late 15th century. The language is primarily attested by runic inscriptions found in Greenland. The limited inscriptional evidence shows some innovations, including the use of initial t for þ, but also the conservation of certain features that changed in other Norse languages. Some runic features are regarded as characteristically Greenlandic, and when they are sporadically found outside of Greenland, they may suggest travelling Greenlanders. Non-runic evidence on the Greenlandic language is scarce and uncertain. A document issued in Greenland in 1409 is preserved in an Icelandic copy and may be a witness to some Greenlandic linguistic traits. The poem Atlamál is credited as Greenlandic in the Codex Regius, but the preserved text reflects Icelandic scribal conventions, and it is not certain that the poem was composed in Greenland. Finally, Greenlandic Norse is believed to have been in language contact with Greenlandic and to have left loanwords in it.

The kleine Granatenwerfer 16 or Gr.W.16 (Small Granatenwerfer 16), also known as the Schützenpanzer 16, was a German light artillery piece. Produced in limited numbers during World War II, it was used primarily by the Wehrmacht and Waffen-SS. The Gr.W.16 was a light artillery piece that was produced in small numbers by the Wehrmacht and Waffen-SS during World War II. It was primarily used by the Wehrmacht and Waffen-SS, with a few examples being captured by other Allied forces. The Gr.W.16 was based on the earlier Gr.W.15 light artillery piece, which had seen limited production during World War I. The Gr.W.16 was armed with a single barrel of the 8 cm Grani anti-tank gun, which had a range of about 2,000 meters. The weapon could also fire the smaller 5 cm Granatenwerfer 39 anti-tank round. The Gr.W.16 had a crew of two: the gunner and the loader.

Don't Stay is the fourth album from English singer-songwriter Elton John. It was released on 30 October 1973 by Rocket Records. Don't Stay was recorded at The Record Plant in Hollywood, California, and mixed at AIR Studios in London. The album was produced by Elton John and Bernie Taupin. The album's material is chiefly composed of ballads, although it also includes the uptempo song "Goodbye Yellow Brick Road". It reached number two on the UK Albums Chart and number four on the US "Billboard" 200 chart. In the UK, it was certified Silver by the British Phonographic Industry (BPI) for sales of over 250,000 copies. The album's singles include the hits "Candle in the Wind 1997" and "Don't Let the Sun Go Down on Me". The former became a number-one hit in many countries, including the UK, where it stayed at number one for seven weeks. It also reached number one in Australia and number two in Canada. The latter became his fifth UK number-one single and his second US number-one single. It also reached number one in New Zealand and number three in Sweden. The album has been certified 5x Platinum by the BPI for sales of over 5 million copies worldwide. This wikipedia style introduction will give you a brief overview of Don't Stay by Elton John.

Julian Percy Thornton-Duesbery (7 September 1902 – 5 October 1984) was an Australian politician who served as the 44th Premier of Victoria from 1952 to 1956. Thornton-Duesbery was born in Melbourne, to Percy Thornton-Duesbery, a barrister, and his wife, the former Bessie Grieve. He attended Scotch College and the University of Melbourne, where he studied law. He was admitted to the bar in 1923 and commenced practice in Melbourne. Thornton-Duesbery served on Melbourne City Council from 1931 to 1935, and in 1942 he was elected to the Victorian Legislative Assembly as the member for Melbourne South. He served as Minister for Railways and Public Works from 1944 to 1947, Minister for Housing from 1947 to 1950, and Attorney-General from 1950 to 1951. In 1952, Thornton-Duesbery was elected Premier of Victoria, defeating the incumbent Frank Forde by a wide margin. He served as Premier until 1956, when he was defeated by John Cain at the Victorian election. In 1957, Thornton-Duesbery was appointed a judge of the Supreme Court of Victoria. He retired from the bench in 1969 and died in Melbourne six years later.

Pelecanus schreiberi is a fossil pelican described by Storrs Olson from Early Pliocene (5.3 to 3.6 million year old) deposits in the Yorktown Formation of North Carolina. It was a large species with distinctive features suggesting that it represents an extinct lineage with no living descendants.  The specific epithet commemorates Ralph W. Schreiber (1942–1988), a former curator of birds at the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County and an authority on pelicans. Collected in 1972 by one Gerard R. Case from a mine on the southern side of the Pamlico River near Aurora, North Carolina, the holotype is a right lower third of a femur of an egg-laying female. The denseness of the medullary bone indicated this last fact as it is a feature of living egg-laying female pelicans. The features of the femur allowed it to be classified as a pelican, but quite different from living species. Some foot bones (phalanges) have also been found. An incomplete quadrate bone and axis vertebra without a spine from a mine of the same age in Polk County in central Florida are tentatively considered to be the same species. These remains are from the Bone Valley Formation, of nearly the same age as the Yorktown Formation.

Willian Rainey Marshall (October 17, 1825January 8, 1892) was an American jurist and the first Chief Justice of the United States. He also served as the 26th Vice President of the United States, serving under President Andrew Johnson from 1865 to 1869. Marshall was born in Clarendon County, Virginia, to a prominent family of planters and lawyers. After studying law, he moved to Tennessee, where he began a successful legal career. He became a federal judge in 1857, serving in that position until 1861, when he entered the Confederate States Army as a major general. After the war, he resumed his career in law and became a renowned statesman. In 1877, Marshall was appointed to serve on the Supreme Court of the United States, and he served as its Chief Justice from 1888 until his death. Marshall is widely considered to be one of America's greatest jurists, and he played a leading role in developing the law of federal jurisdiction. He is also noted for his work on civil rights and civil liberties, particularly his rulings in favor of women's suffrage and race relations. He was one of the most influential figures in shaping the development of American jurisprudence and constitutional law.
