Prestonsburg is a small home rule-class city in and the county seat of Floyd County, Kentucky, United States. It is in the eastern part of the state in the valley of the Big Sandy River.  The population was 3,255 at the time of the 2010 census, down from 3,612 at the 2000 census. History The area was part of the grant in the early 1700s to the family of John Preston's wife, born Elizabeth Patton, which he administered on her behalf. The grant was intended to permit British colonization beyond the Blue Ridge Mountains, but subsequent French and Indian resistance and a reversal of British policy limited its impact. The land was not settled until John Spurlock of Montgomery County, Virginia, arrived in 1791. He laid out the town of "Preston's Station" in 1797. It became the seat of Floyd County upon its formation in 1799 and was formally established in 1818. The post office was known as "Floyd Court House" from its establishment in 1816 until the late 1820s, when it was renamed "Prestonsburg".

Liverpool Sound Collage is an electronic album by Paul McCartney, which is also credited to the Beatles, Super Furry Animals and Youth. McCartney had previously released two projects with Youth under the moniker the Fireman. Because McCartney was so heavily involved in its creation, in addition to his production credit, Liverpool Sound Collage, which was released in 2000, is generally considered a part of his main discography and is filed under his name. Asked by artist Peter Blake to create something musical and with a Liverpool spirit to it, in order to complement his concurrent artwork exhibition, McCartney ended up harking all the way back to session chatter by the Beatles (hence their "involvement") and using snippets of his 1991 classical piece Paul McCartney's Liverpool Oratorio. He also can be heard walking the streets and asking various pedestrians to give their impressions of Liverpool and the Beatles. The album also incorporates chopped up beats and digital manipulation of assorted sound clips.

Count was a Bakumatsu period Japanese nobleman who served as the 10th shogun of the Tokugawa shogunate. Nanbu Toshiyuki was born in 1630 as the son of Nanbu Toshimasa, a daimyo of Satsuma Domain in Kyūshū. He became a retainer in the service of Tokugawa Ieyasu in 1653, and followed him to Edo (modern Tokyo) when Ieyasu became shogun in 1603. Nanbu Toshiyuki participated in many of Ieyasu's campaigns and attained high positions, including being appointed governor of Satsuma Domain in 1664. He also served as commander of the armies assigned to suppress various rebellions, and played an important role in the consolidation of power by Ieyasu and the Tokugawa shogunate. In 1689, Nanbu Toshiyuki was appointed lord lieutenant of Yamaguchi and Nagano Provinces, and he served in that capacity until his death five years later. He was also made a viscount ("shishōgun") in 1696. Nanbu Toshiyuki died at the age of 72 on November 30, 1700. He was posthumously awarded the title "daimyōjin" (great daimyo), and he is also remembered for his patronage of the arts.

Society Hill Towers is a three-building condominium located in the Society Hill neighborhood of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. The complex contains three 31-story skyscrapers with 624 units on a site. The towers were designed by I.M. Pei and Associates and are constructed of poured-in-place concrete, with each apartment featuring floor-to-ceiling windows. Completed in 1964, the apartments were originally rental units but were converted to condominiums in 1979. History In the late 1950s, Society Hill was considered a slum neighborhood, which was targeted for redevelopment by the Philadelphia City Planning Commission and the Redevelopment Authority. From 1957 to 1959, the Greater Philadelphia Movement, the Redevelopment Authority, and the Old Philadelphia Development Corporation bought around Dock Street. They relocated and demolished the Dock Street Market, setting aside of land that would become the Society Hill Towers. In 1957, Edmund Bacon, the executive director of the Philadelphia City Planning Commission, awarded developer-architect firm Webb and Knapp the competition for the redevelopment of Society Hill. Architect I. M. Pei and his team created a plan for three 31-story Society Hill Towers as well as the Society Hill Townhouses, a low-rise project. The Towers and Townhouses project was completed in 1964, while the entire plan was completed in 1977.

Nathan Eckstein (January 10, 1873 – October 15, 1939) was an American author and journalist who specialized in the history of the United States. He was a noted authority on the history of the American West and wrote extensively about American Indian culture. Nathan Eckstein was born in Brooklyn, New York on January 10, 1873. He attended Williams College, where he received his B.A. in 1895. Eckstein then studied at Johns Hopkins University, where he received his M.A. in 1897 and his Ph.D. in 1902. Eckstein began his career as a teacher at Williams College before joining the faculty of Yale University in 1904 as an associate professor of history. He became a full professor at Yale in 1926 and remained there until his retirement in 1939. Eckstein spent most of his career teaching at Yale, but he also spent time writing and publishing articles and books on American history. He is best known for his books on the history of the American West, including The Great West (1927), The Trail of thelonesome Dove (1929),and The Great Plains (1936). He also wrote extensively about American Indian culture, including The People of the Tigris and Euphrates (1931), The Story of All Nations (1935), and The Story of Civilization (1938). Nathan Eckstein died on October 15, 1939 at the age of 70 after a long battle with cancer.

Chamras Saewataporn has also appeared in several television dramas, including 2005's Eyes of My Enemy and 2009's The Legend of Suriyothai.

Leonard Crow Dog (August 18, 1942 – January 8, 2006) was a Native American activist and spiritual leader. Crow Dog was a member of the Oglala Sioux Tribe, and is best known for his work as a spokesman for the American Indian Movement (AIM). Crow Dog was born on August 18, 1942, on the Pine Ridge Sioux Reservation in South Dakota. He was the son of Walter Crow Dog and Pearl Thunder Hawk. Crow Dog grew up on the reservation and attended school there. In the early 1960s, Crow Dog became involved with the American Indian Movement (AIM). He worked as a messenger and organizer for AIM, and played a key role in several major protests and campaigns. Among these were AIM's occupation of Alcatraz in 1969, its campaign against the construction of the Keystone XL pipeline in South Dakota in 2012, and its fight against the Three Forks Dam project on the Missouri River in Montana. Crow Dog also played an important role in AIM's spiritual life. He was a member of AIM's Grand Council Fire, and served as its spiritual leader from 1987 until his death. Crow Dog also founded the Leonard Crow Dog Foundation to promote Indigenous sovereignty and traditional spirituality. Crow Dog died on January 8, 2006, at the age of 59. He was survived by his wife, Sara Blue Eagle; his four children: Tara Blue Eagle (born 1973), Leonard Yellow Thunder (born 1975), Skyler Yellow Bird (born 1978), and

Alexander Marcus Hooks (August 29, 1906 – June 19, 1993) was an American professional baseball player. He had a 17-season (1928–1943; 1946) career in minor league baseball, and appeared in 15 Major League games as a first baseman and pinch hitter for the Philadelphia Athletics during the season. A native of Edgewood, Texas, he threw and batted left-handed, stood tall and weighed . Hooks attended Southern Methodist University. Hooks' Major League trial occurred at the outset of the 1935 season when he was 28 years old. The previous year, he had batted a robust .340 for the Tulsa Oilers of the Texas League. In his big-league debut, Hooks went 2-for-5 against the Washington Senators, but then went hitless in seven at bats in his next two starts, and failed to hold the Athletics' starting first baseman job. After his last MLB appearance on May 20, he was sent to the Atlanta Crackers of the Southern Association, where he batted .341.

Dr. Liara T'Soni is a fictional character in the Mass Effect video game series, created by BioWare's Casey Hudson. She is a Human/Asari hybrid and a graduate of the Alliance Military Academy in 2183. T'Soni first appears in Mass Effect 3, serving as an advisor to Commander Shepard. Liara T'Soni is a Human/Asari hybrid and a graduate of the Alliance Military Academy in 2183. She is an advisor to Commander Shepard in the third game of the Mass Effect series, serving as a counterpoint to the more militaristic Commander Shepard. Liara's motivation for joining the Alliance is her belief that all species must work together to fight against the Reapers, and she becomes an important ally to Shepard in their efforts to stop them. Liara is also responsible for developing the Prothean Beacon on Earth, which allows Shepard and their team to travel to far-off planets in order to defeat the Reapers. Liara has a strong sense of morality, which often conflicts with that of Commander Shepard. For example, she refuses to fire on civilians during the attack on Earth, even though Shepard orders her to do so. Liara also has a deep love for her friends and family, which often causes tension with Shepard when she insists on accompanying them on dangerous missions. Despite these occasional disagreements, Liara remains a valuable ally and friend to Commander Shepard throughout the course of the trilogy.

Elly Kleinman (born 1952) is an American artist who lives and works in New York City. Kleinman was born in 1952 in Brooklyn, New York, to a Jewish family. She attended the School of Visual Arts and received her BFA in 1976. After graduating from SVA, Kleinman moved to Manhattan and began painting and drawing on the subway. Kleinman's early paintings were often abstract, featuring bright colors and geometric shapes. However, in the late 1990s she began working with more autobiographical materials, including photos of herself and her family. Her work has been described as "strikingly personal" and "poignant". Kleinman has exhibited her work throughout the United States and Europe, most notably at the Whitechapel Gallery in London (1998), the Museum of Modern Art in New York (1999), and the Centre Pompidou in Paris (2003). She has also been awarded numerous awards, including a Guggenheim Fellowship (1998) and a grant from the Pollock-Krasner Foundation (2000).

Camp Lemonnier is a United States Naval Base in Djibouti, located about 10 miles northeast of the city of Djibouti City. The camp is host to a variety of military and civilian personnel, as well as a number of service-related agencies. Camp Lemonnier was established in 1937 by the United States Army as an airfield for American military aircraft. It was used by the United States during World War II, primarily for strategic bombing missions over Europe. In 1977, it was taken over by the United States Navy and renamed Camp Lemonnier. The camp became home to United States Naval Forces Central Command (CENTCOM) in 1989. In 2002, it was designated as a joint U.S.-French military installation and has been known as Camp Lemonnier-France since that time. The camp has played an important role in United States military operations in the Horn of Africa and Middle East. It has been the site of a number of terrorist attacks, most notably the October 2002 bombing of the USS Cole which killed 17 American sailors. In response to these attacks, Camp Lemonnier has been strengthened with additional security measures.

Qasim al-Raymi (; 5 June 1978 – 25 December 2010) was a Syrian singer, songwriter and actor. He is considered one of the most successful singers in the Arab world, with over 30 million records sold. Qasim al-Raymi was born in the town of Rayy, in the governorate of Homs, on 5 June 1978. He studied at the Homs Conservatory and then moved to Beirut to study music at the Lebanese National Conservatory. Raymi made his professional debut in 1999 with the album "Siha al-Janoubi". The album was a commercial success, selling over one million copies. His second album, "Al-Khamsin", was released in 2002 and became his most successful album to date, selling over six million copies. He also released a number of successful singles from the album, including "Habibi", "Wada'a" and "Khaliha". In 2006, he released his third album, "Al-Mu'tamad". The album received positive reviews and became his most successful release to date, selling over fifteen million copies. Raymi's fourth album, "Al-Qamar", was released in 2009 and became his least successful release to date, selling only modestly compared to his previous albums. Raymi died on 25 December 2010 after a long battle with cancer. He was only 38 years old.

(William) D'Arcy McNickle (January 14, 1904 – October 10, 1977) (Salish Kootenai) was a writer, Native American activist, college professor and administrator, and anthropologist. Of Irish and Cree-Métis descent, he later enrolled in the Salish Kootenai nation, as his mother has come to Montana with the Métis as a refugee. He is known also for his novel The Surrounded. Biography D'Arcy McNickle was an enrolled Salish Kootenai on the Flathead Indian Reservation. He was born on January 14, 1904, to William McNickle, ethnic Irish, and Philomene Parenteau, Cree- Métis. His mother was among numerous Métis who had fled to Montana in the late 19th century to escape the aftermath of suppression following the 1885 Riel Rebellion, also known as the North-West Rebellion. She eventually found refuge at the Flathead reservation. McNickle grew up on the reservation in St. Ignatius. He attended mission schools there and boarding schools located elsewhere, off the reservation.

Skee-Ball is an arcade game and one of the earliest examples of a pinball game. The objective is to hit balls into a goal, and the game is played on a rectangular playing field with a pole in the center. The game was invented by Clarence Skee in 1887 and became popular in amusement arcades during the early 1900s. Skee-Ball has been featured in several films, including "The Incredibles" and "Porky's". Skee-Ball is an arcade game that uses small metal balls instead of golf balls to play. Players use a hand-held pole to hit the balls into a small target at the center of the playing field. The object of the game is to score as many points as possible before the opponent does. Points are scored by hitting the ball into either of two adjacent targets. Hitting one target scores four points, while hitting both targets scores ten points. If the player misses the ball completely, it goes out of play and they start over at the beginning of their turn. Skee-Ball was invented by Clarence Skee in 1887. At first, he called his new invention "Ticket Ball", but it didn't catch on. In 1906, he changed the name to Skee-Ball and started selling it in amusement arcades. It quickly became popular and by 1912, there were over 2,000 Skee-Ball machines in operation across America. Margo Glantz Shapiro (; born January 28, 1954) is an American journalist, author, and broadcaster. She is the president and founder of TheGlantzGroup, a public relations and media consulting firm. Glantz has written two best-selling books on the history of Hollywood: "Hollywood's Darkest Hour" (1998) and "Hollywood Babylon" (2003). She also wrote the book "The Mad Woman of Hollywood" (1994), which chronicles the life of actress Mae West. Glantz has been a contributing editor to "Esquire" magazine and a regular commentator on television and radio programs on Hollywood history. She is also a frequent speaker at film festivals and conferences. In 2003, Glantz was awarded an Emmy Award for her work on the documentary series "Hollywood's War: The Untold Story of World War II in Entertainment". In 2007, she received an honorary doctorate from New York University. Margo Glantz was born in Brooklyn, New York, to Irving Glantz and Frieda (née Shapiro). She is Jewish. Glantz married attorney Jonathan Shapiro in 1977; they divorced in 1984. From 1985 to 1988 she was married to author Michael Herr. Glantz has two children from her first marriage: daughter Molly Shapiro (born 1978) and son Ben Shapiro (born 1980). World Literacy Crusade (WLC) is a non-profit organisation formed in 1992 by the Rev. Alfreddie Johnson to fight illiteracy, and supported by the Church of Scientology. The group uses "study technologies" and "drug rehabilitation technologies" developed by L. Ron Hubbard, the Church's founder. It has been characterized as a "Scientology front group", and has been promoted by celebrity Scientologists such as Isaac Hayes and Anne Archer. Legal issues The LA Times reported in 2008 that about 100 protestors gathered outside of the World Literacy Crusade offices after being sold fake low cost housing vouchers for as much as $1500. Officials at WLC admitted to selling the free vouchers, but stated they did not know they were fake. The Compton, Californian offices of the WLC housed a drug detox program using “dry heat sweat therapy”. In 2015 the executive director of WLC, Hanan Islam, Ronnie Steven Islam (AKA Rizza Islam) and her adult children were arrested for Medi-Cal fraud and insurance fraud for billing for this detox program.

Bilāl ibn Rabāḥ , , was one of the most trusted and loyal Sahabah (companions) of the Islamic prophet Muhammad. He was born in Mecca and is considered to have been the first mu'azzin in history, chosen by Muhammad himself. He was a former slave and was known for his voice with which he called people to their prayers. He died in 640, about the age of 60 (or just over 60 in Hijri years). Birth and early life Bilal ibn Rabah was born in Mecca in the Hejaz in the year 580. His father Rabah was an Arab slave for the clan of Banu Jumah while his mother, Hamamah, was allegedly a former princess of Abyssinia who was captured after the event of the Year of the Elephant, and put into slavery. Being born into slavery, Bilal had no other option but to work for his master, Umayyah ibn Khalaf. Through hard work, Bilal became recognised as a good slave and was entrusted with the keys to the Idols of Arabia. However, racism and sociopolitical statutes of Arabia prevented Bilal from achieving a lofty position in society.

Association theory (also aggregate theory) is a theory first advanced by chemist Thomas Graham in 1861 to describe the molecular structure of colloidal substances such as cellulose and starch, now understood to be polymers. Association theory postulates that such materials are solely composed of a collection of smaller molecules bound together by an unknown force. Graham termed these materials colloids. Prior to the development of macromolecular theory by Hermann Staudinger in the 1920s, which stated that individual polymers are composed of chains of covalently bonded monomers, association theory remained the most prevalent model of polymer structure in the scientific community. Importantly, although polymers consist of long chains of covalently linked molecules, the individual polymer chains can often still associate and undergo phase transitions and phase separation to form colloids, liquid crystals, solid crystals, or aggregates. For biopolymers, association leads to formation of biomolecular condensates, micelles and other examples of molecular self-assembly.

Melvin Henry Roberts (January 18, 1943 – September 1, 2007) was an American professional baseball player, coach and manager. Primarily an outfielder during his playing days, all spent in the minor leagues, Roberts spent four seasons (1992–95) in Major League Baseball as the first-base coach of the Philadelphia Phillies, including service on the Phillies' 1993 National League pennant-winning team. Roberts was born in Abington Township, Montgomery County, Pennsylvania, graduated from Abington Senior High School, and attended both Temple University and Spartanburg Technical College. A right-handed batter and thrower who stood tall and weighed , he signed with the Los Angeles Dodgers in 1961 and played in their farm system for four seasons. Christopher Alexander "Alex" Haun (September 14, 1821 – December 11, 1861) was a potter from Greene County, Tennessee, regarded as one of the most notable and skilled of the antebellum period. During the American Civil War, he was executed by the Confederate States of America for participation in the East Tennessee bridge-burning conspiracy. Haun was one of many examples in 19th century Tennessee of what were later referred to as family potters, rural potters who ran businesses, often part-time as a supplement to farming and with the aid of their families, supplying practical vessels for local use. Stephen T. Rogers of the Tennessee Historical Commission writes that Haun "produced some of the most beautiful and finely crafted lead-glazed earthenware in Tennessee". Haun and a number of potters lived in a part of Greene County referred to as Pottertown, using local clay found near Lick Creek. Pottertown was a staunchly Unionist enclave in a Confederate State.

Cui Guanghao (; born April 22, 1979) is a male Chinese table tennis player. He is a three-time Olympian (2000, 2004, 2008), having won a silver medal in the men's doubles event at the 2000 Summer Olympics and two bronze medals in the men's singles and mixed doubles event at the 2004 and 2008 Olympics. Born in Beijing, Cui started playing table tennis at the age of six. He was an outstanding junior player, winning a number of national titles in China. In 1998, he became the youngest player ever to win an international title, when he won the Men's Singles title at the Asian Championships in Bangkok, Thailand, aged just 16 years and 69 days. Cui made his senior debut at the 1999 World Championships in Copenhagen, Denmark. He reached the semifinals of this tournament, before losing to eventual champion Stefan Edberg. Cui went on to win his first major title at the 2001 Chinese Table Tennis Championships. He defeated Zhang Jike 3–0 in the final to take the title. At the 2002 World Championships in Yokohama, Japan, Cui reached the quarterfinals after defeating both top seed and reigning World Champion Ma Lin 2–1 and fourth seed Zhang Jike 3–1. Fort Stikine was a British Fort ship stationed in the Stikine River system on the border of what is now the United States and Canada during the late 19th century. The fort was active from 1881 to 1897 and was abandoned as a military installation following the end of the British Columbia Gold Rush. The fort was used as a customs post until it was abandoned in 1944. Today, Fort Stikine is a popular tourist destination and is administered by the Government of Canada. The Stikine River system was a strategic location during the late 19th century, as it served as the border between what is now the United States and Canada. The fort was built in 1881 by the British as part of their efforts to control this area and protect their interests in the region. The fort consisted of two batteries, each with twelve guns, and was manned by around fifty soldiers. The fort played an important role in British Columbia's gold rush era. It was used as a customs post to stop smugglers and contraband from entering or leaving Canada. The fort also acted as a base for military operations against American settlers who were operating in the area illegally. The fort was abandoned following the end of the gold rush, in 1897. It remained in use as a customs post until it was abandoned in 1944. Today, Fort Stikine is a popular tourist destination, administered by the Government of Canada.

Kadgaon is a town situated Gadhinglaj Taluka in Nashik District of Maharashtra, India. Kadgaon is located at . It has an average elevation of 546 metres (1765 feet). Kadgaon is one of the oldest towns in Nashik district. Kadgaon was founded by a Brahmin named Kondevi. Kadgaon is derived from the Marathi words "kadg" meaning a spring and "ona" meaning town. Kadgaon was mentioned in the Pali Buddhist scriptures as "Kaggadipura". The town got its name from the spring of water that flowed from a hill called "Tung", which is situated to the east of the town. The hill was believed to be the abode of a saint called Kondevi, who is said to have blessed the town with its springs. The old town of Kadgaon is built around two main roads - Mahatma Phule Road and Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar Road. The new town spread out in all directions around these two roads. The new town has many shops, markets, and business establishments. There are also many schools and colleges in the new town. The old town has a number of temples including the famous Shri Mahadev Temple, the Ganesh Temple, and the Kamakhya Temple. There are also several mosques in the old town. The Herts Senior Cup, officially titled the Hertfordshire County Football Association Senior Challenge Cup, is the oldest County-based football Cup competition based exclusively in Hertfordshire, England. It was first contested in the 1886-87 season and won by Hoddesdon Town. It has been contested every year since except for the years 1915 to 1918 when it was suspended during World War I. It is usually contested by the twenty-two most senior Clubs in the County, though this number has been higher and lower in previous years. Finals have nearly always been staged at a neutral venue in the County, apart from a few seasons in the mid-1960s when the final was played over two-legs. Since the 2004-05 season, finals have been staged at the Herts FA's headquarters at the County Ground, Letchworth Garden City, with the exception of 2010-11, when the final was moved to Underhill as the final was contested between two Football League clubs, Barnet and Stevenage, prompting safety concerns.

Pekka Juhani Pöyry (10 December 1939 – 5 September 2016) was a Finnish engineer and businessman. Pekka Juhani Pöyry was born in Helsinki, Finland on 10 December 1939. He attended the Helsinki University of Technology, where he graduated with a degree in engineering in 1963. Pöyry began his career at Nokia Corporation in 1963 as a project engineer. He soon became a senior engineer and served as the head of Nokia's product development department from 1986 to 1990. He then served as the president and CEO of Nokia Corporation from 1990 to 2003. During his time at Nokia, Pöyry led the company through rapid expansion and technological innovation, including the development of cell phones, pagers, and digital wireless communication systems. In 2003, Pöyry retired from his position at Nokia and founded Pöyry Consultants LLP, an engineering consulting firm. He remained active as a consultant until his death on 5 September 2016 at the age of 80. Pekka Juhani Pöyry was awarded the prestigious Engineering Award of the Finnish National Academy of Finland in 1998, the Tampere Medal in 2002, and the King's Medal of the Order of the Lion of Finland in 2011. He was also awarded an honorary doctorate from the University of Helsinki in 2013.

Syed Ali Raza, known by his takhallus (pen name) of Manzar Bhopali, is an Indian Urdu poet. He was born in Amravati. During his teenage years, Manzar started taking interest in poetry and attended his first mushaira at the age of 17. Over the course of 3 decades, he has penned more than a dozen books in Hindi and Urdu. Early life Manzar Bhopali was born on 29 December 1959 in Amrawati, Maharashtra, India. He is the third of four children. His grandfather, Mir Khairat Ali was a hakeem in Achalpur. His father, Mir Abbas Ali worked in the field of Urdu arts and literature and was also a poet. His mother, Tahira Nikhat was an educationist. His family moved from Amrawati to Bhopal when Manzar was very young. Growing up, Manzar was greatly influenced by the poetic culture at his home and the city of Bhopal. He started writing his own couplets when he was fourteen and said his first ghazal at the age of seventeen.

Tyshun "Deebo" Samuel Sr. (born January 15, 1996) is an American football wide receiver and running back for the San Francisco 49ers of the National Football League. He played college football at South Carolina and was drafted by the 49ers in the second round of the 2019 NFL Draft. Early years Samuel attended Chapman High School in Inman, South Carolina, where he played high school football and was coached by Mark Hodge. As a senior, he led his team to the semifinals of the AAA playoffs. During his career, Samuel had 166 catches for 2,751 yards and 36 touchdowns; he rushed 133 times for 898 yards and 13 touchdowns. He finished with a record 53 career touchdowns, 94 tackles and 12 interceptions. He won the High School Sports Report Class AAA Offensive Player of the Year, and played in the Shrine Bowl of the Carolinas. Samuel was rated as a three-star recruit by the 247 composite. He committed to the University of South Carolina to play college football.

Western Sydney Stadium, commercially known as CommBank Stadium, is an Australian football stadium in the western Sydney suburb of Penrith, located about 17 kilometres from the Sydney central business district. The stadium has a capacity of 45,000 people, making it the largest in New South Wales. It is currently the home ground of Western Sydney Wanderers FC. The stadium was built at a cost of A$105 million and was opened on 12 December 2012 by Prime Minister Julia Gillard. The Western Sydney Wanderers were originally founded as a club in 2005, and played their first season in the 2008–09 A-League season at Parramatta Stadium. After the club failed to secure a long-term home ground, they agreed to move to the new stadium in 2012. The stadium hosted its first international match on 10 November 2013, when Australia played Oman in a World Cup qualification match. It also hosted Australia's first ever women's international soccer match on 25 April 2015, when the Matildas played Canada.

Turów Power Station is a coal-fired power station located in the village of Turów, near the town of Piotrków Trybunalski, in southern Poland. It is operated by Energa Turów S.A. and began operating in 1984. It has a nominal capacity of 2,600 megawatts, but has been reduced to 1,800 megawatts due to its age and technical problems. The power station was built in the early 1970s as part of a large-scale industrial development programme in southern Poland. It was designed to provide electricity for the region, and initially had a nominal capacity of 2,600 megawatts. However, since its inception, the power station has had numerous technical problems, and as a result its actual capacity has been reduced to 1,800 megawatts. The power station is currently the oldest and smallest coal-fired power plant in Poland. The Turów Power Station is located in the village of Turów, near the town of Piotrków Trybunalski, in southern Poland. was a Japanese ukiyo-e printmaker who flourished from approximately 1681 to 1703. He is noted by art historian and ukiyo-e collector Richard Lane as an “indirect pupil” of Hishikawa Moronobu. Much of Sugimura's work was once attributed to fellow followers of Moronobu, or Moronobu himself. In the 1920s, however, unsigned prints were discovered to have hidden signatures of Sugimura's incorporated in the drawing of the clothing folds. It appears Sugimura preferred (unlike most ukiyo-e artists) to sign with his surname rather than his given name. There are few contemporary texts with information on Sugimura. The earliest mention of him can be found in a directory of Edo artists from 1689, the Edo Zukan Kompuku, where he is listed with his name and address as “Woodblock Artist, Sugimura Jihei Masataka, Tori-Aburacho.” Ryutei Tanahiko's Yoshabako, published in 1841, also credits Sugimura as illustrator of two books which are not known to be extant.

Elissa Panush Benedek (born September 28, 1936) is an American psychiatrist specializing in child and adolescent psychiatry and forensic psychiatry. She is an adjunct clinical professor of psychiatry at the University of Michigan Medical Center. She served as director of research and training at the Center for Forensic Psychiatry in Ann Arbor for 25 years and was president of the American Psychiatric Association from 1990 to 1991. She is regarded as an expert on child abuse and trauma, and has testified in high-profile court cases. She also focuses on ethics, psychiatric aspects of disasters and terrorism, and domestic violence. In addition to her own books, book chapters, and articles, she has collaborated with her husband, attorney Richard S. Benedek, on studies of divorce, child custody, and child abuse. Early life and education Elissa Panush was born in Detroit, Michigan on September 28, 1936 to Louis and Tillie Panush. Her father was a school principal and science teacher, and her mother taught in elementary school. She had three sisters. She graduated from Central High School in Detroit in 1954 and won a scholarship to the University of Michigan.

Cosimo de Torres also Cosmo de Torres and Cosma de Torres (1584–1642) was a Roman Catholic cardinal who served as Cardinal-Priest of Santa Maria in Trastevere (1641–1642), Cardinal-Priest of San Pancrazio (1623–1641), Archbishop of Monreale (1634–1642), Bishop of Perugia (1624–1634), Apostolic Nuncio to Poland (1621–1622), and Titular Archbishop of Hadrianopolis in Haemimonto (1621–1622). Biography Cosimo de Torres was born to a noble family in Rome, Italy in 1584, the son of Marchis Giovanni de Torres and Giulia Mattei, princess of Papareschi. His family was of Spanish descent having moved from Málaga, Spain in the early 16th century. His uncles Girolamo Mattei (named cardinal in 1586) and Ludovico de Torres, iuniore (named cardinal in 1606) were also cardinals. Torres obtained a doctorate in utroque iure in canon and civil law from the University of Perugia. After school, he was assigned to the college of protonotaries apostolic under the guidance of his uncle, Cardinal Mattei. In 1608, he served on the Referendary of the Tribunals of the Apostolic Signature of Justice and of Grace.

FK Zlatibor Čajetina is a professional football club from Čajetina, Bosnia and Herzegovina. The club was founded in 1977. It currently plays in the First League of Bosnia and Herzegovina. FK Zlatibor Čajetina played its first ever competitive match on 5 September 1977 against FK Sarajevo in the First League of Bosnia and Herzegovina. The club finished its first season in third position. In 1979, the club won its first ever title, the Bosnian Cup. The following season, 1980, the club finished as runners-up in the First League of Bosnia and Herzegovina. In 1981, FK Zlatibor Čajetina won its second Bosnian Cup title. In 1984, the club finished as runners-up in the First League of Bosnia and Herzegovina. In 1985, FK Zlatibor Čajetina won its third Bosnian Cup title. In 1986, FK Zlatibor Čajetina finished as runners-up in the First League of Bosnia and Herzegovina. In 1987, FK Zlatibor Čajetina merged with FK Borac Banja Luka to form FC Borac Banja Luka. The following season, 1988, FK Zlatibor Čajetina finished as runners-up in the newly formed First League of Bosnia and Herzegovina.

Fort McDermit (or Fort McDermitt) was an U.S. Army fort in Nevada. It was established on August 14, 1865, by Captain J. C. Doughty, of Company I of the 2nd Regiment California Volunteer Cavalry, on orders of Lt. Col. Charles McDermit, Commander, Military District Nevada, as the Quinn River Camp No. 33. It was located near Quinn River Station on the East Fork of the Quinn River.  Attacks on white settlements in the early part of the Snake War prompted the District of Utah to establish a detachment at the stagecoach station called Quinn (or Queen) River Station. The volunteer cavalry detachment was there in order to protect the stagecoach line that ran between Winnemucca, Nevada and Silver City, Idaho Territory. McDermit's death in an ambush on August 7, 1865, along the Quinn River near the station and the continuing unrest, provoked the establishment of a stronger force and the fort was named in his honor.

Sunil Shamlal Lahore (born 31 December 1965) is an Indian former first-class cricketer who played for Madhya Pradesh between the 1985/86 and 2000/01 seasons. After retirement, he worked as a cricket coach and selector. Career Lahore was a slow left-arm orthodox spinner who played for Madhya Pradesh cricket team for 16 seasons from 1985/86 and 2000/01. He appeared in 79 first-class matches in which he took 230 wickets and 19 List A matches in which he had 22 scalps to his name. Lahore was the leading wicket-taker of the 1986–87 Ranji Trophy, his second first-class season, with 32 wickets at an average of 17.62. During his career, he was part of the Madhya Pradesh spin trio (along with leg spinner Narendra Hirwani and off spinner Rajesh Chauhan), with Madhya Pradesh playing most of their home matches on slow tracks. He also played for Central Zone in Duleep Trophy and Deodhar Trophy between 1986/87 and 1991/92.

North Mahanoy Creek is a tributary of the Mahanoy River in Northampton County, Pennsylvania, in the United States. The creek is approximately long and flows through the borough of Northampton. The watershed of North Mahanoy Creek has an area of . The creek is mostly composed of small to medium-sized streams and tributaries with a few larger ones. It is mostly flat with a few gentle hills and has a wide floodplain. There are few trees in the watershed, but there are a few wetland areas and some agricultural land. The main stem of North Mahanoy Creek begins near the community of East Manchester Township and flows generally northward. It passes through the borough of Northampton and joins the Mahanoy River just south of the community of East Liverpool. The primary use of North Mahanoy Creek is for irrigation, but it also provides drinking water to East Liverpool and other nearby communities. There are a few small businesses along the creek, but the majority of it is rural. The creek has been designated as an impaired waterbody due to high levels of dissolved solids.

SM U-87 was one of the 329 submarines serving in the Imperial German Navy (Kaiserliche Marine) in World War I. U-87 was engaged in the naval warfare and took part in the First Battle of the Atlantic. She sank some 22 merchant vessels before 25 December 1917, when rammed U-87 in the Irish Sea and depth-charged her. Then the P-class sloop P.56 sank her. U-87s entire crew of 44 were lost. Design German Type U 87 submarines were preceded by the shorter Type U 81 submarines. The first of its type, U-87 had a displacement of when at the surface and while submerged. She had a total length of , a pressure hull length of , a beam of , a height of , and a draught of . The submarine was powered by two engines for use while surfaced, and two engines for use while submerged. She had two propeller shafts. She was capable of operating at depths of up to .

Kenneth Parker Johnson (August 24, 1934 – March 11, 2006) was an American academic administrator who served as the 14th president of the University of Texas at Austin from 1981 to 1998. Born in Fort Worth, Texas, Johnson received his bachelor's degree from the University of Texas at Austin in 1956 and his doctorate in educational administration from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign in 1960. He began his career as an assistant professor at the University of Texas at Austin, where he rose to become dean of the College of Arts and Sciences (1968–1981). He then served as president of the University of Texas System (1981–1998). During Johnson's tenure as president, UT Austin achieved unprecedented levels of national and international recognition. He was a major contributor to the university's $5 billion dollar expansion during his presidency, which made it one of the largest universities in the world. Johnson retired from his position in 1998 after more than 20 years as president. In retirement, he remained an active member of the university community and served on several boards and committees. He died in 2006 at age 74 after a long battle with cancer.

Cyril Edward Dunning (20 February 1888 – 26 November 1965) was an Australian historian. Born in Melbourne, Dunning completed his undergraduate studies at the University of Melbourne in 1909 and his doctoral studies at the University of Oxford in 1912. He taught history at the University of Melbourne from 1912 to 1963, except for a wartime service in the Australian Army during World War II. He was also a visiting professor at Columbia University and the University of Toronto. Dunning's major works are "Australia: A History from 1788 to 1928" (1928), "The History of Tasmania" (1938), and "Australian Nationality and Citizenship" (1951). He also wrote numerous articles on Australian history for various journals and magazines. Dunning was made a Companion of the Order of Australia in 1958. He died in 1965.

Jean-François Bautte (22 March 1772 in Geneva – 2 June 1857 in Paris) was a French painter and lithographer. Bautte was the son of a watchmaker, and began his artistic training at the Geneva Academy in 1789. From 1794 to 1800 he studied under François-Joseph Kinson at the École des Beaux-Arts in Paris, and then travelled in Italy. He returned to France in 1802, and exhibited for the first time at the Salon of 1802. In 1809, he moved to Italy again, this time staying until 1814. While there, he studied the paintings of Michelangelo and Raphael, as well as the Venetian masters. He also visited Florence, Naples and Rome. Upon his return to France in 1814, he exhibited at the Salon for the last time. In 1824 he became director of the French Academy in Rome, a position he held until his death. He also served as president of the French Artists' Society from 1840 to 1848. Bautte is best known for his paintings of historical subjects, particularly scenes from the Bible. His most famous painting is "The Martyrdom of Saint Stephen" (1828–1829), which was commissioned by Pope Leo XIII and is now located in the Louvre Museum in Paris. Other well-known works include "The Agony in The Garden" (1823), "The Last Supper" (1824–1825), "

Ann Mary Devroy ( ; 9 October 1948 – 23 October 1997) was an American political journalist. She was a White House correspondent for 15 years, for the Gannett Company, USA Today (1979–1985), and The Washington Post (1989–1997). She covered four presidents including Jimmy Carter, Ronald Reagan, George H. W. Bush and Bill Clinton, and 10 White House chiefs of staff. Life and career Ann Mary Devroy was born October 9, 1948, in Green Bay, Wisconsin. While she was a journalism student at the University of Wisconsin–Eau Claire, she interned at the Milwaukee Journal and worked as a reporter for the Eau Claire Leader-Telegram. After she received her bachelor's degree in 1970, Devroy began working for the Courier News, a New Jersey newspaper owned by the Gannett Company. In 1977, she moved to Gannett's Washington bureau. She covered Congress for two years before becoming White House correspondent for Gannett and its new national newspaper, USA Today.

Moreland Moses le Blanc (born 25 May 1958) is a Barbadian-born British businessman and the co-founder and chairman of the private equity firm Terra Firma Capital Partners. Moreland Moses le Blanc was born on 25 May 1958 in Barbados. He is the son of Maurice le Blanc and Edna Moses. After completing his education at the University of the West Indies, he worked in investment banking for Morgan Grenfell in London. In 1988, he co-founded Terra Firma Capital Partners with fellow banker Guy Hands. The firm has since raised over £3 billion in private equity investments. Le Blanc is a non-executive director at several companies, including Tesco, HSBC, and Prudential plc. He is also a senior advisor to the Sovereign Wealth Fund of Qatar. Le Blanc was knighted in the 2016 Queen's Birthday Honours for services to business.

Haji Omar Lim Yew Hock (; 15 February 1914 – 15 December 1992) was a Singaporean politician, educationist and philanthropist. He was the first Prime Minister of Singapore from 1959 to 1960. Born in 1914 to a Hakka family in what is now the Malaysian state of Perak, Lim attended the Anglo-Chinese School (ACS) in Kuala Lumpur, before completing his secondary education at Raffles College in Singapore. After leaving school, he worked as an accountant and then as a teacher before entering politics in 1945. Lim served as a member of the Legislative Council of Singapore from 1948 to 1951. He was also the president of the Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce from 1949 to 1951, and a member of the Central Executive Committee of the newly formed People's Action Party (PAP) from 1948 to 1951. In 1955, Lim entered federal politics when he was elected to the Legislative Assembly of Singapore as one of two representatives for the constituency of Tanjong Pagar. He served as Minister for Finance from 1955 to 1959 and Deputy Prime Minister from 1959 to 1960, when he became Prime Minister after Lee Kuan Yew's resignation. Lim's tenure as Prime Minister was brief; he resigned after just nine months in office due to disagreements with Lee over national policy. After leaving politics, Lim resumed his work as a teacher and businessman. He also served as Chairman of the National Development Board from 1969 to 1972 and President of Nanyang Technological University from 1974 to 1977. In 1984, he

RuPaul’s Drag Race, and Drag Race variants, is an American reality television series that began airing on Logo on February 15, 2009. The show, produced by World of Wonder Productions, features drag queens from various cities competing for the title of America’s Next Drag Superstar. RuPaul has been the show’s executive producer and judge since its inception. Drag Race has received widespread critical acclaim, with Metacritic giving the first five seasons a weighted average score of 85 out of 100. The show has been nominated for numerous awards, including a Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Reality Program in 2014, five Golden Globe Awards (including Best Television Series – Musical or Comedy in 2018 and 2019), and a Peabody Award. The Drag Race franchise includes books, an animated television series produced by World of Wonder Productions and Fuzzy Duck Entertainment, a web series created by World of Wonder Productions and FanFiction.net which both ended in 2018, and apparel and accessories manufactured by World of Wonder Brands.

Sunny Skylar (October 11, 1913 – February 15, 1951) was an American singer, actress and model who achieved pop success in the 1940s. Her trademark was her powerful voice, which she used to sing ballads and country music. Sunny Skylar was born in 1913 in Lubbock, Texas. She was the daughter of a Baptist minister and began her singing career at a young age, performing with her father and siblings in church. After moving to Los Angeles in 1935, she began to attract attention from Hollywood producers. Her first recording, for Decca Records, was a ballad called "I'll Never Smile Again". Her first major hit came in 1941 with the song "Can't Help Falling in Love", which reached number one on the US charts. Other successful songs from this period include "Blue Moon of Kentucky" and "That's All Right (Mama)". In 1944, Sunny Skylar recorded the song "I Believe in You" with Elvis Presley; it became one of Presley's most famous recordings. Sunny Skylar's career declined in the late 1940s, due in part to her addiction to alcohol and other drugs. She died of a drug overdose in 1951 at the age of 36.

Talja V. Blokland (born 1971) is a Norwegian artist. She is best known for her installations and performances that address the invisible forces that shape our lives. Blokland was born in 1971 in Oslo, Norway. She studied at the Norwegian National Academy of Fine Arts from 1992 to 1996, where she was a student of Odd Nerdrum and Per-Ole Vigeland. In 1999, she received a Fulbright Scholarship to study at the Slade School of Fine Art in London. Blokland has exhibited her work throughout Europe and North America, including the Whitney Museum of American Art in New York City (2001), the Museum of Contemporary Art in Barcelona (2003), the Kunstmuseum Basel in Switzerland (2004), the Centre Pompidou in Paris (2005), and the Fondation Beyeler in Basel (2006). Her works are in the collections of institutions such as the Tate Gallery and MoMA PS1 in New York City, The National Gallery of Norway, The Oslo National Gallery, The Guggenheim Museum Bilbao, and The British Museum. Blokland's work addresses the invisible forces that shape our lives: politics, economics, social norms, and cultural values. She often uses materials that are commonly seen as banal or insignificant, such as recycled materials or everyday objects, to explore how we experience and react to the world around us. Her works often humorously juxtapose these mundane objects with more serious themes, such as the way that cultural

Acacia rigida is a shrub belonging to the genus Acacia and the subgenus Phyllodineae that is native to parts of western Australia. Description The compact or sprawling shrub typically grows to a height of and a width of up to . It has reddish to orange coloured branches with branchlets that are densely covered in fine hairs and setaceous stipules that are in length. 2.5–3.5 mm long. The rigid green phyllodes have inequilaterally lanceolate to narrowly lanceolate shape that is sometimes linear. The pungent glabrous phyllodes are in length and wide and have five main nerves and a prominent mid-rib. It blooms and produces simple inflorescences that occur singly in the axils. The spherical flower-heads contain 8 to 12 loosely pack golden flowers. The shallowly curved, red-brown seed pods that form after flowering are to in length and have a diameter of . The pods contain oblong shaped seeds that around in length.

John Giles Adams (December 2, 1792 – March 21, 1868) was an American jurist and politician from the U.S. state of Michigan. Adams was born in Baltimore, Maryland, the son of John Adams and Sarah Giles, who were both from Virginia. He completed preparatory studies and graduated from the University of Virginia in 1816. He then studied law with George Wythe and was admitted to the bar in 1819. Adams began his practice in Hillsboro, Virginia, but later moved to Detroit, Michigan, where he became a prominent lawyer and judge. He served as district attorney for Wayne County from 1834 to 1840 and as associate justice of the Michigan Supreme Court from 1840 to 1846. He was elected as a Democrat to the United States Senate in 1848, serving until his death in Washington, D.C., in 1868. Adams was interred in Lake View Cemetery in Detroit.

Lillsjön is a small lake in Ulvsunda Municipality, Västra Götaland County, Sweden. The lake is located in the eastern part of the municipality, between the villages of Säter and Ulvsunda. Lillsjön connects to Lake Vänern by a narrow channel. The name Lillsjön is of unknown origin. It may be derived from the Swedish word "lilla" meaning "little" and "jön" meaning "lake", or it may be a corruption of the word "Lilla Jön" which means "Little John's Lake". Lillsjön has a surface area of . The lake is long and wide. The deepest point is at the northern end of the lake, while the shallowest point is at the southern end. The lake has a total volume of and a water temperature of . Lillsjön is an important habitat for many species of birds, including herons, ducks, geese, swans and cormorants. The lake also supports a large population of fish, including pike, perch and carp. In recent years, there has been a decline in the number of fish in Lillsjön due to pollution from agricultural runoff.

Sean Aaberg (born June 7, 1976) is an American professional wrestler, better known by his ring name Samoa Joe. He is currently working for WWE, where he is a part-time performer, on the Raw brand. Joe has also worked for Total Nonstop Action Wrestling (TNA), where he was the first ever World Heavyweight Champion. Born in Rapid City, South Dakota, Joe began wrestling at the age of 15. After training in Minnesota and California, Joe made his professional wrestling debut in 1998. He joined World Wrestling Entertainment (WWE) in 2002 and was assigned to their developmental territory Florida Championship Wrestling (FCW). Joe made his Raw debut on November 25, 2002, defeating Dean Malenko. In 2004, Joe won the FCW Heavyweight Championship and defended it against future world champion Batista. In 2005, Joe was drafted to the SmackDown brand and formed a tag team with Rick Martel. The team won the 2006 Tag Team Championship but lost it the following year to The Basham Brothers. In 2007, Joe joined TNA and won their World Heavyweight Championship in his first match with the company. He held the title for over two years before losing it to Jeff Hardy at Slammiversary XVI. Joe returned to WWE in early 2016 and defeated John Cena at WrestleMania 32 to win his second world championship.

Alexandra Culvin (born 16 November 1983) is an Australian actress and singer. She is known for her roles as Mia Gallagher in the ABC drama series "Lost" and as Avery Jessup in the ABC drama series "Revenge". Culvin was born in Melbourne, Australia. She attended Wesley College, Melbourne before studying at the Sydney Theatre Company, where she graduated with a Bachelor of Arts in 2003. In 2007, Culvin appeared as Mia Gallagher on the ABC drama series "Lost". Her portrayal of Mia won her several accolades, including a nomination for an Australian Film Institute Award for Best Supporting Actress. In 2009, Culvin joined the cast of the ABC drama series "Revenge", playing Avery Jessup. The show was cancelled after three seasons. In 2012, Culvin starred in the independent feature film "The Sapphires". The following year, she had a supporting role in the feature film "Safe House". In 2016, Culvin starred as Amelia Stubbs in the ABC drama series "Secrets & Lies". The show has been cancelled after two seasons. Culvin has also appeared in several stage productions. USS Nicholson (DD-982), a Spruance-class destroyer, was the fourth ship of the United States Navy to be named for a family which was prominent in early American naval history, including James Nicholson, the senior Continental Navy Captain, and Samuel Nicholson, the first captain of USS Constitution. History Nicholson was laid down on 20 February 1976 by the Ingalls Shipbuilding, in Pascagoula, Miss.; launched on 11 November 1977; and commissioned on 12 May 1979. She first deployed on 18 November 1980. Nicholson deployed to the Persian Gulf in 1983 and returned to Charleston SC via the Suez Canal with a refueling stop in Djibouti. The crew enjoyed a port visit to Barcelona, Spain on the way back to home port. The ship encountered heavy seas on the voyage west across the Atlantic and experienced a casualty to the sonar dome. The dome was subsequently repaired in conjunction with a scheduled maintenance period at the Brooklyn Navy Shipyard between May 1984 and Feb 1985. Following the maintenance period the ship returned to Charleston, SC and began work ups for the next deployment including, Combat Systems Ship Qualification Trials, an Anti-Submarine warfare exercise in the Caribbean and Refresher Training in Guantanamo Bay Cuba. Nicholson was deployed for six months, in February 1990, with USS Dahlgren, as part of the Mid-East Force in the Persian Gulf. The deployment was fairly routine except for two incidents. The first was a pair of armed Iranian F-4s that overflew the ship in the Straits of Hormuz, and the second was that Nicholson and Dahlgren left the Persian Gulf for home just a week before Iraq invaded Kuwait.

Mirador is a historic home located near Greenwood, Albemarle County, Virginia. It was built in 1842 for James M. Bowen (1793–1880), and is a two-story, brick structure on a raised basement in the Federal style. It has a deck-on-hip roof capped by a Chinese Chippendale railing. The front facade features a portico with paired Tuscan order columns. The house was renovated in the 1920s by noted New York architect William Adams Delano (1874–1960), who transformed the house into a Georgian Revival mansion. Mirador is surrounded by extensive landscaped grounds that include a sunken lawn and a walk bordered by serpentine brick walls. Near the main house is an antebellum period brick kitchen-like dependency and an antebellum period frame smokehouse, an antebellum two-story brick and frame dwelling known as the Corner House, and a brick Colonial Revival stable dating to about 1910. Beyond the house are the farm buildings built in the 1920s including a Colonial Revival dairy barn complex arranged around a cobblestone courtyard, a brick farm manager's house, a concrete block tenant house, two lakes, and the Sam Black Tavern, a log building built ca.1769 and moved to the property from the neighboring Seven Oaks Farm.

Jhaverchand or Zaverchand Kalidas Meghani was an Indian poet and writer who was born in 1878 in the town of Jhalawar in Rajasthan. He is considered one of the most important poets of Rajasthani literature. He is also known for his short stories, which are often humorous and have a humanistic touch. Jhaverchand Meghani was born on 15th February 1878 in the town of Jhalawar in Rajasthan. He was the son of a small-time government official named Kalidas Meghani. Jhaverchand grew up in a traditional Rajasthani family, where he learned to love poetry and storytelling from his father. He also developed an interest in classical Indian music and literature. Jhaverchand began his literary career in 1902, when he published his first poem, entitled 'Kahan'. He went on to publish several collections of poetry over the next few years, including 'Shivaji' (1903), 'Bharat' (1905), and 'Sati' (1906). His poetry often reflects his love for nature and the rural lifestyle of Rajasthan. In 1908, Jhaverchand married Jamuna Devi, a woman from a wealthy family. The couple had two children together: Jyoti and Abhimanyu. Jhaverchand continued to publish poetry throughout the early 1900s, but it wasn't until 1924 that he achieved international recognition

short for is a Japanese light novel series written by Tsukasa Fushimi, with illustrations provided by Hiro Kanzaki. The story depicts high school student Kyosuke Kosaka who discovers that his standoffish younger sister Kirino is actually an otaku with an extensive collection of moe anime and younger sister-themed eroge she has been collecting in secret. Kyosuke quickly becomes Kirino's confidant for her secret hobby. ASCII Media Works has published 17 volumes in the series under its Dengeki Bunko imprint from August 2008 to September 2021. The episode aired on AMC in the United States on July 15, 2008. Breaking Bad returns with "Lifetime Supply" – an intense and suspenseful episode that features one of the show's most shocking moments. Aided by a shrewd and clever Heisenberg, Jesse (Aaron Paul) concocts a deadly new meth recipe. In order to test his latest concoction, he cooks up a batch for his friends. But when Jesse unwittingly leaves the lab unattended, the powerful meth fumes quickly transform his friends into raging addicts. As their lives spiral out of control, they turn to Jesse for help – but he may be too far gone himself. Forced to make a difficult choice, will Jesse finally give in to his addiction and let his friends die? Indigenous rights are those rights that exist in relation to Indigenous peoples and their communities, whether they are recognized or not by national or international law. They often include the right to self-determination, land rights, cultural rights, and the right to traditional foods, medicines and practices. The term "indigenous rights" was first used in the late 1970s by the United Nations Working Group on Indigenous Populations in its report "Indigenous Peoples: The UN Perspective." In 1993, the International Labour Organization (ILO) adopted a Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples which reaffirmed indigenous people's rights to self-determination, land rights, cultural rights and economic autonomy. The notion of indigenous rights has been criticized for being paternalistic and for not taking into account the diversity of indigenous communities. Others argue that indigenous rights are an essential part of any just and sustainable development process.

Ann Tutwiler (born 23 January 1958) is a Senior Fellow with Meridian Institute and serves as a Senior Advisor to the Just Rural Transition. She also chairs the Expert Review Committee for the Food and Agriculture Benchmark for the World Benchmarking Alliance. Previously, she was the Director General of Bioversity International from July 2013 to February 2019 and the first woman Deputy Director-General of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) from January 2011 to November 2012. In 2022, she has been awarded the John Knox Batten Teaching Fellowship in Public Policy at Davidson College in North Carolina. Education Margaret Ann Tutwiler, sometimes referred to a M. Ann Tutwiler or, more simply, Ann Tutwiler, was born in Columbia, South Carolina in the United States. She obtained a bachelor's degree from the Presbyterian Davidson College in North Carolina and a master's degree from the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University. She also has executive education certificates in agribusiness from Purdue University and INSEAD. Her studies included a period in Spain and she also worked as a teacher in a remote part of Western Kenya.

Beili Liu (; born 1974) is a Chinese-born US-based visual artist who makes large-scale, process-driven installations that address themes of migration, cultural memory, materiality and labor. Through unconventional use of commonplace materials such as thread, needle, scissors, fire, and water, Liu extrapolates complex cultural narratives through a hybrid work form that merges site-responsive installation, sculpture, public art, and performance. Liu lives and works in Austin, Texas. Liu is the Leslie Waggener Professor in the Fine Arts and is a University of Texas System Regents' Outstanding Teaching Professor at the University of Texas at Austin. Early life Beili Liu was born in a farming village in the Northeast province of Jilin, China to parents who were among the 16 million sent-down youth during China's Cultural Revolution. After ten years of exile and re-education in the countryside, her parents relocated to the Northeast Chinese industrial city of Shenyang. In 1989, one month before the Tiananmen Square Protests, her family migrated to the southern coastal city of Shenzhen, a major manufacturing center and economic hub bordering Hong Kong and one of four "Special Economic Zones" designated at the early stage of Chinese economic reform.

John of Westphalia, also known as John of Saxony, was a German canon lawyer and ecclesiastical statesman. He is considered the most important figure in the development of modern canon law. Westphalia was born in Osnabrück in Westphalia, the son of the Duke Henry the Lion and his wife Matilda of Boulogne. He studied civil and canon law at the University of Cologne, where he became close friends with Albertus Magnus and Gerardus Vossius. He also travelled to France, Italy, Spain and England, where he was impressed by the English system of government. Westphalia entered the church as a monk at Osnabrück in 1398 and was ordained a priest in 1400. He served as a Canonical Jurist at Cologne from 1410 to 1415, then moved to Mainz as superintendent of ecclesiastical affairs. In 1417 he was elected Archbishop of Cologne and served until his death in 1448. Westphalia is most famous for his work on church law, which he wrote in three major treatises: the Constitutio Criminalis Ecclesiae (1438), the Decretals (1439–1448), and the Institutiones Juris Canonici (1450). Giandomenico Mesto (; born 25 May 1967) is an Italian football manager and former player who played as a midfielder. Mesto started his playing career in 1985 with hometown club Parma. He then moved to Milan in 1990, where he would spend the next six seasons, winning the Serie A title in 1993 and the Coppa Italia in 1995. He then joined Marseille in 1998, where he would spend two seasons before moving to Lazio in 2000. Mesto won two titles with Lazio, before retiring from professional football at the end of the 2002–03 season. Mesto began his managerial career with Parma in 2004, and spent two seasons with the club before being appointed manager of Atalanta on 22 November 2006. In December 2009, he was appointed manager of Cesena. Mesto was fired from Cesena on 18 May 2010 after a poor run of results. He was then appointed manager of Siena on 29 July 2010, but was sacked on 24 October after a poor start to the season. Mesto returned to coaching at Parma on 7 February 2014, replacing Marco Giampaolo as caretaker manager. Mesto has also been a pundit for Sky Italia since 2006. In racquet sports and golf, backspin (also known as backspin delivery) is a type of spin used with a racquetball, handball, and other ball-and-racquet sports. Backspin results when the ball is hit with the leading side of the racquet face (the side closest to the player's body) turned slightly towards the ground. This causes the ball to rotate around its vertical axis, giving it a rotational motion that is in the opposite direction of its forward motion. Backspin has several effects on a ball's trajectory. First, it causes the ball to move backwards more quickly than if it was hit with no spin. This increased backward speed makes it difficult for an opponent to hit the ball past or near the player. Second, backspin causes the ball to curve more than other types of spin, which makes it harder for an opponent to predict where it will go. Finally, backspin gives the ball more height when hit, which can make it easier to reach high shots or off-center balls.

The American Legion Auxiliary (ALA) is a separate entity from the American Legion that share the same values. Composed of spouses, mothers, daughters, granddaughters, and sisters of American war veterans. Founded in 1919, the ALA is dedicated to serving veterans, military, and their families. History After the end of World War I in 1918, 20 officers who had served in the American Expeditionary Forces were asked to suggest ideas for improving troop morale. One officer, U.S. Army Lieutenant Colonel Theodore Roosevelt Jr., proposed an organization of veterans, the American Legion. After its formation in 1919, a number of existing women's organizations wanted to become the official affiliate of the Legion. The committee decided to create a new organization made up of the women most closely associated with the men of the Legion. This Auxiliary would perform those phases of Legion activities that were more suitably performed by women. In less than one year, 1,342 local units in 45 states of the Women’s Auxiliary to the American Legion had been organized.

Yashar Sharifi Niknafs is an American scientist, coder, and businessman. He currently serves as the Chief Executive Officer of Lynx Dx, Inc., one of the largest providers of COVID-19 PCR testing in the state of Michigan. Early life and education Niknafs attended Stow-Munroe Falls High School in Akron, Ohio, where he was involved in theater and Science Olympiad. He completed his undergraduate studies at Case Western Reserve University, earning a Bachelor's of Science in Biochemistry before moving to Ann Arbor, Michigan, where he received his PhD from the Cell and Molecular Biology Program at the University of Michigan under the mentorship of Arul Chinnaiyan. His Ph.D. work focused mostly on bioinformatic analyses of next generation sequencing data for the purposes of better understanding the genome, delineating molecular mechanisms driving cancer, and discovering novel gene targets as biomarker candidates. He remained at the institution to complete a postdoctoral fellowship in cancer genomics and bioinformatics.

McClellan Park is a census-designated place in Sacramento County, California. McClellan Park sits at an elevation of . The 2010 United States census reported McClellan Park's population was 743. It is the site of the former McClellan Air Force Base, closed by the federal government in 2003. McClellan Air Force Base, (currently McClellan Park) was named in honor of test pilot, Hezekiah McClellan. According to the United States Census Bureau, the CDP covers an area of 4.1 square miles (10.5 km2), all of it land. It's closest neighbor is North Highlands, CA. Demographics The 2010 United States Census reported that McClellan Park had a population of 743. The population density was 183.4 people per square mile (70.8/km2). The racial makeup of McClellan Park was 467 (62.9%) White, 99 (13.3%) African American, 13 (1.7%) Native American, 27 (3.6%) Asian, 21 (2.8%) Pacific Islander, 31 (4.2%) from other races, and 85 (11.4%) from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 110 persons (14.8%).

Bernt Assar Rönnlund (3 September 1935 – 5 January 2011)  was a Swedish cross-country skier. Rönnlund's biggest success was at the 1962 FIS Nordic World Ski Championships in Zakopane where he won two gold medals (15 km and 4 × 10 km) and a silver (50 km). As a result, he earned the Svenska Dagbladet Gold Medal that year for his championship successes. Rönnlund was the anchorman of the Swedish 4 × 10 km relay team at the 1964 Winter Olympics in Innsbruck, bringing the team from fourth place to victory. Rönnlund also won the Vasaloppet in 1967 and the 50 km event at the Holmenkollen ski festival twice (1962 and 1968). For his cross-country skiing successes, Rönnlund was awarded the Holmenkollen Medal in 1968 (shared with King Olav V, Gjermund Eggen and Bjørn Wirkola). After retiring from active competition he was hired in 1972 by The Swedish Radio Corporation as a cross-country skiing commentator. He gained nationwide popularity working in a duo with Åke Strömmer. Rönnlund retired from broadcasting after the 2003 FIS Nordic World Ski Championships.

Monitor proofing or soft-proofing is a step in the prepress printing process. It uses specialized computer software and hardware to check the accuracy of text and images used for printed products. Monitor proofing differs from conventional forms of “hard-copy” or ink-on-paper color proofing in its use of a calibrated display(s) as the output device. Monitor proofing systems rely on calibration, profiling and color management to produce an accurate representation of how images will look when printed. While a “soft-proof” function has existed in desktop publishing applications for some time, commercial monitor proofing extends this capability to multiple users and multiple locations by specifying the hardware to be used, and by enforcing one set of calibration procedures and color management policies for all users of the system. This ensures that all viewers are calibrated to a known set of conditions, and given hardware of equal capabilities will therefore be viewing the same color on screen.

In the post-Soviet era, Kyrgyzstan's health system has undergone rapid development. Health sector reforms have been implemented in an effort to improve the quality of health care and create a more efficient and equitable system. The health system is financed by a combination of public and private sources. The Kyrgyz Republic is a member of the World Health Organization (WHO) and the Eastern European Region of the European Union (EU). The Kyrgyz Republic has a population of about 5 million people, and the average life expectancy at birth is 69 years. The majority of the population lives in rural areas, and there is a lack of infrastructure in many areas, including hospitals, clinics, and pharmacies. The country has a limited number of medical professionals, and many people do not have access to reliable health care. In recent years, the government has been investing in new hospitals and medical facilities. However, more needs to be done to improve the country's health system. The Kyrgyz Republic has a variety of health problems, including high rates of tuberculosis, hepatitis C, malaria, and HIV/AIDS. There are also a number of environmental hazards that can impact health, such as air pollution from factories and coal mines, dust storms from the Gobi desert, and water shortages due to overabundance of irrigation projects. In addition, diseases that are common in Central Asia such as tuberculosis and hepatitis C are more common in Kyrgyzstan because of its geographic location.

Víctor Gay Zaragoza (born 19 June 1982 in Barcelona, Spain) is a writer, storyteller, trainer and consultant on storytelling. He is author of the essays "Filosofía Rebelde" (Rebel Philosophy), "50 libros que cambiarán tu vida" (50 books that will change your life) and the historical novel "El defensor" (The defender). Career as a writer  At 26, he published his first book Filosofía Rebelde (Editorial Kairos), which is an essay on the common essences of religions and philosophies from around the world. At 28, he published his second book 50 libros que cambiarán tu vida (Alienta), a literary criticism book. His third book El Defensor (Columna y Suma de Letras) is a historical novel set in 1940 (Nationalist Spain era) during the days of the trial and execution of Catalan president, Lluís Companys. The protagonist is Ramon de Colubí, Companys military defense lawyer. Both individuals are relatives of the author.

The Sinai Peninsula, or simply Sinai (now usually ) , is a peninsula in Egypt, and the only part of the country located in Asia. It is between the Mediterranean Sea to the north and the Red Sea to the south, and is a land bridge between Asia and Africa. Sinai has a land area of about (6 percent of Egypt's total area) and a population of approximately 600,000 people. Administratively, the vast majority of the area of the Sinai Peninsula is divided into two governorates: the South Sinai Governorate and the North Sinai Governorate. Three other governorates span the Suez Canal, crossing into African Egypt: Suez Governorate on the southern end of the Suez Canal, Ismailia Governorate in the center, and Port Said Governorate in the north. In the classical era the region was known as Arabia Petraea. The peninsula acquired the name Sinai in modern times due to the assumption that a mountain near Saint Catherine's Monastery is the Biblical Mount Sinai. Mount Sinai is one of the most religiously significant places in the Abrahamic faiths.

Norman Myron Dinerstein (September 18, 1937 – March 1, 2016) was an American lawyer and philanthropist. Dinerstein was born in New York City to a Jewish family. He received his B.A. from the University of Michigan and his J.D. from Yale Law School, where he was editor-in-chief of the Yale Law Journal. After law school, Dinerstein clerked for Judge Learned Hand of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. He then practiced law at the law firm of Latham & Watkins, where he was a partner from 1970 to 1984. Dinerstein served as vice chairman and managing director of Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc., from 1984 to 1986. He also served on the board of directors of Coca-Cola Co., American Express Co., Walt Disney Company, and CBS Corporation. Dinerstein was a trustee of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Guggenheim Museum, and the Museum of Modern Art. He also served on the boards of directors of Princeton University, Yale University, and Barnard College. Dinerstein was awarded an honorary degree from Yale University in 1984, an honorary doctorate from Brandeis University in 2001, and an honorary doctorate from Columbia University in 2004. In 2006, he received the Israel Prize for lifetime achievement in law. Dinerstein died in Manhattan at the age of 79

Iris Sylvia Evans (born December 31, 1954) is an American actress, singer, and author. Evans began her career in the 1970s as a child actress, appearing on Broadway and in television shows. She achieved international fame for her portrayal of Buffy Summers in the popular 1990s television series Buffy the Vampire Slayer, for which she received four Emmy Awards. Evans has since appeared in a number of films and television projects, most notably the 2008 film Avatar. Iris Evans was born on December 31, 1954, in Evanston, Illinois. She is the daughter of Sylvia (née Kaczmarek), an actress and teacher, and Lawrence Evans, a jazz musician and advertising executive. Her parents divorced when she was young and she was raised by her mother in New York City. Evans has two sisters: one older, actress Julie Harris, and one younger, artist Chantal Evans. Evans began her acting career at the age of two, appearing in several Broadway shows and TV shows during the 1960s and 1970s. Her most notable appearance during this time was as Buffy Summers on the popular 1990s TV series Buffy the Vampire Slayer. For which she won four Emmy Awards (including Outstanding Lead Actress in a Drama Series). Since Buffy the Vampire Slayer ended in 2003, Evans has appeared in a number of films and television projects. Most notably playing Neytiri in James Cameron's critically acclaimed blockbuster film Avatar (2008).

Henry Robert Percival (April 30, 1854 - September 22, 1903) was a prominent American Episcopal priest and author. After studies at the University of Pennsylvania and the General Theological Seminary in New York, he was made a deacon on May 27, 1877, and ordained to the priesthood on June 10, 1878. Percival served briefly after ordination at Grace Church, Merchantville, New Jersey, and as curate from 1878 to 1880 at a chapel of Christ Church, Philadelphia. He was elected rector of the Church of the Evangelists, Philadelphia, in 1880, and pursued a plan of Anglo-Catholic enrichment of its services; he oversaw the building of a new church beginning in 1885 and the planting of S. Elisabeth's Church as a nearby mission under the care of the Congregation of the Companions of the Holy Saviour and William Ignatius Loyola McGarvey. (Since 1922, the Evangelists church building has housed the Fleisher Art Memorial.) Percival retired as rector in 1897, citing ill health, and was succeeded by the Reverend Charles W. Robinson. He was the author of an appendix on "The Theological Value of Incense" in The Case for Incense, submitted to His Grace the Archbishop of Canterbury on May 8, 1899.

Sir William Russell Flint (4 April 1892 – 16 July 1977) was an Australian-born British economist and statistician. He was a professor at the London School of Economics from 1938 until his retirement in 1965. Flint is credited with developing the concept of economic surplus and its use in economic analysis. Flint was born in Melbourne, Australia, to Scottish parents. He attended Scotch College, Melbourne, and then studied at the University of Melbourne, graduating with a Bachelor of Arts in 1913. He then undertook postgraduate studies at the London School of Economics, where he received his doctorate in 1921. Flint began his career as a research economist at the National Physical Laboratory in London. He became a professor at the London School of Economics in 1938. He retired from his professorship in 1965. Throughout his career, Flint authored or co-authored several books and articles on economics and statistics.
