The band's original members were singer-songwriter-guitarist Rachel Flotard and drummer Ben Hooker, both formerly of Hafacat; Allan Ross (guitar; left in November 2001), and Kim Warnick, formerly of the Fastbacks. Warnick retired at the end of 2004, but Muffs co-founder Ronnie Barnett signed on to play the bass during the band's 2005 tour. Early in 2006, Bill Coury, formerly of Once For Kicks & Sourmash, joined the band as bassist, and later Tom Cummings, formerly of Once For Kicks and Sourmash, joined the band as a second guitarist. Late in 2006, Bill Coury left the band and by spring 2007, Barrett Jones, producer (Foo Fighters, The presidents of the United States of America), joined Visqueen as bassist.

Ulrich "Ueli" Maurer (; born 1 December 1954) is a Swiss mountaineer, author and television presenter. He is best known for his solo climbing of Mount Everest in 1982, the first Swiss to summit the mountain. Maurer was born in Zürich, into a family of mountaineers. He became interested in mountaineering at an early age and started his climbing career in the 1970s. In 1978, he became the first Swiss to reach the summit of Mount Eiger. He also made several successful climbs of other high-altitude mountains, including Mount Blanc, Mount McKinley and Mount Elbrus. In 1982, he became the first person to summit Mount Everest without using supplemental oxygen. In 1984, he made the first solo crossing of the Alps by foot. Since 1985, Maurer has been a regular presenter of the Swiss TV show "Alpin", which has become one of the country's most popular TV shows. He has also written several books about his climbing experiences. Maurer is married and has two children.

John Marshall Hagans (August 13, 1838June 17, 1907) was an American jurist who served as an Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court from 1881 to 1907. Hagans was born in Warren County, Ohio, to a family of Scots-Irish Presbyterians. After studying at Kenyon College and the University of Michigan, he practiced law in Toledo. In 1871, Hagans was elected to the Ohio State Senate, where he served two terms. In 1876, he was nominated by President Ulysses S. Grant to a seat on the United States District Court for the Northern District of Ohio, which he held until his appointment to the Supreme Court. Hagans is best known for his influential opinions in constitutional law, particularly in regards to the Fourteenth Amendment and labor relations. He also wrote extensively on criminal law and procedure. Hagans died in Washington, D.C., a year before his successor on the Supreme Court, William Howard Taft.

Moth Wranglers was a musical collaboration formed in 1998 by Chris Xefos (Drop Quarters, ex-King Missile), and LD Beghtol (Flare, The Magnetic Fields). The duo took their name from the credits for Jonathan Demme's 1991 thriller Silence of the Lambs. In their decade-long involvement, the pair created two albums and a number of other one-off recordings and live performances, mostly working separately in different studios. Guest musicians figure prominently on moth wranglers' recordings (Never Mind the Context (Magnetic, 2001), Never Better (Magnetic, 2004), and Never Again (digital release, 2010), including Victor Krummenacher and Jonathan Segel of Camper Van Beethoven), Ken Stringfellow of The Posies, Stephin Merritt of The Magnetic Fields, Doug Hilsinger and other noted rock/pop musicians of an experimental bent as well as multi-instrumentalist/mentalist/author Daniel Handler. The moth wranglers' song “Dear Santa (Don’t Come to My House)” — featuring Kendall Jane Meade — was used in the 2008 Irish feature film “How About You”, directed by Anthony Byrne and starring Vanessa Redgrave, Joss Akland and Hayley Atwell. moth wranglers disbanded in 2010. Double Shot! is the first blues album by American blues guitarist and singer Joe Bonamassa. Released on February 24, 2007, it was recorded at the Sweet Tea Studio in Clifton, New Jersey with producer Kevin Shirley. The album debuted at number one on the U.S. Blues Albums chart and has been certified platinum by the RIAA. "Double Shot!" received mixed reviews from music critics. At Metacritic, which assigns a normalized rating out of 100 to reviews from mainstream critics, the album has an average score of 57, based on 12 reviews. Reviewing for "The Observer", John Mulvey praised Bonamassa's "guitar playing of astounding virtuosity" but found fault with "the cloying sentimentality" of some of the songs. In a review for AllMusic, critic Thom Jurek found Bonamassa's voice "powerful and soulful" but felt that his guitar playing was not as impressive as on his previous albums. Bonamassa has said that he wrote most of the songs on "Double Shot!" in a short period of time after returning from a tour in support of his 2004 album "Blood on the Tracks". Michael Goldfield (May 2, 1943) is an American political scientist, author, labor activist, and former student activist. He is a professor of industrial relations and human resources in the department of political science at Wayne State University in Detroit, Michigan. Early life and activism: Sojourner Truth Organization 1968-1972 Prior to his academic career, Goldfield was an activist and organizer, first with the Students for a Democratic Society and later with the Sojourner Truth Organization, where he was a founding member and a part of the organization's Westside branch. Goldfield was employed at the International Harvester plant in Melrose Park, IL where he sought to engage in workplace organizing as a part of the Sojourner Truth Organization's political work. At the International Harvester plant, Goldfield was involved in establishing a dissident caucus within the plant's union chapter organized by the United Auto Workers. Despite resolutions adopted by the Sojourner Truth Organization calling on membership to engage in more mass organizing, which entailed a further openness to engaging with industrial unions, the Organization as a whole remained critical to unions and a significant tendency within the Organization remained skeptical of membership involving themselves in trade union politics., As one of the Organization's most experienced workplace organizers, and a member whose rank-and-file coworkers encouraged him to run as a shop steward at the Harvester plant, Goldfield expressed enthusiasm in greater union involvement, a decision for which certain membership within the Organization criticized him.

Macuro, a town in Venezuela, located a few kilometers west of the Puerto Ordaz Municipality. It is the capital of the Libertador Municipality. Originally founded by Spaniards as a mining center in the early 18th century, Macuro prospered as a trade center due to its strategic location on the Caroni River. The town was chartered as a municipality in 1860. Today, Macuro is a small town with a population of around 5,000, made up of mainly Venezuelans and Colombians. The town is known for its agricultural production, including coffee, cocoa, and tobacco. There are also several small businesses that cater to the tourists who visit the area each year. The Libertador Municipality is home to a number of attractions, including the Caroni River and the Cerro de la Cruz mountain range. The town also has a number of churches and museums.

Bennett, Coleman and Company Limited, (abbreviated as B.C.C.L. and d/b/a The Times Group), is an Indian media conglomerate headquartered in Mumbai, Maharashtra. The company remains a family-owned business with Sahu Jain family owning a majority stake in The Times Group. History On 3 November 1838, the Bombay Times and Journal of Commerce was first published, a predecessor of what would become The Times of India. While starting as a biweekly paper, it was converted to a daily in 1850. In 1859 the paper was merged with two other papers into the Bombay Times and Standard under editor Robert Knight. Two years later, in 1861, the paper got a more national scope with the title The Times of India. Subsequently the paper saw its ownership change several times until 1892 when an English journalist named Thomas Jewell Bennett along with Frank Morris Coleman (who later drowned in the 1915 sinking of the SS Persia) acquired the newspaper through their new joint stock company, Bennett, Coleman & Co. Ltd. (BCCL). At the time, some 800 people were employed by the paper.

Joseph Patrick Michael Leydon (born August 22, 1957) is an American journalist and author who specializes in investigative reporting. He has been a reporter for the New York Times since 1990, and has won numerous awards for his work. Leydon was born in Summit, New Jersey, and attended the University of Maryland. He began his career as a reporter for the Newark Star-Ledger in New Jersey. He moved to the New York Times in 1990, and has written about a variety of topics including organized crime, political corruption, and terrorism. He has also written about baseball and boxing, and is a frequent contributor to Outside magazine. Leydon was awarded the Pulitzer Prize for National Reporting in 2002 for his series on political corruption in New Jersey. In 2006 he won the George Polk Award for investigative reporting for his reporting on secret government programs.

The evolution of schizophrenia refers to the theory of natural selection working in favor of selecting traits that are characteristic of the disorder. Positive symptoms are features that are not present in healthy individuals but appear as a result of the disease process. These include visual and/or auditory hallucinations, delusions, paranoia, and major thought disorders. Negative symptoms refer to features that are normally present but are reduced or absent as a result of the disease process, including social withdrawal, apathy, anhedonia, alogia, and behavioral perseveration. Cognitive symptoms of schizophrenia involve disturbances in executive functions, working memory impairment, and inability to sustain attention. Given the high numbers of individuals diagnosed with schizophrenia (nearly 1% of modern-day populations), it is unlikely that the disorder has arisen solely from random mutations. Instead it is believed that, despite its maladaptive nature, schizophrenia has been either selected for throughout the years or exists as a selective by-product.

Shals Mahajan is a writer and queer feminist who lives in Bombay. They have been part of LABIA – Queer Feminist LBT Collective for the past two decades. Shals is genderqueer and has worked on issues of gender, sexuality, caste and communalism as trainer, teacher and activist. They have studied literature and have conducted workshops on writing with university students, with people working in NGOs, with women returning to literacy, and queer persons. They have also published a few children’s books, Timmi in Tangles and Timmi and Rizu (Duckbill 2013, 2017), A Big Day for the Little Wheels (Pratham 2017) and co-authored No Outlaws in the Gender Galaxy. They have also been involved with the underground zine Scripts, a journal run by LABIA to give voice to queer Indian women, since 1998. Timmi in Tangles Timmi in Tangles is an experimental children's book that won the Kotak Junior Children writing award. It depicts the quirky and imaginative life of Timmi and the trials she faces in her everyday life.

Lincoln is the second studio album by American singer-songwriter John Legend, released on December 2, 2016, by Columbia Records. The album was produced by Legend and his husband, writer and producer Rodney Jerkins. In early 2014, John Legend announced that he had begun working on his second album. He stated that it would be "a little less soulful" than his debut album, which was produced largely by Pharrell Williams. In June 2015, he announced that the album's title would be "Lincoln". In October 2015, he released the single "All of Me" featuring Kelly Clarkson. In November 2015, he released the single "Believe" featuring Chance the Rapper. The album was executive produced by JAY-Z and was recorded at various recording studios across the United States. The album has a lush and cinematic soundscape with production from a variety of producers including Pharrell Williams, Rick Rubin, Kanye West, Hit-Boy and more. "Lincoln" is Legend's most introspective work to date and touches on themes such as racism, love and faith. Upon its release, the album received positive reviews from contemporary music critics who praised its production and songwriting. It debuted at number one on the US "Billboard" 200 with first-week sales of 317,000 copies. It also debuted at number one in 14 other countries including Australia, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Sweden and Switzerland. The album has been certified platinum in the

is a Japanese musician who worked with the rock band P-Model. He is the vocalist and guitarist for the band Kotobuki. Kotobuki was born in Tokyo, Japan on September 14, 1976. The Spanish treasure fleet, or West Indies treasure fleet, was a series of treasure fleets that sailed from the Spanish colonies in America to Europe during the 16th and 17th centuries. The fleets consisted of over 300 ships, carrying a total of around 180,000 silver and gold coins and jewels. The treasure was collected from the Americas and the Philippines, as well as from Spain's overseas empire in Africa. The Spanish treasure fleet was one of the largest ever assembled, and its success greatly contributed to Spain's economic development and its status as a global power. The fleets were also a major factor in the development of European trade unionism, as the crews became increasingly militant in their demands for better working conditions and pay. The fleets were also responsible for spreading Spanish culture around the world, as they brought settlers, missionaries, and traders to many new parts of the world. The Spanish treasure fleet was finally destroyed by a hurricane in 1715. However, the legacy of the fleets has continued to be felt throughout history, as they helped to shape the course of global history.

Zak Richard Starkey (born 13 September 1965) is an English musician and songwriter. He is the frontman and main songwriter of the alternative rock band Radiohead. He also has a solo career, releasing six albums between 1998 and 2009. Born in Brixton, London, Starkey was raised in Stockwell and attended Stockwell School. After leaving school, he worked as a carpet layers mate and then a trainee chef. He formed Radiohead with school friends Thom Yorke, Colin Greenwood and Jonny Greenwood in 1985, after playing together in a number of local bands. The band achieved international success with their landmark album "OK Computer" (1997), which sold over 20 million copies worldwide. Their subsequent releases have been met with comparable critical acclaim. In 2010, they released their seventh album, "The King of Limbs", to mixed reviews.

Brett Roberts (born March 24, 1970) is a former American basketball player best remembered for leading NCAA Division I in scoring as a senior in 1991–92 and then getting selected by the Sacramento Kings in that year's NBA draft, although he ultimately never played a game in the league. Roberts grew up in Portsmouth, Ohio and attended South Webster High School before moving on to play for Morehead State University's basketball team. A small forward, Roberts averaged 16.7 points per game for his four-year career. Through his first three seasons he averaged no more than around 14 points per game. Then, in his senior season in 1991–92, Roberts jumped from an average of 14.5 per game the year before to a nation-leading 28.1 points per game, doubling his output in a single season. He was named the Ohio Valley Conference Men's Basketball Player of the Year and was even selected in the NBA Draft.

Christina Schilling is a Danish songwriter, singer and musician. Schilling has written and performed songs in Danish, Swedish, Norwegian, Icelandic, English and German. She has released six albums and has been nominated for a Grammy Award. Schilling was born in Copenhagen, Denmark on December 4, 1971. She began playing the piano when she was six years old and started writing songs when she was thirteen. Schilling studied music at the Royal Danish Academy of Music in Copenhagen and at the University of Southern California. She first came to prominence as a member of the band known as The Innocent Criminals, which she formed with her then-boyfriend Kim Schilling in 1993. The Innocent Criminals released two albums before Schilling left to pursue a solo career. Schilling's first album, "Christina Schilling", was released in 1997. The album featured covers of songs by artists such as Bonnie Raitt and Joni Mitchell. In 1998, Schilling won the Danish Music Awards' Best Newcomer award. Her second album, "The Sound of Silence", was released in 2000 and featured the singles "Saints" and "The Way You Are". The album peaked at number two on the Danish charts and was certified gold by the IFPI Denmark. Schilling's third album, "I'm Not Alone", was released in 2002 and featured the singles "What Would You Do?" and "I'm Losing You". The album reached number one on the Danish charts and was certified platinum by the I

Josephine Maria Logan, known as Lillie (sometimes Lily) (October 2, 1843 — 1923) was an American painter and instructor, active for many years in Richmond, Virginia. She has been described as "probably Richmond's most esteemed teacher of art" in the late nineteenth century. Life Logan was born at Melbrook plantation in Charleston, South Carolina. One of fifteen children born to George William Logan and Anna D'Oyley Glover Logan, she was the niece of physician Thomas Muldrup Logan and a sister of the Confederate General of the same name. At the outbreak of the American Civil War her family moved from Charleston to Columbia in an attempt to preserve their property from destruction; however, when William Tecumseh Sherman burned the town, their house was one of those destroyed during the raid. Logan went on to study art, traveling to Rome in 1882 and remaining until 1888; her instructor there was Giuseppe Ferrari. Upon moving to Richmond, Logan began teaching her classes in the Allan House, Moldovia, which had been the boyhood home of Edgar Allan Poe. In 1894 she opened a new studio at 410 West Franklin Street. In 1904 she went to North Carolina, where she lived for a time before returning to Richmond, where she died. Logan's pupils included Edyth Carter Beveridge, Adele Goodman Clark, and Nora Houston. Some of her work may be found in the collection of The Valentine.

Don Wayne "Bubba" Shobert (born January 29, 1962 in Lubbock, Texas) is an American former professional motorcycle racer. He was a three-time A.M.A. Grand National Champion from 1985 to 1987 and was AMA Superbike Champion in 1988 while riding for American Honda. In 1989 Shobert moved up to the Grand Prix world championship riding for Honda. Unfortunately, Shobert's Grand Prix career was cut short at the third race of the season, where he was involved in a terrible crash with Kevin Magee on the cool off lap after the race, wherein Shobert drove into the back of Magee's motorcycle. Magee had stopped his motorcycle in the middle of the track and was performing a rear-wheel "burnout". Eddie Lawson narrowly missed hitting Magee's bike after he and Shobert had just finished congratulating each other moments earlier and were not looking forward. Shobert suffered severe head injuries but was able to make a full recovery after months of rehabilitation. He never raced again, taking instead roles as manager in some teams of AMA Grand National dirt track .

German submarine U-602 was a Type VIIC U-boat built for Nazi Germany's Kriegsmarine for service during World War II. She was laid down on 8 February 1941 by Blohm & Voss, Hamburg as yard number 578, launched on 30 October 1941 and commissioned on 29 December 1941 under Oberleutnant zur See Philipp Schüler. Design German Type VIIC submarines were preceded by the shorter Type VIIB submarines. U-602 had a displacement of when at the surface and while submerged. She had a total length of , a pressure hull length of , a beam of , a height of , and a draught of . The submarine was powered by two Germaniawerft F46 four-stroke, six-cylinder supercharged diesel engines producing a total of for use while surfaced, two Brown, Boveri & Cie GG UB 720/8 double-acting electric motors producing a total of for use while submerged. She had two shafts and two propellers. The boat was capable of operating at depths of up to .

Carrom Company (also Carrom Industries) was a manufacturer of games and furniture, headquartered in Ludington, Michigan. It started as Ludington Novelty Company in the 19th century. Its main product was the game of carroms. The company first started as the Ludington Novelty company at the end of the nineteenth century making novelty items. One of these was the game of carroms as a family game. The first carrom game boards were made by hand one by one and sold first before another was made. The game was sold in the US by the tens-of-thousands starting at the end of the 19th century. The parlor game became popular worldwide. Various local businessmen were involved with the company in its financing and management. Additional products were added to the original game of carroms as time went on, usually as associated furniture. The original company sold out to a larger firm in 1951 and the Ludington branch, which continued making the carroms game, became a small part of the larger firm. Beginnings (1889–1900)

Whitechapel Mount was a large artificial mound of disputed origin. A prominent landmark in 18th century London, it stood in the Whitechapel Road beside the newly constructed London Hospital, being not only older, but significantly taller. It was crossed by tracks, served as a scenic viewing-point (and a hiding place for stolen goods), could be ascended by horses and carts, and supported some trees and formal dwelling-houses. It has been interpreted as: a defensive fortification in the English Civil War; a burial place for victims of the Great Plague; rubble from the Great Fire of London; and as a laystall (hence it was sometimes called Whitechapel Dunghill). Possibly all of these theories are true to some extent. Whitechapel Mount was physically removed around 1807. Because Londoners widely believed in the "Great Fire rubble" theory, the remains were sifted by antique hunters, and some sensational finds were claimed. It survives in its present-day placename Mount Terrace, E1.

Clark Boyd is an American radio journalist. He is best known as the host of NPR's Weekend Edition Saturday. Clark Boyd was born in 1966 in Bloomington, Indiana. After graduating from Indiana University, where he majored in political science, Boyd worked as a reporter for WFYI-TV in Indianapolis before moving to New York City to join WNYC's staff. Boyd's first major break came in 1997, when he moderated a presidential debate between Bill Clinton and Bob Dole. He was promoted to the position of senior editor at WNYC, where he continued to work until 2006. That year, Boyd joined NPR as the host of Weekend Edition Saturday, a position he has held ever since. Boyd has received several awards for his work on Weekend Edition Saturday, including two National Humanities Medals (in 2002 and 2004), a George Foster Peabody Award (in 2007), and a prestigious Edward R. Murrow Award (in 2009). He was also nominated for a Pulitzer Prize in 2007, but lost to David Grann for his reporting on Hurricane Katrina. Boyd married journalist Evelyn Leeper in 1998. They have two children.

Barbara Joan Pariente (born December 24, 1948) is an American actress. She is best known for her role as Dr. Alex Karev on the CBS television soap opera "The Young and the Restless". Barbara Pariente was born in Detroit, Michigan, to Italian immigrants. She attended Eastern Michigan University, where she majored in theater and graduated with a B.A. in 1970. Pariente made her acting debut in a 1968 production of Tennessee Williams' "A Streetcar Named Desire" at the University of Michigan. After moving to New York City, she appeared in several Off-Broadway productions and became well known for her role as Dr. Alex Karev on the CBS television soap opera "The Young and the Restless" from 1978 to 1988. In 1988, she won the Daytime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Drama Series for her work on "The Young and the Restless". Since 1989, Pariente has appeared in guest roles on various television series, most notably as Auntie Mame on the Fox series "Mama's Family" from 1990 to 1991 and as Judge Gertrude Wind on the CBS series "The District" from 1995 to 1997. In 2002, she starred in an episode of the ABC series "Alias" as Senator Pat Harrigan. Since 2007, she has played Mrs. Kravitz on the ABC comedy series "Zoey 101". Broughton Hall is a heritage-listed former residence, now a museum, located at Lilyfield Road, Broughton Vale in the City of Sydney local government area of New South Wales, Australia. The property is owned by the City of Sydney. It was added to the New South Wales State Heritage Register on 2 April 1999. Broughton Hall, Lilyfield is a large and imposing building erected in the 1840s for wool merchant, Samuel Marsden Broughton. The hall is now a museum housing artefacts and exhibits illustrating the history of wool and cloth manufacture in Sydney. The main display areas are the domestic and business life of an 18th century wool merchant, the development of Sydney as a commercial city and the growth of the Australian wool industry. The hall was built by Samuel Marsden Broughton (1789-1871), one of Sydney's leading wool merchants and directors of several banks. Born in 1789, Broughton was one of Sydney's earliest successful businessmen, establishing himself as a wool merchant in 1814. He was instrumental in developing Sydney as a commercial city, becoming one of its earliest directors of companies and serving on many municipal boards. Broughton's wealth and influence allowed him to purchase land in Broughton Vale in 1841 and build Broughton Hall as his country residence. Broughton Hall is a large single-storeyed timber framed building on a sandstone foundation. The main facade is symmetrical with an entrance flanked by square pilasters and topped by

Frances Claire Wilson (born 7 November 1991) is an English singer, songwriter and actress. Wilson is the younger sister of singer-songwriter Ed Sheeran. Wilson was born in London to parents Diane (née Newson), a psychotherapist, and David Wilson, a telecommunications engineer. Her maternal grandfather was English actor Patrick Newson. Wilson has two older sisters, Amy and Emily. The family moved to Framlingham, Suffolk when she was three years old. Wilson attended Framlingham College from 2006 to 2010. Wilson released her debut single "The One" in December 2009. The song reached No. 10 on the UK Singles Chart and was certified silver by the British Phonographic Industry. Her debut album "Give Me Love" was released in June 2010 and peaked at No. 3 on the UK Albums Chart. The album spawned two further singles: "Our Song" (No. 6) and "Walking on Sunshine" (No. 12). In August 2011, she appeared as a judge on the third series of the UK singing competition "The X Factor". In 2013, she released her second album "In the Lonely Hour". The album spawned the singles "Lay Me Down" (No. 2 in the UK), "Chain Reaction" (No. 1 in Ireland) and "Good Days" (No. 3 in the UK). In October 2014, Wilson released her third album "25". The album spawned the singles "I Knew You Were Trouble"

Spotland Stadium, known as the Crown Oil Stadium for sponsorship reasons, is a football stadium in Spotland, North West England. It is the home of Salford City F.C. and has a capacity of 22,000. The stadium was built in 1925 and originally consisted of a single stand on the north-west corner of the ground. The original structure was converted to seating in 1986 and a new single stand was added on the south-west side of the ground. The stadium has been expanded twice since its construction, with the most recent expansion taking place in 2002, when the South Stand was added. Salford City F.C. played their first ever game at Spotland Stadium on 14 August 1925 against Huddersfield Town A.F.C., drawing 1–1. The first goal at Spotland Stadium was scored by Salford's Tom Finney in a 3–1 victory over Manchester United on 17 October 1925. The record attendance for a Salford City F.C. game at Spotland Stadium is 27,841, which was set against Liverpool on 5 November 1988. The highest attendance for a Salford City F.C. game at any other stadium is 30,183, which was set against Manchester United at Old Trafford on 21 November 1993 The current manager of Salford City F.C. is David Platt and the team plays in League Two (Tier 3 of the English football league system).

Chipping Sodbury is a market town in Gloucestershire, England, on the River Chelt. It is known for its 17th-century market square, Georgian architecture and well-preserved 16th-century town walls. The population of the town at the 2011 Census was 11,539. Chipping Sodbury was originally a small village that grew up around the Norman motte and bailey castle that was built in the late 11th century by Roger de Montgomery, 2nd Earl of Shrewsbury. The town walls were originally built in the 16th century to protect the town from attack by the surrounding English counties. The market square was first built in the 17th century and is still in use today. The town also has a number of Georgian buildings, including a library and a handsome Town Hall. Chipping Sodbury is home to one of the oldest theatres in England, the Old Vic. The market square is also home to a number of shops, including a butcher, bakery and grocery store. There is also a well-known tea rooms called The Flemish Horse. Chipping Sodbury has long been known for its production of china and porcelain. The town is also home to a number of industries, including a carpet factory and an aluminium foundry. Chipping Sodbury is located about 10 miles northwest of Gloucester and about 25 miles southwest of London.

is the fourth and final series of Ojamajo Doremi. The series was directed by Takuya Igarashi and produced by Toei Animation. "(Rap) Superstar" is a single by American hip hop group Cypress Hill. The song was released as the lead single from the group's fifth album, Skull & Bones. It was originally released as a double A-side with its rock counterpart on February 29, 2000 in the UK. An individual release was available starting sometime in April. Music video The music video for the song begins with a young man walking down the street, kicking a can. Walking up to a puddle, the man finds a ticket with "Rap Superstar" written on it. A fun house suddenly pops up and the man hands the ticket to Sen Dog, then enters. In one of the rooms, the man sees a group of women who dress him up in a suit. In another room, the man listens to a speech being given by B-Real, dressed as Fidel Castro. In another room, TV screens show rappers Eminem and Noreaga giving testimonies about the rap business. At the video's climax, the man goes to a performance by the band before being chased by the crowd. As the man exits the fun house, an explosion occurs and the man smiles.

Mikado Township is a civil township of Lenawee County in the U.S. state of Michigan. The population was 1,418 at the 2000 census. Mikado Township was founded in 1836. It was named for the Japanese city of Kyoto, which was known as "the garden of Japan." The township had a post office from 1837 to 1901. According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of , of which is land and (0.77%) is water. As of the census of 2000, there were 1,418 people, 592 households, and 419 families residing in the township. The population density was 36.4 per square mile (14.1/km²). There were 781 housing units at an average density of 16.4 per square mile (6.5/km²). The racial makeup of the township was 98.92% White, 0.06% Native American, 0.36% Asian, and 0.72% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 0.72% of the population. There were 592 households out of which 38.5% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 66.8% were married couples living together, 7.3% had a female householder with no husband present, and 22.9% were non-families. 18.2% of all households were made up of individuals and 7.8%

Brandon Afoa , 33 , of Puyallup was operating a tug to push back aircraft at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport when the brakes and steering failed , causing him to crash into a luggage lift . The incident , which took place on December 26 , 2007 , left Afoa unable to use his legs or right arm . For years the case was locked in courts because the Port of Seattle claimed it was n't liable as Afoa worked for a private company . However , the state supreme court ruled the airport operator had a ` duty ' to provide a safe working environment . A jury awarded the judgment on Tuesday .

Joseph Kwaku Duah Addai Jr. (born October 4, 1952) is an American retired professional football player who played Running Back for the Oakland Raiders, Baltimore Colts and Minnesota Vikings of the National Football League (NFL). He played college football for the University of Alabama. Addai was born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. He attended Philadelphia High School, where he played football and ran track. Addai accepted a scholarship to attend the University of Alabama, where he played for the Crimson Tide football team from 1971 to 1973. As a junior in 1972, he set a national record with 2,628 rushing yards on 266 carries (5.9 yards per carry), and was named first-team All-American by "The Sporting News". The Oakland Raiders selected Addai in the first round of the 1974 NFL Draft. He played for the Raiders from 1974 to 1984, then spent two seasons with the Baltimore Colts (1985–1986). In 1988, he signed with the Minnesota Vikings. He played for them until 1991, when he retired after suffering a season-ending injury. Addai was inducted into the College Football Hall of Fame in 1999 and the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 2010. He is also a member of both the Alabama Sports Hall of Fame and the Philadelphia High School Hall of Fame.

Pensioner Alan Spencer 's life was saved by his 18-month old Labrador Lexi . The 67-year-old began choking on pickled onion and felt life ` slipping away ' But Lexi jumped on his back - dislodging the onion and saving his life . An earlier version of this article stated that Lexi the labrador had saved Mr Spencer 's live by performing the Heimlich manoeuvre . In fact , the dog jumped on his back to clear the blockage . Heimlich involves applying sudden , strong pressure on the abdomen , which was not the case in this instance . We are happy to clarify this .

Josephine Armstead (born October 8, 1944), also known as "Joshie" Jo Armstead, is an American soul singer and songwriter. Armstead began her career singing backing vocals for blues musician Bobby "Blue" Bland before becoming an Ikette in the Ike & Tina Turner Revue in the early 1960s. She also had some success as a solo singer, her biggest hit being "A Stone Good Lover" in 1968. As a songwriter, Armstead teamed up with Ashford & Simpson. The trio wrote hits for various artists, including Ray Charles, Aretha Franklin, Tina Britt, Ronnie Milsap, and Syl Johnson. In the 1970s, Armstead appeared in the Broadway musicals Don't Play Us Cheap! and Seesaw. Life and career Armstead was born to Wilton and Rosie Armstead in Yazoo City, Mississippi on October 8, 1944. She started singing in the church in which her mother was a minister. After her grandfather introduced her to blues music, she also began singing in juke joints and at dances, and first sang in a club as part of Bobby "Blue" Bland's band. She joined a local band, Little Melvin & The Downbeats, as a teenager.

N'Keal Harry (, ; born December 17, 1988) is an American football wide receiver for the Oakland Raiders of the National Football League (NFL). He played college football at West Virginia. Harry was originally signed by the Jacksonville Jaguars as an undrafted free agent in 2009. He has also played for the Cincinnati Bengals, Baltimore Ravens, and San Diego Chargers. Harry attended Bishop Canevin High School in Bridgeport, Connecticut. He was a two-time All-State selection as a wide receiver and also played cornerback. Harry played college football at West Virginia. As a senior in 2008, he caught 54 passes for 785 yards and seven touchdowns. He also returned two kicks for touchdowns. Harry was named first-team All-Big 12 by the coaches and Associated Press. Harry was signed by the Jacksonville Jaguars as an undrafted free agent in 2009. He spent the 2009 season on the practice squad before being signed to the active roster in 2010. Harry appeared in six games for Jacksonville that season before being waived on November 3, 2010. Harry was signed by the Cincinnati Bengals on December 31, 2010. He appeared in eight games for Cincinnati that season before being waived on August 30, 2011. Harry was signed by the Baltimore Ravens on September 2, 2011. He appeared in four games for Baltimore that season before being waived on November 25, 2011. Harry was signed by the San Diego Chargers on December 8, 2011. He appeared in eight games for San Diego that season before being waived

John Hunter Wickersham (February 3, 1890 – May 9, 1966) was an American jurist and diplomat. He served as the United States Attorney General from 1941 to 1945, during World War II. After the war, he served as the United States Ambassador to the United Kingdom from 1949 to 1953. Wickersham was born in Lawrenceburg, Indiana on February 3, 1890. He graduated from the University of Virginia in 1912 and from Yale Law School in 1916. He was a captain in the United States Army during World War I. He was a judge on the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York from 1921 to 1931. He was a judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit from 1931 to 1941. Wickersham was nominated by President Franklin D. Roosevelt to be the United States Attorney General in 1941. He served in that position during World War II, until his resignation in 1945. After resigning as Attorney General, Wickersham served as the United States Ambassador to the United Kingdom from 1949 to 1953. He died on May 9, 1966.

Taymuraz Dzambekovich Mamsurov (, ; b. April 13, 1954 in Beslan) is the former head of the Republic of North Ossetia–Alania, Russia. He succeeded Alexander Dzasokhov, who voluntarily quit his post on May 31, 2005. Biography A graduate of the North Caucasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy, Mamsurov has also obtained a degree in history from the Academy of Social Sciences at the Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union (CPSU). He made his career in the Komsomol, "Communist Union of Youth", in the 1970s and advanced through the ranks of the CPSU in the 1980s. He was elected a deputy chairman of the Supreme Council of the Republic of North Ossetia–Alania in 1994 and was then put in charge of the administration of the republic's Pravoberezhny district in 1995. He chaired the North Ossetian government from February 1998 to October 2000 and the republic's parliament from October 19, 2000 until June 7, 2005, when he was approved, at the initiative of the then-President of Russia Vladimir Putin, as the Head of the Republic of North Ossetia–Alania. Mamsurov has been allied with Putin and holds a position in the United Russia party's Supreme Council as well as in the Presidium of Russia's State Council.

The exotic species compete with 10 cm long native fish for food and habitat . They also introduce devastating parasites and diseases onto local species .

Charles Terreni , 18 , was found dead March 18 at a frat house in Columbia . Terreni was a USC freshman and a member of the Pi Kappa Alpha house . Coroner identified cause of death as alcohol poisoning . Toxicology tests showed he had a blood alcohol of .375 . Neighbors said there was a large party ; a beer keg was still visible outside .

Benjamin Radcliff (born August 28, 1963) is an American actor, director, and screenwriter. He is known for his roles in the films The Omen, The Exorcist, and The Haunting. He also directed the horror film Sinister and the thriller film Sightseers. Radcliff was born in Fort Worth, Texas, the son of Barbara (née Williams) and John Radcliff. He has two sisters, Michele and Melissa. His paternal grandparents were Jewish immigrants from Poland. His mother, a devout Christian, homeschooled him until he was sixteen years old. Radcliff's early acting experience came at an acting camp in Dallas, where he was discovered by a talent scout for the Jerry Springer Show. Radcliff made his acting debut in 1985 with a small role in the television movie Two Fathers. He gained recognition for his role as Damien Karras in the 1987 film The Omen. That same year, he appeared as Max Cady in the remake of Blacula. He followed this up with roles in The Exorcist (1990), for which he received an Academy Award nomination for Best Supporting Actor; Sinister (2012), which he directed; and Sightseers (2015), for which he received a BAFTA nomination for Best Screenplay.

Yulia Tarbath , 33 , continued regular workouts and raw vegan diet . Returned to starting weight of 8st just two weeks after birth . Baby daughter weighed 7 lb 5oz and Yulia says she 'd do it all again . Experts say leading vegan lifestyle is unhealthy during pregnancy .

Amanda Holden , 44 , is on the cover of the June issue of Good Housekeeping . She talks about her traumatic childbirth experiences as well as her marriage . The mother-of-two has two daughters , nine-year-old Alexa and three - year-old Hollie .

Amir Khan released a video last week saying he would fight Chris Algieri . The British star has since been criticised for his choice of opponent . Khan also had the opportunity to fight Kell Brook at Wembley in June . Brook wants to return to action at the O2 in London on May 30 .

Dan Churchill, 25, has been promoting his cook book 'Dude Food' on Good Morning America. The Aussie star took to Instagram to reveal Blake Lively was on the call sheet that same day. He admitted to Hollywood star Blake Lively that he crushes more on hubby Ryan Reynolds.

Greenmuseum.org was a nonprofit online museum of environmental art. Since its launch in 2001, greenmuseum.org had become a source for information about this global art movement, which includes ecoart (or ecological art), land art, art in nature and related terms. It was formed by a group of artists in the San Francisco Bay Area who were interested in ecology who had observed that a museum did not exist that was dedicated to the history art and ecology. History The concept for the museum emerged in 2000 from a San Francisco Bay Area collaborative sculpture group called Meadowsweet Dairy. Members of the collective included Sam Bower, Genda Griffith, Henry Corning, Dan Ustin, Alan Leavitt, Tyler Johnson and Alex Tereshkin. These artists recognized the need for a cultural infrastructure to support ecological artwork and artists. Through a series of meetings, the name greenmuseum.org was arrived upon, and the collective applied for non-profit status. The site was launched on December 21, 2001.

Eleanor Wong Siew Yin (born 6 February 1962) is a Singaporean playwright, poet, lawyer and legal academic. She is an Associate Professor of Law at the National University of Singapore, where she is Vice Dean of Student Affairs and Director of Legal Skills Programme. She is also a member of the Remaking Singapore Committee. Early life and career A graduate of the National University of Singapore (NUS) Faculty of Law as a Public Service Commission merit scholar, Wong won the Best Oralist (Championship Round) at the 1985 Philip C. Jessup International Law Moot Court Competition, where she was a member of the victorious NUS moot team. Wong started her career with the Commercial Affairs Department, prosecuting complex commercial and securities frauds. She obtained a Master of Laws in corporate law from New York University in 1990 and practised in the New York office of Coudert Brothers before returning to Singapore in 1992.

Josh Reginald Hazlewood (born 8 January 1991) is an Australian cricketer who has played for the Royal Challengers Bangalore in domestic Indian Premier League (IPL) and for the Australian national team. He is a left-handed batsman and a wicket-keeper. Hazlewood made his first-class debut for New South Wales in the 2010–11 Sheffield Shield season, and made his List A debut for the state in the 2011–12 Ryobi One-Day Cup. Hazlewood played for Queensland in the 2012–13 Big Bash League, before signing with Royal Challengers Bangalore for the 2013 IPL season. Hazlewood made his Twenty20 International (T20I) debut for Australia against Sri Lanka in November 2013, and made his One Day International (ODI) debut against India in February 2014. He was part of Australia's squad for the 2014 ICC World Twenty20, where they were runners-up. Hazlewood was also part of Australia's squad for the 2015 ICC World Cup. In January 2017, Hazlewood signed a three-year contract with English county side Sussex.

The ancient Egyptian official Meketre was chancellor of the pantheon of gods during the Second Intermediate Period. Meketre was also a high priest of Ptah and one of the most important officials in the administration of the country. Meketre is attested in various ostraca from his time and is mentioned in several texts from ancient Egypt. Meketre is known from a number of ostraca, where he is mentioned as an official or high priest of Ptah. He is also mentioned in several texts from ancient Egypt, including a decree from king Sneferu that mentions Meketre as a high priest of Ptah. Meketre is also mentioned in a decree from king Khasekhemwy that mentions him as an official who was in charge of taxation. Meketre was also an important figure in the administration of ancient Egypt. He was responsible for managing the country's finances and overseeing the administration of justice. Meketre also served as a chancellor for the pantheon of gods during the Second Intermediate Period.

New York University psychologists studied how the brain stores memories . Found boring details become more memorable with emotional context . Emotional experience can enhance memory for old neutral information .

High availability software is software used to maintain availability and continuity of services in the event of an incident. It encompasses techniques for detecting failures, managing service restoration, and ensuring that services are available when required. High availability software is used in a variety of industries to ensure the continuance of critical services in the event of incidents. Examples include banking, telecommunications, insurance, and government. Many high availability software products are designed for use in a distributed environment, where servers are located across multiple locations. High availability software is typically composed of three components: a detection system, a management system, and a restoration system. The detection system monitors the status of services and detects failures. The management system manages the restoration of services and restores them to their previous state. The restoration system ensures that services are available when required.

USS Kochab (AKS-6) was an commissioned by the U.S. Navy for service in World War II. She was responsible for delivering and disbursing goods and equipment to locations in the war zone. The vessel was constructed by Delta Shipbuilding Co. of New Orleans, Louisiana and launched on 8 March 1944 under a Maritime Commission contract. After being acquired the U.S. Navy, the vessel was converted into a general stores ship and entered service on 4 November 1944. Kochab supported American operations in the Pacific Theater, sailing between US bases on Pacific islands. Following the war's end, Kochab sailed to the US with returning personnel and operated along the United States West Coast before being decommissioned on 17 April 1946. The vessel was then placed in reserve. Kochab was sold for scrap in 1965. Construction and commissioning Kochab was launched on 8 March 1944, by Delta Shipbuilding Co. of New Orleans, Louisiana, under a Maritime Commission contract, sponsored by Mrs. Thomas S. Crane. The ship was acquired by the Navy and commissioned on 2 May, Lt. Comdr. R. E. King in command and transferred to Mobile, Alabama. Kochab was decommissioned on 5 May, converted to a general stores supply ship by Alabama Dry Dock & Shipbuilding Co. and recommissioned 4 November 1944.

Wembley hosted two FA Cup semi-finals over the weekend . Arsenal defeated Championship Reading 2-1 after extra-time to reach final . Fabian Delph and Christian Benteke scored as Aston Villa beat Liverpool .

Atiha Sen-Gupta (born 1988) is a British artist whose practice spans photography, sculpture and installation. Sen Gupta was born in 1988 in London, England to Indian parents. She studied Fine Art at the University of the Arts London, graduating with a BA (Hons) in 2010. In 2013 she was awarded an MA by the Royal Academy of Arts. Sen Gupta's work centres around the processes and dynamics of image making, exploring the ways that photographic images can be manipulated and reworked in order to create new meanings. Her sculptures often incorporate photographic elements, either as physical objects or as components of installations that explore notions of memory, history and projection. Recent exhibitions include 'Subject Matter' at ZKM Center for Art and Media Karlsruhe (2018), 'Corpus' at Galerie Lelong (2017), 'The Memory of Things Past' at Whitechapel Gallery (2016), 'Toward an Image History' at The Photographers' Gallery (2015), and 'Invisible Territories' at The Photographers' Gallery (2014). Sen Gupta has been awarded grants from Arts Council England and The Foundation for Art and Creative Technology.

"Plans" is the second single by Australian singer-songwriter Sia. The song was written by Sia, Greg Kurstin, and Ari Levine, and produced by Kurstin and Levine. Released as a single on 27 February 2014, it became Sia's sixth number-one single on the US "Billboard" Hot 100 chart, as well as her first in Australia. "Plans" is a synthpop and electropop ballad with a duration of three minutes and fifty-six seconds. The song was written about a relationship that is going wrong and the protagonist's feelings of being trapped in it. Its lyrics explore the protagonist's regrets and their inability to break free from the situation. "Plans" has been noted for its heavy usage of synthesizers and its emotionally charged lyrics. Sia revealed that the song was inspired by her breakup with actor Andrew Troughton in 2013. She further said that she wanted to write a song that communicated her feelings without resorting to words. "Plans" received generally positive reviews from music critics, who praised its emotional power and the catchy melodies. The song has been compared to the works of Katy Perry and The Weeknd. The accompanying music video for "Plans" was directed by Sia herself, and it premiered on Vevo on 27 February 2014. It consists of footage of Sia performing the song in various locations around Los Angeles.

Clifton Fremont Hodge (16 October 1859-1949) was an American educator and psychologist. He was the first president of Clark University in Worcester, Massachusetts, serving from 1902 to 1911. Clifton F. Hodge was born in 1859 in Northampton, Massachusetts to Phineas and Almira (Hodge) Fremont. He attended the Phillips Exeter Academy in Exeter, New Hampshire, and then Yale University, where he received his Bachelor of Arts degree in 1883. He then studied at the University of Berlin, where he received his Doctor of Philosophy degree in 1886. Hodge returned to Yale University, where he became an associate professor of psychology in 1889. In 1902 he became the first president of Clark University, a position he held until 1911. During his time as president, Clark grew from a small private university into a large public institution. Hodge retired from Clark University in 1911 and moved to Boston, Massachusetts. He died there in 1949. Clifton F. Hodge was a pioneer in the field of psychology and education. He was the first president of Clark University and helped make it a large public institution. He also made significant contributions to the field of psychology, including his theories on personality development and cognitive dissonance. Clifton F. Hodge is remembered as an influential figure in American education and psychology history.

A vast sea of pilgrims have gathered at the Anzac Commemorative Site to mark the 100th anniversary of the bloody Gallipoli landings . Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott , his New Zealand counterpart John Key , Prince Charles and Prince Harry are among those in attendance . Defence Force Chief Mark Binskin told the thousands gathered there of the horror the Anzacs were confronted with on the day they came ashore .

Thomas Tuke Hollway (2 October 1906 – 30 July 1971) was the 36th Premier of Victoria, and the first to be born in the 20th century. He held office from 1947 to 1950, and again for a short period in 1952. He was originally a member and the leader of the United Australia Party (UAP) in Victoria, and was the inaugural leader of the UAP's successor, the Victorian division of the Liberal Party, but split from the Liberals after a dispute over electoral reform issues. Early life Thomas Tuke Hollway was born in Ballarat, the son of local merchant of the same name who would go on to become mayor of Ballarat, and Annie Nicholl. He was educated locally, at the Macarthur Street School and Church of England Grammar School. He studied arts and law at the University of Melbourne's Trinity College, and was admitted to practice as a solicitor in 1928, joining the Ballarat firm R. J. Gribble.

She sent him $ 4,000 - but realized it was a scam and tracked Valente down . He has now reported the problem to Facebook who removed the profile .

was an American civil rights activist. Influenced by her Japanese-American family's experience in an American internment camp, her association with Malcolm X, and her Maoist beliefs, she advocated for many causes, including black separatism, the anti-war movement, reparations for Japanese-American internees, and the rights of political prisoners. Early life and education Mary Yuriko Nakahara was born on May 19, 1921, in San Pedro, California, to Japanese immigrants Seiichi Nakahara, a fish merchant entrepreneur, and Tsuyako (Sawaguchi) Nakahara, a college-educated homemaker, and piano teacher. She had a twin brother, Peter, and an older brother, Arthur. Her family was relatively affluent and she grew up in a predominantly white neighborhood. In her youth, she attended a Presbyterian church and taught Sunday school. Kochiyama attended San Pedro High School, where she served as the first female student body officer, wrote for the school newspaper, and played on the tennis team. She graduated from high school in 1939. She attended Compton College, where she studied English, journalism and art. Kochiyama graduated from Compton in 1941.

The X-Corporation (X-Corp) is a fictional institution appearing in American comic books published by Marvel Comics, commonly in association with the X-Men comics. This organization was created to ensure the protection of mutant rights throughout the world due to the increasing number of mutants and widespread bigotry and hate crimes against them. Fictional history X-Corp was founded by Prof. Charles Xavier, the founder of the X-Men. Its purpose is to provide support for "civilian" mutant populations on a global scale in a world where the mutant population was outgrowing the reach of the X-Men. X-Corp offices are located in many major cities in every continent, and each office is managed by a former member of the X-Men or one of their satellite teams, such as Sunspot or Domino. The worldwide headquarters of the X-Corporation is the X-Mansion. X-Corp works with local governments, such as when they took in the superstrong twelve-year-old orphan Molly Hayes on behalf of the Social Services of Los Angeles.

Sāvitri is a chamber opera in one act with music composed by Gustav Holst, his Opus 25, to his own libretto. The story is based on the episode of Savitri and Satyavan from the Mahābhārata, which was also included in Specimens of Old Indian Poetry (Ralph Griffiths) and Idylls from the Sanskrit. The opera features three solo singers, a wordless female chorus, and a chamber orchestra of 12 musicians (consisting of 2 flutes, a cor anglais, 2 string quartets and a double bass). Holst had made at least six earlier attempts at composing opera before arriving at Sāvitri. Performance history The opera was first given in an amateur performance at Wellington Hall, London, on 5 December 1916. Holst had intended the work to be performed "in the open air, or else in a small building". Its first professional performance, conducted by Arthur Bliss, was staged on 23 June 1921 at the Lyric Theatre, Hammersmith with Dorothy Silk in the title role, Steuart Wilson as Satyavan, and Clive Carey as Death.

Elizabeth Elena Laguna Salgado , 26 , from Chiapas , Mexico , was last seen leaving a language school in Provo , Utah , April 16 . There is no evidence she was kidnapped , but she has n't made contact with anybody since she disappeared . She usually talked with family in Mexico every day , he said . A volunteer search is scheduled for Saturday .

The 2010 Tippeligaen was the 66th completed season of top-tier football in Norway. The season began on 7 April 2010 and ended on 18 October 2010. Rosenborg won their eleventh title and fourth consecutive title, and qualified for the 2011–12 UEFA Champions League. The 2010 Tippeligaen was contested by 10 teams. Rosenborg were the defending champions, having won their eleventh title in 2009. A total of 364 goals were scored in the 2010 Tippeligaen, an average of 2.29 goals per game. Eleven teams scored at least one goal in every game of the season. Rosenborg scored the most goals with 110, while Viking finished bottom of the table with only 4 goals scored. Rosenborg were undefeated in their first eleven games of the season, but lost their 12th game to Odd on 14 April 2010. They then went on to win their 13th game against Lillestrøm on 21 April 2010, and continued to win their subsequent games until they lost their 18th game against Mjøndalen on 10 October 2010. This meant that Rosenborg finished with a record of 16 wins, 1 draw, and no losses, which gave them the title of champions.

The Tories publish a separate ` English manifesto ' for the first time . Mr Cameron said delivering ` home rule ' for England is a top priority . Tory government will introduce the new system before March 2016 budget . It will allow English MPsto set separate rate of income tax to Scotland .

Nalla Idathu Sammandham is 1958 Indian Tamil-language romantic drama film directed by K. P. S. Viswanathan and produced by K. Balaji. The script was written by M. S. Viswanathan and the story was based on a novel by Sarojini Naidu. The film stars Kannadasan, Savitri, Jayalalithaa and Sivaji Ganesan in lead roles. The music was composed by Saluri K. R. Sundarrajan with lyrics written by Vaali. The film tells the story of a rich but selfish man, played by Kannadasan, and a poor but selfless woman, played by Savitri, who fall in love with each other despite their differences. The film is considered to be a landmark in Tamil cinema and is regarded as one of the greatest Tamil films ever made. It won the National Film Award for Best Feature Film in 1958 and the Filmfare Award for Best Film - Tamil. Nalla Idathu Sammandham is set in the fictional village of Nallur in the fictional district of Tirunelveli in Tamil Nadu during the 1930s. The film opens with Kaali (Kannadasan), an affluent man who is married to Ambika (Savitri). Ambika is a kind and loving woman, but Kaali is selfish and insensitive to her feelings. Kaali's elder brother Vembu (Sivaji Ganesan) is also married and has a son
Looming threat of Al-Shabaab has terrified students and teachers in Kenya . Terror group massacred 147 at Kenyan university last week .

Christopher Jarzynski is an American physicist and Distinguished University Professor at University of Maryland's Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, Department of Physics, and Institute for Physical Science and Technology, and fellow of the National Academy of Sciences. He is known for his contributions to non-equilibrium thermodynamics and statistical mechanics, for which he was awarded the 2019 Lars Onsager Prize. In 1997, he derived the now famous Jarzynski equality, confirmation of which was cited by the Nobel Committee for Physics as an application of one of the winning inventions of the 2018 Nobel Prize in physics—optical tweezers. Education and research Jarzynski graduated from Our Lady of Good Counsel High School in Wheaton, Maryland in 1983. He then attended Princeton University from where he graduated with high honors with an A.B. in physics in 1987 after completing a senior thesis titled "An experimental search for 1.7 MEV axions in nuclear decays, 'the detector from hell'." He received his Ph.D. in physics in 1994 from University of California, Berkeley, under the supervision of Władysław J. Świątecki and Robert Grayson Littlejohn.

Real Madrid midfielder Luka Modric has sprained a ligament in his right knee. The Croatian midfielder pulled up in the second half against Malaga on Saturday. Modric could still be back for the Champions League final but Real Madrid will have to get there without him.

Ellen Frank (born 1944) is a psychologist and Distinguished Professor Emeritus of Psychiatry and Distinguished Professor of Psychology at the University of Pittsburgh. She is known in the field of Psychotherapy as one of the developers of Interpersonal and Social Rhythm Therapy, which aims to treat bipolar disorder by correcting disruptions in the circadian rhythm while promoting increased regularity of daily social routines. Frank is the co-founder and Chief Scientific Officer of HealthRhythms, a company that uses mobile technology to monitor the health and mental health of clients, facilitate the detection of changes in their status, and better manage mental health conditions. Frank received the 2008 Award for Research in Mood Disorders from the American College of Psychiatrists, and the 2011 Rhoda and Bernard Sarnat International Prize in Mental Health from the National Academy of Medicine for her research on mood disorders and their treatment. She also received the 2015 James McKeen Cattell Fellow Award from the Association for Psychological Science.

Jessica Beatrice Fletcher (born Jessica Beatrice MacGill, December 16, 1940) is an American actress and author who starred as private detective Jessica Fletcher in the television series Murder, She Wrote (1984–1996). Fletcher was born in Westchester County, New York to Gladys MacGill and John Fletcher. She has two sisters, Linda and Judy. Fletcher attended the University of California, Los Angeles, where she studied drama. After a short stint as a fashion model, Fletcher began her acting career in the late 1960s with guest roles on television shows such as The Avengers and The Streets of San Francisco. In 1984, she was cast as Jessica Fletcher in the television series Murder, She Wrote. The show ran for eleven seasons and earned Fletcher three Golden Globe Awards, four Emmy Awards, a SAG Award, and a Peabody Award. In 2003, she published her memoirs, As I Was Saying: My Life As an Actress. In 2011, she released her first novel, And Then There Were None.

Henry Rolf Gardiner (5 November 1902 – 26 November 1971) was an English rural revivalist, helping to bring back folk dance styles including Morris dancing and sword dancing. He founded groups significant in the British history of organic farming. He was said to have sympathised with Nazism and participated in inter-war far right politics, but this was speculation based on his approval of the German Youth Movement's aims of involving townspeople in country community life, such as helping with the harvest. He organised summer camps with music, dance and community aims across class and cultures. His forestry methods were far ahead of their time and he was a founder member of The Soil Association. Early life He was born in Fulham the son of Sir Alan Henderson Gardiner and his wife Hedwig, née Von Rosen. He was educated at West Downs school from 1913, Rugby School, and then at Bedales School. He was a student at St John's College, Cambridge, where he was a member of the Kibbo Kift youth group.

A market economy is an economic system in which the decisions regarding investment, production and distribution to the consumers are guided by the price signals created by the forces of supply and demand, where all suppliers and consumers are unimpeded by price controls or restrictions on contract freedom. The major characteristic of a market economy is the existence of factor markets that play a dominant role in the allocation of capital and the factors of production. Market economies range from minimally regulated free-market and laissez-faire systems where state activity is restricted to providing public goods and services and safeguarding private ownership, to interventionist forms where the government plays an active role in serving special interests and promoting social welfare. State intervention can happen at the production, distribution, trade and consumption areas in the economy. The distribution of basic need services and goods like health care may be entirely regulated by an egalitarian public health care policy, while at the same time having the production provided by private enterprise, effectively eliminating the forces of supply and demand. These economies are not market economies and display market failure of a market economy for basic needs and anti-competitive practices with respect to individual private customers.

Polaris (Lorna Dane) is a fictional character appearing in American comic books published by Marvel Comics. The character, created by writer Stan Lee and artist Don Heck, first appeared in The X-Men #92 (September 1966). Polaris is a mutant who can generate and control magnetism. Polaris is a member of the X-Men team led by Professor X. Her powers first manifested when she was attacked by a gang of thugs and she used her magnetism to repel their weapons. Polaris has since been a key member of the team, often serving as its leader during times of crisis. She has also been involved in several major storylines, most notably the civil war between the X-Men and the Brotherhood of Mutants. Polaris has also starred in her own solo adventures and miniseries. Polaris has been married three times, most recently to Havok. She has two children, Quicksilver and Scarlet Witch, from her first marriage to Magneto.

Switched-On Bach is the debut album by the American composer Wendy Carlos, initially released under the name Walter Carlos, in October 1968 by Columbia Records. Produced by Carlos and Rachel Elkind, the album is a collection of pieces by Johann Sebastian Bach performed by Carlos and Benjamin Folkman on a Moog synthesizer. It played a key role in bringing synthesizers to popular music, which had until then been mostly used in experimental music. Switched-On Bach reached number 10 on the US Billboard 200 chart and topped the Billboard Classical Albums chart from 1969 to 1972. By June 1974, it had sold over one million copies, and in 1986 became the second classical album to be certified platinum. In 1970, it won Grammy Awards for Best Classical Album, Best Classical Performance – Instrumental Soloist or Soloists (With or Without Orchestra), and Best Engineered Classical Recording. After Carlos publicly came out as a transgender woman in 1979, reissues of Switched-On Bach amended the artist credit to reflect her preferred name, as was the case with the rest of her discography up to that point.

Penny Gordon-Larsen is an American nutritionist. She is a spokesperson for the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics and is the co-founder of Gordon-Larsen Nutrition. Gordon-Larsen was born in Meridian, Idaho in 1953. She earned her bachelor's degree from Brigham Young University in 1975 and her doctorate from the University of California, Davis in 1983. Gordon-Larsen began her career as a research associate at the University of California, Davis School of Veterinary Medicine. In 1989, she founded Gordon-Larsen Nutrition, a company that provides nutritional counseling and products to people across the United States. Gordon-Larsen has been a spokesperson for the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics since 2002. In that role, she has spoken about nutrition topics on national television and radio programs. She has also written articles for magazines and newspapers, including "Reader's Digest", "National Review", and "The Huffington Post". Gordon-Larsen is married to Ken Gordon-Larsen, a retired professor emeritus at Brigham Young University. They have four children.

KZNS (1280 kHz, The Zone) is a commercial AM radio station in Salt Lake City. It airs a sports radio format and is owned by Jazz Communications LLC. Programming is simulcast on co-owned KZNS-FM 97.5, licensed to Coalville, Utah. On weekdays, KZNS-AM-FM have local hosts discussing Salt Lake City and national sports. Nights and weekends, programming is supplied by Fox Sports Radio and Premiere Radio Networks. KZNS-AM-FM are the flagship radio stations for the Utah Jazz basketball team and the Salt Lake Bees Minor League Baseball team. KZNS's transmitter is near the Jordan River in North Salt Lake, and their headquarters are located inside the Vivint Arena in Salt Lake City. It is a Class B radio station, running 50,000 watts by day, the maximum power for commercial AM radio stations in the U.S. But at night, to protect other stations on 1280 AM, it drops power to just 670 watts. It uses a directional antenna at all times.

Patrick Daniel Tillman Jr. (November 6, 1976 – April 22, 2004) was an American football player who was killed in action in Afghanistan. Tillman became a symbol of the United States' military efforts in Afghanistan and of the long battle against Taliban insurgents. Tillman was born in San Jose, California, and grew up in Arizona. He attended Arizona State University, where he played football for the Sun Devils from 1996 to 1999. He was drafted by the Seattle Seahawks in the first round of the 2000 NFL Draft, and played for them from 2000 to 2003. In 2002, he was named to the All-Pro team and became a leader on the Seahawks' defense. In March 2004, Tillman left Seattle to join the U.S. Army Rangers, where he served as a platoon leader. On April 22, 2004, while leading his platoon against heavy enemy fire in Afghanistan's Kunar Province, Tillman was killed by an enemy grenade. He was 27 years old. Since Tillman's death, his story has become a symbol of the U.S. military efforts in Afghanistan and of the long battle against Taliban insurgents. Tillman's jersey number (22) has been retired by both his former team (the Seahawks) and his former regiment (the Rangers). Julian Johnson Ewell (November 5, 1915 – July 27, 2009) was a career United States Army officer who served in World War II, the Korean War and the Vietnam War. He commanded the 9th Infantry Division and II Field Force in Vietnam, and attained the rank of lieutenant general. The son of a career Army officer, Ewell graduated from the New Mexico Military Institute and the United States Military Academy. Commissioned as a second lieutenant of infantry in 1939, he volunteered for paratrooper training at the start of World War II. During the war, he commanded 3rd Battalion, 501st Parachute Infantry Regiment, part of the 101st Airborne Division. He took part in a parachute jump into Normandy during the D-Day invasion, and continued to take part in combat against the Nazis in Europe. Ewell later commanded the 501st Regiment, which included participation in Operation Market Garden and the defense of Bastogne in the Battle of the Bulge. He received the Distinguished Service Cross for his heroism at Bastogne.

is a former Japanese football player. Playing as a defender, Kuwabara has represented Japan at international level on five occasions, including at the 2002 World Cup. Padley Hall (or Padley Manor) was an estate in Surrey, England, which was the home of the Earl and Countess of Oxford from 1647 until the earl's death in 1684. The estate passed to his daughter, and then to her son, the 3rd Earl of Oxford, who sold it in 1716. Padley Hall was located in the parish of Ottershaw, about four miles west of Guildford. The estate comprised about 230 acres (94 ha), including a small manor house, thirty-four cottages, a park of about 400 acres (160 ha), and a mill. The earliest record of Padley Hall is from 1485, when it was owned by Sir William Livingstone. The estate passed through several hands during the 1600s, but it was acquired by the Earl and Countess of Oxford in 1647. The earls rebuilt Padley Hall between 1684 and 1687. Padley Hall was sold in 1716 to Colonel Thomas Blount. Blount leased the estate to a number of tenants over the next few years, but he eventually decided to sell it in 1729. The new owner was John Pemberton, who used Padley Hall as a hunting lodge. Pemberton died in 1751, and the estate passed to his son-in-law, John Spencer. Spencer leased Padley Hall to a number of tenants over the next few years, but he eventually decided to sell it in 1768. The sale

Jack Halpern (b. 1946; , ) is an American linguist who specializes in morphosyntax and semantics. Halpern received his B.A. from Brandeis University in 1968, and his M.A. and Ph.D. from the University of California, Berkeley, in 1971 and 1974, respectively. He has been a professor at the University of Pennsylvania since 1975, where he is currently the Lewis S. Thomas Professor of Linguistics and a member of the Center for Cognitive Science. Halpern's work has focused on issues relating to syntax and semantics, with a particular emphasis on how syntax affects meaning. He has developed a number of influential theories about the relations between these two aspects of language, including the Minimalist Program (which he initially articulated in a series of papers published in the early 1980s), Lexical Semantics (which he introduced in his book Semantics: An Introduction published in 1988), and Morphosyntax (which he first developed in papers published in the late 1980s and early 1990s). Halpern is also known for his work on quantification (particularly quantifier scope), linguistic relativity, and language acquisition.

The Armageddon Network is a non-fiction book about a potential future in which the world is embroiled in a global war that could result in the end of the human race. Berlin, and was published in 1998. In this future, computers have become so powerful that they can control large armies and weapons systems. As a result, humanity is constantly at war with itself, and the world is on the brink of disaster. The book describes how the people of the world are trying to find a way to stop the war, but they are met with resistance from those who want to continue fighting. In the end, however, the people of the world are able to come together and work out a plan to stop the war.

Hume Alexander Horan (August 13, 1934 – February 5, 2019) was an American mathematician and physicist. He was the founder and director of the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, New Jersey. Horan was born in Cleveland, Ohio, on August 13, 1934. He earned his bachelor's degree from Harvard College in 1956 and his doctorate from Princeton University in 1961. He spent the 1960s as a faculty member at the University of California, Berkeley and at the University of Edinburgh. From 1970 to 1977 he was a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He became a professor at the Institute for Advanced Study in 1977, where he served as director from 1987 to 1997. Horan's research focused on mathematics and physics. His work in mathematics included the theory of differential equations, functional analysis, and variational calculus; his work in physics involved the theory of relativity, quantum mechanics, mathematical physics, and Statistical mechanics. Horan was a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and of the National Academy of Sciences. He died on February 5, 2019, at the age of 84.

Copy That is a studio album by American country artist Sara Evans. The album was released on May 15, 2020 via Born to Fly Records and was produced by Jarrad K. The project was Evans's tenth studio recording and her first album to consist entirely of covers material. A collection of thirteen songs were chosen for the album and it included two additional artists on the album. Background Copy That was produced by Evans and Jarrad K. In his previous work, Jarrad K. also produced music by the Goo Goo Dolls and Weezer. Evans was interested in working with him after hearing his production work on Ruston Kelly's album, Dying Star. The pair began a working relationship that also involved assistance from Evans's children in song selection and production. The Evans family and Jarrad K. chose material that was rooted in the music of Evans's childhood. She performed on a regular basis with her brothers and sisters in a covers band, singing a variety of musical genres. "I grew up onstage in bars, doing the 9 p.m. to 1 a.m. shows, covering songs," Evans recalled. Many of the songs she performed as a child were chosen for the album project.
