Sherry Chen (; born December 15, 1955) is a Taiwanese politician. She is currently the Minister of the Interior since May 2018. Chen was born in Taipei, Taiwan on December 15, 1955. She attended National Chengchi University and obtained her bachelor's degree in economics in 1979. Chen then attended the University of Nottingham, where she obtained her master's degree in business administration in 1983. Chen began her career in 1982 as an associate professor at National Chengchi University. She then served as the Minister of Labor from 2000 to 2002, and was subsequently elected to the Legislative Yuan in 2002. Chen served as the Minister of Economic Affairs from 2006 to 2008, and was subsequently re-elected to the Legislative Yuan in 2008. Chen was then appointed as the Minister of Transportation and Communications in 2012, and served until May 2018 when she was appointed as the Minister of the Interior.

Leigh Tesfatsion is a computational economist who has made significant contributions to the field of economic forecasting. In particular, Tesfatsion is known for his work on dynamic stochastic general equilibrium models and for his development of methods for forecasting long-term economic dynamics. Leigh Tesfatsion was born in 1964 in Tel-Aviv, Israel. He received his B.A. in Economics from the Hebrew University of Jerusalem in 1986 and his M.A. and Ph.D. degrees in Economics from the University of California, Berkeley, in 1990 and 1994, respectively. Tesfatsion has been a professor at the University of California, Davis since 1994 and is currently the Eberly Family professor in economics and director of the UC Davis Center for Regional Economic Analysis. Tesfatsion's research focuses on economic forecasting and dynamic stochastic general equilibrium models. He has developed methods for forecasting long-term economic dynamics, including prediction markets and Bayesian inference. His work has had a significant impact on the field of economics, and he has been cited more than 2,000 times in scholarly journals. Tesfatsion has also made significant contributions to public policy. He is a member of the National Academy of Sciences (NAS) and the American Academy of Arts and Sciences (AAAS). He is also a foreign member of the Royal Swedish Academy of Science (Kungliga Vetenskapsakademien).

Devendra Triguna is an Indian Ayurveda practitioner, known for his expertise in Pulse diagnosis (Nadi vaidyam in Ayurvedic terms). He is a former honorary physician to the President of India and the incumbent president of the Association of Manufacturers of Ayurvedic Medicine (AMAM) and the All India Ayurvedic Congress (AIAC). The Government of India awarded him the fourth-highest civilian award, the Padma Shri, in 1999, and followed it up, a decade later, with the third-highest honour of the Padma Bhushan in 2009. Biography Tiriguna was born in a family of traditional Ayurveda practitioner, to renowned Ayurvedic physician and Padma Vibhushan awardee, Brihaspati Dev Triguna and learned Ayurveda from his father. He started his medical practice at his father's clinic, located in the periphery of New Delhi, in a village by name, Sarai Kale Khan. When Triguna retired from active practice shortly before his death in 2013, Devendra Triguna took over the management of the clinic. He claims to have curative protocols for several diseases such as Blood cancer, kidney ailments, abdominal diseases, skin diseases, Spondylitis, asthma, arthritis, insomnia and Hyper tension.

Khlong Maha Nak is a khlong (canal) in Bangkok and considered one of Bangkok's oldest canals. It starts from Khlong Rop Krung (old city moat) in the area of Mahakan Fort and Wat Saket's Golden Mount and continues to the east as far as ends at the intersection with Khlong Saen Saep in Ban Khrua neighbourhood, tote distance 1.3 km (0.81 mi). The canal was canalize by the royal intention of King Phutthayotfa Chulalok (Rama I) in 1783 after establishment of Rattanakosin kingdom (today's Bangkok) only one year, used as a waterway for people to boating and playing Khlon Sakkawa (กลอนสักวา; a kind of Thai poem). An ancient culture that has been around since Ayutthaya period. Its name "Maha Nak" is derived from the namesake canal used in the old Ayutthaya kingdom. It's believed that, it received this name from a monk named "Maha Nak", who initiated the canalize for use in the war after the end of Burmese–Siamese War (1547–49) shortly.

KAFA-FM (97.7 FM, "The New 97.7"), originally started in 1964, is the unlicensed United States Air Force Academy cadet radio station. Run and staffed by current Officer Cadets and limited permanent party members, KAFA is the voice of cadets to the Colorado Springs area. With no formal budget or permanent staff, KAFA had no set transmission hours or format. The frequency was changed from 104.5 FM in October 1993 to 104.3 FM where it stood until June 2006. In 2004, KAFA was given a grant and updated its studio to current radio broadcasting industry standards with the introduction of Prophet Systems software and Dell computers. In June 2006, KAFA changed frequency to 97.7 FM. The station subsequently solidified a format of Alternative rock and Indie rock branded as "The New 97.7". With the change to a new format came new popularity. The station has a large on-line web audience. The programming also allows distinct DJs and personalities to maintain their own distinct shows, most notably, "Dan and Dave," their most popular show.

Late Greek means writings in the Greek language in Late Antiquity and the Early Byzantine period; and in other words, from about the late 2nd century AD until about the late 7th century AD. The intellectual center of Late Greek was Alexandria in Egypt. Alexandria came under Arabic rule starting in the 640s AD, which is sometimes taken as the ending-point of the Late Greek period. In terms purely of linguistics and language style, writings in Late Greek were conservative, whereas style began to change during the 8th century to some extent, and hence the ending-point of Late Greek is sometimes put at the beginning of the 8th century. Notable examples of Late Greek writers include Clement of Alexandria (died c. 215), Galen (died c. 216), Origen (died c. 254), Diophantus (died c. 290), Porphyry (died c. 305), Zosimos of Panopolis (died c. 325), and many others. See the article Byzantine literature for more.

Relationship Development Intervention (RDI) is a trademarked proprietary treatment program for autism spectrum disorders (ASD), based on the belief that the development of dynamic intelligence is the key to improving the quality of life for autistic people. The program's core philosophy is that autistic people can participate in authentic emotional relationships if they are exposed to them in a gradual, systematic way. The goal of treatment is to systematically build up the motivation and tools for successfully interacting in social relationships, to correct deficits in this area that are thought to be common to all autistic people. RDI focuses on cultivating the building blocks of social connection—such as referencing, emotion sharing, coregulation, and experience sharing—that normally develop in infancy and early childhood. RDI is a family-based program, where trained consultants support families to alter their interaction and communication styles. There is a period of parent education, followed by an assessment of both the child and the child-parent relationship. After that consultants support the family through a set of specific objectives to build a "guided participation" relationship between parents and child that will allow the child to once again become a "cognitive apprentice" to the parents. Once the cognitive apprenticeship is in place, the family can move on to specific cognitive remediation objectives for the child. These are developmentally staged objectives designed to restore optimal neural connectivity through a series of "discoveries" and "elaborations".

James Lick (August 25, 1796 – October 1, 1876) was an American real estate investor, carpenter, piano builder, land baron, and patron of the sciences. The wealthiest man in California at the time of his death, Lick left the majority of his estate to social and scientific causes. Early years James Lick was born in Stumpstown (now Fredericksburg) Pennsylvania on August 25, 1796. Lick's grandfather, William Lick, served during the American Revolutionary War under General George Washington and his son, John Lick, during the American Civil War. The son of a carpenter, Lick began learning the craft at an early age. When he was twenty-one, after a failed romance with Barbara Snavely, Lick left Stumpstown for Baltimore, Maryland, where he learned the art of piano making. He quickly mastered the skill, and moved to New York City and established his own shop. In 1821 Lick moved to Argentina, after learning that his pianos were being exported to South America.

Pacorus I (also spelled Pakoros I; ; c. 180 BC – c. 130 BC) was the first king of the Indo-Greek kingdom. Pacorus was succeeded by his son, Menander I. Pacorus was probably born in the mid-2nd century BC in eastern Punjab or eastern Afghanistan, according to Polybius. He was a member of the Arachosian family, which was prominent during the time of the Mauryan Empire. He may have been a relative of the Indo-Greek king Antimachus I, who was also an Arachosian. In 190 BC, Antimachus I died suddenly and left behind two young sons, Eucratides I and Antimachus II. The former was almost certainly murdered by his younger brother, who then made himself king of the whole of Alexander's empire. Eucratides I managed to retain control of parts of Bactria and Arachosia until his death in 145 BC. The Greek general Seleucus I took advantage of the situation and invaded India, ostensibly to help Eucratides I but in fact with the intention of capturing Antimachus II. He defeated Eucratides I in battle and took control of Bactria and Arachosia, setting up his own Indo-Greek kingdom. Khaled Farid Kharroubi (born February 11, 1951) is a Lebanese politician and diplomat who has been the Prime Minister of Lebanon four times. Kharroubi was born in Beirut, Lebanon. He is a member of the Maronite Catholic Church. He attended the American University of Beirut, where he earned a degree in political science. Kharroubi began his political career in 1978, when he was elected to the Lebanese Parliament as a representative for the Baalbek-Hermel region. He served as Deputy Prime Minister from 1991 to 1992, and as Minister of Finance from 1992 to 1995. Kharroubi was elected Prime Minister for the first time in 1996, and held the position until 1999. He was re-elected in 2001 and 2005. In January 2008, Kharroubi announced that he would not seek reelection in the May 2008 elections, citing mounting tensions with Hezbollah over its role in the Lebanese political system. Kharroubi has been a vocal critic of Hezbollah's paramilitary arm, which he has called a "terrorist group". In November 2006, he threatened to withdraw Lebanon's support for Hezbollah if it did not disarm. In April 2007, Kharroubi met with U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice in Rome to discuss ways to end the 2006 Lebanon War between Israel and Hezbollah. Walter Theodore "Sonny" Rollins (born September 7, 1930) is an American jazz saxophonist and composer. He is considered one of the most influential and acclaimed jazz musicians of the 20th century. Sonny Rollins was born in St. Louis, Missouri, and raised in the city's Central West End. He learned to play the saxophone from his father, a jazz musician who played professionally in the 1920s. Rollins attended Lincoln High School in St. Louis and then studied at the University of Missouri, where he joined the jazz ensemble known as the BeBop band. He later transferred to New York City and worked with Art Blakey's Jazz Messengers. In 1957, Rollins recorded his first solo album, featuring compositions by Blakey, Hank Mobley, and George Coleman. The album was a commercial success, spawning several follow-up recordings over the next few years. Rollins became associated with hard bop and bebop styles of jazz playing and developed a reputation as one of the most difficult saxophonists to play with. He also gained a following among mainstream audiences thanks to his collaborations with popular singers such as Aretha Franklin and Tina Turner. In the late 1960s and early 1970s, Rollins began to experiment with funk music and soul jazz styles, which led to his breakthrough album "Saxophone Colossus" (1974). This album featured collaborations with such prominent funk artists as James Brown, Parliament-Funkadelic, Sly & The Family Stone, and Chaka Khan. Rollins continued to experiment

Dean Evan Hart, O.D., M.A., M.S. (Candidate) is a professional ophthalmologist and medical doctor with over 20 years of experience. He has a background in both ophthalmology and medical sciences and has worked extensively in both private practice and as a staff physician at several hospitals. He also has extensive experience working with patients and their families, as well as being an expert in numerous medical disorders affecting the eyes. Marie Costine, born in Cloyne County Cork, Ireland, on October 3, 1882, was an American author of children's books. She was the first author to win the prestigious Newbery Medal for her novel The Cricket on the Hearth. Marie Costine was born on October 3, 1882, in Cloyne County Cork, Ireland. She emigrated to America with her family when she was only five years old. After graduating from high school in New York City, Marie studied art at the Art Students League of New York. She then moved to Chicago and began working as a freelance illustrator. Marie's first book, The Cricket on the Hearth, was published in 1912. It was awarded the prestigious Newbery Medal and became a bestseller. Marie wrote more than twenty other books over the course of her career, many of which were also successful and received awards. Marie Costine died on May 5, 1961, in Stamford, Connecticut.

Fascia iliaca blocks (FIC, FICB) is a group of fifteen anatomical structures that together form the fascia iliaca, a sheet of connective tissue that wraps around the entire pelvis and extends anteriorly to cover most of the iliac crests and sacrum. The fascia iliaca blocks are: Fascia iliaca block 1: The anterior inferior iliac spine, a bony prominence on the ilium that articulates with the sacrum. Fascia iliaca block 2: The greater trochanter, the largest bony prominence on the femur. Fascia iliaca block 3: The lesser trochanter, located below the greater trochanter. Fascia iliaca block 4: The inguinal ligament, an elastic band of tissue that connects the femoral head with the upper part of the inguinal canal. Fascia iliaca block 5: The pubic symphysis, a fibrous joint between the two pubes. Fascia iliaca block 6: The obturator foramen, a hole in the pelvic floor through which passes the obturator nerve and other vessels. Fascia iliaca block 7: The ischial tuberosity, a round knob on either side of the pelvic opening. Fascia iliaca block 8: The common iliac crest, a prominent ridge on either side of the ischial

James Peter Richard Heaslip (born 15 December 1983) is an Irish rugby union former player who played for Leinster and Ireland. He played as a number 8. Heaslip earned 95 caps for Ireland during his international career from 2006 to 2017, making him one of the most capped players in Irish national team history. Early life Heaslip was born in Tiberias, Israel, while his father, retired Brigadier General Richard Heaslip, was there on duty with UNIFIL. His father was one of the founding officers of the elite Army Ranger Wing (ARW), Ireland's special operations force. The youngest of four children, he has two brothers and a sister. Jamie and his family moved back to Ireland when he was still young, settling in the town of Naas where he lived until moving to Dublin aged 17. He attended Newbridge College, in County Kildare. In 2004, he starred in the U-21 World Cup, held in Scotland, where Ireland finished as runners-up to New Zealand. Following his performance, Heaslip was nominated for the IRB Under-21 World Player of the Year award.

Farnham Pottery is located in Wrecclesham near Farnham, Surrey, England. The pottery was founded in 1794 by Josiah Wedgwood and his son Josiah Wedgwood II. The pottery was the first to be established in the new town of Farnham, and was responsible for the development of the local trade in bone china. The pottery is best known for its bone china, which was a popular choice for tea sets and other pieces of decorative tableware. This type of china is made from white bone ash and clay, with a glaze that is usually a light pink or rose. The pottery also produces a range of other types of pottery, including stoneware, earthenware, and porcelain. Today, the pottery is owned by the Scottish company Wedgwood plc and is still operational as a production facility. The pottery has been designated a Grade II* listed building, and is open to the public for tours on certain weekends during the year.

General Sir Trevor Chute, KCB (31 July 1892 – 16 February 1969) was a senior British Army officer who served in World War I, World War II and the Korean War. He is most notably remembered for his command of the 7th Armoured Division during the Battle of Normandy in 1944, which saw the division liberate much of France from German occupation. Trevor Chute was born on 31 July 1892, the son of Major General John Chute and his wife Dame Agnes Hayman. He was educated at Haileybury College, where he captained the cricket team and won the college's Sword of Honour in 1913. He then attended the Royal Military College, Sandhurst, graduating with a commission as a lieutenant in the Royal Engineers on 15 July 1915. During World War I, Chute served with the 2nd Battalion, The Rifle Brigade (Prince of Wales's Own). He was severely wounded in action at Sanctuary Wood on 26 September 1916 and spent several months recuperating in hospital. Upon his return to duty, he was posted to the 3rd Battalion, The Rifle Brigade (Queen's Royal Regiment). In March 1918 he took command of his battalion and fought in the Battle of Cambrai before being invalided home with trench fever on 18 November 1918. Following his return to England, Chute was appointed an instructor at the Royal Military College, Sandhurst. In May 1920 he was transferred to the British Army of Occupation in Germany and appointed Deputy Assistant Adjutant General

Pandit Ram Kishore Vyas was a freedom fighter and senior Indian National Congress leader from the state of Rajasthan before he died. Born to Pandit Laduram on 23 May 1908 in Jaipur. He held various offices including Lt Governor of Pondicherry in 1980, Speaker of Rajasthan Legislative Assembly 1972-1977, Home Minister of Rajasthan, President of Rajasthan Pradesh Indian National Congress thrice. He represented the Hawamahal and Chomu Rajasthan assembly constituencies twice each. He died of a heart attack on 16 April 1981 in Jaipur and was cremated with full state honours. Buta Singh, the Home Minister of India paid a floral tribute on behalf of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi. His sons Ramakant Vyas and Radhey Kant Sharma held various posts in RPCC including Vice President in 2008 and General secretary in 1998 and Radhey Kant Sharma was an IAS officer who was accused of corruption charges but case was later abated in 2017 because he died in 2011 at the age of 86 years. His grandson Rupesh Kant Vyas is working as General Secretary of Rajasthan State Congress since February 2016.

Betty Bourke (née Lucas, 23 July 1908 – 10 October 1997) was an Australian actress, best known for her roles in Australian films in the 1930s and 1940s. Betty Bourke was born on 23 July 1908 in Melbourne, Victoria, to Joseph Lucas and his wife, Felicity (née Bourke). She was educated at Presbyterian Ladies' College and then the National Theatre School of Australia. Bourke made her stage debut in 1929, appearing in productions of "Hamlet" and "The Importance of Being Earnest". Bourke's first film appearance was as a bit part player in "The Adventures of Barry McKenzie" (1931), but it was her performance as Billie Cameron in the Australian feature film "Kings Row" (1934) that brought her to national attention. In 1935 Bourke co-starred with John Gavin and Chips Rafferty in the Australian production of "The Thin Man", which became one of the biggest hits of the year. She followed this success with roles in several more popular Australian films, including "The Ghost and Mrs. Muir" (1936), "The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert" (1940), and "The Swan Princess" (1943). Bourke retired from acting in the early 1950s, but continued to work on stage until her death on 10 October 1997. She was cremated and her ashes scattered at sea.

Slieve League or Slieve Liag is a mountain on the Atlantic coast of County Donegal, Ireland. At , it has the second-highest sea cliffs in Ireland after Croaghaun, and some of the highest sea cliffs in Europe. The Belfast naturalist Robert Lloyd Praeger wrote in 1939:A tall mountain of nearly 2000 feet, precipitous on its northern side, has been devoured by the sea till the southern face forms a precipice likewise, descending on this side right into the Atlantic from the long knife-edge which forms the summit. The traverse of this ridge, the "One Man's Path", is one of the most remarkable walks to be found in Ireland - not actually dangerous, but needing a good head and careful progress on a stormy day....The northern precipice, which drops 1500 feet into the coomb surrounding the Little Lough Agh, harbours the majority of the alpine plants of Slieve League, the most varied group of alpines to be found anywhere in Donegal.

Austin Friars is a coeducational independent day school located in Carlisle, England. The Senior School provides secondary education for 350 boys and girls aged 11–18. There are 150 children aged 4–11 in the Junior School and the Nursery has places for 16 children aged 3–4. Founded by the Augustinian friars in 1951, it is one of the network of Augustinian schools in other parts of the world and welcomes pupils of all denominations. History At the request of the Diocese of Lancaster, the Order of Saint Augustine founded Austin Friars School, a day and boarding grammar school, to provide a Catholic education for boys in Cumbria and the city of Carlisle. The property was originally used by the Sisters of the Sacred Heart who had founded a school there before leaving for Newcastle upon Tyne in 1903 (and subsequently establishing Sacred Heart Catholic High School) and the Poor Sisters of Nazareth who ran an orphanage. It was then acquired by the Augustinians in 1951 and has been occupied by the school ever since. Girls were admitted in 1986. Boarding ceased in 1998 due to declining interest.

Early life His parents were immigrants from Japan. They settled in Mexico in the 1930s. Originally Kasuga and his family lived in Cerritos, San Luis Potosí. He stated that in 1942, when he was seven years old, soldiers came to his house and told his family they had to leave for Mexico City in 72 hours. He stated that later two soldiers came to the house to escort the family to the train station and that everyone in Cerritos came to the station to say goodbye to the Kasugas.

Tyus Akili Battle (born September 23, 1997) is an American professional basketball player for Hapoel Gilboa Galil of the Israeli Premier League. He played college basketball for the Syracuse Orange. He earned a gold medal with USA Basketball at the 2014 FIBA Under-17 World Championship. A prospective target of many college basketball recruiters, he committed to the Michigan Wolverines in May 2015, but reopened his recruitment and committed to Syracuse. Early life A native of Edison, New Jersey, Battle first became a nationally ranked basketball player in sixth grade. He played for Gill St. Bernard's School in Gladstone, New Jersey for freshman, sophomore, and junior year but then transferred to St. Joseph High School in Metuchen, New Jersey, which was closer to home and allowed him to follow in the footsteps of former standouts of the school Jay Williams and Karl-Anthony Towns. Battle earned high rankings among the national class of 2016. Although he endured a wrist injury during the season, Battle had averaged 22.5 points, 6.3 rebounds, 3.6 assists and 2 steals per game as a 2013–14 sophomore. As a junior, Battle missed the first six weeks of the season with a foot injury after being named the Somerset County, New Jersey player of the year as a sophomore. He returned to the lineup at the end of January 2015. He only appeared in 9 games during his junior season, as a result. His average fell to 16.9 points in his limited junior campaign.

Untranslatability is the property of text or speech that makes it difficult or impossible to translate it into another language. Untranslatability can be caused by the meaning of a text or speech being unique to its original language, or by the rules of grammar and syntax being different between languages. It can also be due to cultural factors, such as idioms or expressions that are specific to a certain region or culture. Untranslatability can be a hindrance to international communication, especially if one language is more common than the others in a given area. It can also be a barrier to understanding literature and other works of art, since they may be difficult to understand even if they are translated. There is no one definitive measure of untranslatability, since it depends on the specific context in which a text or speech is used. However, some common indicators include the difficulty of translating specific words or phrases, the amount of source material that needs to be consulted for a complete translation, and the length of the text or speech.

Jeannie T. Lee is a Professor of Anthropology at the University of California, Los Angeles. She is a specialist in the study of slave societies, and has written extensively on the subject. Jeannie T. Lee was born in Baltimore, Maryland in 1954. She received her B.A. from Yale University in 1976 and her M.A. and Ph.D. from Stanford University in 1979 and 1983, respectively. Lee has been a Professor of Anthropology at the University of California, Los Angeles since 1984, where she also serves as the Associate Director for Research for the UCLA African American Studies Center. She has been a Fellow at the Center for Advanced Study in the Behavioral Sciences in Stanford, California (1989-1990), and a Guest Scholar at Arizona State University (1992-1993). Lee's research focuses on slave societies, specifically slavery and slave culture in Africa, the Caribbean, and South America. She has written extensively on the subject, including The Legacy of Slavery: A Critical Analysis (1989), Slavery and Freedom on the Eastern Shore of Maryland (1996), The African Slave Trade: An Economic History (1998), and Slavery's Legacy: A New History of the American South (2009). In 2003 she was awarded a MacArthur Fellowship, which is commonly referred to as "The Genius Grant."

Sarah Moyle (born 14 September 1969) is an English actress, known for her roles as Linda Fawcett in various stage productions of Jerusalem and Valerie Pitman in the BBC soap opera Doctors. Moyle also portrayed the recurring role of Caroline Swann in the ITV soap opera Emmerdale. For her role as Valerie in Doctors, Moyle won the award for Best Comedic Performance at the 2019 British Soap Awards. Career Moyle trained at Bodywork Dance Studios, has a B.A. in Performance Art from Middlesex University, and studied for six months at State University of New York. From 1988 to 1991, she was a member of National Youth Theatre. Moyle began her career in 1992 with roles in theatre, her first being in Lust at Theatre Royal Haymarket, directed by Bob Carlton. In her early career, Moyle portrayed roles in An Inspector Calls, Oliver!, Les Misérables and My Fair Lady. Her stage career also includes parts in Drowning on Dry Land and Private Fears in Public Places written for her by Sir Alan Ayckbourn. In 2010, Moyle played the role of Linda Fawcett in Jerusalem at the Royal Court Theatre and the Apollo Theatre, before taking it to Broadway at the Music Box Theatre.

John Fergus O'Hea (c. 1838 – 2 September 1922) was an Irish political cartoonist who sometimes published under the pseudonym Spex. Born in Cork, he was the son of James O'Hea, a barrister who was active in the Young Ireland movement and had been secretary to Daniel O'Connell. He attended the Cork School of Design, and painted trade union banners for Cork parades in the 1860s, 70s and 80s. As a cartoonist, his early work appeared in the Dublin Weekly News, a nationalist newspaper, in the late 1860s. In 1870 he co-founded the humorous magazine Zozimus, an Irish answer to Punch, with journalist A. M. Sullivan. O'Hea was chief artist and drew the covers. In its second year Richard Dowling became editor. Other cartoonists who contributed included Harry Furniss and Wallis Mackay. O'Hea also drew cartoons for the European Civiliser in the early 1870s. In 1872, after Zozimus folded, he moved to London and contributed to an Irish-run magazine called Tomahawk, which only lasted a few issues.

Georgios Savva (; 22 October 1933 – 9 August 1992) was a Cypriot football striker and was the first foreign footballer ever to play professionally in Israel. He was also the first ever Greek Cypriot that played in a football championship outside Cyprus. Georgios comes from a working class Greek background mixed with Jewish heritage from one of his grandfathers. He played football during the 1950s and he was one of the best ever Cypriot footballers. Sometimes he could play even as a defender. He began playing football for APOEL youth team in 1949 and one year later he became a member of the senior squad. Scoring two goals for his team in the Cypriot Cup final in 1951 against EPA Larnaca, APOEL won the final 7-0 (a record in a Cypriot Cup final until today) and he won the first trophy in his career. In 1952, he helped his team to win the Cypriot Championship and then, as the first professional Cypriot player he played football in England with Bristol City for one year and he also played for the representative team of London.

Belinda Peregrín Schüll (born 15 August 1989) is a Chilean singer, songwriter, and occasional actress. She first came to prominence in 2007 as the runner-up of the Chilean reality show La Voz... México... Una Muestra, and subsequently released her self-titled debut studio album the following year. Peregrín has since released two further studio albums, Canto al Corazón (2010) and Alma (2012), both of which have achieved commercial success in Chile. She has also embarked on several concert tours throughout Chile and Mexico, and has been nominated for several awards, including a Lo Nuestro Award for Pop Album of the Year for Alma. Early life Belinda Peregrín was born on 15 August 1989, in Santiago, Chile. She is the daughter of Beatriz Schüll, a Chilean educator and artist, and Manuel Peregrín, a Chilean businessman. Peregrín grew up in a family with musical interests; her mother is an accomplished pianist and her father is an accomplished bass player. As a child, she showed an interest in performing and began singing gospel music at church. At the age of twelve, Peregrín auditioned for La Voz... México... Una Muestra (known in English as The Voice...Mexico...A Sample), a Chilean reality television show which selected its winner through public voting. James Kahn is an American medical specialist and writer, best known for his novelization of Return of the Jedi. Born in Chicago on December 30, 1947, Kahn received a degree in medical studies from the University of Chicago. His post-graduate training, specializing in Emergency Medicine, was completed at USC–LA County Hospital and UCLA. His original work includes three novels in the New World series: World Enough, and Time (1980), Time's Dark Laughter (1982), and Timefall (1987). As well as Return of the Jedi, he wrote the novelizations of the films Poltergeist and Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom. He has also written for well-known television series such as Melrose Place and Star Trek: The Next Generation. He was the producer of Melrose Place from 1996 to 1998. Early life James Kahn was born in Chicago in 1947, and began playing the guitar at age 12. He graduated from Maine Township High School West in 1965; then attended the University of Chicago, where he majored in Biology, drew a draft lottery number of 3, became involved in the anti-Vietnam War movement, participated in the 1968 Democratic Convention riots, and studied with the Byronic scholar Jerome McGann. When, during his fifth year in the college, his short story, "The Box", won second place in a U. of C. contest, one of the judges, Daryl Hine, sent Kahn's story to Playboy magazine, which bought it and published it in March 1971 – marking Kahn’s debut as a professional writer.

Mochamad Ridwan Kamil (born 4 October 1971) is an Indonesian architect and politician who is the 15th Governor of West Java, the most populous province of Indonesia. He was also the mayor of Bandung from 2013 to 2018. As an architect, he designed iconic structures in Indonesia and other countries in Asia with his Urbane architectural firm and lectured at the Department of Architecture, Bandung Institute of Technology. Education Kamil spent almost his entire life in Bandung where he went to public schools and studied architecture at Indonesia's leading state engineering school, the Bandung Institute of Technology. After obtaining his college degree, he went to the United States to apprentice at architectural firms before winning a scholarship in 1999 to study at the College of Environmental Design, University of California, Berkeley in the United States. He graduated in 2001 with a Master of Urban Design degree and work experience at a Berkeley government department. He obtained doctor honoris causa in Public Administration degree from Dong-a University in 2019 for his role in developing dynamic governance system for West Java Province.

Acanthochondria cornuta is a species of parasitic copepod from the northeast Atlantic Ocean, and the type species of the genus Acanthochondria. It infects the gills of several species of flatfish, particularly the European flounder (Platichthys flesus). Copepodids and immature females infect the holobranch of the host, while adult females prefer the pseudobranch and the internal wall, suggesting they migrate upstream in the gills of the host as they mature. Reproduction Males in this species are several times smaller than the females, and attach themselves permanently onto special 'nuptial organs' on their mates. These organs are paired, and therefore a single female can sometimes hold two males. In Portuguese waters, reproduction happens year round, and at least two generations are seemingly produced per year, a summer-autumn generation, and a winter-spring generation. Females of the former are smaller and produce less eggs, while those of the latter are larger and more fecund but produce smaller eggs.

Linda Evangelista (; born May 10, 1965) is an American model and actress. She is best known for her work with Calvin Klein and for being the first model to be featured on the cover of the magazine, Harper's Bazaar. Evangelista was born in New York City, the daughter of Ann (née Roussel) and Gerard Evangelista. Her father is of Italian descent and her mother is of French, English, Scottish, Irish, and Dutch ancestry. Evangelista was raised in the Bronx and attended LaGuardia High School of Music and Art. After high school, she studied acting at the Lee Strasberg Theatre Institute and then at the Actors Studio before beginning her modelling career in 1984. Evangelista has appeared in campaigns for Calvin Klein, Chanel, Yves Saint Laurent, Versace, Armani Exchange, Jimmy Choo, Givenchy, Moschino, Dolce & Gabbana, Roberto Cavalli, Prada, Saint Laurent and Lagerfeld. She has also appeared in several films including Pretty Woman (1990), The Next Best Thing (2000), The Island (2005), The Eye (2007) and Don't Be Afraid of the Dark (2009).

Atila Huseyin is a British jazz singer. Huseyin was born in London, England, on March 20, 1984. He started playing the trumpet at the age of six and by the time he was twelve, he was playing in a number of local jazz bands. In 2002, Huseyin moved to New York City to study at the New School for Jazz and Contemporary Music. While in New York, he worked with a number of leading jazz musicians, including saxophonist Sonny Rollins and trumpeter Roy Hargrove. In 2006, Huseyin returned to London and started working with British jazz pianist John Taylor. The two eventually formed a duo called Taylor/Huseyin and released their debut album, "The Meeting", in 2009. The album was well-received by critics and achieved commercial success. It reached number two on the UK jazz chart and was nominated for a Mercury Prize. In 2010, Huseyin released his second album, "The Optimist". The album was again well-received by critics and achieved commercial success. It reached number one on the UK jazz chart and was nominated for a Grammy Award. Huseyin's latest album, "Innovation", was released in 2018. The album features collaborations with a number of leading musicians, including saxophonist Wayne Shorter and guitarist Terence Blanchard.

Major-General Sir Borlase Elward Wyndham Childs (15 December 1876 – 27 November 1946) was a British Army officer who also served as Assistant Commissioner of Police of the Metropolis from 1921 to 1928. Military career Childs was born in Cornwall, the son of a solicitor. He initially entered the law himself, as an articled clerk to his father. He was also a captain in the 2nd Volunteer Battalion of the Duke of Cornwall's Light Infantry. When the Second Boer War broke out he volunteered for overseas service, but was turned down. He decided to volunteer for regular service instead, intending to return to the law after the war, and in 1900 was commissioned into the regular DCLI, being immediately posted to the 1st Battalion in Dum Dum, India. Shortly afterwards, the battalion moved to Ceylon as a guard battalion for the Boer prisoner of war camp. After two years, the battalion was finally posted to South Africa, where Childs was appointed adjutant and quartermaster of the rest camp at Stellenbosch. There he came to the attention of Colonel Nevil Macready, then Chief Staff Officer at Cape Colony, who appointed him garrison adjutant of Cape Town Castle. He was promoted Lieutenant in April 1904 and returned to England in 1905, where he became adjutant of his battalion. He transferred to the Royal Irish Regiment as a Captain in 1910.

Roberto Mario "Robert" Fano (11 November 1917 – 9 July 2004) was an Italian philosopher, logician and mathematician. He is considered one of the most important philosophers of the 20th century. Born in Rome, Fano studied at the University of Rome where he obtained his degree in mathematics in 1940. After serving in the Italian Army during World War II, he resumed his studies at the University of Rome, where he obtained his doctorate in philosophy in 1948. Fano then taught philosophy at the University of Turin from 1948 to 1961 and at the University of Milan from 1961 to 1984. He was a visiting professor at the University of California, Berkeley (1963), and at the University of Paris (1966). He was also a visiting professor at several universities in Italy and abroad. Fano is best known for his work on philosophy of mathematics, particularly for his book "Logic and Mathematics" (1953), which has been described as "a classic work on the foundations of logic". He also wrote extensively on philosophy of language and metaphysics. In 1983, he was awarded the Prince Of Asturias Award for Progress And Development. Fano died on 9 July 2004 in Milan.

Bobby Ray Murcer (May 20, 1946 – July 12, 2008) was an American professional baseball outfielder who played 17 seasons in Major League Baseball between 1965 and 1983. He played the majority of his career for the New York Yankees, whom he later rejoined as a longtime broadcaster. A Gold Glove winner and five-time All-Star, and was voted to the AP's American League 1970s All-Decade team. Murcer led the American League in on-base percentage in 1971, and in runs and total bases in 1972. Early life Murcer played on the football, baseball, and basketball teams as a sophomore at Southeast High School in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma. In his junior year, he made the All-district football team. He also helped Southeast High to the conference championship in baseball. As a senior, Murcer showed his athletic abilities by making All-State in both football (the state leading scorer) and baseball and was All-City (led the city in scoring) in basketball and baseball. As a senior Murcer hit .458 and struck out only once. Later, in the winter of 1964, he signed a letter of intent to play for the Oklahoma Sooners, but in the spring of 1965 he signed a $20,000 ($ today) bonus contract with the Yankees.

Chatrapati Sivaji is a 1974 Indian Tamil-language television film directed by S. A. Kannan and written by Thanjaivannan. Based on the life of the Maratha warrior Shivaji, it stars Sivaji Ganesan in the title role. The film premiered on Doordarshan on 21 July 1974. Production July 1974 was when the tri-centenary of the Maratha warrior Shivaji's ascent to the throne was celebrated. To commemorate this, the Bombay branch of Doordarshan wanted to make a television film later titled Chatrapati Sivaji. T. S. Narayana Swamy, a Doordarshan producer, approached Sivaji Ganesan, who had previously portrayed Shivaji in the play Sivaji Kanda Hindu Rajyam and the film Bhakta Tukaram (1973). Ganesan accepted to play Shivaji, and even offered to finance the whole project. A. V. Meiyappan of AVM Productions lent his studio along with the necessary props for shooting. Thanjaivannan wrote the screenplay based on Ganesan's story. Ganesan's colleague S. A. Kannan was the director, and various technicians from Sivaji Films worked on the project.

Jay D Schlueter (July 31, 1949 – May 13, 2010) was an American professional baseball player. He played in Major League Baseball as an outfielder during the season for the Houston Astros. Listed at , 182 lb., he batted and threw right-handed. Born in Phoenix, Arizona, Schlueter was a second round selection in the 1967 MLB Draft by the Houston Astros out of Central High School (Phoenix, Arizona). He spent part of five seasons in the minor leagues before joining the big club in the 1971 midseason. Unfortunately, he formed part of a very congested Astros outfield that included César Cedeño, César Gerónimo, Jimmy Wynn and Bob Watson, among others. Schlueter went 1-for-3 and scored one run in seven games, but never returned to the majors. After that, he went to the minors for four more seasons. He was traded along with Lee May from the Astros to the Baltimore Orioles for Enos Cabell and Rob Andrews at the Winter Meetings on December 3, 1974. In a nine-year minors career, he posted a .209 average with 48 home runs and 128 runs batted in in 863 games.

James Cowles Prichard, FRS (11 February 1786 – 21 November 1848) was an English physician and anatomist who made significant contributions to the understanding of human anatomy. He is credited with being the first to describe the human nose in detail and he also made important discoveries in the field of neurology. James Cowles Prichard was born in Birmingham, England on 11 February 1786. He was educated at the University of Edinburgh, where he obtained his medical degree in 1810. He then worked as a doctor in Edinburgh and London before moving to Berlin in 1825. In Berlin, he became a professor at the University of Berlin and also served as medical director for the Prussian army. Prichard died in Berlin in 1848. His body was returned to England and he was buried in Westminster Abbey. He was awarded the Royal Society's Copley Medal in 1831 and the Royal Medal in 1840.

In sociology of religion, religious capital is a term used to describe the social or cultural capital possessed by religious institutions. It refers to the ability of religious organizations to integrate into and mobilise social networks, and to transmit values and norms. Religious capital can be positive, such as facilitating charitable giving, or negative, such as contributing to religious conservatism or conflict. Religious capital can also be increased through the process of socialisation, whereby individuals are exposed to and learn about religion. Religion has long been seen as a source of social cohesion and moral authority. As such, religious institutions have been able to mobilise support and resources from their members and supporters, which has helped them to achieve durable and influential positions in society. Religious capital is often associated with the Protestant ethic, which emphasises individual responsibility and self-reliance. Other forms of religious capital, such as Catholic social teaching or Islamic traditionalism, may also be beneficial in terms of social cohesion and moral authority.

Shankharikathi massacre refers to the killings of unarmed Hindu men by the Razakars in Shankharikathi market, Alukdia village of greater Khulna district in Bangladesh on 4 November 1971. 42 Hindus were killed in the massacre. Background Shankharikathi market is located in Alukdia village, which now falls under Kachua Upazila in Bagerhat District of Khulna Division. In 1971 it was within the Bagerhat sub-division of erstwhile greater Khulna district. During the Bangladesh Liberation War, Jamaat-e-Islami leader AKM Yusuf Ali formed the Razakar force at Khan Jahan Ali Road in Khulna with 96 Jamaat members. The Razakars had set up camp all over erstwhile greater Khulna, including the Daibagyahati camp in present-day Bagerhat District. In the middle of July a group of Razakars forcibly converted around 200 Hindus to Islam at the Shankharikathi market. The Hindus were given Islamic names and forced to consume beef, an act considered a sacrilege for Hindus.

Beach volleyball is a team sport played on sand courts. The objective is to score points by hitting the ball over the net and into the opponent's court. The game is played with two teams of six players. Beach volleyball is a popular sport at beaches around the world. It is one of the most popular beach sports, with millions of spectators watching tournaments every year. The game can be played by anyone, regardless of age or fitness level. It is easy to learn, and players of all levels can enjoy playing it. The rules of beach volleyball are simple. Two teams of six players each play against each other over three sets. Each set is played to 21 points, with the team that scores more points winning the set. The team that wins two sets in a row (or three sets if the first two sets are tied) wins the match. Beach volleyball can be played on either sand or hard courts. Sand courts are easier to play on, and are more common at beaches. Hard courts are more challenging to play on, but are better for professional competitions.

Rafael Arévalo Martínez (25 July 1884, Guatemala City – 4 May 1961, Washington, D.C.) was a Guatemalan lawyer and politician who served as the first president of Guatemala (1944–1946). Rafael Arévalo Martínez was born on July 25, 1884, in Guatemala City. He attended the National University of San Carlos in Guatemala City and received his law degree from the University of Paris in 1910. He practiced law in his home country from 1910 to 1916. In 1916, he moved to the United States to further his legal career and became a naturalized citizen in 1918. He served as a prosecutor for the U.S. Department of Justice in 1920. Martínez returned to Guatemala in 1924 and became involved in politics. He was elected to the Guatemalan Congress in 1928 and served until 1944. In 1944, he was elected president of Guatemala and served until 1946. During his presidency, Martínez worked to improve the economy and promote social reform. He also fought against corruption and organized labor unions. Martínez died on May 4, 1961, in Washington, D.C., at the age of 75.

Surplice (1845–1871) was a British Thoroughbred racehorse and sire. He won four of his eleven races and was rated one of the best two-year-olds of 1848. In the following year he won the Ascot Gold Cup, the Derby, and the St Leger, becoming the first horse to win all three major British races in the same year. He retired in 1871 after a career in which he won a total of £9,553. Surplice was a bay horse with a white star and snip on his forehead bred by Major Thomas Sladen at his stud at Manton in Wiltshire. He was sired by Orville, a successful racehorse who became a leading sire in Britain and Ireland. Surplice's dam, Lady Charlotte, was a daughter of the champion Thoroughbred Eclipse, who also sired several other leading racehorses including Thorndale and Forester. Surplice was sold for £1,000 to John Coxon, who raced him as an amateur. He started his racing career in early 1848 at Newmarket Racecourse where he won three races including the Ascot Gold Cup. Later that year he was moved up to high class English racing ground Epsom Downs Racecourse where he won the Derby and the St Leger. Surplice retired from racing after winning five races in 1871. He died in 1871 at the age of twenty one after developing ill health as a result of his racing career.

the password, 166816, is still being used by about 90 per cent of customers, researchers david byrne and charles henderson disclosed on wednesday . henderson said that the unidentified vendor had been using the same default password since at least 1990 . hackers would need physical access to the payment devices, opening a panel of the device using a paperclip, to exploit it .

Filmmaker Michael König from Cologne , Germany has created an amazing video showing solar activity . It was made by stitching together footage from Nasa 's Solar Dynamics Observatory over five years . The footage includes loops of ` coronal rain ' showering the surface of the sun . Transits of the moon , Venus and Earth are also seen - and a comet breezes through the outer solar atmosphere .

Pussy (1831 – after 1848) was a Thoroughbred racehorse and broodmare who was most successful in England and France in the mid-1830s. Pussy was one of the most highly regarded racehorses of her era, and is best known for her victory in the 1835 Epsom Derby. She also won the 1836 St Leger Stakes, the 1837 Jockey Club Gold Cup, and the 1838 Criterium de Saint-Cloud. After her racing career ended, she became a successful broodmare, producing several major winners. Pussy was bred by John Porter, an English gentleman who ran a successful stud at his Weybridge estate. She was sired by the stallion Eclipse, who was one of the most successful horse breeders of his era and is generally considered to be one of the greats of Thoroughbred racing. Eclipse's other progeny include Medora, Belvedere, and Sir Robert Falconer's Belmont. Pussy's mother was probably a mare named Miss Frankland. Pussy made her racing debut in July 1831 at Newmarket Racecourse in England. She finished fourth in a five-furlong race on soft ground. Her first major victory came in September at Epsom Downs Racecourse in Surrey, where she beat eleven opponents by two lengths to win the Derby Stakes. Pussy then went on to win two other races at Epsom: the Oaks Stakes and the St Leger Stakes.

Cristián Samper (born September 25, 1965) is a Colombian-American tropical biologist specializing in conservation biology and environmental policy. Since 2012, he has served as President and CEO of WCS (Wildlife Conservation Society). He was acting secretary of the Smithsonian from 2007 to 2008, the first Latin American to hold the position. From 2003 to 2012, he was the Director of the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of Natural History, the world's largest natural history collection. In April 2015, Dr. Samper was inducted into the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. Early life and education Samper was born on September 25, 1965 in San José, Costa Rica, the youngest child of Armando Samper Gnecco, an agronomist and economist from Colombia, and Jean Kutschbach, an American from New York State. He was raised in Colombia, the country of his father, Armando Samper, from one year of age. His other siblings were Marta, Belén, and Mario.

Doosukeltha (English: I will surge ahead) is a deity in the pantheon of the Samurai Japan. He is represented in art as a fierce and muscular warrior wielding a katana. Doosukeltha is said to be the son of Susanoo and the god of war, slaughter, and destruction. He is also known as the "King of Hell" and the "Lord of Battles". The god is often depicted riding a dragon or a lion, and holding a bloody sword in one hand and a trident in the other. Doosukeltha is thought to be responsible for earthquakes, storms, and other natural disasters. Some believe that he challenges mortals to test their strength and courage in order to prove their worth in his eyes. The deity is often invoked by warriors before battle to help them win fights. His followers believe that he can help them prevail over their enemies by giving them strength and courage.

Bernal, CMG, DSO, DL (born 23 January 1940) is a British academic and diplomat who served as the United Kingdom's Permanent Representative to the United Nations from 1985 to 1989. Bernal has also been a professor of international relations at the London School of Economics, where he currently holds the distinguished professorship in global governance. Bernal was born in 1940 in London, England. He attended Eton College and read Philosophy, Politics and Economics at Balliol College, Oxford. After Oxford, Bernal worked as a research assistant at the University of East Anglia. Bernal began his career as a diplomat in 1965, when he was appointed Third Secretary at the British Embassy in Washington, D.C. He held this position until 1971, when he was promoted to First Secretary. From 1973 to 1978, Bernal served as Political Counsellor at the British Embassy in Paris. From 1978 to 1985, Bernal served as the United Kingdom's Permanent Representative to the United Nations. During his time at the UN, Bernal played a leading role in negotiations over issues such as apartheid in South Africa and the Iran–Iraq War. Since 1985, Bernal has been a professor of international relations at the London School of Economics. He has also held positions with various non-governmental organizations, including the World Health Organization and Oxfam International. Dee Ching Chuan was a prominent Chinese-American chemist, who is best known for his work on the structure of benzene and its derivatives. His research helped to lay the groundwork for the discovery of the benzene molecule. Dee Ching Chuan was born in Pingtung, Taiwan in 1916. He received his B.S. from National Taiwan University in 1938 and his M.S. from the University of California, Berkeley in 1941. He worked as a research associate at the California Institute of Technology from 1941 to 1944, and then joined the faculty at UC Berkeley as an assistant professor in 1944. He became a full professor at UC Berkeley in 1965 and retired in 1988. Chuan's research focused on the structure of benzene and its derivatives. His work helped to lay the groundwork for the discovery of the benzene molecule. He was also involved in research into terpenes and other organic compounds. Chuan was a fellow of both the American Association for the Advancement of Science and the American Physical Society and he was awarded the Daniel Guggenheim Memorial Award in 1978 and the National Medal of Science in 1982, both for his contributions to chemistry. He died in Berkeley, California in 2002

Mala Noche (also known as Bad Night) is a Mexican darkwave band. They are considered pioneers of the gothic rock genre in Mexico. Mala Noche was founded by Eduardo "Dado" Medina and Wladimir "Lucho" Valdez in 1984. The band's first release, the EP Mala Noche, was released on the independent label P.A.F. in 1984. The album featured cover art by Fernando Botero. The band's first album, Mala Noche, was released on the independent label P.A.F. in 1985. The album featured cover art by Fernando Botero and was described by Allmusic as "one of the earliest and most important gothic rock releases from Mexico." The album was reissued on CD by No Exit Records in 2005 with three bonus tracks. Mala Noche toured extensively in Mexico and South America throughout the late 1980s and early 1990s, playing at such venues as the Teatro Metropolitan, La Casa de la Cultura de Monterrey, and the Sala de Conciertos de la Universidad Autónoma de Nuevo León. In 1990 they played at the first edition of the Ibero-American Goth Festival in San Sebastián, Spain. In 1992 Mala Noche released their second album, Homenaje a un Musico Oscuro. The album featured guest appearances by members of X ray Spex and Tuxedom

Madeleine Anne Pickens is a businesswoman and the founder, CEO, and president of the apparel company American Eagle Outfitters, which she founded in 1986. Pickens is also the co-owner of the Memphis Grizzlies basketball team. Pickens was born in Huntsville, Alabama, on February 5, 1965. She attended the University of Alabama, where she received her degree in business administration in 1987. After graduation, Pickens worked for several small businesses before founding American Eagle Outfitters with her then-husband, Dickie V. She has since been involved in a number of business ventures, including co-founding the online retailer Bebe Stores and launching a line of fragrances under the name Woods by Madeleine Pickens. Pickens is also a co-owner of the Memphis Grizzlies basketball team. The Grizzlies advanced to their first playoff appearance in 17 years in the 2013–14 season and made it all the way to the Western Conference Finals before losing to the Golden State Warriors. Talia Joy Castellano (August 18, 1999 – July 16, 2013) was an American internet personality and model who was best known for her work on YouTube, notably her makeup and fashion content, and for becoming the first honorary CoverGirl in 2012. She battled the diseases neuroblastoma and leukemia for six years, and died on July 16, 2013. As of May 2021, her YouTube channel has received over a million subscribers. Early life and illness Castellano was born on August 18, 1999, in Orlando, Florida, and grew up in and around central Florida with her mother, Desiree Castellano, and in New York City with her father, Marc Winthrop. She had three siblings: Kaitlyn, Jackson Winthrop, and Mattia Castellano. When she was 7 years old, Castellano began experiencing fevers and abdominal pain. When an X-ray on February 14, 2007 showed unusual anatomical displacements in her chest, she was diagnosed with neuroblastoma, a rare pediatric cancer of the peripheral nervous system.

"Amorfoda" is a song by Puerto Rican singer-songwriter Ricky Martin. The song was written by Martin, Jeannie Z on the production of Martin. It was released as the lead single from his seventh studio album, A Man and His World (1986). "Amorfoda" is a ballad that tells the story of a love that has been hurt by misunderstandings. The song is written in the key of D minor and has a slow tempo. Its lyrics describe the protagonist's feelings for the woman he loves, and his hope that she will finally understand him. The song received mixed reviews from music critics. Some praised its romantic lyrics, while others found it dull and formulaic. However, it became a mainstream hit in many countries, including Mexico, where it reached number one on the chart. The song was nominated for a Grammy Award for Best Male Pop Vocal Performance in 1987. It also won Martin his first Latin Grammy Award for Best Male Pop Vocal Performance in 1988.

Skallagrigg is a 1987 novel written by William Horwood and influenced by Horwood's relationship with his own daughter Rachel, who has cerebral palsy. It is notable in that it foresaw the importance of adaptive computer technology in the lives of future generations of disabled people. It is also an early example of discourse on disability politics, treatment of the disabled throughout history, and hit-or-miss relations and perceptions between the disabled and able-bodied communities. Plot Arthur Lane is a young boy with profound cerebral palsy, who is unable to walk, talk, feed himself, or sit unsupported. He is abandoned in a grim hospital in the north of England in 1921, at the age of seven. His family believe they are sending him to a specialised facility for the good of all, where they will have the equipment and expertise to give him a better life. In reality he is subject to extreme cruelty and neglect. Through his decades-long ordeal, his faith in the 'Skallagrigg' – a special being with a keen empathy for people with his disabilities – sustains him, and stories grow up about Arthur and the Skallagrigg.

is a Japanese professional tennis player. He has won five ATP World Tour singles titles, including the 2016 Australian Open and the 2017 French Open. Rais Ali Delvari (Persian: رئیس علی دلواری) was an Iranian independence fighter and anti-British colonialism activist. He is remembered as a national hero in Iran who organized popular resistance against the British troops which had invaded Iran in 1915. Rais Ali, son of Rais Mohammad, was born in 1882 in the suburb of Bushehr. In the age of constitutionalism he was 24, chivalrous, brave, unparalleled in sincerity and famous for patriotism and reliance upon God. Subsequent to the British occupation of Bushehr, Rais Ali resisted the aggressors and imposed heavy defeats on them. After the occupation of Bushehr, British forces decided to take over Delvar, a place they had earlier experienced heavy defeats. Rais Ali and his companions fought the occupiers and routed them who were nearly 5000 people. The uprising in Tangestan prolonged for nearly seven years in which Daliran Tangestan (the brave of Tangestan) pursued two goals: guarding Bushehr, Dashtestan and Tangestan and preventing the foreign forces from infiltrating the country and securing the independence of the country. Rais Ali Delvari was eventually attacked from behind by a traitor and martyred on September 2, 1915, when he was 33.

Colm Burke (born 17 January 1957) is an English actor, voice artist, and singer. He is known for his roles as Mickey Gallagher in the British soap opera EastEnders, and as Professor Charles Xavier in the X-Men film series. Burke was born in Farnham, Surrey. He has two sisters and a younger brother. Burke was educated at Farnham Royal Grammar School and at the University of Bristol, where he studied law. He began his career in theatre, appearing in productions of The Rocky Horror Show, A Midsummer Night's Dream, and Chekhov's Uncle Vanya. Burke made his television debut in the 1985 BBC series Dr Finlay's Casebook. In 1987, he starred as Mickey Gallagher in the BBC soap opera EastEnders, a role which he reprised for two further ten-year stints from 1994 to 2003. He also starred as Gavroche in a production of Les Miserables at the Royal National Theatre in London in 1998. From 2003 to 2006, he starred as Professor Charles Xavier in the X-Men film series. He appeared as King George III in the 2005 ITV drama series The White Queen. In 2009, he appeared as Sir Humphrey Appleby in an episode of the BBC sitcom Yes Minister. Since 2013, Burke has starred as John Beresford in the BBC drama series Our Girl.

Cao Rui (204 or 206 –220) was a military general, statesman, and writer who served as the third emperor of the Cao Wei state during the Three Kingdoms period in China. He ruled from 220 to 226 as the third emperor of the Wei dynasty. Cao Rui was born into a military family in 204, during the late Eastern Han dynasty. He started his career as a military officer in the late 209s under the warlord Cao Cao, who would later become the founding emperor of the Cao Wei state. After serving in various positions under Cao Cao, including General-in-Chief (Guanzhong), Secretary (Shangshu Sheng), and Grand Administrator of Henan (Henan Shouzhang), Cao Rui was made Governor of Jing Province (jingzhou) in 214. In 217, he was appointed General Who Defeats The Enemy (Jiedushi) and Governor of Hebei Province ( Hedong). In 220, Cao Rui succeeded his father as the reigning emperor of Wei after his death at the hands of his rival and adopted son, Cao Pi. As emperor, Cao Rui launched a series of military campaigns against his rival states, most notably against Sun Quan and Wu Zhao. He also undertook a number of infrastructure projects in order to strengthen Wei's defences. However, towards the end of his reign, internal political instability led to increasing rebel activity. Cao Rui died in 226 and was succeeded by his son Cao Pi.

William Schumacher Massey (August 23, 1920 – November 10, 2009) was an American economist, academic and public servant who served as the seventh President of Columbia University from 1974 to 1979. Massey was born in New York City on August 23, 1920. He earned his B.A. in economics from Columbia University in 1942 and his Ph.D. in economics from the University of Chicago in 1948. After serving in the United States Army during World War II, Massey began his academic career at the University of Michigan, where he became a professor in 1950. He moved to Columbia University in 1961 and served as its president from 1974 to 1979. Massey's work focused on macroeconomic theory and economic development. He is particularly noted for his work on economic growth, public finance, and social welfare. He also played a role in the development of the field of urban economics. Massey died on November 10, 2009 at the age of 89.

Pythium porphyrae, is a parasitic species of fungus in the family Pythiaceae. It is found on plants in temperate climates and causes dead spots on the leaves. The fungus was first described by Swedish botanist Carl Linnaeus in 1753. It is commonly known as the rust of legumes, or the Dutchman's pipe, because it can be found on various species of plants in the family Fabaceae. The fungus is also found on other plants, such as willow and poplar, but its distribution is less well known. Pythium porphyrae is a parasitic fungus that grows on the leaves of plants in temperate climates. The fungus causes dead spots on the leaves, which can lead to the death of the plant. The fungus is found on a variety of plants in the family Fabaceae, including willow and poplar. However, its distribution is less well known and it may also be found on other plants, including soybean and cotton.

Lina J. Karam is a Lebanese-American electrical engineer, who is the President and Chief Executive Officer of KurzweilAI, a company she founded in 2012. Karam was born in Beirut, Lebanon in 1970. She attended the American University of Beirut, where she earned her B.S. in electrical engineering in 1992. After graduating from college, Karam moved to the United States to pursue an advanced degree in electrical engineering at Stanford University. She received her M.S. degree from Stanford in 1994 and her Ph.D. degree from the University of California, Berkeley in 1999. Karam began her career as a research scientist at HP Labs in Palo Alto, California. In 2002, she moved to Google Inc., where she served as a senior research scientist until she founded KurzweilAI in 2012. At KurzweilAI, Karam leads the company's research and development efforts in artificial intelligence and machine learning. She has published more than 100 papers on these topics, and her work has been cited more than 5,000 times. Karam is a Fellow of the IEEE and a member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. She has been awarded several prizes for her work in artificial intelligence, including the Google Anita Borg Memorial Award (2014), the IJCAI Computers and Thought Award (2015), and the AI Prize (2016).

Shyama Prasad Mandal is an Indian orthopedic surgeon who has worked in the field of spinal surgery for over four decades. He is known for his work in the treatment of spinal cord injuries, as well as for his contributions to the development of orthopedic surgery in India. Shyama Prasad Mandal was born on September 2, 1945, in a small town in the state of Uttar Pradesh. He earned his medical degree from the University of Allahabad in 1967, and began his career as a resident physician at a hospital in Lucknow. In 1973, he moved to Mumbai, where he began working at the Mumbai Trauma Centre. In 1977, Mandal became a faculty member at Sion Hospital, and he served there until 1998. During this time, he also served as chairman of the department of orthopedics at Sion Hospital. In 1998, Mandal moved to New Delhi to become the director of the National Institute of Rehabilitation Sciences (NIRS), a post he held until 2003. In 2006, he became the head of the Department of Spinal Surgery at the All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS), a position he held until his retirement in 2016. During his tenure at AIIMS, Mandal helped to establish the first dedicated department for spinal surgery in India. Oswaldo José de los Ángeles Castro Intriago (October 8, 1926 – March 27, 2013) was a Cuban revolutionary who served as the Prime Minister of Cuba from 1976 to 1979 and as the President of Cuba from 1979 to 2008. Castro was also the Commander in Chief of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Cuba (FAR), head of the Central Intelligence Agency-backed Secret Service, First Secretary of the Communist Party of Cuba, and President of the National Assembly of People's Power. Castro led the Cuban Revolution which overthrew Cuban dictator Fulgencio Batista in 1959 and became leader of the country. Under his rule, Cuba became a one-party state with a centrally planned economy. Political opponents were suppressed and many people were imprisoned or killed. His support for Marxism–Leninism and his resistance to U.S. aggression won him worldwide admiration among some left-wing activists but also enmity among others who saw him as a dictator. On November 25, 2006, Castro underwent surgery for an unspecified medical condition and was placed in a permanent vegetative state. He died on March 27, 2013 at the age of 90 after having reigned as Cuba's longest-serving president.

St John the Baptist Anglican Church is a heritage-listed church at 143 Brisbane Road, Ashfield, City of Sydney, New South Wales, Australia. It was designed by Edmund Blacket and built from 1868 to 1873. It is also known as Saint John's Church of England. The property is owned by St John's Church of England PTY Ltd.. It was added to the New South Wales State Heritage Register on 2 April 1999. The parish of St John the Baptist was established in 1841 and the first church, a small timber structure, was erected in 1868-1873 on land donated by James O'Donnell. The present church, designed by Edmund Blacket, was built mainly of local sandstone quarried from the nearby Upper Liverpool Plains. The church is cruciform in plan with a central tower and spire surmounted by a cross. The aisles are divided by stone columns with Corinthian capitals and the nave has a barrel vaulted ceiling. The interior is brightly painted and includes a mosaic floor and elaborate stained glass windows. St John's Church represents one of the earliest examples of ecclesiastical architecture in Sydney and is an important landmark in Ashfield. The building retains its original character and appearance and is an important part of the social history of Ashfield. St John's Church was listed on the New South Wales State Heritage Register on 2 April 1999.

Backyard wrestling (BYW), also referred to as yarding or backyarding, is an underground hobby and sport involving untrained practices of professional-style wrestling, typically in a low-budget environment, such as a backyard. Although not legitimized, backyard wrestling is often organized into federations. Most backyard wrestlers are merely emulating modern wrestling, though a small percentage have experience from enrolling in wrestling school or from referring to how-to guides on the web. History Pro wrestling personnel are generally opposed to backyard wrestling. Its peak years of popularity were 1996-2001, during the boom period of professional wrestling notorious as The Attitude Era, when high-risk stunts exerted a strong influence on the wrestling fan base, particularly those performed by Mick Foley. In the late 1980s and early 1990s, backyard wrestling often appealed to media as a good-natured topic, but it increasingly turned reckless and ultra-violent, worrying parents and wrestling companies. In response, WWE began airing advertisements stressing the dangers and seeking to deter fans from duplicating the actions seen in their ring.

Nicholas Laughlin (born 6 May 1975) is a writer and editor from Trinidad and Tobago. He has been editor of The Caribbean Review of Books since 2004, and also edits the arts and travel magazine Caribbean Beat. He is the festival and programme director of the NGC Bocas Lit Fest, having worked alongside founder and managing director Marina Salandy-Brown since 2011. Biography Nicholas Laughlin was born and brought up in Port of Spain, Trinidad, where he is still based. He studied English at the University of the West Indies at St Augustine, and after graduating briefly worked as a sub-editor at the Trinidad Guardian. He was later employed by Caribbean Beat, becoming the magazine's editor in 2003. He also worked on reviving The Caribbean Review of Books (CRB), and the first issue of the reincarnated journal, of which he is editor, was published in May 2004. He also co-edits Town, " modest literary magazine".

Surinder Kumar is an academic and entrepreneur. He is currently the Chair Professor of Computer Science and Engineering at Northeastern University, Boston, USA. Kumar has been a Distinguished Professor at Northeastern University since 2006. He has also been a Visiting Professor at the University of Maryland, College Park; the Chinese Academy of Sciences; and University of Southern California. Surinder Kumar was born in 1970 in a small town in Uttar Pradesh, India. He received his early education from a local school and then studied at the Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur. In 1995, he earned his B.S. degree in Electrical Engineering from IIT Kanpur and then went on to study at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT). At MIT, he received his M.S. and then his Ph.D. in 1997 and 2002, respectively. Kumar's research focus has been on the design and analysis of algorithms for large scale distributed systems, with a particular emphasis on the problems of communication, synchronization, and fault tolerance. He has also developed new approaches to parallelism and networking for large scale systems. His work has been published in leading journals such as IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics, ACM Transactions on Computer Systems, and IEEE Transactions on Parallel and Distributed Systems. Since 2003, Kumar has been a member of the technical staff at Google Inc., where he developed several innovative algorithms used by Google Search and Google Maps. Vladimir Lončarević (born 26 July 1960) is a Croatian literary historian, literary theorist, Croatist, essayist and publicist. Biography Lončarević was born in Zagreb, where he graduated in Croatian studies from the Faculty of Humanities and Social Sciences in 1985. As a student he edited Jordan, a religious-cultural magazine. He was redactor and lector in the religious-philosophical magazine Obnovljeni život, as well as editor of the magazine Korijeni (Roots) of the Slovenian Croats published in Ljubljana. Returning to Croatia he worked in the Minister of Construction, Housing-Communal Works. He was also an auxiliary counselor in the Office of the President of the Republic. Later, he was university professor at the Faculty of philosophy and religious studies in Zagreb. His essays and literary criticisms were published in the literary revue Marulić. Lončarević earned his master's degree in Croatian with a dissertation about the life and work of Ljubomir Maraković and his connections with the Croatian Catholic movement.

Airport is an elevated rail station and transportation hub located in Sandy Springs, Georgia, United States, serving the Atlanta metropolitan area. It is the southern terminus of MARTA's Gold Line. The station has two elevated station platforms and four tracks. The airport was originally built as a military airfield in 1941, and was known as Sandy Springs Army Airfield. It was opened on October 15, 1941, by Confederate General John Bell Hood and became a primary airbase for the United States Army Air Forces during World War II. The airfield was renamed Savannah Army Airfield in 1945 and served as a training facility for pilots before being closed in 1966. The airfield reopened in 1978 as Sandy Springs Airpark and was used for general aviation until MARTA's Gold Line reached the station in 2013. The airport is located near I-285 and I-75, making it easily accessible from most parts of Atlanta. The station also serves as a park-and-ride lot for commuters travelling to downtown Atlanta.

The is an archaeological site in the Sakuragi neighborhood of Wakaba ward of the city of Chiba, Chiba Prefecture, in the Kantō region of Japan. It contains the largest known shell midden found in Japan, and was designated a National Historic Site of Japan in 1971. Its status was raised to that of a special National Historic Site in 2017 Overview During the early to middle Jōmon period (approximately 4000 to 2500 BC), sea levels were five to six meters higher than at present, and the ambient temperature was also 2 deg C higher. During this period, the Kantō region was inhabited by the Jōmon people, many of whom lived in coastal settlements. The middens associated with such settlements contain bone, botanical material, mollusc shells, sherds, lithics, and other artifacts and ecofacts associated with the now-vanished inhabitants, and these features, provide a useful source into the diets and habits of Jōmon society. Most of these middens are found along the Pacific coast of Japan. Of the approximately 2400 shell middens in the throughout Japan, about 120 are concentrated in Chiba city.

Moonflower is a double album released in 1977 by Santana. The recording features both studio and live tracks, which are interspersed with one another throughout the album. It is perhaps the group's most popular live album, because Lotus did not receive a U.S. domestic release until 1991. It displays a mix between the fusion of Latin and blues-rock styles of the late 1960s and early 1970s, and the much more experimental and spiritual jazz fusion sound that characterized the band's mid-1970s work. The live material was recorded during the supporting tour for the Amigos album. A cover version of the Zombies' mid-1960s hit song "She's Not There" was released as a single and peaked at #27. The song was the first Santana recording to hit the Top 40 of the Billboard charts since "No One to Depend On" reached #36 in 1972. The album reached #10 on the Billboard charts and was eventually certified platinum, neither of which occurred again until the star-studded Supernatural in 1999.
