Marianne Nøhr Larsen (born 1963) is a Danish anthropologist and writer who since 2002 has run the networking facility "Center for Interkulturel dialog" (Centre for Intercultural Dialogue) in Copenhagen. Biography Born on 26 March 1963, after matriculating from Helsingør Gymnasium, Nøhr Larsen studied anthropology at the University of Copenhagen graduating in 1995. Since 2002, she has headed the Copenhagen networking consultancy "Center for Interkulturel Dialog" where she has arranged courses and workshops on intercultural dialogue. In particular, she has helped Greenlanders and Muslims adapt to life in Denmark. In regard to Muslim women, she has worked on problems associated with arranged marriages and wearing headscarves. She has spoken out against the efforts of the Danish authorities to force the Danish way of life on ethnic minorities: "The more you force them to act in a given way, the more they'll fight against it." Nøhr Larsen has also written about the difficulty experienced by homosexuals belonging to ethnic minorities.

Henrik Bull (28 March 1864 – 2 May 1937) was a Norwegian composer and conductor. Bull was born in Ålesund, Norway. He studied at the Royal Academy of Music in Stockholm, Sweden, and then at the Berlin University of the Arts. He was also a pupil of Johannes Brahms. Bull's early compositions were in a Scandinavian romantic style, but he later turned to classical music. His best-known works are orchestral works such as the Violin Concerto (1907), the Fourth Symphony (1927), and the Concerto for Strings (1929). He also wrote chamber music, including the Piano Quintet (1905) and the String Quartet (1915). Bull served as conductor of various Norwegian orchestras, including the Oslo Philharmonic Orchestra from 1909 to 1916 and the Bergen Philharmonic Orchestra from 1921 to 1931. He also conducted performances of his own works in Europe and America. Bull died in Oslo in 1937.

Hot reading is a technique used when investigating a target or subject. It is a form of investigative journalism which involves reading very selectively and quickly, in order to extract the most important and relevant information. Hot reading can be used when investigating any topic or target, but is particularly useful when investigating people or organizations who may be reluctant to talk to journalists or who have something they want to hide. By reading quickly and selectively, journalists can extract key information that will help them to understand their subject better. Hot reading is not without its risks, however. By reading too quickly or selectively, journalists may miss important clues or information that could lead them down the wrong path. Additionally, by focusing on key information rather than the entire story, journalists may miss important details that could later prove important. Despite these risks, hot reading is an essential tool for journalists who want to get the most out of their investigations. By taking the time to read carefully and selectively, journalists can build a more complete picture of their target and ultimately produce more accurate stories.

Easterwood Airport (, Easterwood Field) is the regional airport for Texas A&M University, Bryan-College Station and Brazos County, Texas. Reached from Farm-To-Market Road 60 West (Raymond Stotzer Parkway), it is three miles southwest of College Station and from Texas A&M University. There is no public transportation from Easterwood Airport to the surrounding cities; however, in the fall of 2019, a new university bus route was established to connect Easterwood Airport with the Engineering Quad and the Texas A&M Hotel and Conference Center. The airport bus route is available only to those with a University ID or Brazos Transit District ID. Despite owning and managing the airport, there are no aviation courses at the university. The William A. McKenzie Terminal at Easterwood Airport provides daily flights to Dallas/Fort Worth, Houston and seasonal service to Birmingham (AL). The terminal has free 2 hour visitor parking and drop off areas on the upper level and shuttle/taxi pick up areas on the lower level.

Colonel Robert George Wardlaw-Ramsay FLS, FZS (25 January 1859 – 16 December 1936) was a Scottish natural historian and ornithologist who specialised in the study of seabirds. He was also a pioneering ornithologist in the study of flight behaviour, and is considered one of the fathers of modern ornithology. Wardlaw-Ramsay was born in Inverness, Scotland on 25 January 1859, the son of Rev. Robert Wardlaw-Ramsay and his wife Jane née Ramsay. He was educated at Harrow School and Christ Church, Oxford, where he graduated with a Bachelor of Arts degree in 1882. After spending a year travelling in France and Italy, he undertook postgraduate research at the University of Leipzig, where he received his doctorate in 1888 with a thesis on the plumage of gulls. Wardlaw-Ramsay returned to Scotland to take up a position as assistant professor of zoology at the University of Glasgow. He remained at the university for the rest of his career, eventually becoming professor emeritus. In 1896, Wardlaw-Ramsay became secretary-manager of the Scottish Ornithologists' Club, a position he held until 1932. During this time he produced over 100 publications on ornithology and other related subjects. He was also involved in many archaeological excavations, including those at Skara Brae and Cnoc Arian (both in Scotland). In 1903, Wardlaw-Ramsay married

Joseph Pierre LaSalle (born 28 May 1916 in State College, Pennsylvania; died 7 July 1983 in Little Compton, Rhode Island) was an American mathematician specialising in dynamical systems and responsible for important contributions to stability theory, such as LaSalle's invariance principle which bears his name. Biography Joseph LaSalle defended his Ph.D. thesis on ″Pseudo-Normed Linear Sets over Valued Rings″ at the California Institute of Technology in 1941. In 1946 he joined the Mathematics Department at the University of Notre Dame as an assistant professor and remained there until 1958, becoming a full professor in 1956. During a visit to Princeton in 1947–1948, LaSalle developed a deep interest in differential equations through his interaction with Solomon Lefschetz and Richard Bellman, with whom he developed a close friendship. From 1958 until 1964 LaSalle was based at the Research Institute for Advanced Studies (RIAS) in Baltimore, where he worked closely with Lefschetz and in 1960 published his extension of Lyapunov stability theory, known today as LaSalle's invariance principle.

Johnnie B. Marshall Jr. (born June 2, 1961) is an American electric blues guitarist, songwriter, and singer. His best known songs are "Found Another Woman" and "98 Cents in the Bank". Discovered by Johnny Rawls in the mid 1990s, Marshall has released three albums and continues as a live performer to the present day. Life and career Marshall was born in Whigham, Grady County, Georgia, United States. He sang in a gospel choir as a child, and later learned to play the drums to back another gospel group. Marshall soon became more interested in the electric guitar, and had lessons to assist him in playing the instrument. He became proficient enough to form his first band, The Blues Ignitors. However, he needed to find full-time employment working in a meat packing factory, to support his own growing family. In his spare time, Marshall regularly attended his local juke joint, Dave's CC Club, in Tallahassee, Florida, where he studied the musicians who performed there. In addition, Marshall performed there himself and one night was spotted by another musician on the bill, Johnny Rawls. In the late 1990s, Rawls helped to develop Marshall's burgeoning career. This led to Rawls playing rhythm guitar, supplying some vocals and producing Marshall's debut album.

The Send was an American alternative rock project of Falling Up ex-guitarist, Joseph A. Kisselburgh of Albany, Oregon, was signed to Tooth & Nail Records. On June 23 The Send began a winter retreat with labelmate, Hawk Nelson, around Major League Baseball venues. The first single off Cosmos was "An Epiphany," which quickly gained some success, reaching No. 5 on Christian Hit Radio. TheSendOnline.com has links to record label Tooth & Nail, and management companies Third Coast Artists and Paradigm management. However, none of those sites have The Send listed on their active roster. In fact, the only site to have any information on the Send at all is toothandnail.com. Leland Stanford Morgan (aka Le Morgan; 9 June 1886 San Francisco – 12 August 1981 Oakland, California) was an American commercial artist. He began in 1910 in San Francisco and eventually moved across the bay to Oakland where he remained for the rest of his life. Morgan is known for his illustrations of sheet music covers by publishers mostly in the San Francisco Bay area. Career At age 17, Morgan graduated from the California Business College in San Francisco in December 1903. In 1930, Morgan began teaching Fashion Art and Commercial Art at the Fox Art Institute and School of Commercial Art, founded in 1921 in Oakland by Elton Villers Frederick Fox (1893–1970). In 1930, when he began teaching there, they renamed it the Fox-Morgan Art Institute and Commercial Art School. Fox returned to his native home in Victoria, Australia, in 1935, and Ruel Curtis Dean became associated with the school for two years. In 1937, the school was renamed Art Institute on the 3rd floor at 339 15th Street, Oakland, and Morgan became its head. Notable alumni of the Fox-Morgan School include Dong Kingman.

Henry Ossawa Tanner (June 21, 1859 – May 25, 1937) was an American artist and the first African-American painter to gain international acclaim. Tanner moved to Paris, France, in 1891 to study at the Académie Julian and gained acclaim in French artistic circles. His painting Daniel in the Lions' Den (1895, location unknown) was accepted into the 1896 Salon, the official art exhibition of the Académie des Beaux-Arts in Paris. Tanner's Resurrection of Lazarus (1896, Musée d'Orsay, Paris) was purchased by the French government after winning the third-place medal at the 1897 Salon. In 1923, the French government elected Tanner chevalier of the Legion of Honor. After pursuing art on his own as a young man, Tanner enrolled at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts in Philadelphia in 1879. The only black student, he became a favorite of the painter Thomas Eakins, who had recently started teaching there. Tanner made other connections among artists, including Robert Henri. In the late 1890s, art patron Rodman Wanamaker sponsored Tanner's trip to the Mutasarrifate of Jerusalem after seeing the artist's paintings of biblical themes.

Giuseppe Marzotto (born 30 January 1944, in Arzignano) is a former Italian international motorcycle speedway rider. Career Marzotto began competing in scooter gymkhanas at the age of 16, riding under the pseudonym "Charlie Brown" because his parents were opposed to him entering in such events. He won the Trofeo Nazionale Gincane four times from 1966–1969. When he was 19 he took up motocross and rode until 1974 before deciding to focus on speedway. His first speedway meeting was at Lonigo in 1968. In 1974 he finished runnerup in the Italian Speedway Championship and the following year won the title. In 1976 he joined the Wolverhampton Wolves and rode in 11 meetings in the British League. In 1977 he rode in Germany for the MSC Olching Club. He later rode for the Moto Club La Favorita. During his career he won the Italian Championship five times and represented Italy in team and best pairs events. He also rode in Argentina and New Zealand. He helped Armando Castagna when he first began riding speedway, giving him advice and technical support.

Denis Edward Arnold MC (16 July 1918 – 18 November 1988) was an English professional footballer who played as a winger. He played in the Football League for Birmingham City and Burnley, and in the Scottish League for Rangers. Arnold was born in Birmingham, England, and began his career with local side Aston Villa before joining First Division side Birmingham City in 1939. He made over 100 appearances for the Blues before being sold to Burnley in 1951 for £7,000. He spent two seasons with Burnley, helping them to promotion to the top division in 1952–53. He then moved to Scottish side Rangers, where he made 128 appearances over three seasons. He retired from playing in 1955, after suffering a broken leg in a match against Celtic. After retiring from football, Arnold became a coach with Chelsea and Bristol City. He died at the age of 76 in 1988 after a long battle with Alzheimer's disease.

Kampong Siem (; "Port of Siam") is a district located in the eastern part of Bangkok, Thailand. It is bounded by Samsen Road to the north, Bangkok Noi Road to the south, Ratchaprasong Road to the east and Phra Ram IV Road to the west. The Kampong Siem district is a largely residential area with a few commercial establishments. The main economic activity is retail and wholesale trade. Kampong Siem is also home to a number of embassies, including those of Cambodia, Indonesia and Malaysia. The district has a population of around 350,000 people. The name Kampong Siem is believed to originate from the fact that the area was once a seaport where vessels from the Kingdom of Siam (now Thailand) would dock. The district was originally called Wat Kampong Siem (วัดแขวงเอมิ), but was later renamed Kampong Siem in honour of King Vajiravudh (Rama VI) who reigned from 1910 to 1925.

John Stanley Sherlock (1 October 1908 – 18 December 1984) was an English detective and writer of mystery novels. He is best known for the character of Professor Moriarty in the Sherlock Holmes stories written by Arthur Conan Doyle. Sherlock was born in 1908 in London, England to Stanley Sherlock, a solicitor, and his wife Alice. He was educated at Eton College and Trinity College, Cambridge, where he read mathematics and natural sciences. He served in the Royal Air Force during World War II, reaching the rank of captain. Sherlock's first job after the war was with the British Secret Service, where he worked on Operation Mincemeat, a secret plan to entice German military leaders to land in Spain so that they could be captured by Allied forces. He also wrote a book about the project, which was published posthumously in 1975. Sherlock's writing career began in 1946 with the publication of The Adventure of Silver Blaze, a novel based on his wartime experiences. His most famous characters are Professor Moriarty and Sherlock Holmes, who first appeared in A Study in Scarlet in 1887. The stories are widely read and have been adapted for television, theater, and film numerous times. Sherlock died in 1984 at the age of 80.

Bir Abu Matar is an archaeological site located in the central Sinai Peninsula, in Egypt. It is one of the most important Neolithic sites in the region, and has been described as one of the most significant archaeological discoveries of the last decade. The Bir Abu Matar site was first discovered in 2001 by a team of Egyptian and Swiss experts while excavating a site known as Tell el-Mutesellim. The site was initially thought to date back to the Early Dynastic Period, but further excavations revealed that it was occupied during the Neolithic period, around 4500 BC. The discovery of evidence for early agriculture and animal husbandry at Bir Abu Matar has made it one of the most significant archaeological finds of recent years. The site is located on a promontory overlooking the Nile Valley, and features settlements dating back to the Neolithic period. The buildings at Bir Abu Matar are made from mud-brick and stone, and are decorated with elaborate carvings. The site has also yielded evidence for early practices such as tattooing and scarring, which have been used to differentiate between social groups. The discovery of Bir Abu Matar has helped to redefine understanding of the Neolithic period in eastern Africa, and has led to renewed interest in ancient cultures in that region. The site is currently under protection by the Egyptian government, and will remain open to visitors until 2025.

Efkan Eren (born July 12, 1989) is a Turkish professional basketball player for the Turkish club Fenerbahçe. He is a 2.07 m (6 ft 9 in) tall power forward-center. He played there for two seasons, averaging 8.5 points and 5.1 rebounds in EuroLeague play. In 2011, he moved to the Greek team Panathinaikos Athens, and averaged 10.4 points and 6.4 rebounds in 33 games during his two seasons there. In June 2013, Eren signed with the Turkish club Fenerbahçe. In 41 games with Fenerbahçe in the 2013-14 season, he averaged 12.9 points and 7.5 rebounds. In 2014-15, he averaged 18 points and 10 rebounds in 47 games played as Fenerbahçe won the Turkish League championship. In July 2016, Eren joined the NBA's Sacramento Kings on a one-year deal worth $2 million USD. B. Kalyani Amma (22 February 1884 – 9 October 1959) was a writer, editor, teacher and social reformer from Kerala. Kalyani Amma’s most notable work is Vyazhavatta Smaranakal (Memories of a Cycle of Twelve Years) and Ormayil Ninnum (Reminiscences). She was one of the editors of two of the earliest magazines published for women in Kerala, Sharada and Malayalamasika. Kalyani Amma was the wife of Swadeshabhimani K. Ramakrishna Pillai, a political writer, journalist and editor. Early life and education B. Kalyani Amma lived in the erstwhile princely state of Travancore during the turn of the century. She was born in Kuzhivilaakathu House, Kuthiravattom, Thiruvananthapuram, on 22 February 1884. She was the daughter of Subbraayan Potti and Bhagavathy Amma. She belonged to a traditional Nair family. She completed her matriculation in a Zenana Mission School with financial help from missionaries who taught and ran the school. The school where she studied did not officially have a high school. The school authorities engaged tutors to teach her and two other friends.

Michel Faber (born 13 April 1960) is a Dutch-born writer of English-language fiction, including his 2002 novel The Crimson Petal and the White. His latest book is a novel for young adults, D: A Tale of Two Worlds, published in 2020. Life Faber was born in The Hague, Netherlands. He and his parents emigrated to Australia in 1967. He attended primary and secondary school in the Melbourne suburbs of Boronia and Bayswater, then attended the University of Melbourne, studying Dutch, Philosophy, Rhetoric, English Language (a course involving translation and criticism of Anglo-Saxon and Middle English texts) and English Literature. He graduated in 1980. He worked as a cleaner and at various other casual jobs, before training as a nurse at Marrickville and Western Suburbs hospitals in Sydney. He nursed until the mid-1990s. In 1993 he, his second wife and family emigrated to Scotland. Faber's second wife Eva died of cancer in July 2014 and he published a poetry collection, Undying, about this event in 2016.

Black and white photos offer a rare glimpse of the Chinese capital 's landmarks devoid of tourists . Quiet scenes are a far cry from modern-day Beijing , one of the most populous cities in the world .

John Nihill (May 25, 1850 – May 29, 1908) was an Irish-born soldier in the U.S. Army who served with the 5th U.S. Cavalry during the Indian Wars. A participant in the Apache Wars, he received the Medal of Honor for bravery when he single-handedly fought off four Apache warriors in the Whetstone Mountains of Arizona on July 13, 1872. At the time of his death, he was the only enlisted man to be admitted as a member of the Military Order of the Loyal Legion of the United States. A well-known Indian fighter during his lifetime, Nihill was close friends with William F. "Buffalo Bill" Cody and Captain Jack Crawford. He was also considered at one time to be one of the top marksmen in the United States armed services. By 1885, he had won every shooting award offered by the US military and was barred from accepting awards at further competitions.

Prestonwood Town Center was a two-level enclosed shopping mall in Plano, Texas, United States that was opened in 1976. The mall had an occupancy of over 150,000 people at its peak. In 2006, the mall was sold to Simon Property Group for $525 million and was closed in 2008 as part of a plan to redevelop the area. Prestonwood Town Center was built on the site of what had been a small shopping district on the north side of Plano. The original developers were the H.A. Richardson Company and the mall opened on November 8, 1976 with fifty stores and an ice rink. Anchor stores included JCPenney, Sears, and Waldenbooks. The first phase of expansion added a food court and a movie theater in 1978. The mall reached its peak in the early 1990s; at that time there were over 150 stores and an occupancy of over 170,000 people. A major redevelopment project began in 1996 with the addition of a two-story wing on the east side of the mall that increased the total number of stores to 176. In 2006, Prestonwood Town Center was sold to Simon Property Group for $525 million; as part of the deal, Simon also acquired Richland Square Mall in nearby Richardson. The closure of Prestonwood Town Center began in 2008; most of the stores were closed by early 2009 and only a few remain open as part of Simon's Richland Square Mall chain.

Chen Guangbiao (; born July 1968) is a Chinese business magnate, philanthropist and political advisor. He is the founder, chairman and CEO of Starry Sky International Holdings Limited, a conglomerate with interests in real estate, entertainment, technology and telecommunications. Chen Guangbiao was born in Wuhan, Hubei province in July 1968. He graduated from Wuhan University with a degree in law. In 1995, he founded China's first private real estate development company, Soho China Development Company Ltd. In 1998 he founded Suntech Power Holdings Co., Ltd., a solar cell manufacturer. In 2003, Chen established Gree Inc., a Silicon Valley-based artificial intelligence company which was later acquired by Google Inc. In 2004, Chen founded Avenue Capital Group LLC, an investment firm that has made numerous investments in the entertainment and technology industries. Chen also serves as an advisor to several Chinese state-owned enterprises. Chen Guangbiao is a member of the National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference (CPPCC). In September 2013 he was elected as the chairman of the CPPCC's Financial and Economic Affairs Committee.

Craig Anthony Raine, FRSL (born 3 December 1946) is a Scottish poet, novelist, short story writer and critic. Raine was born in Edinburgh, the only child of Edward Raine, a civil servant, and his wife, Betty (née Craig). He was educated at the Royal High School in Edinburgh and at Balliol College, Oxford. After a year at the University of California, Berkeley, he returned to Oxford to study English Literature. He graduated with a First in 1971. Raine's early poetry reflects the Romantic movement and its emphasis on self-expression. His first book of poems, "The Stone Angel", was published in 1972. Raine's early novels include "The Book of Evidence" (1977), which won the Somerset Maugham Award, and "In the Country of Last Things" (1982), which was nominated for the Booker Prize. "The Book of Evidence" is set in Glasgow during the 1930s and '40s and tells the story of a lawyer who becomes involved in political extremism. "In the Country of Last Things" is set in an unspecified European country during World War II and tells the story of two families caught up in the conflict. Raine's later novels include "The Year of Magical Thinking" (2005), which was shortlisted for the Booker Prize and won the 2007 Orange Prize for Fiction; "The Book Thief" (2007), which was nominated for both the Booker Prize and the Nobel Prize; and "World War Z" (2013),

Caladenia doutchiae, commonly known as the purple-veined clown orchid or purple-veined spider orchid is a species of orchid endemic to the south-west of Western Australia. It has a single hairy leaf and usually only one greenish-yellow and red flower with short, downswept petals, and lateral sepals that are broad at the base then narrow to a glandular tip. Description Caladenia doutchiae is a terrestrial, perennial, deciduous, herb with an underground tuber and a single, erect, narrow linear, hairy leaf, long and wide. Usually only one greenish yellow and red flower, long and wide is borne on a stalk tall. The petals are downswept and relatively short whilst the lateral sepals are relatively wide near the base but narrow to a thread-like end covered with reddish glandular hairs. The labellum is greenish-yellow with red markings, a red tip and smooth edges. There is a dense, narrow band of short, red-tipped calli along the centre line of the labellum. Flowering occurs from August to October. This species is similar to the short sepalled spider orchid C. brevisura and the puppet orchid C. incrassata but is distinguished from them by its longer sepals and narrower band of calli.

Peniel E. Joseph is an American scholar, religious leader, and author. He is the founder and president of The Shalom Center, an interfaith dialogue and education center in Los Angeles, California. Joseph was born in Brooklyn, New York, to parents of Ethiopian Jewish descent. Joseph's father was a rabbi and later a professor at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America. Joseph attended public schools in the New York City area before enrolling at Brandeis University, where he received his B.A. in 1988. After graduation from Brandeis, Joseph attended Harvard Divinity School where he earned his M.A. in 1991 and his Ph.D. in 1994. While at Harvard, Joseph studied with such luminaries as Reinhold Niebuhr and John Rawls. Joseph began his career as a lecturer at Brandeis University before moving to Los Angeles in 1998 to found The Shalom Center. The Shalom Center is an interfaith dialogue and education center that has hosted such luminaries as Desmond Tutu, Rick Warren, and Bill McKibben. Joseph has also authored several books on religion and ethics, including Truth & Beauty: An Introduction to Ethics (2003), Why Jesus? A Biography (2005), and What Jesus Wants from You (2008).

Lauren Orlandos Hanson (born Lauren Michelle Orlandos; October 30, 1986) is an American actress, singer, and model. Hanson is known for her role as Alex Dunphy on the Fox sitcom Modern Family and for her lead voice role as Mia in the animated series Phineas and Ferb. Hanson was born in Thousand Oaks, California, to Barbara (née Orlandos), an administrative assistant and homemaker, and Gilbert Hanson, a real estate broker. She has two sisters, Stacey (born c. 1977) and Jill (born c. 1980). Hanson's family is of Lebanese descent. She attended Thousand Oaks High School, where she was a member of the drama club and choir. After graduating from high school in 2004, Hanson studied at New York University's Tisch School of the Arts, but did not complete her degree. In 2006, she moved to Los Angeles to pursue an acting career. Hanson made her acting debut in an episode of the WB series "Gilmore Girls" in 2006. That year she also appeared in the films "The House Bunny" and "Death Sentence". In 2007 she had a supporting role in "The Omen III". In 2008, Hanson landed her breakthrough role as Alex Dunphy on Fox's Modern Family. The show became one of the network's most successful comedies and won two Emmy Awards for Outstanding Comedy Series in 2013 and 2014. Hanson also voiced Mia on the animated series Phineas and Ferb from 2011

John Coates (29 June 1865 – 16 August 1941) was a leading English tenor, who sang in opera and oratorio and on the concert platform. His repertoire ranged from Bach and Purcell to contemporary works, and embraced the major heldentenor roles in Richard Wagner's operas. For more than 40 years, with only a four-year interruption for military service during World War I, he overcame the limitations of a voice that was not naturally large by impressing listeners with his intense artistic expression, lively diction, musical versatility and memorable stage presence. Coates spent some time on the European continent, toured Australia and South Africa in 1912–13 and performed in North America in the 1890s and again in 1925. He performed most often, however, in his native country and became a beloved figure at England's regional music festivals. Elgar's Dream of Gerontius was one of his specialties. After 1921, he limited his performances to the concert stage and recitals, still performing a wide-ranging repertoire, but championing English composers. A dispute with music publishers about royalties clouded his later years.

Star Chamber is a one-act play by English playwright William Shakespeare, believed to have been written between 1589 and 1592. The play is an adaptation of a French play, Le Châtelet, by Pierre Beaumarchais. The play is based on the story of Pierre Beaumarchais' imprisonment and trial before the French National Assembly for his involvement in the French Revolution. The title refers to the Star Chamber, a medieval English court that was infamous for its harsh treatment of criminals. The play was first published in the quarto version in 1613. It was entered into the Stationers' Register on 26 February 1613 and published later that year with the title The Spanish Tragedy. In 1623, it was published in the folio version with the title The Tragedy of Star Chamber. The title page of this edition states that the play was " lately re-written by W. Shakespeare". The first Folio text is a revision of the Quarto text, with about 5,600 words deleted and about 7,000 words added. The play has been frequently performed since its Elizabethan era debut. It has been adapted for film and television more than any other Shakespeare play.

The 1981 Victorian Football Association season was the 100th season of the top division of the Australian rules football competition, and the 21st season of second division competition. The Division 1 premiership was won by the Port Melbourne Football Club, after it defeated Preston in the Grand Final on 20 September by 113 points; it was Port Melbourne's 14th Division 1 premiership, the second of three premierships won in a row between 1980 and 1982, and the fifth of six premierships won in nine seasons from 1974 until 1982. The Division 2 premiership was won by Camberwell; it was the club's second Division 2 premiership, and it was the last premiership ever won by the club. Rule changes After trialling it during the 1980 finals series, two field umpires were used during all Division 1 matches in 1981. Division 2 continued to be officiated by a single field umpire during the home-and-away season, and by two field umpires during finals.

Timothy DeCamp Wilson is an American social psychologist and writer. He is the Sherrell J. Aston Professor of Psychology at the University of Virginia and teaches public policy at the Frank Batten School of Leadership and Public Policy. He is known for his research on self-knowledge and the influence of the unconscious mind on decision-making, preferences and behavior. He is the author of two popular books on psychology, Strangers to Ourselves: Discovering the Adaptive Unconscious and Redirect: The Surprising New Science of Psychological Change. Career Wilson is best known for his research on the adaptive unconscious, self-knowledge, and affective forecasting. With Richard Nisbett, Wilson authored one of psychology's most cited papers, "Telling more than we can know verbal reports on mental processes," that demonstrated the difficulty humans have in introspecting on their own mental processes (Psychological Review, 1977, cited 2731 times as of May 22, 2007 according to ISI Web of Knowledge). His longtime collaborator is Daniel Gilbert of Harvard University.

"A Fratricide" (German: Ein Brudermord) is a term used to describe the act of killing one's brother. It is a serious crime that can carry significant penalties, depending on the circumstances surrounding the killing. In most cases, fratricide is a result of family feuds or rivalry between brothers. It can also occur as a result of severe anger or jealousy. In some cases, fratricide may be motivated by revenge or hatred. Regardless of the reasons, fratricide is always a tragic event. Victims often suffer from intense emotional pain and grief. They may also experience physical trauma as a result of the attack. Anyone convicted of fratricide can face severe penalties, including prison time and a fine. If the victim was younger than 18 years old, the perpetrator may also be subject to child custody proceedings.

Menzies Dickson (c. 1840 – 1891) was a photographer in Hawaii. Life He was born in 1840 in Charlestown, Massachusetts. He served in the Union Navy during the American Civil War. In 1867, he came to the Kingdom of Hawaii from Cincinnati and established a photograph studio on Fort Street in Honolulu. He took many portraits, and some photographs of sights and objects. James J. Williams (1853–1926) worked in his studio, buying it out in 1882. Subjects of his portraits included John Adams Cummins, Archibald Scott Cleghorn, Kalakaua, poi dealer, grass dealer, Kamehameha IV, Kapiolani (1879), Keelikolani, Keelikolani with Parker and Cummins, Leleiohoku, Likelike (1868), Liliuokalani, Major Moehonua, Martin and Moehonua (survivors of Honolulu Courthouse riot of 1874), Queen Emma wearing Niihau lei, Queen Kapiolani, and William Pitt Leleiohoku (1874 or 1876). He also photographed the Princeville plantation in Hanalei, the Punchbowl Crater and Waiuli (Wailua) Lower Falls on Kauai.

Julia Wolfe (born December 18, 1958) is an American author, critic, and educator. She is the author of six books of fiction, including The Book of Joan, a National Book Award Finalist in 2006. Wolfe was born in 1958 in Manhattan to a father who was a lawyer and a mother who was an artist. She attended Phillips Exeter Academy and graduated from Yale University in 1980 with a B.A. in English literature. Wolfe then studied at the University of Iowa Writers' Workshop, receiving an MFA in 1983. Wolfe's first novel, The Book of Joan, was published in 1997 and won the National Book Award for Fiction. Her second novel, The Kite Runner, was published in 2002 and won the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction. Her third novel, Thirteen Ways of Looking at a Blackbird, was published in 2009 and won the National Book Critics Circle Award for Fiction. Her fourth novel, The Vegetable Years, was published in 2014 and won the Los Angeles Times Book Prize for Fiction. Her fifth novel, Humboldt's Gift, was published in 2017 and won the National Book Award for Fiction. Her sixth novel, The Assassination of Gianni Versace: A Novel, will be published in 2019. Wolfe has also written criticism and essays for publications such as The New York Times Magazine, Harper's Magazine, The New Republic, Slate, and n+1. She currently teaches at Bard College and Yale University.

Stanley Dyson (1920–2007) was an art teacher and Outsider Art artist. Early life and education Stanley Dyson was born in Chesterfield, Derbyshire on 24 July 1920, the only child of George and Mary Alice Dyson. Stanley's mother was born Mary Alice Bowler and she died of pneumonia on 13 February 1926, aged 33, when Stanley was 5. It is thought that Stanley then moved to either Holymoorside or Newbold to live on a farm. Stanley's father George carried on living at 35 Church Street, Old Whittington which still stands today. Stanley went to school in Whittington and left at 16 to work as a clerk at the Sheep Bridge Works. As a teenager, just before World War II, Stanley took measurements and followed up on local details of churches and old houses in Derbyshire for Pevsner and his 'Buildings of England' series. Stanley later moved to Norfolk in 1966 when his daughter was two and after that he stopped painting.

Skulls found in the cave also had been cut and shaped into bowls and cups . Researchers at the Natural History Museum in London believe cannibalism may have been regular part of disposing of dead relatives at the time .

Transaction Language 1 (TL1) is a widely used management protocol in telecommunications. It is a cross-vendor, cross-technology man-machine language, and is widely used to manage optical (SONET) and broadband access infrastructure in North America. TL1 is used in the input and output messages that pass between Operations Support Systems (OSSs) and Network Elements (NEs). Operations domains such as surveillance, memory administration, and access and testing define and use TL1 messages to accomplish specific functions between the OS and the NE. TL1 is defined in Telcordia Technologies (formerly Bellcore) Generic Requirements document GR-831-CORE. History TL1 was developed by Bellcore in 1984 as a standard man-machine language to manage network elements for the Regional Bell Operating Companies (RBOCs). It is based on Z.300 series man machine language standards. TL1 was designed as a standard protocol readable by machines as well as humans to replace the diverse ASCII based protocols used by different Network Element (NE) vendors. It is extensible to incorporate vendor specific commands.

John Madden Towey (born February 13, 1940) is an American actor. He studied acting and directing at the Goodman Theatre in Chicago. He received B.F.A. degree in directing in 1967. Acted two seasons at the Arena Stage in Washington D.C. (1977–78 and 1981). Acted two seasons at the Guthrie Theatre in Minneapolis (1984–1986) and two seasons at The Public Theater in New York 1987-89, before moving to Los Angeles in 1990. A classically trained pianist, John has performed over 100 programs since 2001 at grade schools in the Los Angeles Unified School District. The program is an introduction to classical music entitled, Piano Masters. He also gives piano concerts at retirement homes throughout Southern California. Background Towey was born in Rochester, Minnesota, to Helen Madden and Robert F. Towey, an undertaker in business with his brother Richard L. Towey. Towey's father was the son of John H. Towey, who started the funeral business in Stewartville, Minnesota in the beginning of the 20th century. Towey served in the Army during the Vietnam War and was stationed for a time in San Juan, Puerto Rico. Prior to entering the Army he attended Saint John's University in Collegeville, Minnesota and subsequently moved to Chicago to attend the Goodman School of Drama at the Art Institute of Chicago (now at DePaul University).

Dolby Digital, originally synonymous with Dolby AC-3, is the name for what has now become a family of audio compression technologies developed by Dolby Laboratories. Originally named Dolby Stereo Digital until 1995, except for Dolby TrueHD, the audio compression is lossy, based on the modified discrete cosine transform (MDCT) algorithm. The first use of Dolby Digital was to provide digital sound in cinemas from 35 mm film prints; today, it is now also used for applications such as TV broadcast, radio broadcast via satellite, digital video streaming, DVDs, Blu-ray discs and game consoles. The main basis of the Dolby AC-3 multi-channel audio coding standard is the modified discrete cosine transform (MDCT), a lossy audio compression algorithm. It is a modification of the discrete cosine transform (DCT) algorithm, which was first proposed by Nasir Ahmed in 1972 and was originally intended for image compression. The DCT was adapted into the modified discrete cosine transform (MDCT) by J.P. Princen, A.W. Johnson and Alan B. Bradley at the University of Surrey in 1987.

English China Clays PLC, or ECC, was a British company that operated in the ceramic tile industry. Established in 1901, ECC became one of the largest ceramic tile manufacturers in the world. In 1986, ECC merged with Schreiner Corporation to form Schreiner-ECC. The ceramic tile industry is one of the most important and rapidly growing sectors of the global economy. Ceramic tiles are used in a variety of applications, including flooring, countertops, walls, and ceilings. The market for ceramic tiles is growing at a rate of 6 percent per year, and is expected to grow to $25 billion by 2020. ECC was one of the pioneers and leading players in the ceramic tile industry. The company was founded in 1901 by two brothers, Edward and Charles Clays. ECC grew rapidly during its early years, becoming one of the largest ceramic tile manufacturers in the world. In 1986, ECC merged with Schreiner Corporation to form Schreiner-ECC. The merger created a global leader in the ceramic tile industry with a portfolio of brands that include London Stone, Country Stone, Greystone Ceramics, and Interstone Ceramics. During its more than 100-year history, ECC always placed a priority on innovation and quality. The company was responsible for many breakthroughs in the ceramic tile industry, including the development of glazed tiles (in 1935), pre-glazed tiles (in 1957), and porcelain-coated tiles (in

The Clarkson Cup is a women's ice hockey championship contested by the Canadian national women's ice hockey team and the United States national women's ice hockey team. The championship is named in honor of Terry and Linda Clarkson, the owners of the National Hockey League (NHL)'s Columbus Blue Jackets, who donated the trophy in 2007. The Clarkson Cup is contested between the champions of the Canadian Women's Hockey League (CWHL) and American Women's Hockey League (AWHL). The CWHL was founded in 2007 as a successor to the former Women's National Hockey League (WNHL), which folded after the 2003–04 season. The AWHL was founded in 2001 as an amateur league. The championship was first played in 2008 as a three-game series between the NWHL champion Boston Blades and the AWHL champion Buffalo Beauts. The Boston Blades emerged as champions, winning two games to one. The 2009 Clarkson Cup saw Boston defeat Buffalo 3–1 to win their second championship. In 2010, Montreal defeated Toronto 2–1 to win their first title. The 2011 Clarkson Cup saw Montreal defeat Toronto 3–2 in a shootout after a 1–1 tie in regulation time. In 2012, Montreal won their third title by defeating Boston 3–2 in a shootout. In 2013, Toronto won their first title by defeating Montreal 4–3 in overtime. As of 2019, Toronto leads all teams with six championships (2009, 2010, 2012, 2013, 2015, 2019).

"My Affair" is a ballad that lasts for three minutes and forty-four seconds. The song features a lush production, with Adele's vocals being supported by strings and a choir. King Hagler (also spelled Haiglar) or Nopkehee (c. 1700–1763) was a chief of the Catawba Native American tribe from 1754 to 1763. Hagler is known as the "Patron Saint of Camden, South Carolina." He was the first Native American to be inducted into the South Carolina Hall of Fame. He is known for opposing the sale of alcohol to Catawbas and other Native Americans, and encouraged the Catawba people to abstain from alcohol. He worked to negotiate fair land rights and treaties for the Catawba people. Like other Native American Nations, the Catawba do not use European titles of royalty among themselves. Merrell gives Hagler's title among the Catawba as Eractasswa or Arataswa, which the Catawba translate as "Chief"; "King" is the English translation and conception, though many Catawba adopted this nomenclature for ease of communication with the settlers. Hagler is also known by several other names and other spellings, such as King Haigler, Haiglar, Nopkehe, Arataswa and Oroloswa. Hagler's anglicized name is possibly a nickname derived from his tendency to bargain or "haggle" over political decisions, although there is no conclusive evidence to support this.

Lisa Deshaun Leslie (born July 7, 1972) is an American former professional basketball player. She is currently the head coach for Triplets in the BIG3 professional basketball league, as well as a studio analyst for Orlando Magic broadcasts on Fox Sports Florida. Leslie played in the Women's National Basketball Association (WNBA). She is a three-time WNBA MVP and a four-time Olympic gold medal winner. The number-seven pick in the 1997 inaugural WNBA draft, she followed her career at the University of Southern California with eight WNBA All-Star selections and two WNBA championships over the course of 11 seasons with the Los Angeles Sparks, before retiring in 2009. Leslie was the first player to dunk in a WNBA game. In 2011, she was voted in by fans as one of the Top 15 players in WNBA history. All throughout her WNBA career, Leslie also played for USA Basketball in international competition, winning four Olympic gold medals (1996, 2000, 2004, 2008) and two FIBA World Championships (1998, 2002).

West Ogwell is a village and former civil parish and manor in Devon, England, located 2 miles south-west of the town of Newton Abbot and 1 mile west of the village of East Ogwell. It is now in the civil parish of Ogwell, administered by Teignbridge District Council. The church and manor house "lie hidden away on their own". Church The disused former parish church (West Ogwell Church), which stands next to the manor house, was built in the 13th-century and is a grade I listed building. Since 1982 it has been owned by the Redundant Churches Fund. In the opinion of Pevsner it is of exceptional interest "both for its early structure undisturbed by the usual Perp(endicular) remodelling and because its simple and charming late Georgian interior has escaped radical Victorian restoration". Polwhele (1793) wrote of West Ogwell Church: "West Ogwell is a very small parish containing no more than thirty-five inhabitants...West Ogwell Church is dark and damp".

"Travelers" is the fifteenth episode of the fifth season of American science fiction television series The X-Files, and the 111th episode of the series overall. It was written by John Shiban and Frank Spotnitz, directed by William A. Graham and aired in the United States on March 29, 1998, on the Fox network. The episode earned a Nielsen household rating of 9.9, being watched by 15.06 million people in its initial broadcast. The episode received mixed reviews from television critics. The show centers on FBI special agents Fox Mulder (David Duchovny) and Dana Scully (Gillian Anderson) who work on cases linked to the paranormal, called X-Files. Mulder is a believer in the paranormal, while the skeptical Scully has been assigned to debunk his work. In this flashback episode, a young Fox Mulder visits retired FBI Agent Arthur Dales (Darren McGavin), who tells him about one of the first X-Files, a case that Mulder's father, Bill, was involved in.

The 2020 Copa CONMEBOL Sudamericana was the 38th edition of the Copa Sudamericana, South America's premier club football tournament organized by CONMEBOL. The competition was scheduled to be played in April and May 2020, but was postponed to June due to the FIFA World Cup. The tournament returned to a 16-team format, with the first stage featuring eight teams. The eight winners of the first stage qualified for the final stage, which featured four teams. The defending champions were Flamengo of Brazil, who claimed their sixth title. Tigres UANL of Mexico were the runners-up. A total of 24 clubs entered the competition, including the 10 members of CONMEBOL and 16 from six South American leagues: Argentina ( Primera División ), Bolivia ( Liga Boliviana de Fútbol ), Chile ( Primera División ), Colombia ( Categoría Primera A ), Paraguay ( Primera División ), Peru (Liga Peruana de Fútbol), and Venezuela (Liga Bolivariana de Fútbol). Carol Steen is an artist, writer and curator who lives and works in New York. She has had over 20 solo gallery exhibitions, her first solo exhibition in 1973 was at the Detroit Institute of Arts, and her work has been in over 50 group exhibitions including shows at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, the Brookgreen Gardens Museum in South Carolina, the Cranbrook Museum in Michigan, and the DeCordova Museum in Massachusetts. Steen's work has also been exhibited at the Theatre for a New Audience in Brooklyn, NY, the Museum of Modern Art of Ukraine, and Wayne State University, Detroit, Michigan. Steen has been the recipient of fellowships from the MacDowell Colony in Peterborough, New Hampshire; the Printmaking Workshop in New York City; and the New York Foundation for the Arts (NYFA); among others. Her work is in the collections of several public art collections including the Detroit Institute of Arts, the Robert McGlaughlin Gallery in Canada, and the Library of Congress.

Philip Dalton Hepworth (12 March 1888 – 21 February 1963) was a British architect. He studied in both the UK and France, at the Architectural Association School of Architecture and the École des Beaux-Arts, and returned to work as an architect after serving in the First World War. He rose to prominence in the 1930s, featuring in a book by architectural critic Trystan Edwards and winning the commission in 1932 to design Walthamstow Town Hall, which was eventually completed in 1942. Another civic building of this period was Wiltshire County Hall at Trowbridge. He also designed a handful of private houses, including Pemberley, in Loughton, 1936. He lived in Zoffany House in Strand-on-the-Green, Chiswick, London, from 1936. During the Second World War, he was appointed one of the Principal Architects of the Imperial War Graves Commission (now the Commonwealth War Graves Commission). In this post-war stage of his career, he designed several war memorials and numerous cemeteries for the British war dead. Examples of his Commission work are found in France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Germany. His work was said to have followed the style of that of two of his predecessors as Commission architects, Edwin Lutyens and Herbert Baker. Hepworth, who died in 1963, was described in his obituary as an architect of "great speed and brilliance" and "sensitivity and eccentricity", influenced by "classical, English and local Norman styles". A number of his buildings are listed.

Aigialosauridae (from Greek, aigialos = "seashore" and sauros= lizard) is a family of Late Cretaceous semiaquatic varanoid lizards closely related to the mosasaurs. Regarded by some paleontologists as a distinct monophyletic group and by others as an adaptive grade within the basal mosasauroids, recent molecular and morphological data suggests that they are the oldest known members of the lineage leading to the mosasaurs. The family is recognized as containing two species, normally classified into two genera; Aigialosaurus and Opetiosaurus. When used as an adaptive grade rather than as an actual monophyletic group, many other basal mosasauroids of uncertain affinities are occasionally referred to as "aigialosaurs", such as the genera Komensaurus, Haasiasaurus, Carsosaurus and Dallasaurus and even entire mosasaur clades, such as the Tethysaurinae. The term "plesiopedal mosasaurs" or "mosasaurs with a plesiopedal limb condition" is a more formal way to refer to such primitive species firmly within the family Mosasauridae.

The Lufttransport Staffel 7 (LT St7 or LTS7) was a World War II German transport squadron. The squadron operated from airfields in occupied France and Belgium as part of the Luftwaffe's Transport Command. The squadron was formed on 1 November 1940 at Zeltweg Airfield, near Vienna, Austria as I./LT St7. It served with III./ transport wing, based in occupied France. The squadron flew several types of aircraft, including the Heinkel He 111, Junkers Ju 88 and Junkers Ju 52. In December 1942 it was transferred to II./ transport wing, based in Belgium. It flew the Junkers Ju 88 and Dornier Do 17. In 1944 it was transferred to IV./ transport wing, which was destroyed in combat in May 1945. The squadron surrendered to the British on 9 May 1945 at Lübeck Airfield, Germany. In all, the squadron flew 1,729 missions and delivered 1,851 tons of cargo and passengers to Allied forces in Europe.

Orvon Grover "Gene" Autry (September 29, 1907 – October 3, 1997) was an American singer and actor whose career spanned more than 75 years. Autry is regarded as one of the most successful and influential singing cowboys of all time. His signature song, "The Old Gray Mare", remains popular and is now considered a standard. Autry was born in Tioga County, Texas, the son of Clara (née Moore) and Osmon Autry. His parents were both of pioneer stock, his father coming from Ohio and his mother from Kentucky. He had a brother, Roy, and a sister, Enid. In 1911, the family moved to Los Angeles, where Autry attended Arlington High School. He began working in the oil fields of California at age 16 as a roustabout. In 1926, he made his first appearance on the national stage in The Squaw Man, playing a role with Ben Turpin and Maude Adams. In 1926, Autry made his first recordings with Columbia Records as part of a hillbilly band led by Foy Vance. These recordings did not sell well and he lost money on them. In 1927 he recorded two songs with singer Bill Monroe and his band: "Oklahoma!" and "Kentucky Waltz". These records were far more successful, leading to a contract with RCA Records. Edward Nassour (April 7, 1911 – December 12, 1979) was an American mathematician who worked in the fields of analytic number theory and mathematical physics. Nassour was born in 1911 in New York City, and attended the City College of New York. He received his bachelor's degree from CCNY in 1932, and his doctorate from Columbia University in 1938. He spent most of his career at the University of Chicago, where he was a professor from 1959 until his retirement in 1978. Nassour's work in analytic number theory concentrated on problems such as the Diophantine equation and the Riemann hypothesis. His work in mathematical physics focused on problems such as the structure of the universe and the origin of mass. He was also a member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and the National Academy of Sciences. Nassour died in 1979.

Black United Front also known as The United Front of Black African Organizations was a coalition of organizations in the 1940s and 1950s in the United States which united African Americans to fight against segregation and racism. The Black United Front was created in 1945 when representatives from various African American organizations met in Chicago to discuss ways to combat racism. The goal of the Black United Front was to unite African Americans and work together to improve their conditions. The Black United Front was made up of organizations such as the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP), the Urban League, the National Negro Congress, and the Council of Federated Organizations. The Black United Front played an important role in the Civil Rights Movement. The group helped organize protests, held rallies, and lobbied Congress. The Black United Front also worked to recruit new members and raise money for civil rights causes. In 1954, the Black United Front merged with other civil rights organizations to form the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP).

Scombroid food poisoning, also known as simply scombroid poisoning, is a foodborne illness caused by the ingestion of scombroid fish or seafood that has been contaminated with a toxin. It typically manifests as nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea within 12 hours of ingestion, and can be fatal if not treated promptly. Scombroid fish are typically found in tropical and subtropical seas, and are most commonly caught in the Gulf of Mexico. They are often contaminated with toxins such as histamine and tetrodotoxin, which can cause scombroid food poisoning when consumed. The most common sources of scombroid poisoning are contaminated seafood products such as sushi and sashimi, but it can also be caused by eating raw or undercooked fish. Symptoms of scombroid food poisoning typically subside within a few days but can occasionally lead to serious health consequences such as liver failure. Treatment typically involves inducing vomiting and diarrhea using activated charcoal or antibiotics, and supportive care is usually required until the patient recovers.

William Plotnikov (May 3, 1989 in Megion, Chuvashia, Russia) is a Russian historian, writer, and political scientist. He specializes in Russian history of the 18th century. Plotnikov was born in 1989 in Megion, Chuvashia, Russia. In 2009 he graduated from the Russian State University for the Humanities with a degree in history. From 2009 to 2013 he worked as an assistant professor at the same university. In 2013 he moved to Saint Petersburg to work as a senior research associate at the Institute of Russian History of the Russian Academy of Sciences. Plotnikov's research focuses on Russian history of the 18th century, particularly on the development of Russian statehood and society during that time period. He has written articles and book chapters on a variety of topics related to Russian history during the 18th century, including social and economic development, education, religion, and culture. Plotnikov is also a published writer. His articles have appeared in journals such as "Soviet History", "Russian History", and "European History Quarterly". His book project, titled "The Emergence of Russian Statehood: 1721-1781" (in preparation), will cover the same period of time as his research focuses but from a broader perspective that takes into account both domestic and international events influencing Russia's development. Plotnikov is currently a member of the editorial board for "Russian History" magazine and is also an associate editor for "Russian Studies in History".

Boston United Football Club is an association football club based in Boston, England. The club was formed in 2004 and competes in the National League North, the sixth tier of English football. The club's home ground is the New England Revolution Stadium. The club's history is characterized by a series of near misses, with Boston United having competed in the Football League twice, both times as champions of their division only to be relegated at the end of each season. However, after a successful play-off campaign in 2016–17, Boston United secured their place in the National League North for the following season. They finished as runners-up in their first season in the division and reached the second round of the FA Cup before being eliminated by Championship side Reading. Boston United were formed in 2004 after a merger between Boston Rovers and United Automobiles (later renamed United Autos). The new club played their first competitive match against Aldershot Town on 10 October 2004. They finished their first season as league champions, but were relegated at the end of the 2005–06 season. They spent two seasons in Division Two before being promoted back to Division One at the end of 2007–08. They finished as champions again in 2009–10, but were relegated at the end of 2010–11. After narrowly avoiding relegation from Division One during their first two seasons back, Boston United secured their place in the Football League for the 2012–13 season after finishing as runners-up in Division Two. The Northern Brewery is a former industrial brewery in the town of Huddersfield, West Yorkshire, England. The brewery closed in 2002. The Northern Brewery was founded in 1892 by a group of local businessmen led by Joseph W. Heywood. The brewery initially produced porter and stout, but soon began to produce other beers including a light lager. In 1902, the brewery was bought by the Hudsons Bay Company and production increased. However, during the Second World War, the brewery was damaged by bombing and production was halted for a period. After the war, production resumed and the brewery became one of the largest producers of porter in the country. However, in the 1990s, competition from larger breweries and a change in consumer tastes led to the closure of the Northern Brewery in 2002. The Northern Brewery is now a tourist attraction and is open to visitors on certain days during the year. The brewery has been restored and is now used as a museum dedicated to brewing history.

Union 55+ (in Dutch: Unie 55+) was a Dutch political party that was active from 1988 until 2006. It was a successor to the Christian Democratic Appeal (CDA) and the Liberal Party (LP), which had been merged in 1988. Union 55+ aimed to represent the interests of the 55+ age group, and claimed to be the only party capable of representing their interests. The party also promoted a social welfare programme, which it said would help to make life more affordable for older people. Union 55+ was one of the most successful Dutch parties in terms of election results. In the 1997 general election, it won 14 seats in the House of Representatives, making it the third-largest party in the chamber. In the 2001 election, Union 55+ won 21 seats, making it the second-largest party in the House of Representatives. In the 2003 election, Union 55+ won 20 seats, making it the largest party in the House of Representatives. However, Union 55+ never managed to form a coalition government with another party. In 2006, Union 55+ merged with the Christian Democratic Appeal (CDA) to form the new Christian Democratic Party (CDA).

Barro Colorado Island is located in the man-made Gatun Lake in the middle of the Panama Canal. The island was formed when the waters of the Chagres River were dammed to form the lake in 1913. When the waters rose, they covered a significant part of the existing tropical forest, but certain hilltops remained as islands in the middle of the lake. It has an area of . The island was set aside as a nature reserve on April 17, 1923 by the U.S. Government. Initially administered by the Panama Canal Company under the direction of James Zetek, since 1946 Barro Colorado Island has been administered by the Smithsonian, together with five adjacent peninsulas, as the Barro Colorado Nature Monument. This Monument has an area of 54 km2. It is among the most-studied areas of tropical forest in the world. The Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute (STRI) has a permanent research center on the island, dedicated to studying tropical forest ecosystems. Because the Island's diverse ecosystem has been very little altered by humans, Barro Colorado has been studied for over eighty years within a great variety of biological disciplines. Only the larger fauna disappeared from Barro Colorado after the lake was flooded in 1914. Many scientific studies have been conducted to document the changes in the species composition of the island.

Archibald Watson FRCS (27 July 1849 – 1 September 1929) was a British surgeon who is considered to be the father of modern surgery. Watson was born on 27 July 1849 in Edinburgh, Scotland. He was educated at the Royal High School and the University of Edinburgh, where he studied medicine. He qualified as a doctor in 1875. Watson began his medical career as a house surgeon at the Edinburgh Royal Infirmary. In 1877, he moved to London and began working at the Middlesex Hospital. In 1883, he became a member of the Royal College of Surgeons of England. He served as president of the college from 1908 to 1909. Watson is considered to be the father of modern surgery. His work on surgical techniques and procedures led to major improvements in the quality of patient care and outcomes for surgery. His work also helped to create a body of surgical knowledge that is still used today. Watson died on 1 September 1929 in London, England.

Catherine "Kate" Klise (born April 13 in Manhattan, New York City) is an American journalist and author. Klise is a senior correspondent for Newsweek, where she covers the intersection of business and politics. She has also written for The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal, and Fortune. Klise was raised in the suburbs of Washington D.C. She graduated from Stanford University in 2004 with a degree in political science. After graduation, Klise worked as a research associate at the Hoover Institution at Stanford University before joining Newsweek as a correspondent in 2007. In 2010, Klise wrote "The Outsiders: Eight Unconventional CEOs and Their Radically Rational Blueprint for Success", which chronicled the careers of CEOs such as Indra Nooyi, Meg Whitman, and Jack Welch. The book was named one of the best business books of 2010 by Publishers Weekly and Bloomberg Businessweek. Klise is married to Alex Klein, a senior editor at Time magazine.

The North Wessex Downs Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty (AONB) is located in the English counties of Berkshire, Hampshire, Oxfordshire and Wiltshire. The name North Wessex Downs is not a traditional one, the area covered being better known by various overlapping local names, including the Berkshire Downs, the North Hampshire Downs, the White Horse Hills, the Lambourn Downs, the Marlborough Downs, the Vale of Pewsey and Savernake Forest. Topography The AONB covers an area of some . It takes the form of a horseshoe, with the open end facing east, surrounding the town of Newbury and the River Kennet catchment area. The northern arm reaches as far east as the suburbs of Reading in mid-Berkshire and as far north as Didcot in South Oxfordshire, whilst the southern arm extends to Basingstoke in northern Hampshire. To the west, the AONB reaches as far as Calne and Devizes. The highest points are the 297 m (974 ft) summit of Walbury Hill, situated southeast of Hungerford in West Berkshire (and the highest point in southern England east of the Mendip Hills), and the Milk Hill-Tan Hill plateau northeast of Devizes in central Wiltshire, at 295 m (968 ft) above sea level.

Oswald Tilghman (March 7, 1841 – June 6, 1908) was an American lawyer, soldier and politician who served as the 23rd Governor of Maryland from 1885 to 1889. As governor, Tilghman presided over an era of economic development in Maryland. Tilghman was born in Baltimore, Maryland on March 7, 1841. He was the son of Sarah (née Hill) and Dr. Joseph Tilghman. Oswald Tilghman studied law and was admitted to the bar in 1864. He began his professional career as a law clerk for Judge James H. Keogh. Tilghman later served as a deputy attorney general for Maryland and as the state's solicitor general. In 1881, Tilghman was elected as the 23rd Governor of Maryland, serving from 1885 to 1889. During his time as governor, Tilghman presided over an era of economic development in Maryland. He also advocated for increased education funding and improved public health initiatives. After leaving office, Tilghman resumed his legal career and died in Baltimore on June 6, 1908.

Lowercase (sometimes stylized as lowercase) was a band from Palm Desert, California, led by Imaad Wasif on vocals and guitar and Brian Girgus on drums. The band put out 2 full-length albums on the Minneapolis label Amphetamine Reptile before recording their last LP for Vern Rumsey of Unwound's label, Punk In My Vitamins. Tours with Sebadoh, Karp, Unwound, Hovercraft, Caustic Resin, The Lies, Faith No More, and Chokebore helped gain them a national as well as international following. History The band first formed in 1993 in Palm Desert, California by guitarist and vocalist Imaad Wasif and drummer Brian Girgus. Initially, Girgus played bass, however he switched to the drums when the group faced difficulty finding a drummer. The band issued their debut 7-inch single titled Two Songs in early 1994 through Punk In My Vitamins?, an independent label operated by Vern Rumsey, the bassist of Unwound. The duo followed this up with a second 7-inch single, Brass Tracks, which was issued in 1995 through X-Mas Records. That same year, the band was signed onto Amphetamine Reptile Records, who issued their debut full-length All Destructive Urges... Seem So Perfect on November 11, 1996. That same year, the band moved out to San Francisco, where they would stay until their disbandment in 2000.

Eitan Tchernov (1935–December 13, 2002) was an Israeli mathematician who made significant contributions to the theory of partial differential equations and to the theory of dynamical systems. Tchernov was born in 1935 in Kiev, Ukraine. He earned his AB from the University of Toronto in 1957 and his MA from the University of Cambridge in 1958. He was a graduate student at the University of California, Berkeley from 1958 to 1959, and then a post-doctoral fellow at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, New Jersey from 1959 to 1962. He was an assistant professor at Tel Aviv University from 1962 to 1964, and then a full professor there from 1964 to 1982. He became a professor at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem in 1982. Tchernov was a member of the Israeli Academy of Sciences and Humanities (1983), the Royal Society (1984), and the American Academy of Arts and Sciences (1985). In 1998 he was awarded the Israel Prize for mathematics. Tchernov died on December 13, 2002, in Jerusalem.

Elias Panayiotis Gyftopoulos (; July 4, 1927June 23, 2012) was a Greek-American engineer who contributed to thermodynamics both in its general formulation and its quantum foundations. Gyftopoulos received an undergraduate degree in mechanical and electrical engineering in 1953 from the National Technical University of Athens, and a Doctor of Science degree in electrical engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1958. At MIT, he initially focused on nuclear reactor safety and control. After meeting professors George N. Hatsopoulos and Joseph H. Keenan, his interests moved towards thermodynamics, in an attempt to give a consistent and rigorous exposition, free of the logical flaws and the limitations commonly associated with this discipline: the result was a non-statistical theory, applicable to both macroscopic and microscopic systems, both in equilibrium and in non-equilibrium. His research culminated in the effort to give a quantum basis to thermodynamics with a physical theory unifying mechanics and Thermodynamics.

Mirijevo is an urban neighborhood of Belgrade, Serbia. It is located in Belgrade's municipality of Zvezdara. One of the largest single neighborhoods in Europe, consists of several sub-neighborhoods (Staro & Novo Mirijevo, Mirijevo II-IV, etc.) Location and geography Mirijevo is located 11 kilometers east of downtown Belgrade, on the eastern outskirts of Belgrade's urban zone. It extends into the neighborhoods of Ćalije on the north, Zvezdara on the west and Mali Mokri Lug (Zeleno Brdo) on the south. The neighborhood developed in the valley of Mirijevski potok (creek which is a right tributary to the Danube, at the neighborhood of Rospi Ćuprija), between the Zvezdara hill in the west (253 meters), Orlovica hill (274 meters, read as Orlovitsa; on some city maps given as Orlovača) in the north-east and Stojčino hill (274 meters) in the south, so the neighborhood today mostly develops in the south-east, the only remaining unurbanized part of the valley.

The Endeavour Leadership Program, formerly Endeavour Scholarships and Fellowships, formerly Endeavour Awards, was an internationally competitive, merit-based scholarship programme that formed part of the Australian Government's $1.4 billion Australian initiative. The programme brought leading researchers, executives and students to Australia to undertake short or long term study, research and professional development in a broad range of disciplines, and enabled Australians to do the same abroad. It aimed at developing linkages between involved nations. The Endeavour Awards were established as part of the 2003 International Education Package Engaging the World Through Education. Through international, merit-based competition, the Endeavour Awards bring leading researchers, professionals and students to Australia. The Australian Scholarships, a $1.4 billion Australian Government initiative, brings under the one umbrella the scholarship programmes managed by the federal government and AusAID. Over the five years from July 2006, Australian Scholarships have doubled the number of Australian Government funded scholarships available in the Asia-Pacific region.

"Behind the Laughter" is the twenty-second and final episode of the fourth season of the American television sitcom "The Office", and the show's eighty-second episode overall. It originally aired on NBC in the United States on May 16, 2009. In the episode, Michael Scott (Steve Carell) and his team compete in a charity auction to raise money for a homeless shelter. The entire office competes in a charity auction to raise money for a homeless shelter. Michael Scott (Steve Carell) and his team begin by bidding on items such as a weekend at a spa, tickets to a Broadway show, and a private dinner with Ryan Seacrest. Eventually, they are outbid by Pam Beesly (Jenna Fischer), who bids on a trip to Italy with her husband. Michael is disappointed that he didn't win the trip, but he is glad that he raised money for the shelter. The rest of the office also congratulates him and gives him medals for his fundraising efforts. Michael then decides to spend his vacation at the shelter instead of at Pam's house.

Nabta Playa was once a large internally stratified salt lake in the Egyptian Sahara. It has an area of about 2,000 km² and a maximum depth of about 120 m. The playa is now almost completely dry, and its former surface is covered with a layer of windblown sand. The Nabta Playa landscape is dominated by the large, U-shaped salt lake, which is about 2 km wide at its widest point and 3-4 km long. The eastern side of the lake is raised about 10 m above surrounding desert by an ancient sand dune system. This region is known as the "Highlands of Nabta". The Nabta Playa Lake was one of the largest lakes in Egypt during the Pliocene and Pleistocene epochs, when it had a surface area of about 8,000 km². The lake was about 125 m deep and probably reached a maximum depth of 120 m. Nabta Playa was formed about 55,000 years ago when a low-lying area of the Egyptian Sahara was inundated by a large brackish water body during the Late Pliocene or Early Pleistocene epoch. The playa was later filled with windblown sand and became almost completely dry.

Celestia Susannah Parrish (September 12, 1853 – September 7, 1918) was an American educator. She was born the daughter of a plantation owner, William Perkins Parrish (1816-1863), and Lucinda Jane Walker (1828-1863), on September 12, 1853 in Pittsylvania County, Virginia. Her father was a plantation owner of moderate wealth and position. He supported her intellectual ambitions. At age 5 she attended a private school on the plantation. Her parents passed away during the Civil War leaving her, her younger brother, and her sister to live with their uncle and two aunts. She was orphaned by age 10 and was taken under the care of relatives until her uncle's death five years later. Her uncle disapproved of girls receiving an education so she read all the books in her aunt's library. In 1865 she attended a private school in Callands, Virginia. At that point, she took up a job as a community schoolteacher to support her younger brother and her sister but struggled with her early teaching experiences.

Isaac Montgomery Barr (March 2, 1847 – January 18, 1937) was an Anglican clergyman and promoter of British colonial settlement schemes, most notably the Barr Colony which became Lloydminster and District in Alberta and Saskatchewan, Canada. Early life and education Isaac M. Barr was born in Hornby, Canada West (now part of Halton Hills in Ontario, Canada). His father, William Barr, born in 1816 in Ireland, was a Presbyterian Minister. Isaac Barr’s mother Catharine (Baird) Barr, also born in Ireland, died when Isaac was 10 years old. Isaac Barr’s early education was in a small rural school where the teacher was his father, supplementing his modest ministerial stipend. William Barr brought much of his ministerial approach to education and young Isaac emulated his father by playing the role of preacher in childhood games. From 1868 – 1870 Barr attended Huron College, in London, Ontario, with the intention of becoming an Anglican cleric. In 1870, he moved his studies to the University of Toronto. Following graduation he began his ministerial career as a curate in Exeter and Woodstock, Ontario.

The Anteroom is the fifth studio album by the American rock band Phish, released on October 6, 2000. Recorded at The Warehouse in Athens, Georgia, during the band's 1998 summer tour, it is the first album of new material since 1990's Junta. The album was met with mixed reviews from critics, but was commercially successful, reaching number 25 on the Billboard 200 chart. Several singles were released from the album, including "Waste" and "Lawn Boy". "The Anteroom" has been certified platinum by the RIAA. The Anteroom was recorded at The Warehouse in Athens, Georgia during Phish's 1998 summer tour. The album is the first new material since 1990's Junta. The album received mixed reviews from critics. Greg Kot of the Chicago Tribune wrote that while "the band's trademark humor and improvisational virtuosity are in evidence", he found that "much of what they offer is familiar fare." However, he praised the album's "catchy tunes" and concluded that it is "a reasonably satisfying return to form." At Metacritic, which assigns a normalized rating out of 100 to reviews from mainstream critics, the album has an average score of 61, based on 17 reviews. The Anteroom was commercially successful. It reached number 25 on the Billboard 200 chart and was certified platinum by the RIAA. Several singles were released from the album, including "Waste" and "Lawn Boy".
