Lumley Thelwall was a Welsh politician who sat in the House of Commons in 1656. Thelwall was the son of either Simon or Edward Thelwall of Plas-y-ward. He was a captain in the Parliamentary army. In April 1649 he was ordered to take his troop to Ireland. On "18 June 1649, Calendar State Papers record "Letters that the inhabitants of Drayton in Shropshire, on the last Lord's Day in the Night, fell upon Capt. Thelwel's Troop, and disarmed and pillaged them. Col. Clive late M.P. caused great alarm, having led a riotous multitude to attack the troop of horse of Capt. Lumley Thelwell, and dispersed them as traitors and rebels, and seized and sold their horses in the open market in Salop" . An order of the Council of State was made 30 September 1650 for writing a letter to the Lord Deputy of Ireland, recommending Capt. Lumley Thelwall for the office of Sword Bearer in Ireland. In 1656, he was elected Member of Parliament for Denbighshire for the Second Protectorate Parliament replacing John Jones who chose to sit for Merioneth.

Allan Arthur Pearse (22 April 1915 – 14 June 1981) played first-class cricket for Somerset in nine matches between 1936 and 1938. He was born and died at Watchet, Somerset. Pearse was a middle-order right-handed batsman whose club cricket was for Watchet Cricket Club, where Harold Gimblett was his contemporary. As a 16-year-old, playing for Watchet against Wellington Cricket Club, he joined Gimblett with the Watchet score at 37 for seven chasing a total of 160. The pair added the 123 runs needed, Gimblett scoring 91 and Pearse 33. Pearse followed Gimblett into the Somerset side, making his debut in 1936 at the Agricultural Showgrounds, Frome, the same ground where Gimblett had made his sensational debut a year earlier. In his first innings he scored 20, which was the second highest of the Somerset innings against Kent. But in five other first-class matches in the 1936 season he failed to score more than 10 in any innings, and in two matches in 1937 he also made little impression. His last first-class game in 1938 saw him batting at No 10 and failing to score in either innings.

The Toronto Roadrunners were an ice hockey team in the Ontario Hockey League. The Roadrunners played their home games at the Scarborough Civic Centre in Scarborough, Ontario. The Toronto Roadrunners were founded in 1996 as an expansion team to the Ontario Hockey League. They were originally known as the Toronto Jr. Canadiens, and played their first season in the league at the Metro Centre in Toronto. The team finished last in their inaugural season, but improved markedly the following year, qualifying for the playoffs for the first time and losing to the Ottawa 67s in the Division Semi-Final. In 1998, the Roadrunners moved to their current home, Scarborough Civic Centre. The team made it to the OHL Finals that year, but lost to the Peterborough Petes. In 1999, they made it to the OHL Finals again, this time defeating the Kitchener Rangers to win their first OHL championship. The Roadrunners remained a playoff team throughout most of their tenure in the OHL, reaching the playoffs every year from 1998 until 2007, when they finished second in their division and did not qualify for the playoffs. In 2008, however, they qualified for the playoffs and reached the Eastern Conference Final before being eliminated by eventual champions London Knights. Fazal Mahmood (Punjabi, ), (18 February 1927 – 10 June 2010) was a Pakistani singer and actor. In a career spanning six decades, Mahmood was known for his soulful and emotive voice, and his versatile stage skills. He attained popular acclaim for his work in Pakistani films, notably for his roles in the historical dramas "Sarfarosh" (1973) and "Zindagi Na Milegi Dobara" (2007). Mahmood was born on 18 February 1927 in Lahore, Punjab, British India. He originally wanted to be a doctor, but shifted to music after he saw an advertisement for a singing contest. Mahmood initially started out as a qawwali singer, but soon began performing pop and folk songs as well. He first came to prominence in the 1960s, when he performed regularly on Pakistani television shows. In 1973, Mahmood starred in the historical drama "Sarfarosh", which won him widespread critical acclaim. The following year, he appeared in the romantic comedy "Dil Chahta Hai". Mahmood subsequently starred in several other commercially successful films, including "Ajaib Nahi Aaya" (1976), "Insaaf" (1981), and "Tere Bin Laden" (2008). He also appeared in several notable stage plays, including the 1972 play "Mera Naam Joker" and the 2006 play "Naya Khiladi". Burnet Rhett Maybank (March 7, 1899September 1, 1988) was an American historian, who specialized in the history of the American South. He was the Sterling Professor of History at Yale University from 1948 to 1971, and president of the American Historical Association from 1959 to 1960. Maybank was born in 1899 in Nashville, Tennessee. He attended Vanderbilt University, where he received his B.A. in 1922 and his M.A. in 1923. He then attended the University of Chicago, where he received his Ph.D. in 1935. Maybank began his teaching career at Duke University in 1935, where he served as a professor until 1948 when he became Sterling Professor of History at Yale University. During his tenure at Yale, Maybank mentored many young historians and was known for his meticulous research and writing style. He retired from Yale in 1971 and died in 1988. Maybank's writings focused primarily on the history of the American South, and he is considered one of the leading historians of that region. His notable works include "The South Since 1865" (1948), "The Negro in American History" (1948), "The Southern Dilemma" (1956), and "The Political Economy of Slavery" (1969). He also wrote numerous articles for journals such as "The Journal of Southern History" and "The American Historical Review".

William Wishart Biddle (June 19, 1900 – September 9, 1979) was an American lawyer who served as the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York from 1949 to 1963. He is best known for his prosecution of Alger Hiss, a high-ranking State Department official accused of being a Soviet spy. William W. Biddle was born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania on June 19, 1900. After graduating from Princeton University in 1921, he studied law at the Harvard Law School. He served as a naval aviator during World War II, achieving the rank of lieutenant commander. Biddle was appointed United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York by President Harry S. Truman in 1949. He served in that position until his retirement in 1963. During his tenure, he prosecuted several high-profile cases, including the prosecution of Alger Hiss. Biddle died on September 9, 1979 in Woodstock, Virginia.

Remember..., released in Australia under the title "Remember When", is a 2004 Australian drama film directed by Greg McLean and written by McLean and Reg Watson. The film is based on the true story of two backpackers, Dean Wells (Sam Neill) and Karen Matthews (Mia Wasikowska), who are kidnapped in Australia in 1994 and held hostage for 15 months. The film premiered at the 2004 Cannes Film Festival, where it won the Palme d'Or. It was nominated for three Academy Awards, including Best Picture. The film tells the story of Dean Wells (Sam Neill) and Karen Matthews (Mia Wasikowska), two backpackers who are kidnapped in Australia in 1994 and held hostage for 15 months. They are held in remote locations, such as the Australian Outback and the Torres Strait Islands, until they are freed by police. The kidnapping has a profound effect on both of them; Wells becomes reclusive and suffers from post-traumatic stress disorder, while Matthews becomes promiscuous and addicted to drugs. They eventually marry and have a child.

Michael Christopher Sheen (born 5 February 1969) is a Welsh actor, television producer and political activist. After training at London's Royal Academy of Dramatic Art (RADA), he worked mainly in theatre throughout the 1990s and made notable stage appearances in Romeo and Juliet (1992), Don't Fool with Love (1993), Peer Gynt (1994), The Seagull (1995), The Homecoming (1997), and Henry V (1997). His performances in Amadeus at the Old Vic and Look Back in Anger at the National Theatre were nominated for Olivier Awards in 1998 and 1999, respectively. In 2003, he was nominated for a third Olivier Award for his performance in Caligula at the Donmar Warehouse. Sheen has become better known as a screen actor since the 2000s, in particular through his roles in various biographical films. For writer Peter Morgan, he starred in a trilogy of films as UK prime minister Tony Blair: the television film The Deal in 2003, followed by The Queen (2006) and The Special Relationship (2010), earning him nominations for both a BAFTA Award and an Emmy. He was also nominated for a BAFTA as the troubled comic actor Kenneth Williams in BBC Four's 2006 Fantabulosa!, and was nominated for a fourth Olivier Award in 2006 for portraying the broadcaster David Frost in Frost/Nixon, a role he revisited in the 2008 film adaptation of the play. He starred as the controversial football manager Brian Clough in The Damned United (2009).

Sir George Fairbairn (23 March 1855 – 2 January 1932) was a Scottish Liberal Party politician who served as Liberal MP for Aberdeen South from 1906 to 1918 and 1923 to 1924. Born in Aberdeen, Fairbairn was the son of George Fairbairn, a merchant, and his wife Eliza. He was educated at Aberdeen Grammar School and at the University of Edinburgh, where he graduated with an MA in 1878. In 1881 he became a lawyer and began practice in Aberdeen. He also became involved in politics and was elected to the Aberdeen City Council in 1890. Fairbairn first stood for Parliament at the 1892 general election, when he unsuccessfully contested the Aberdeen South seat. He was elected at the 1906 general election, and held his seat until 1918, when he resigned due to service in the First World War. At the 1923 general election, Fairbairn was re-elected as MP for Aberdeen South, but he resigned in 1924 due to ill health. He died two years later at the age of 73.

Gummersbach is a town in the state of North Rhine-Westphalia, Germany, being the district seat of the Oberbergischer Kreis. It is located east of Cologne. History In 1109 Gummersbach was mentioned in official documents for the first time. The document in question concerned the lowering of the episcopal tax for the church in Gummersbach by Archbishop Frederick I. At that time the name of the town was spelled as Gumeresbracht. Gummersbach received town privileges in 1857. In 1855 Gummersbach's industrial history began with the foundation of the company Steinmüller. With the company's success the little village began to grow to a town. After the company was bought in 1998 the production in Gummersbach was closed and most of the company's area was unused. Due to the fact that by the time this area made up half of the downtown area the town of Gummersbach bought this area to develop it. In the following years a multifunctional arena, shopping mall, university, movie theater, court, police station, hotel, offices and a park were built.

William Everard Pedley (16 June 1858 – 9 July 1920) was an English civil engineer and cricketer who played first-class cricket for Sussex. After emigrating to the United States he became a well known irrigation engineer in Southern California. He gave his name to the community of Pedley, California, now a neighborhood within the city of Jurupa Valley, California. England Pedley was born at Stubbing Court, Wingerworth, Derbyshire, the son of Thomas Humphrey Pedley and his wife Mary Gully, daughter of John Gully. He joined the Royal Engineers and in 1877 became a member of the Institution of Civil Engineers. In 1879 Pedley played two matches for Sussex against Kent and Surrey. Against Kent he took 7 for 36 and was not out on 16 in his second innings to help Sussex to victory. He also played for the Royal Engineers and Gentlemen of Sussex. Pedley next appeared playing for his native Derbyshire in the 1888 season.

Maraland is a region in the southeastern coast of the African continent. It is bordered by the Indian Ocean to the east, the Gulf of Aden and Red Sea to the south, Somalia to the west, and Kenya to the north. The area of Maraland is about 1,100,000 km². The region has a diverse geography with rugged coastline, fertile valleys and highlands. The highest mountain in Maraland is Mount Kilimanjaro in Tanzania, with an altitude of 5,892 m (19,341 ft). The region has a long history dating back over 2,000 years. The first inhabitants were the Himba people. They were followed by the Bantu people who migrated from central Africa. Maraland was later colonised by the Portuguese in the 16th century. The British took over during World War II and administered the region as part of Kenya. After independence in 1963, Maraland became a republic within the newly formed African Union. The economy is based largely on agriculture, with coffee being the main crop. There is also some fishing and tourism. The main languages spoken in Maraland are Swahili and English.

Nathaniel Ward (1578 – October 1652) was an English divine and antiquarian. Ward was born at Chipping Campden, Gloucestershire, in 1578, the son of Humphrey Ward, a gentleman farmer. He was educated at Winchester College and Trinity College, Cambridge, where he graduated B.A. in 1598 and M.A. in 1602. Ward became a Fellow of Trinity in 1602 and was ordained deacon in the same year and priest in 1605. He was appointed chaplain to Sir Richard Grenville, 1st Baronet, in 1610, and became vicar of Wootton Bassett in 1612. In 1614 he was appointed chaplain to King James I and in 1615 lecturer on divinity at Cambridge University. He received a Doctor of Divinity (D.D.) from Cambridge University in 1620. Ward entered the clerical household of Prince Charles, later King Charles I, as chaplain-in-ordinary in 1621. On the outbreak of the English Civil War he became chaplain to the forces under the command of Sir Thomas Fairfax and served until Fairfax's death in 1643. He then retired to his estate at Wootton Bassett but continued to take an active part in public life until his death at the age of eighty-eight years on October 1652. The shrike-babblers are a group of small birds in the genus Pteruthius. They are native to the Indomalayan realm, and were traditionally placed in the family Timaliidae before molecular phylogenetic studies in 2007 found that they were best considered as belonging to the family Vireonidae which was then thought to be restricted to the New World. They were traditionally classified into five species with several subspecies but changes in the status of these species on the basis of the phylogenetic species concept suggest more forms in a cryptic species complex. Most species are found in montane forests, with some species descending down to lower altitudes during the winter. The shrike-babblers range in size from 11.5–20 cm in length and weigh 10-48 g. They are divergent in plumage and size but all possess a stout black hooked bill, short rictal bristles and a distinctive juvenile plumage. They all exhibit sexual dimorphism in plumage, with the males generally brighter. The song is simple and monotonous.

Widewuto (also Viduutus, Vidvutus, Witowudi, Waidewut, Vaidevutis) is an extinct giant sloth that lived in North and South America during the Pleistocene epoch. It was the largest and most powerful land animal of its era, with a shoulder height of 2.3 meters (7.5 feet) and a weight of up to 1,500 kilograms (3,300 pounds). Widewuto is one of the best-known Pleistocene megafauna genera, and was named after the ancient Incan deity Wiracocha. The genus is known from a variety of specimens, including skulls, limb bones, and tusks. The species is known from only a few specimens, but is thought to have ranged across much of North and South America. Widewuto was probably an apex predator that hunted large prey such as horses, camels, and mammoths. It may have been killed by humans or by other larger animals, such as the dire wolf or saber-toothed cat. Widewuto was likely extinct by 10,000 BC, although there is some debate about its extinction date.

Juvénal Habyarimana (; ; 8 March 19376 October 1994), also known as Juvenal Bemba, was a Rwandan politician and president of Rwanda from 1973 to 1994. His rule was marked by human rights abuses, genocide and economic mismanagement. Habyarimana was born in the town of Ntarama in 1937. He attended the University of Kigali before becoming active in the nationalist movement. In 1959 he was arrested and spent six years in prison, during which time he formed close ties with the Belgian administrator Jean-Paul Akayesu. After his release he became deputy minister for youth and sports in the government of President Désiré Kabila. In 1973 Habyarimana was elected president of Rwanda on a platform of radical nationalism. He quickly became one of Africa's most powerful leaders, and his rule was marked by human rights abuses, genocide and economic mismanagement. He refused to allow foreign observers into Rwanda during the 1994 genocide, which led to widespread criticism from the international community. On 6 April 1994, Habyarimana was assassinated by members of the Rwandan Patriotic Front while travelling in a presidential plane en route to Kigali airport.

Paraspur is a Nagar Panchayat and block in Kanpur district in the state of Uttar Pradesh, India. It is located at . The Nagar Panchayat of Paraspur covers an area of and has a population of 121,964. The Block has 105 villages. The town of Paraspur is the municipal corporation headquarters for this block. Paraspur is located at . It has an average elevation of 154 metres (508 feet). The climate in Paraspur is tropical wet and dry. The average annual temperature is 27 degrees Celsius. The annual rainfall is 946 mm. The economy of Paraspur is mainly agricultural with a small industrial sector. Major crops are cotton, sugarcane, wheat, maize, and jowar. There are also poultry and dairy farms in the area. There are several fertilizer and pesticide factories in the vicinity. The main source of employment is agriculture with a small number of people working in the industrial sector.

Andrew Wachtel (born February 10, 1959) is an American scholar, translator and educator. He was Rector (President) of Narxoz University in Almaty, Kazakhstan between 2018 and 2020. Previously, he served as president of the American University of Central Asia (2010-2018) and as the Dean of The Graduate School, Northwestern University (2003-2010). Wachtel was elected to the Council on Foreign Relations (NY) in 2001 and to the American Academy of Arts and Sciences in 2003. Biography After graduating from Harvard College in 1981, Wachtel pursued a Ph.D. in Slavic Languages and Literatures at the University of California, Berkeley (completed 1987). While still a Ph.D. student, he was appointed a Junior Fellow at the Harvard Society of Fellows (1985–88). He was appointed Assistant Professor of Slavic Languages and Literatures at Stanford University, where he taught between 1988 and 1991. In 1991, he was appointed Associate Professor of Slavic Languages and Literatures at Northwestern University. He remained at Northwestern for 19 years, serving at various times as Chair of the Department of Slavic Languages and Literatures, Director of the Program in Comparative Literature, Director of the Roberta Buffett Center for International and Comparative Studies and Dean of the Graduate School.

Masculinizing hormone therapy, also known as transmasculine hormone therapy, is the use of hormones to change the physical characteristics of a person's gender. Masculinizing hormone therapy is generally used to increase masculinity in transgender people, though it can also be used to change other physical characteristics that are considered gender-nonconforming or non-masculine. It is not typically used to alter a person's sex characteristics, which are determined by their chromosomes and anatomy. Masculinizing hormone therapy is controversial and has been met with resistance from many transgender people and their advocates. Some believe that it can cause harm to transgender people and lead to undesired physical changes, while others believe that it can help trans people achieve a more masculine appearance and feel more comfortable in their own skin. There is no single approach to masculinizing hormone therapy, and each person's situation is unique. Some people choose to take hormones alone, while others combine hormones with other treatments such as surgery or psychotherapy. There is no single answer for how long masculinizing hormone therapy should last, and each person's treatment plan should be based on their individual needs and goals.

Badwater Ultramarathon 2011 participation After completing the George Archer 6 day race in South Africa, he was invited to race in the Badwater Ultramarathon in Death Valley, California, USA, which has been deemed by National Geographic as the toughest organised race in the world. He participated in the 34th edition of the Badwater Ultramarathon between 11 July and 13 July. On 13 July, he completed the race in his first attempt with a time of 41 hours 6 minutes and 1 second.

The Re-entry Permit (Form I-327) is a travel document similar to a certificate of identity, issued by the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services to U.S. lawful permanent residents to allow them to travel abroad and return to the United States. It is a passport-like booklet with a blue-green cover with the words "TRAVEL DOCUMENT" on the front. Individuals whose application for permanent residency has not yet been approved can instead apply for advance parole (Form I-512). Purpose The main purpose of the re-entry permit is to allow permanent residents to leave the United States for an extended amount of time without abandoning their permanent residence. For short trips abroad of up to one year, the Permanent Resident Card itself allows re-entry to the United States. Permanent residents must maintain their permanent residence in the United States, or lose their permanent residency. Even for trips abroad of less than one year, permanent residents may be questioned as to whether they have maintained residence in the United States. Any trip abroad of one year or more automatically causes permanent residence to be lost. If a U.S. permanent resident intends to take a long trip abroad, he/she may apply for a re-entry permit. It is issued for up to two years. It establishes that the permanent resident did not intend to abandon permanent resident status.

Jean-Barthélemy Hauréau (; 9 November 1812 – 5 December 1883) was a French painter, sculptor, and architect. Hauréau was born in Paris on 9 November 1812, the son of a sculptor named Jean-Baptiste Hauréau. He began his artistic training at the École des Beaux-Arts under François-Édouard Picot and Jean-Auguste-Dominique Ingres, but soon abandoned it to travel to Italy, where he studied under Raphael and Michelangelo. Upon his return to France, he exhibited his first paintings at the Salon of 1833. After a brief period of study in Rome, Hauréau settled in Normandy in 1837. There he became friends with Édouard Manet and Gustave Courbet, who encouraged him to pursue a career as an artist. In 1840 he exhibited two paintings at the Paris Salon: "The Baptism of Christ" and "The Return from the Tomb of Jesus". The following year he was elected to the National Academy of Design. He spent most of the 1850s travelling throughout Europe, exhibiting his paintings in Vienna, Munich, London, Dresden, Cologne, and other cities. In 1855 he received a commission to paint the ceiling of the main hall of the new Palais Bourbon in Paris; this project occupied him for six years. In 1862 Hauréau was made a Chevalier of the Legion of Honor. Hauré

The First Alcibiades, also referred to as Alcibiades I, was a statesman and general of ancient Greece. He was the son of the politician Alcibiades I and the father of the general Alcibiades II. Alcibiades first achieved prominence as a military commander, serving in the Persian War against Athens and then in the Peloponnesian War against Sparta. In 404 BC, he led an Athenian army against Thebes and was victorious, gaining him considerable power and prestige. After his victory at Cythera, Alcibiades became a political figure in Athens. He played a major role in the development of Athenian democracy, serving as its constitutional advisor from 411 to 407 BC. In 404 BC, he led an Athenian army against Thebes and was victorious, gaining him considerable power and prestige. After his victory at Cythera, Alcibiades became a political figure in Athens. He played a major role in the development of Athenian democracy, serving as its constitutional advisor from 411 to 407 BC. In 409 BC, Alcibiades was accused of corruption by Pericles, who tried to have him removed from office. Alcibiades fled to Sparta, where he made several powerful friends and obtained military support for a coup attempt against Pericles in Athens. He failed spectacularly at this attempt (409 BC), resulting in his exile from Athens for 10 years. Moses James Tyson Jr. (born May 21, 1958) is an American astrophysicist and television personality. He is the son of astrophysicist and Nobel Laureate, Dr. Samuel T. Tyson, and grandson of civil rights leader Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. He is currently a professor at the University of California, Santa Cruz. Born in New York City, Tyson began his scientific career as a high school student at The Bronx High School of Science, where he was a National Merit Scholar and winner of the NASA Fellowship for College Students. He then attended Princeton University, where he received his B.A. in physics in 1981 and his M.A. in 1983. Tyson then completed his Ph.D. at Harvard University in 1988, under the direction of Drs. Geoffrey W. Burbidge and Robert Dicke. Tyson's research focuses on the origins and evolution of stars, galaxies, and intergalactic matter. His work has been published in leading astrophysical journals, including Nature, The Astrophysical Journal Letters, and The Astrophysical Journal Supplement Series. He has also written several books on astronomy, including The Origin of Stars (1994), The Amazing Story of Cosmology (1998), and Death by Black Hole (2005). Abd al-Fattah Ismail Ali Al-Jawfi (; 28 July 1939 – 13 January 1986) was the Marxist de facto leader of People's Democratic Republic of Yemen from 1969 to 1980. He served as Chairman of the Presidium of the Supreme People's Council (head of state) and founder, chief ideologue and first leader of the Yemeni Socialist Party from 21 December 1978 to 21 April 1980. He died under mysterious circumstances during the 1986 South Yemen Civil War, where no body was found. Biography Born in July 1934 in the Hugariah district, Taiz of North Yemen, he was educated in Aden, where he subsequently worked in an oil refinery from 1956 to 1959 as an apprentice. As a co-founder of the Arab Nationalist Movement in South Yemen, he contributed to the formation of a number of Movement cells before he was arrested by the British authorities in Aden for political incitement of workers.

Cruces Basin Wilderness is a wilderness area located in the Santa Catalina Mountains, in the eastern Santa Catalina Island Group of the Channel Islands of California. The wilderness is situated within the boundaries of both Los Padres National Forest and Santa Catalina National Forest. Cruces Basin Wilderness is a 32,000 acre area that includes the headwaters of both the Little Santa Rosa and San Rafael Rivers, as well as the San Rafael Swell. The wilderness is part of the larger Santa Catalina Island Wilderness. Cruces Basin Wilderness was designated as a wilderness area in 1980. The wilderness is home to a diverse array of plants and animals, including black bears, brown bears, coyotes, eagles, foxes, mountain lions, bobcats, and rattlesnakes. There are also numerous wildflowers that can be found in the basin including lupine, phlox, larkspur, paintbrush, and ceanothus. Cruces Basin Wilderness is open to hiking, backpacking, and camping. There are several trails that crisscross through the basin including the East Ridge Trail and the West Ridge Trail.

Josh Eric Eppard (born December 6, 1979) is an American musician and songwriter, best known as the lead vocalist and pianist for the indie rock band Midtown. Eppard was born in Kansas City, Missouri, but raised in Lawrence, Kansas. He played the piano from a young age and started playing drums in middle school. In high school, he started playing guitar and writing songs. He attended the University of Michigan for music education, but dropped out after two years to focus on Midtown. Eppard has released four albums with Midtown: "The Shade" (2002), "The Hard Way" (2004), "All We Ever Wanted" (2006), and "Full Circle" (2009). He has also released two solo albums: "Shake It Out" (2011) and "Wave Goodbye" (2013). In early 2014, Eppard announced that he was going on hiatus from Midtown to focus on his solo projects. In late 2016, it was announced that he would be rejoining Midtown for their fifth album. Eppard has received praise from music critics for his unique vocals and songwriting skills. He has been nominated for several awards, including a Grammy Award nomination for Best Alternative Music Album for "All We Ever Wanted". Eppard is also a prominent activist in the LGBT community. In 2013, he came out as gay in an interview with OUT magazine.

HD 10550 is a single star in the equatorial constellation of Cetus. It is a faint star but visible to the naked eye with an apparent visual magnitude of 4.98. Based upon an annual parallax shift of , it is located around 1,100 light years from the Sun. The star is moving closer with a heliocentric radial velocity of −33 km/s. It has a high peculiar velocity of and may be a runaway star. The stellar classification of this star is , showing the spectrum of an evolved K-type giant star with an overabundance of CN in the atmosphere. The measured angular diameter of this star, after correction for limb darkening, is . At the estimated distance of this star, this yields a physical size of about 77 times the radius of the Sun. The star is radiating around 2,537 times the Sun's luminosity from its enlarged photosphere at an effective temperature of 4,110 K.

Christoph Albrecht (4 January 1930 – 24 September 2016) was a German organist, conductor, composer, musicologist, and music educator. He was born in Salzwedel. He has toured extensively as an organist, appearing in concerts and recitals throughout Europe and in the United States. He is the author of several publications on the topics of liturgy and hymnology. He has also written extensively on sacred music from the 16th through the 18th centuries, and has been instrumental in publishing many forgotten works from that period. Albrecht studied the organ with Günther Ramin. From 1943–1948 he served as organist at the Church of St. Mary in Salzwedel. In 1953 he was appointed cantor at the Naumburg Cathedral and lecturer at Kirchenmusikschule Halle. In 1960 he became director of the Kirchenmusikschule Dresden. From 1976 to 1992 he was organist and choirmaster at St. Mary's Church, Berlin. He died in Berlin in 2016.

A block wargame is a board wargame that uses blocks to represent units, terrain, and other features of the battlefield. The pieces are usually movable and can be placed on the board either as individual units or as groups. This allows for a high degree of tactical flexibility in game play. Block wargames are a relatively recent development in the world of board wargames. The first block wargame was War in the Pacific 1944, which was published in 1994 by GMT Games. Since then, many other block wargames have been published, including the popular game Steamroller from Avalon Hill. The popularity of block wargames has led to a number of variants of the original game format. Some games, like War in the Pacific 1944, use blocks to represent entire armies, while others, like Steamroller, use blocks to represent only specific unit types. Block wargames are typically very complex and difficult to play. This complexity is due not only to the use of blocks as unit representations, but also to the fact that block wargames are often designed to allow for a high degree of tactical flexibility in game play. This allows players to adjust their strategy on a moment-by-moment basis in order to take advantage of whatever situation the game may present them with.

Lionello Balestrieri (12 September 1872October 24, 1958) was an Italian composer and conductor. He is most famous for his operas, which are often based on classical or romantic themes. Born in Naples, Balestrieri studied at the Naples Conservatory with Niccolò Paganini and Pietro Mascagni. In 1895 he joined the faculty of the conservatory, where he taught composition until 1928. He also served as conductor of the Naples Philharmonic from 1904 to 1909 and of the Teatro San Carlo in Naples from 1920 to 1928. Among his notable students were Rossini Storico, Goffredo Petrassi, Luigi Dallapiccola, and Cesare Monteverdi. Balestrieri's best-known works are his operas, which are often based on classical or romantic themes. His first opera, Il trovatore (1906), was based on the opera of the same name by Giuseppe Verdi. Other well-known examples include La traviata (1911), Rigoletto (1915), and Don Giovanni (1921).

Song of Norway is an operetta written by Edvard Grieg and Ivan Turgenev in 1875. The libretto is based on the fairy tale of Norwegian king Harald Fairhair and his courtesan Gudrun. The story tells of a love triangle between the king, Gudrun, and her courtier Sigurd. Sigurd desires Gudrun but is unaware of her true feelings for the king. The king loves Gudrun but is unable to have her because of Sigurd's love for her. Gudrun eventually dies in Sigurd's arms, and the king is grief-stricken. The opera was first performed at the Kroll Opera House in Bergen on 14 January 1876, with Ivar Torgersen as Sigurd, Emmy Wettergren as Gudrun, and Edvard Grieg as the King. It was later performed at other major opera houses around Europe. The United States premiere took place at the Boston Opera House on 9 November 1887, with Frits Zerny as Sigurd, Lillian Nordica as Gudrun, and George Hoefer as the King. In 1907 the opera was performed in London at Her Majesty's Theatre with Jens Albinus in the title role and Emma Calvé as Gudrun. Petre Paul Negulescu (October 18, 1870 – February 2, 1949) was a Romanian historian, political scientist, sociologist and publicist. He was also the founder and first president of the Romanian Academy. Born in 1870 in Neamt County, Negulescu studied at the University of Vienna and then at the University of Paris, where he earned a doctorate in 1896. Returning to Romania, he became a lecturer at the University of Bucharest and then a professor at the University of Iași. From 1907 to 1909, he served as rector of the latter institution. In 1917, Negulescu founded and became president of the Romanian Academy. He served in that position until his death in 1949. Among his major works are "The History of Romania" (1920), "The History of Modern Romania" (1924), "Political Science" (1927), "Sociology" (1937), and "Public Opinion" (1939).

The vinyl revival, also known as the vinyl resurgence, is the renewed interest and increased sales of vinyl records, or gramophone records, that has been taking place in the music industry. Since 2007, vinyl records have enjoyed renewed popularity in the West and in East Asia. The analogue format made of polyvinyl chloride had been the main vehicle for the commercial distribution of pop music from the 1950s until the 1980s and 1990s when it was largely replaced by the compact disc (CD). Since the turn of the millennium, CDs have been partially replaced by digital downloads and streaming services. However, in 2007, vinyl sales made a sudden small increase, starting its comeback, and by the early 2010s, it was growing at a very quick rate. In some territories, vinyl is now more popular than it has been since the late 1980s, though vinyl records still make up only a marginal percentage (less than 6%) of overall music sales.

Lt Col Megh Singh (born 1 March 1988) is an Indian Army officer who has been awarded the Ashok Chakra, the highest military decoration for gallantry in the face of the enemy, for his role in Operation Vijay, an ambush against Pakistani troops in Jammu and Kashmir on 12 September 2016. Born to a Sikh family in Jammu and Kashmir's Kupwara district, Singh attended the Sikh National Defence Academy (SNDA) and the Royal Military Academy Sandhurst. He was commissioned into the Indian Army as a second lieutenant on 1 March 2008. After completing his training at the Infantry School of Training and Tactics, he was posted to the 16th Infantry Brigade, 7th Infantry Division. Singh has since served in various roles including that of commanding officer of the 10th battalion of the 3rd Gorkha Rifles, commanding officer of an infantry brigade and as a deputy infantry commander at Army headquarters.   In September 2016, he led an ambush against Pakistani troops in Jammu and Kashmir which killed several soldiers. The operation was hailed as a success by Indian authorities and was credited with boosting morale within Indian forces. Singh has since been awarded the Ashok Chakra for his actions.

Photo-activated localization microscopy (PALM or FPALM) and stochastic optical reconstruction microscopy (STORM) are two recently developed methods for imaging and reconstructing 3D structures with resolution less than 100 nm. FPALM and STORM are based on the use of a photosensor that detects light scattered from target objects and uses optical reconstruction methods to generate a three-dimensional image. The majority of FPALM and STORM studies have been performed using silicon probes, which offer high spatial resolution, long scan time, and small size. However, the use of silicon probes also has several disadvantages, including the need for cryogenic conditions and the susceptibility to damage from water and other chemicals. The development of organic semiconductor photo detectors has led to the development of PALM and STORM using organic photo probes. By using organic photo detectors, PALM and STORM can be implemented in a variety of devices including mobile phones, digital cameras, and microscopes. Additionally, PALM and STORM can be used to image multiple targets simultaneously, which is a major advantage over FPALM and STORM.

Vicarage Hill is a cricket ground located in Cheltenham, Gloucestershire. The ground has been used for first-class and List A cricket since 1892 and it has hosted 44 first-class matches, the last of which was in 2006. It has also hosted 54 List A matches, the last of which was in 2002. The ground is located in the town centre, adjacent to Cheltenham Racecourse and a short distance from the Gloucester ring road. The first recorded match on the ground was in 1892 between Cheltenham College and Cheltenham Town. From 1902 to 1902 the ground hosted Gloucester Town in the Minor Counties Championship. In 1902, 1903, 1904 and 1905 Cheltenham College played Gloucester Town in the annual University Match. From 1906 to 1907 Cheltenham College played a combined team of Oxford University and Cambridge University in a series of four matches. In 1908, 1909 and 1910 Cheltenham College played Oxford University in three matches. In 1911 Cheltenham College played Cambridge University in a single match. The ground first hosted major cricket when it played host to one of the two semi-finals of the 1928 Benson & Hedges Cup. The other semi-final was held at Lord's Cricket Ground. The ground has also hosted one final of the Benson & Hedges Cup, in 1954 when Cambridge University won against Oxford University by 8 wickets. Stillwater (, meaining: "Water quiet") is a city in, and the county seat of, Payne County, Oklahoma, United States. It is located in north-central Oklahoma at the intersection of U.S. Route 177 and State Highway 51. As of the 2010 census, the city population was 45,688, making it the tenth-largest city in Oklahoma. The Stillwater Micropolitan Statistical Area had a population of 78,399 according to the 2012 census estimate. Stillwater was part of the first Oklahoma Land Run held on April 22, 1889, when the Unassigned Lands were opened for settlement and became the core of the new Oklahoma Territory. The city charter was adopted on August 24, 1889, and operates under a council-manager government system. Stillwater has a diverse economy with a foundation in aerospace, agribusiness, biotechnology, optoelectronics, printing and publishing, and software and standard manufacturing. Stillwater is home to the main campus of Oklahoma State University (the city's largest employer) as well as Northern Oklahoma College – Stillwater, Meridian Technology Center, and the Oklahoma Department of Career and Technology Education. The city is home to the National Wrestling Hall of Fame and Museum.

Alan John Julian (born 11 March 1983) is an English football coach and former footballer. Born in Barnsley, Yorkshire, Julian joined Sheffield Wednesday as an apprentice in 1999 and made his first-team debut in 2001. He spent four seasons with the club, making 129 appearances and scoring six goals before joining Rotherham United in 2006. Julian spent three seasons with Rotherham, making 108 appearances and scoring three goals before signing for Bradford City on a free transfer in 2009. He made 131 appearances and scored 12 goals for Bradford City, before joining Notts County on a free transfer in 2013. He made 73 appearances and scored nine goals for Notts County before joining Lincoln City on a free transfer in January 2016. He made 26 appearances and scored one goal for Lincoln City before retiring in May 2016. Julian began his coaching career with Sheffield Wednesday as an assistant coach under Stuart Gray in the 2013–14 season. In December 2016, he was appointed head coach of National League club Grimsby Town. Julian left Grimsby Town in January 2019 after two unsuccessful spell as head coach.

Changsha–Kunming high-speed railway is a China Railway high-speed rail line that connects the provincial capitals of Changsha in Hunan and Kunming in Yunnan. The line is expected to reduce travel time between the two cities from around 5 hours by train to less than 2 hours. Construction on the line began in 2007 and was completed in 2013. The Changsha–Kunming railway is a key part of China's national high-speed rail network. It links Changsha, the capital of Hunan Province, with Kunming, the capital of Yunnan Province, and cuts travel time between the two cities from around 5 hours by train to less than 2 hours. The line was constructed at a cost of $8.5 billion and was completed in 2013. The Changsha–Kunming high-speed railway has eight stations, including Changsha Railway Station and Kunming Railway Station. The line has a total length of 449 kilometres and can accommodate trains travelling up to 300 km/h.

Unstan ware is the name used by potters in the United Kingdom for a type of earthenware made from a slip and stoneware body and a glazed, painted or enamelled cover. Unstan ware is a type of earthenware made in the United Kingdom from a slip and stoneware body and a glazed, painted or enamelled cover. The slip is made from a clay that is very soft and easily worked, while the stoneware body is harder and more durable. The cover is usually brightly coloured and designed to match the interior of the pot. Unstan ware was first produced in the late 18th century by Josiah Wedgwood, who named it after his son-in-law, Unstan. Wedgwood was famous for his fine earthenware productions, many of which were marked with his trademark ‘Wedgwood’s wonder’. Unstan ware was popular among the British middle classes during the Georgian era, and was often used for decorative purposes rather than as cookware.

Cottonwood, including the Cottonwood Ranch and Cottonwood House, is an unincorporated settlement in the North Cariboo region of the Central Interior of British Columbia, Canada. Originally a ranch, it is located in the northern Cariboo Plateau, just 8 km northwest of Coldspring House, which is at the confluence of the Swift River and Lightning Creek, which is the beginning of the Cottonwood River. Lightning Creek was one of the more famous of the gold-bearing creeks of the Cariboo Gold Rush. Cottonwood House Historic Site Cottonwood House Historic Site is a store, museum and heritage property located on the right bank of the Cottonwood River, adjacent to the highway from Quesnel to Wells and Barkerville, which was the "capital" of the Cariboo Gold Rush; the route of the highway is nearly identical to that of the Cariboo Wagon Road, which ran from Yale at the foot of the Fraser Canyon and the head of steamboat navigation on the Fraser to Barkerville. Cottonwood House was the last major roadhouse on the route before its terminus at Barkerville, although Coldspring House and Beaver Pass House are just farther along the route. Its provincial park status was cancelled by Order in Council in 1999, but it remains a provincial heritage property.

The Shapiro time delay effect, or gravitational time delay, is an anomaly in the laws of physics that was first predicted by physicist Irwin Shapiro in the early 1960s. It occurs when the gravitational field of an object affects the time passing in a surrounding medium. The Shapiro time delay effect is a strange phenomenon that was first predicted by physicist Irwin Shapiro in the early 1960s. It occurs when the gravitational field of an object affects the time passing in a surrounding medium. The effect is due to the way that gravity works - it affects the movement of particles and objects inside a gravitational field. This can cause them to experience a delay in their natural progression, or even to stop altogether. The Shapiro time delay effect can have strange and unexpected consequences. For example, it has been shown to cause objects to move faster in certain directions than they would otherwise, and it can even cause them to fall towards a central point faster than they would if there were no gravitational field present. Although the effect is still relatively unknown, researchers are continuing to explore its potential implications.

Warren N. Lieberfarb (born September 28, 1943) is an American economist and former Deputy Assistant Secretary of Labor for Economic Policy in the United States Department of Labor during the Clinton Administration. Lieberfarb earned his A.B. from Harvard College in 1965 and his M.A. and Ph.D. from the University of Chicago in 1968 and 1971, respectively. He has been a professor at Boston University since 1971, where he is currently a Distinguished Service Professor of Economics and Public Affairs. Lieberfarb is the author or editor of fifteen books, including The Economics of Poverty and Inequality (with Emmanuel Saez), The Political Economy of Social Security Reform (with Donald Boudreaux), and Why Government Fails: A Guide to Fixing Our Broken System (with Bruce Bartlett). He has written more than 1,000 academic articles, reviews, and op-eds. Lieberfarb has been a visiting professor at the London School of Economics, the Université Libre de Bruxelles, the University of Cologne, and the Universidad Autónoma de Madrid. He has served on the editorial boards of Economic Policy Review, Journal of Economic Perspectives, Public Choice, and Social Science Quarterly. In October 2009, Lieberfarb testified before the U.S. Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions on "The Macroeconomic Effects of Health Reform: An Update."

King's Highway 409, commonly referred to as Highway 409, is a 96.4 km (60.8 mi) long north–south highway in the Canadian province of Ontario. The highway runs from the US border near Fort Erie to the city of Burlington, and it intersects with Highway 401 in Niagara Falls. Highway 409 serves as a main route between Toronto and the Niagara Region, and it also serves as a connector between the Toronto area and southern Ontario. The section of Highway 409 between Fort Erie and Hamilton is known as the Golden Horseshoe Route. The highway has been designated as a National Historic Site of Canada.[1] The highway was first designated in 1926 as part of Highway 2, which extended from Windsor to Sarnia. The section of Highway 409 between Hamilton and Burlington was designated as Highway 9 in 1937. The section of Highway 409 between Fort Erie and Niagara Falls was designated as the Queen's Highway in 1954. In 1987, the designation was extended to include the portion of Highway 409 between Hamilton and Niagara Falls.[2]

Johann Staden (baptized 2 July 1581 – buried 4 October 1637) was a German physician, alchemist and astrologer. He is considered one of the most significant figures in the history of chemistry and is also credited with being one of the first chemists to isolate and identify sulfuric acid. Staden was born in Aurich, Lower Saxony, the son of a weaver. After completing his primary and secondary education in Aurich, he studied medicine at the University of Wittenberg, where he was influenced by Johannes Agricola. After completing his studies in 1606, he moved to Basel to study alchemy with Michael Maier. In 1614 he moved to Frankfurt am Main, where he began to practice medicine. He also began to lecture on chemistry and astrology at the University of Frankfurt. In 1616 Staden met Johann Glauber, who was at that time working on a salt project at the Royal Salt Works in Darmstadt. Glauber invited Staden to work with him on this project, and Staden accepted. The two men completed their work on the salt project in 1624. This accomplishment marked the beginning of Staden's long career as a chemist. In 1625 Staden moved to Jena, where he became associate professor of medicine and chemistry at the University of Jena. In 1627 he was made head of the university's medical school. The Aleutian Islands campaign was a military campaign conducted by the United States, Canada, and Japan in the Aleutian Islands, part of the Territory of Alaska, in the American Theater and the Pacific Theater of World War II starting on June 3, 1942. In the only two invasions of the United States during the war of a U.S. incorporated territory, a small Japanese force occupied the islands of Attu and Kiska, where the remoteness of the islands and the challenges of weather and terrain delayed a larger American-Canadian force sent to eject them for nearly a year. Successful Japanese invasions of other U.S. territories, which were unincorporated territories, in the western Pacific shortly after the Attack on Pearl Harbor included Wake Island, Guam, and the Philippines. The islands' strategic value was their ability to control Pacific transportation routes as US General Billy Mitchell stated to the U.S. Congress in 1935, "I believe that in the future, whoever holds Alaska will hold the world. I think it is the most important strategic place in the world." The Japanese reasoned that control of the Aleutians would prevent a possible US attack across the Northern Pacific. Similarly, the US feared that the islands would be used as bases from which to carry out a full-scale aerial attack on US West Coast cities like Anchorage, Seattle, San Francisco, or Los Angeles.

Keevin Galbraith (born 1979) attended high school and played lacrosse at Malvern Prep. Keevin was a student-athlete at the University of Delaware and was a four year defensive starter on the lacrosse team. At Delaware, Keevin earned All-tournament team in 2000 and 2001, 1st team All-Conference in 2001 and was one of two players from UD to play in the North South game in 2001. He was also chosen as one of the top 40 Seniors in 2001 to play in the 1st MLL combine. After college, Keevin was signed as a free agent by the Philadelphia Wings in the NLL, where he played five years, from 2002 to 2006. To improve his indoor game, he went to Vancouver, Canada to play for the North Shore Thunder during 2002 and 2003 summers. He was then picked up by the New York Titans as a free agent in 2006, and played three years before deciding to retire. In 2007, Keevin was 1 of 23 players chosen to play for the USA indoor national team, and helped the team win a bronze medal. Keevin also played for the world champion Philadelphia Barrage in 2006. In 2010 Keevin was asked to be an assistant coach for Team USA in the indoor world games where he coached the likes of Casey Powell and Paul Rabil.

Magic Millions Sales Pty Ltd is an Australian Thoroughbred racehorse auction house which holds auctions around Australia each year including its world famous Gold Coast Yearling Sale at Surfers Paradise in Queensland. Seven days of auctions are joined by a major Thoroughbred horse race meeting where all nine races are only open to horses who were bought at auctions staged by Magic Millions over the previous years. The race events includes the $2 million Magic Millions Classic for two-year-olds - a race which carries a $500,000 bonus for all female raced runners. The Gold Coast Raceday alone boasts prizemoney of $10 million and was the first race meeting held in Australasia with a $10 million total purse. The Gold Coast Yearling Sale is considered to be a top level auction in global racing circles, with buyers from Hong Kong, Japan, Europe, South Africa, New Zealand, China, the United States and the Middle East. The record for an individual horse purchase as a yearling was made by Patinack Farm twice at the 2008 Magic Millions where that team spent $2.2 million on two Redoute's Choice colts - one a three quarter brother to Dance Hero and one a three quarter brother to their stable star Casino Prince.

Durham University scientists studied a ` clump ' of dark matter . It was found to lag behind the galaxy it was associated with . This suggests dark matter particles can self-interact and slow down . It means dark matter may not be as oblivious to our universe as we thought .

Michael Edward Killeen Hussey (born 27 May 1981) is an Australian cricketer who has represented both Australia and New Zealand in international cricket. He is a right-handed batsman and right-arm medium pace bowler. Hussey made his first-class debut for New South Wales in the 2000–01 season, and played for the state team until the end of the 2007–08 season. He then moved to Tasmania, where he played for the state team from 2008 to 2013. Hussey was selected to play for Australia in the 2010 ICC World Cricket League Division Two tournament. He made his Test debut for Australia against Pakistan in the same tournament. Hussey played three Tests for Australia in 2010, scoring 213 runs at an average of 41.33, with a high score of 85 not out. He also played one Test for New Zealand in March 2012, scoring 162 not out. Hussey was named Man of the Match in both Tests against Pakistan. In December 2013, Hussey signed a three-year contract with English county side Surrey. He made his debut for Surrey in the 2014 County Championship against Durham. In February 2018, Hussey announced his retirement from professional cricket.

Three Legged Cross is an extended village within Verwood civil parish in east Dorset, England. It lies to the south of the town of Verwood and to the north of West Moors. Its population in 2014 was estimated at 2,740. Origins Various explanations have been put forward for the etymology of 'Three Legged Cross', which is recorded as a toponym from the sixteenth century onwards. One theory is that a type of gibbet known as a 'three-legged mare' once stood here; another theory is that there may once have been a boundary stone in the area marking the convergence of three great estates: Lord Shaftesbury's to the west, Lord Normanton's to the north and east, and the nineteenth-century banking family, the Rolles-Fryer's, to the south. The simpler explanation is that the name signifies the zigzagging configuration of the B3072 through this district, whereby the road is effectively divided into three separate stretches, or 'legs'.

Bhola Thapa (born July 7, 1967) is a Nepali educationist, researcher, author and the Vice Chancellor of Kathmandu University. He is also a Professor in the Department of Mechanical Engineering at Kathmandu University. Early life and education Thapa initially received his School Leaving Certificate from HMG board from Laboratory High School, Kirtipur, Kathmandu in 1983. He then got his Proficiency Certificate Level (Science) from Amrit Science Campus, Lainchaur, Kathmandu in 1986 under Tribhuvan University. Thapa completed his Bachelor of Engineering in Mechanical Engineering from Punjab Engineering College and got his degree from Panjab University, Chandigarh, India in 1991. Thapa completed his Master of Engineering in Mechanical Engineering in 1999 from Birla Institute of Technology and Science, Pilani, Rajasthan, India. Thapa then worked from April 2001 – September 2004 to receive his PhD in thesis title Sand Erosion in Hydraulic Machinery from Institute of Energy and Process Engineering, Norwegian University of Science and Technology (NTNU), Trondheim, Norway.

Olympia Provisions (formerly Olympic Provisions) is an American meat and restaurant company that produces artisan charcuterie based out of Portland, Oregon. Background and history Founded in 2009 as Olympic Provisions, the company began as Oregon's first USDA salumeria in a 900 square foot production facility attached to a European-inspired restaurant in the Olympic Cereal Mill building. The owners came from a variety of backgrounds, with Nate Tilden also co-owning Clyde Common and Elias Cairo having background as a chef and first generation Greek-American. The idea began when Elias Cairo decided he wanted to open a meat plant inside of a restaurant, and he gathered a group of cofounders which included his sister Michelle, Tilden, Martin Schwartz, and Tyler Gaston. Nate Tilden and Elias Cairo worked together at Castagna prior to opening Olympia Provisions, where Cairo served as head chef. The company began by selling their salami exclusively at farmers' markets and in their restaurant. After receiving nationwide recognition they needed to expand their production facility to meet their demand. In April 2011, Olympia Provisions opened a second restaurant alongside a 4,000 square foot production facility. Two years later, Olympia Provisions had outgrown its second production facility, and in February 2014 production moved to a 34,000 square foot building two blocks from the Southeast restaurant. Currently, Olympia Provisions participates in seventeen farmers' markets throughout the Pacific Northwest. The company's products are sold in Whole Foods and Trader Joe's stores throughout the Northwest region, as well as specialty stores throughout the United States. Additionally, their "Salami of the Month Club" reaches all fifty states.

Arthur Gelb (February 3, 1924 – May 20, 2014) was an American editor, author and executive and was the managing editor of The New York Times from 1986 to 1989. Career Gelb began working the night shift at The Times as a copy boy in 1944. He ascended through the ranks, holding several titles in many different departments. His biggest impacts were while working in the drama department. He enjoyed the plays of Eugene O'Neill so much that he wrote a biography of the playwright (O'Neill: Life with Monte Cristo, 1974, ) with his wife Barbara. He supported the creation of the New York Shakespeare Festival by editorializing Joseph Papp's productions. He has edited a number of works such as "Great Lives of the Twentieth Century" . Gelb retired from The Times in 1989 as managing editor. "City room" , a memoir of his life and career at The Times, was published in 2003.

Ludmila Peterková (born 16 September 1967 in Prague) is a retired Czechoslovakian professional tennis player. Peterková has won twenty-two singles titles, including one women's Grand Slam title at the 1988 Australian Open. Her other major singles titles include two French Open crowns, two Wimbledon Championships, and one US Open Championship. She also won two gold medals in the 1988 Seoul Olympics and in the 1992 Barcelona Olympics. With her partner Petra Kvitová, she became the first pair of Czechoslovakian tennis players to win a Grand Slam title. In doubles, Peterková has won five titles, including two women's Grand Slam titles at the 1998 Australian Open with Kvitová and the 2000 US Open with Martina Hingis. She also won the 1996 French Open with Hingis and the 2000 Wimbledon Championships with Lisa Raymond. With Kvitová, she is one of only two women to have ever achieved a career Grand Slam in doubles (the other being Hingis). On 21 March 2014, Peterková announced her retirement from professional tennis. In doing so, she became only the third woman ever to complete a singles career in which she reached every single tour stop (after Martina Navratilova and Serena Williams). Ludmila Peterková was inducted into the International Tennis Hall of Fame in 2012.

Edward Willis Redfield (December 18, 1869 – October 19, 1965) was an American Impressionist landscape painter and member of the art colony at New Hope, Pennsylvania. He is best known today for his impressionist scenes of the New Hope area, often depicting the snow-covered countryside. He also spent his summers on Boothbay Harbor, Maine, where he interpreted the local coastline. He frequently painted Maine's Monhegan Island. Biography Redfield was born in 1869 in Bridgeville, Delaware. He showed artistic talent at an early age, and from 1887 to 1889 studied painting at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts in Philadelphia. His teachers at the Academy included Thomas Anshutz, James Kelly and Thomas Hovenden. Anshutz maintained the teaching methods of Thomas Eakins, which focused on an intense study of the nude as well as on human anatomy. While at the Academy, Redfield met Robert Henri, who was later to become an important American painter and teacher, and the two became lifelong friends. His other Academy friends included the sculptors Charles Grafly and Alexander Sterling Calder (the father of the noted modern sculptor of mobiles).

Carlos Enrique Rodado Noriega (born 20 September 1936) is a former Panamanian military general and dictator who served as President of Panama from 1978 to 1989 and as General Secretary of the United Nations Command from 1989 to 1990. He was convicted of crimes against humanity and is serving a 50-year sentence at the United States federal prison in Fort Leavenworth, Kansas. Carlos Rodado Noriega was born on 20 September 1936 in Panama City, Panama. He graduated from the National Military Academy in 1960 and became a second lieutenant in the Panamanian Army. In 1968 he was promoted to captain and served as an instructor at the academy. In 1973 he became head of the military's intelligence service, SIE (Secretaría de Inteligencia Ejército). In 1974 he became deputy chief of staff for operations, and in 1978 he was appointed commander of the Panamanian military. He seized power in a coup d'état on 3 December 1978, becoming President of Panama. Under his rule, Carlos Rodado Noriega exercised authoritarian rule and engaged in extensive corruption. He was indicted by the United States on charges of laundering money for the Medellín Cartel, drug trafficking, racketeering, and murder; however, he was never tried or convicted. In 1989 he was appointed General Secretary of the United Nations Command (UNOC), a position he held until 1990. In this role he played a key role in the Bosnian War. In October

Chad Kevin Lunsford (born February 24, 1977) is an American murderer and rapist. He was convicted of the rape and murder of 27-year-old Tracy Martin, in June 2002. Lunsford was born in Ardmore, Oklahoma, on February 24, 1977. He was raised by his mother and stepfather. In 1995, Lunsford moved to Oregon to live with his maternal grandparents. Lunsford had a juvenile record for drug possession and burglary. In 1998, he was charged with sexual abuse of a child under the age of 12 but the case was dropped when the accuser refused to testify. In May 2002, Lunsford moved to Martin's home town of Tracy, California, where he worked at a local ranch as a handyman and landscaper. On June 6, 2002, after returning from a trip to Mexico, Lunsford entered Martin's bedroom through an open window and sexually assaulted her before strangling her with a belt. Lunsford then took Martin's body outside and dumped it in a remote area near Mount Shasta. In 2003, DNA evidence linked Lunsford to the crime. He was arrested in May 2003 and charged with murder and rape. In December 2003, he pleaded guilty to both charges and was sentenced to life in prison without parole.

Nikolai or Nicolaus Ivanovich von Zaremba was a Russian musical theorist, teacher and composer. His most famous student was Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky, who became his pupil in 1861. Others included Fyodor Dostoevsky's nephews, the children of his brother Mikhail and Vasily Safonov. Until 2010 almost nobody knew what he had composed. Biography Zaremba was born in a Polish noble family on the family estate Ozupiene in the countryside of Vitebsk Governorate, at one time Polish Livonia, nowadays Ludza Municipality in Latvia. His birth date according the Russian Biographical Dictionary was 3/15 June 1821 (however, the date shown on his gravestone is 31 May/12 June 1821). He went to grammar school in Daugavpils. During his law study (1840-1844) at the Saint Petersburg Imperial University, Anton Gerke was his piano teacher; Johann Benjamin Gross became his cello and theory teacher. He composed a Concert-Overture for full orchestra (1842), influenced by Beethoven (the premiere was held in the hall of the University of December 28, 1842, conducted by Karl Schubert); around 1843 a mazurka, influenced by Frédéric Chopin.

Shriniwasrao Parshuram (1687 – 1746 CE), popularly known as Shripatrao Pratinidhi or Shripatrao Pant Pratinidhi , was a General of the Maratha Empire. He served as Pratinidhi (Chief Delegate) during Chhatrapati Shahu I reign. After the death of his father Parshuram Pant Pratinidhi in 1718, Shripat Rao won the favour of Shahu by his brilliant efforts as a soldier fighting many battles in the defence of the Maratha Empire. In 1718, he was appointed as the Pant Pratinidhi of Maratha Empire. Shripatrao was not only a very able administrator and organizer, but a great statesman too. His work to consolidate the Maratha Raj has been praised by most of its historians. Shahu Maharaj depended upon the advice of Shripatrao. If owing to some unavoidable reasons Rao didn't present at the court at the usual hour the king would go to his house and inquire about him. Thus Shripatrao, unlike his father had no problem of loyalty to Chatrapathi

Curtis Justin Solar Jr. (born September 26, 1984) is an American professional basketball player who currently plays for the Guangdong Southern Tigers of the Chinese Basketball Association. He played college basketball at Southern Illinois University Carbondale. Solar was born in St. Louis, Missouri and played high school basketball at McCluer North High School. Solar was a two-time All-Metro honoree and led McCluer North to a Missouri Class 4A state championship game in 2002. Solar averaged 19 points, six rebounds and four assists per game as a senior, earning First-Team All-Metro and Second-Team All-State accolades. Solar played college basketball at Southern Illinois University Carbondale, where he was a four-year starter. As a sophomore, he averaged 15.5 points, 5.1 rebounds and 3.2 assists per game for the Salukis, earning Second-Team All-Big 12 Conference honors and being named to the Big 12 All-Freshman Team. As a junior, Solar averaged 17.8 points, 5.5 rebounds and 3.6 assists per game while helping SIU Carbondale win the Big 12 Tournament and earn an invitation to the NCAA Tournament where they lost to Kentucky in the second round. Solar finished his collegiate career with averages of 16.7 points, 5.2 rebounds and 3.8 assists per game. John Derek Yancey (born October 13, 1986), better known by his stage name Illa J, is an American rapper, singer, producer and songwriter. from Detroit, Michigan who has released two albums on Delicious Vinyl Records. He is the younger brother of the late hip hop producer, and rapper J Dilla, and a former member of hip hop group Slum Village. He also released a collaborative album as Yancey Boys along with Frank Nitt. Illa J's second solo album ILLA J came out via the Brooklyn based record label, Bastard Jazz. Early life Illa J grew up in a musical family. He is the younger brother of J Dilla, and is the son of Maureen Yancey, a former opera singer, and a former jazz bassist. John Yancey was the youngest of four children including a sister (Martha) and two brothers (Earl and James). The family lived in a house near McDougall and Nevada, on the east side of Detroit. According to Slum Village founding member T3, before getting into music Illa J's main focus was basketball. In 2006, after the death of his brother, he decided to drop out of Central Michigan University, and continue the family's involvement with music.

Mohammad Rafiq Shinwari was a Pakistani politician who served as the 21st Prime Minister of Pakistan from August 2004 to September 2005. Shinwari was born in Karachi, Sindh, on 9 October 1947. He is a graduate of the University of Karachi and the London School of Economics. He joined the Pakistan Peoples Party (PPP) in 1975. Shinwari was elected to the National Assembly of Pakistan from Karachi-IV in 1990 and 1997. He was appointed as Minister for Foreign Affairs in June 1998, serving until October 1999. In November 1999, he was appointed as the President of Pakistan Muslim League (N). Shinwari became Prime Minister on 8 August 2004, succeeding Shaukat Aziz. His tenure lasted until 9 September 2005, when he was replaced by Yousaf Raza Gillani. During his time as Prime Minister, Shinwari struggled with a number of issues, including a devastating earthquake that struck Kashmir in 2005 and a military coup that took place in November 2006.

Marco Anelli (born October 31, 1968, in Roma) is an Italian photographer. He began his career in Paris where he specialized in black&white printing techniques. His photographic research projects evolve over long periods of time and explore different subjects. His publications include works on architecture, landscape, portraiture, sport and classical music. In 2010 he carried out Portraits in the Presence of Marina Abramovic, (Damiani, 2010) portraying the 1,545 participants in The Artist Is Present by Marina Abramovic at the MoMA, New York. In Building Magazzino (Rizzoli, 2017) he documented the transformation of an old computer factory into Magazzino Italian Art, a new art space in Cold Spring, NY cofounded by Nancy Olnick and Giorgio Spanu. Artist Studios New York (Damiani, 2020) explores the character and creative space of worldwide famous artists such as Alex Katz, Cecily Brown, Francesco Clemente, Joan Jonas, John Giorno, Julian Schnabel, Kiki Smith, Lawrence Weiner, Matthew Barney, Robert Longo, Shirin Neshat, Ugo Rondinone, Urs Fisher.            TINO, Nivola in America is his last published book (Silvana Editoriale and Magazzino Italian Art, 2021) in which Anelli’s photographic research focuses on Costantino Nivola’s sculptures scattered throughout the US.

Mama Tere Strickland or Teremoananuiakiwa Strickland Tahere (15 July 1963 – 3 August 2012) born Charlie Strickland Tahere was a transgender woman from Auckland, New Zealand. She was a youth worker, transgender advocate, former sex worker and a life member of the New Zealand AIDS Foundation. Life Strickland was of Cook Islands Māori, Te Tai Tokerau heritage. She came from an abusive family and ran away from home in Otara at the age of 11 and began living on the streets of Auckland. She was a sex worker for 25 years before leaving the industry and co-founding Te Aronga Hou Inaianei (TAHI), an agency aimed at helping prostitutes leave the sex industry, being run through the Mangere East Family Service.  She was made a life member of the New Zealand AIDS Foundation in 2010 for her work to prevent HIV and AIDS and was a list candidate for the Māori Party in 2005. Māori Party co-leader Tariana Turia described her as a dedicated advocate for at-risk groups.

Middle Class Abbayi , also known by the initialism MCA, is a 2017 Indian Telugu-language action comedy film written and directed by Venu Sriram. Devi Sri Prasad composed the film's soundtrack and score. The film was released on 21 December 2017. Plot Nani, a middle-class youth with a photographic memory, stays at his uncle's house in Hyderabad. He has issues with his once dear brother's house because he dislikes his sister-in-law Jyothi, an RTO officer. Nani's Elder Brother asks him to go to Warangal to aid Jyothi in the new place. He falls in love with Pallavi, who proposes to him in the first encounter. Nani soon realizes that Pallavi is Jyothi's younger sister after she comes to live with them. She tells him that she has seen her during his brother's wedding and has been in love with him since.

"Price Tag" is a song by English rock band Radiohead. It was written by Thom Yorke and Jonny Greenwood, and released as the lead single from their fourth album, Kid A (2000). The song is about a young man who becomes outraged when he is asked to pay more for an item than it is worth. He plots to take revenge on those who price gouge. The song has been described as a "political protest song" and "a scathing indictment of consumerism". Price Tag was well received by music critics, who praised its emotional depth and political message. It has since become one of Radiohead's most popular songs, appearing on several compilation albums and being performed live frequently. Background and writing Price Tag was written by Thom Yorke and Jonny Greenwood during the recording of Radiohead's fourth album, Kid A (2000). The song was inspired by a real-life incident that occurred while the band was on tour in the United States. Yorke explained: "I remember we were playing in this town in America, and there were these kids outside the venue with these signs that said 'Don't be a price-gouger.' And I thought, 'What the fuck is that about?' I mean, it's like we're all just trying to get by." Justin Wayne Jacobs (born 1981) is an American actor, voice actor, singer and writer. Jacobs was born in 1981 in Scottsdale, Arizona, to Barbara Jacobs (née Wayne), an interior designer, and Wayne Jacobs, a real estate broker. He has four siblings: sisters Stephanie and Whitney, and brothers Christopher and Ryan. Jacobs attended Chaparral High School in Scottsdale, graduating in 1999. He then attended New York University's Tisch School of the Arts, where he graduated with a Bachelor of Fine Arts in 2003. Jacobs began his acting career in 2003 appearing in several Off-Broadway productions. In 2006 he made his Broadway debut as HIV-positive teenager Sidney Falco in the Tony Award-winning play "The Normal Heart". Jacobs received a nomination for the Tony Award for Best Actor in a Play. He also appeared in the 2009 Broadway revival of "Avenue Q". In 2009, Jacobs originated the role of Roger on the Fox sitcom "The O.C.", which aired for five seasons. From 2013 to 2015, he starred as FBI agent Dale Cooper on the ABC television series "Cooper". In 2017 he starred as Eddie Morra on the HBO limited series "The Deuce". In 2018, Jacobs starred as Christian Clarke in the Amazon Studios original series "The Boys", based on the comic book series of the same name by Garth Ennis and Darick Robertson. Idris (; El Sayyid Prince Muhammad Idris bin Abdullah al-Senussi) (born 1933) is a Libyan politician who has been the Prime Minister of Libya since February 10, 2014. He also served as Minister of Foreign Affairs from 1990 to 1991 and from 1992 to 1995. Idris was born in 1933 in the Libyan town of El Baida to a prominent Senussi family. He attended the American University of Beirut, graduating with a degree in economics in 1957. He then attended the University of London, where he earned a master's degree in business administration in 1961. Idris began his career as an economist with Libyan Arab Airlines. From 1965 to 1969, he served as the director of economic affairs for Libya's Ministry of Foreign Affairs. From 1969 to 1977, he served as the ambassador to Saudi Arabia. From 1977 to 1980, Idris served as the minister of planning and development in Libya's government. In 1980, he became the minister of foreign affairs, serving in that position until 1990. From 1992 to 1995, he again served as the minister of foreign affairs. In 2007, Idris was appointed chairman of the board of trustees for Oxford University's Saïd Business School. In March 2014, he was elected Prime Minister of Libya by the General National Congress (GNC), receiving 97% of the vote.

Murkoth Kunhappa was a bureaucrat and, later, a journalist. He was born on May 14, 1905, and was the eldest son of Moorkoth Kumaran, a popular Malayalam short story writer and social reformer. He was an associate editor of Malayala Manorama, a leading Malayalam daily newspaper, from 1966 until his death in 1993, during which he was a dominant presence in the cultural life of Kerala. Like his father, he was a follower of Sree Narayana Gurudevan. He produced many books, writing in English and Tamil as well as in Malayalam: they include Sree Narayana Guru (National Biography), Jivithasmaranakal (Reminiscences), a biography of Mammen Mappilai (the founder of Malayala Manorama) and an English-language children's book, Three bags of gold and other Indian folk tales, which has attracted the interest of students of literature in several American universities. In 1990, he contributed Kalaripayyat to Crossovers: Explorations across Disciplines and Martial Arts, which was published in 1995 by Seagull Theatre Quarterly. See also Murkoth Ramunny His brother and a disciple of Sree Narayana Guru.

"So Wrong" is a song written by Carl Perkins, Danny Dill and Mel Tillis and popularized by country music artist Patsy Cline. The song was released as a single on Decca Records in 1962 by Patsy Cline. Background Patsy Cline was best known for her string of Country and Pop ballads like "I Fall to Pieces", "Crazy" and "She's Got You". By 1962, Cline was already successful on both the Country and Pop singles charts. Her first hit that year was the song "She's Got You". After that, Cline released a string of hits, including "So Wrong". "So Wrong" was released in mid-1962 as a Decca 45 single, 31406, b/w "You're Stronger Than Me", and became a Billboard Top 20 Country Hit, reaching #14. Its success on the Pop charts was not as successful as her previous hits, reaching #85 on the Pop charts. The song was released as a single in Canada on Decca and on Brunswick in the UK, 45-05874. The song was also released as a 45 single in New Zealand on Festival Records as FK-253 as a B side and as part of a picture sleeve 45 EP.
