Fort Santo Domingo is a historical fortress located in the Santo Domingo municipality, in the Distrito Nacional (National District), Dominican Republic. The fortress is located on a hill overlooking the city of Santo Domingo. The fort was built in 1565 by the Spanish on the site of an earlier indigenous settlement. The fortress served as the capital of the Dominican Republic from 1795 to 1821. In 1822, Santo Domingo was moved to its current location and the fortress lost its significance. Today it is a popular tourist destination and a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The fort is composed of a series of square walls with bastions and towers, surrounded by a moat. The walls are up to high and have a total length of . The fortress has a total area of . The main entrance to the fort is through the north gate, which is still partially intact. Other entrances are through the south gate and through three arches in the east wall. The fort contains many buildings, including a palace, churches, a jail, and military barracks. The palace was used as the main residence of the governor of Santo Domingo. The churches include a church of Santo Domingo and two churches dedicated to San Francisco and Santa Ana. The jail was used to detain criminals and political opponents of the Spanish colonial government. The military barracks were used by the Spanish to train their troops.

Heraldry is the system of visual identification of people, places, and things in the world through the use of heraldic emblems and devices. The word "heraldry" is derived from the Old French word heralder, from the Latin heraldus, meaning a bearer of a message or news. Heraldry may date back to the early medieval period, when armored knights would identify themselves to one another using mounted emblems. By the end of the Middle Ages, coats of arms had become widespread among nobility and even commoners. Coats of arms continued to be displayed by sovereigns and other officials well into the modern period. The design and display of coats of arms is governed by heraldic law, which varies from country to country. In the United Kingdom, for example, there are three main sources of arms—the College of Arms at London, the Court of Chivalry in Westminster, and the Crown Office. Heraldry has been used by various cultures throughout history to identify people, places, and things. It remains an important part of modern society, particularly in countries that maintain royal families.

Paul Marino (born March 10, 1980) is a film director, producer, animator, voice actor, and author currently focused on machinima, the art of using engines from video games to create films. He is a co-founder and the executive director of the Academy of Machinima Arts & Sciences (AMAS), a non-profit organization formed in 2002 to promote and organize the growth of machinima. Marino also co-founded the ILL Clan, a machinima production group, and, working under the pseudonym ILL Robinson, helped to create a number of the group's machinima pieces. In particular, he directed Hardly Workin', an August 2000 comedy video that won a Best in SHO award in Showtime's alt.SHO.com Alternative Media Festival, held on February 8, 2001, and an award for Best Acting at the AMAS's 2002 Machinima Film Festival. Independently of the ILL Clan, Marino has worked on other machinima projects. Using Valve's first-person shooter Half-Life 2, he created I'm Still Seeing Breen, a 2005 music video set to Breaking Benjamin's song "So Cold". The video aired on MTV2's television program Video Mods. He has worked with Rooster Teeth Productions on their Sims 2 machinima series, The Strangerhood, as both a voice actor and a visual effects designer. Working with Rooster Teeth, he also helped to develop Strangerhood Studios, a short spin-off series commissioned in 2005 by the Independent Film Channel. Strangerhood Studios was the first machinima series to be commissioned for broadcast, and won an award for Best Editing at the 2005 Machinima Film Festival.

Breastfeeding by HIV-infected mothers is the practice of breastfeeding of HIV-infected mothers and include those who may want to or are currently breastfeeding. HIV can be transmitted to the infant through breastfeeding. The risk of transmission varies and depends on the viral load in the mother's milk. An infant can be infected with HIV throughout the duration of the pregnancy or during childbirth (intrapartum). Background Breastfeeding with HIV guidelines established by the WHO suggest that HIV-infected mothers (particularly those in resource-poor countries) practice exclusive breastfeeding only, rather than mixed breastfeeding practices that involve other dietary supplements or fluids. Many studies have revealed the high benefit of exclusive breastfeeding to both mother and child, documenting that exclusive breastfeeding for a period of 6 months significantly reduces transmission, provides the infant with a greater chance of survival in the first year of life, and helps the mother to recover from the negative health effects of birth much more quickly.

"" (They killed my mother) is a soprano aria from act 3 of the 1896 opera Andrea Chénier by Umberto Giordano. It is sung by Maddalena di Coigny to Gérard about how her mother died protecting her during the turmoils of the French Revolution. Music The aria is a favourite show piece of a spinto soprano, especially ones who specialize in the Italian idiom of verismo. In the opera, the aria is placed in the third act, after Gérard's aria "", another famous aria which showcases the baritone playing Gérard. Comprising a range between C to B, the tessitura of the aria lies in the octave between F and F, with the second section lying higher than the first section. The instrumentation of the aria is especially effective, for example the string tremolo which suggested the fires that destroyed Maddalena's home. The aria itself is divided into two sections: a tender melancholic opening part which recalls Maddalena's misadventures; and a heroic second part, full of high arching phrases, which suggested the voice of the god of love. An oppure was written by Giordano as alternative to accommodate the climactic top B, providing shorter phrases and two full measure rests. A performance takes about five minutes.

René de Nebesky-Wojkowitz (29 June 1923 – 9 July 1959) was a Czech ethnologist and Tibetologist. He is mostly known for his 1956 publication Oracles and Demons of Tibet, which was the first detailed study of Tibetan deity cults. Biography René Mario de Nebesky-Wojkowitz was born in Groß Hoschütz in Moravia on 29 June 1923. After completing his secondary education in Leitmeritz and Prague, he devoted himself to the study of Central Asian ethnology, Tibetan, and Mongolian at the universities of Berlin and Vienna. It was especially the teachings of the late Robert Bleichsteiner at the University of Vienna that encouraged him to specialize in Tibetan studies. Before the defense of his doctoral thesis (see Bibliography, no. 3) on November 3, 1949 he published two articles on the Bön religion and the state oracle. From November 1949 to July 1950 he continued his studies in Italy under the direction of Giuseppe Tucci and Joseph Rock, as well as in London at the School of Oriental and African Studies and the London School of Economics.

A breathing mask is a mask that is worn by an individual to help them breathe more easily and to protect them from breathing in harmful substances. Breathing masks are often used by people who are working or playing in environments that contain harmful particles, such as coal mines, factories, or volcanoes. They are also used by people who have respiratory problems, such as asthma, allergies, or cystic fibrosis. The most common type of breathing mask is a facemask. This is a mask that covers the entire face except for the eyes and mouth. Facemasks are usually made of cloth, rubber, or plastic and are fitted with a nose clip and a mouthpiece. They are usually worn with a head harness to keep them in place. Another type of breathing mask is the snorkel mask. This is a mask that is worn over the mouth and nose. It is made of flexible material and has a tube that goes over the nose and down into the mouth. It is held in place with straps that go around the head.

Elijah Moshinsky (8 January 1946 – 14 November 2006) was an Israeli mathematician. Moshinsky was born in Tel Aviv, Israel on 8 January 1946. He received his B.Sc. in mathematics from the Hebrew University of Jerusalem in 1968, and his M.Sc. and Ph.D. from the University of Cambridge in 1973 and 1977 respectively. Moshinsky worked at the University of California, Berkeley from 1977 to 1992, when he moved to the Hebrew University of Jerusalem as a full professor. In 1992 he was appointed Rector of the university, a position he held until his death in 2006. Moshinsky's research focused on geometric analysis, differential geometry, and symplectic geometry. He is best known for his work on vector bundles and their associated tensor products, including the Moshinsky fibration theorem, the Moshinsky–Stein theory of singularity points, and the Moshinsky–Toda theory of symplectic manifolds.

Helen Elizabeth Moore is an American mathematician. She is a professor of mathematics at the University of California, Berkeley and a fellow of the American Mathematical Society. Moore is noted for her work in algebraic geometry, functional analysis, Lie theory and Banach spaces. Moore was born in Seattle, Washington, and grew up in the suburb of Bellevue. She graduated from Bellevue High School in 1979 and from the University of Washington in 1983 with a B.A. in mathematics. She then studied at the University of Cambridge, where she received her Ph.D. in 1988 under the supervision of Robin Wilson. Moore began her career at the University of California, Berkeley, where she has been a professor of mathematics since 1995. She also holds a joint appointment as a professor at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory and a fellow of the American Mathematical Society. Moore's research focuses on algebraic geometry, functional analysis, Lie theory, and Banach spaces. In 2018 she was awarded the Abel Prize, one of the world's most prestigious mathematical awards.

Arthur Wellesley Hughes (1870–1950) was a Canadian musician and composer. Born in Kingston, Ontario, he separated from his family at a young age, spending many years in the United States as an itinerant circus musician. He was a performer on piano, calliope, and alto horn. His circus associations on record include: Mighty Haag Circus, Downie & Wheeler Circus (1912); Hagenbeck-Wallace Circus (1922); Sells-Floto Circus (1923); and Ringling Bros & Barnum & Bailey Combined Shows (1924-26). He was with Robbins Bros. Circus (1928–29) whence his Robbins Bros. Triumphal March arose, and Miller Bros. 101 Ranch Wild West Show, and Walter L. Main Circus (1930–31). Hughes worked as composer and arranger for the Waterloo Music Company of Waterloo, Ontario, from 1932-1935. At other times, Hughes worked as arranger in the Whaley, Royce and Cundy-Bettoney publishing houses. According to his own account, Hughes wrote band music in the USA for much of his life, under various pen names, including Arthur Wellesley and H W Arthur. In his 70s, Hughes returned to Kansas, which he considered his home. It is reported that he died in an indigent ward in a New York City hospital in 1950.

She embarked on her music career in 2006, with the release of her debut album, "The Weight". Newton has since released two more albums, "Liberation" (2009) and "The Awakening" (2013). She has also released two extended plays and five singles. Her most successful single to date is the song "A Little Bit of You" which peaked at number 10 on the US "Billboard" Hot 100. In addition to her musical work, Newton is also a fashion designer and has created clothing lines for Target and Lane Bryant. Newton was born in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, to jazz singer Dee Dee Newton and songwriter Gary Newton. She was raised in Los Angeles and Seattle. Her father is Black American and her mother is Caucasian American. Newton has stated that she identifies as multiracial. Newton has a younger brother, Taj. Newton began taking piano and singing lessons at the age of three. She began writing songs at the age of twelve and recorded her first demo at the age of fifteen. In 2003, she won a talent competition held by Seattle's KEXP radio station which led to her signing with the independent record label Nettwerk Records in 2006. The Kansas City Ballet (KCB) is an American professional ballet company based in Kansas City, Missouri. The company was founded in 1957 by Russian expatriate Tatiana Dokoudovska. The KCB presents five major performances each season to include an annual production of The Nutcracker. In the 2016–2017 season, KCB grew to an all-time high with 30 company dancers, 15 second company dancers, 64 full-time and part-time staff, and a network of over 400 local volunteers. The KCB, its school, and its staff are all housed in, operate from, and rehearse at the Todd Bolender Center for Dance and Creativity, a renovated, seven-studio, office, and rehearsal facility in Kansas City, Missouri, that opened in August 2011. The company performs at and is the resident ballet company at the nearby Kauffman Center for the Performing Arts, a performance venue in downtown Kansas City that opened in September 2011. History

Kathleen "Kay" Walsh (15 November 1911 – 16 April 2005) was an English actress, dancer, and screenwriter. Her film career prospered after she met her future husband film director David Lean, with whom she worked on prestige productions such as In Which We Serve and Oliver Twist. Early life and career Walsh was born on 15 November 1911 in Chelsea, London. She was raised in Pimlico by her grandmother. She began her career as a dancer in West End music halls, and at the age of 17 she began going out with Pownoll Pellew (later 9th Viscount Exmouth), and they shared an interest in sports cars. She made her film debut in How's Chances? (1934) in a small part, and had a larger role in Get Your Man, another 1934 film. She continued to act in "quota quickies" films for several years. Walsh first met David Lean, then a film editor, in 1936, during the filming of Secret of Stamboul. They began a relationship, and Walsh broke her engagement to Pellew. Walsh and Lean married on 23 November 1940. She moved on to prestige films with appearances in In Which We Serve (1942) and This Happy Breed (1944), both directed by Lean and written by Noël Coward. Walsh campaigned for Lean to receive co-director credit on In Which We Serve.

Anomalies, Vol. 1 is a compilation album by the American rock band Cave In. The album was officially released on December 14, 2010 through Hydra Head Records, however copies could be obtained one month earlier on Black Friday. Despite its title, Anomalies, Vol. 1 is actually the second release in Cave In's Anomalies series, which a grouping of releases that compile previously unreleased or rare tracks. Released earlier in 2010, Anomalies, Vol. 2 was a live album of a recorded performance from 2003. Song history The opening track from Anomalies, Vol. 1, "Mr. Co-Dexterity," was originally released on Japanese editions of Cave In's 1998 debut album Until Your Heart Stops. After making the conscious decision not to play heavy metal music anymore in the late 1990s, after the release of Until Your Heart Stops, Cave In started recording material that was more spacey and alternative that eventually culminated in the Creative Eclipses EP. The song "Inflatable Dream" was a previously unreleased track from these sessions. The studio version of "Innuendo and Out the Other" was originally released on 2000s Jupiter.

Toyin Ojih Odutola (born 1985) is a Nigerian-American contemporary visual artist known for her vivid multimedia drawings and works on paper. Her unique style of complex mark-making and lavish compositions rethink the category and traditions of portraiture and storytelling. Ojih Odutola's artwork often investigates a variety of themes from socio-economic inequality, the legacy of colonialism, queer and gender theory, notions of blackness as a visual and social symbol, as well as experiences of migration and dislocation. Early life and education Ojih Odutola was born in 1985 in Ile-Ife, Nigeria, where both her parents were teachers. In 1990 her mother, Nelene Ojih, took Toyin and her two-year-old brother to the United States to accompany their father, Dr. Jamiu Ade Odutola, in Berkeley, California, where he was undergoing research and teaching chemistry at the university. After four years in Berkeley, the family moved to Huntsville, Alabama in 1994 where her father became an associate professor at Alabama A&M University and her mother a nurse. Ojih Odutola is of Yoruba and Igbo descent from her paternal and maternal heritage, respectively.

Numerius (or Gnaeus) Fabius Ambustus (  c. 190 BC – c. 169 BC) was a Roman general and politician. After the death of Publius Cornelius Scipio Africanus, he was elected consul for 124 BC with Quintus Metellus Macedonicus. He is best known for his role in the Battle of Zama, where he commanded one of the two legions that defeated the Etruscan army led by king Hannibal. Fabius was born into a wealthy family around 190 BC, in Rome. His father was Gnaeus Fabius Maximus Ambustus, who had been consul in 191 BC. His maternal uncle was Lucius Cornelius Lentulus Spinther, who had been consul in 184 BC. He married a woman called Terentia in about 145 BC. Fabius served as praetor in 131 BC and as quaestor in 129 BC. He was elected consul for 124 BC with Quintus Metellus Macedonicus, and served until 122 BC. During his consulship, he fought two campaigns against the Ligurians and defended Rome against an attack by the Samnites. In 121 BC, he was appointed dictator to deal with the Social War in Italy. He used his military experience to good effect, defeating several larger armies and reducing the number of allies that each of the two main factions could recruit. Ada Barbara Harriett Tarry (2 January 1881 – 10 October 1955), known by her stage name Suzette Tarri, was an English comedian and singer, popular on radio as well as on stage in the 1930s and 1940s. Biography She was born in Hoxton, London. She performed as a child violinist in the 1890s, and made her first stage appearance as a singer in Walthamstow in 1905. In her early career, she specialised in roles as a theatrical soubrette, singing light comic songs, and by 1913 was regularly accompanied by her husband, the Scottish singer and comic entertainer Tom Copeland. She and Copeland made their first appearance on BBC Radio in 1923. By 1929, her accompanist was David Jenkins, and by the early 1930s they were billed together in radio performances as a "comedy duo".  They later married. When Jenkins moved into music publishing, Tarri continued as a solo act, performing in clubs and theatres.

WGFL-DT2, virtual channel 28.2 (UHF digital channel 26), is a Fox-affiliated television station licensed to Gainesville, Florida, United States. The station is owned by the Hearst Corporation. WGFL-DT2 maintains transmitter facilities located in Alachua County southeast of Gainesville. The station first signed on the air on October 10, 1984 as WFXJ-TV, airing an analog signal on UHF channel 26 from a transmitter in unincorporated Alachua County. It was the first television station in the Gainesville market, and was acquired by the Tribune Company (now Hearst Corporation) shortly afterward. The station became a charter affiliate of FOX in 1985. In 1996, WFXJ-TV moved its operations to a new studio on West University Avenue in Gainesville; at the same time, it upgraded its signal to VHF channel 10. In 1997, WFXJ-TV changed its call letters to WGFL-TV to reflect its new affiliation with The Fox Network. In 2002, WGFL-TV upgraded its signal to digital channel 28. In 2004, WGFL-TV moved its studios again; this time to the former studios of WCJB (channel 27) on Northwest Second Street in Gainesville. Rose Lomathinda Chibambo (8 September 1928 – 8 December 2008) was a Zambian artist and sculptor. She is considered one of the most important artists of Zambia, and has been praised for her unique fusion of traditional sculpture techniques with contemporary painting and drawing styles. Rose Chibambo was born on 8 September 1928 in the village of Lomathinda, in the district of Ndola in Northern Rhodesia (now Zambia). She was the youngest of nine children. Her parents were farmers who were active in the local community and encouraged their children to pursue their own interests in art. Chibambo began her training in traditional sculpture techniques at the age of 12, under the tutelage of her father. In 1952 she enrolled at the School of Fine Arts in Lusaka (then known as Livingstone University), where she studied under Professor John Nkumbula. While at the university, she also started working as a graphic designer for a local newspaper. In 1957, Chibambo married fellow artist Kenneth Muhanga and moved to Livingstone, where they started their own studio. The couple had two children together, but they divorced in 1977. Chibambo continued to work primarily as a sculptor throughout her life, although she also began painting and drawing in the 1960s. Her real breakthrough came after she moved to London in 1973 to take part in a joint exhibition by Zambian artists organised by the British Council. Morris Jacob Raphall (October 3, 1798 – July 1, 1865) was an American jurist and politician who served in both the United States House of Representatives and the United States Senate. He was a leader in the movement to abolish slavery in the United States. Raphall was born in Mansfield, Connecticut on October 3, 1798. He studied law and was admitted to the bar in 1822. He commenced practice in Mansfield and served as the town solicitor from 1827 to 1830. In 1830, Raphall was elected as a Democratic-Republican to the Twenty-second Congress, serving from March 4, 1831 to March 3, 1833. He served as chairman of the Committee on Expenditures in the Department of State (Twenty-second Congress). In 1836, he was elected as a Democrat to the Twenty-fifth Congress and served from March 4, 1837 to March 3, 1839. He was an unsuccessful candidate for reelection in 1838 to the Twenty-sixth Congress. After leaving Congress, Raphall resumed his law practice in Mansfield. In 1840, he was elected as an anti-slavery Whig to the Thirty-third Congress and served from March 4, 1841 to March 3, 1843. He was an unsuccessful candidate for reelection in 1842 to the Thirty-fourth Congress. In 1846, Raphall was elected as a Democrat to the Thirty-fifth Congress and served from March 4, 1847 to March 3

Manakula Vinayagar Temple is a Hindu temple located in the town of Thanjavur, Tamil Nadu, India. The temple is dedicated to the god Vinayagar and is considered one of the most important religious sites in Tamil Nadu. The temple complex consists of a large number of shrines, including a huge granite Vijayanagar style Rajagopuram, numerous gopurams, and a large tank. The temple is a major tourist attraction in Thanjavur and is also visited by pilgrims from other parts of India. Manakula Vinayagar Temple is located in the town of Thanjavur, Tamil Nadu, India. Nothing Is Sound is the fifth studio album by the English rock band Radiohead, released on 9 July 2017 through XL Recordings. It is the band's first album since 2005's Hail to the Thief and their first since their return as a full-time recording entity in March 2015. Following the tour for their previous album, "The King of Limbs", Radiohead began work on Nothing Is Sound in late 2014. Recording took place at several locations across Europe, with additional production taking place at Air Studios in London. The album was mixed by Nigel Godrich and mastered by Steve Hoffman at Sterling Sound in New York City. Nothing Is Sound is an electronic and experimental album that draws upon influences from 1980s electronic music, Krautrock, and 1970s funk. Lyrically, it explores themes of isolation and loss, as well as the fragility of life. Upon its release, it received generally positive reviews from music critics, who praised its sonic experimentation and lyrical depth. It debuted at number one on the UK Albums Chart and became Radiohead's seventh number-one album in the United Kingdom. It has also charted moderately in other countries, including Australia and the United States. Hailed by some as their best work in over a decade, Nothing Is Sound received widespread critical acclaim upon its release. It was named one of the best albums of 2017 by numerous publications, including Rolling Stone, NME, Pitchfork, Stereogum, The Observer, and The Guardian.

Kent Vaughn Flannery (born 1934) is a Canadian writer, critic, and professor. He is the author of over twenty books, including the novels The Beggar's Opera (1981), The Bush Garden (1987), and The Circle Game (1998). Flannery has been awarded the Guggenheim Fellowship and the Commonwealth Writers' Prize. Flannery was born in 1934 in Montreal, Quebec, Canada. He attended McGill University where he studied English literature. He has also taught at McGill and at Dartmouth College. Flannery's work often deals with themes of isolation and exile. His novels The Beggar's Opera (1981), The Bush Garden (1987), and The Circle Game (1998) are set in Ireland, Quebec, and England respectively. His most recent novel is The Unconsoled (2002). Flannery is a critic as well as a novelist. He has written for publications such as the New York Review of Books and the Times Literary Supplement. He has also served on the board of directors for the Canadian Book Centre. Flannery was made an Officer of the Order of Canada in 1984 and a Companion of the Order of Ontario in 2001.

Lai Tung Pai, (sometimes spelled Lai Tong Pai, also known in Mandarin as Pán Quán 蟠拳, in Cantonese as Pùhn Kyùhn 盤拳 or coiling fist style) is a martial art of Chinese origin, coming from the Siu Lahm (Mandarin Shaolin) tradition in the Guangdong providence of China. The art was developed at the Henan Siu Lahm Temple and then was moved to the Hoi Tung Temple in Kwangtung when the former was burned down during the Ching Dynasty. The dates are not certain, as the only living person, Kong Hoi (surname given first as in Chinese tradition), studied at the Hoi Tung Temple in the early 20th century, but it is believed the style originated in the early 1600s. Albert Henrik Mohn (25 November 1918 – 1 February 1987) was a Norwegian chemist who was awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1972. He is best known for his pioneering work on carbon–carbon bond formation and his role in the development of radical polymer chemistry. Albert Henrik Mohn was born in Trondheim, Norway on 25 November 1918. After completing his high school education in 1934, he enrolled at the University of Oslo, where he studied chemistry under Per-Ole Sverre Riis and Guttorm Schjelderup. In 1941, he completed his undergraduate studies and began working as a research assistant at the Norwegian Institute of Technology. In 1947, Mohn was appointed a professor at the University of Bergen, where he remained until his retirement in 1982. During that time, he also served as the university's rector from 1972 to 1973. Albert Henrik Mohn was awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1972 for his pioneering work on carbon–carbon bond formation and his role in the development of radical polymer chemistry. He died on 1 February 1987.

The United States Tax Court decided two cases in the early 1990s, Veit v. Commissioner and Laidlaw v. Commissioner, that have had a significant impact on the interpretation of the income tax laws. Veit v. Commissioner concerned a husband and wife who were both self-employed truck drivers. The couple had two children, one of whom was disabled. The husband earned income from his truck driving, while the wife earned income from her job as a secretary. The couple reported their combined income on their tax returns, and the IRS assessed a deficiency against the husband based on its interpretation of the law as it existed at the time. The Tax Court held that the husband was entitled to claim his wife's income as his own for purposes of calculating his tax liability, and the IRS was required to refund him the deficiency amount. Laidlaw v. Commissioner concerned a single father who worked as a computer programmer. The father received income from his job in addition to Social Security benefits that he received as a retired military officer. The father reported his combined income on his tax returns, and the IRS assessed a deficiency against him based on its interpretation of the law as it existed at the time. The Tax Court held that the father was entitled to claim both his salary from his job and his Social Security benefits as his own for purposes of calculating his tax liability, and the IRS was required to refund him the deficiency amount. The Veit v. Commissioner decision has broadened the definition of what constitutes "earned

Doux commerce (lit. gentle commerce or soft trade) is a French term used to describe the practice of trade that is conducted in a way that is considered more humane or less harmful to the environment than traditional trade practices. The doux commerce movement was initiated in the early 18th century by François-Noël Desbarats, Marquis de La Galissonnière, in an effort to improve the living conditions of the people of Haiti in the wake of the devastating earthquake of 1755. The movement spread to other parts of the world and today it is considered one of the cornerstones of sustainable development. Doux commerce principles include: 1. Respect for human rights: Doux commerce principles emphasize the importance of human rights and the need to protect the rights of workers, farmers, and consumers. 2. Sustainable development: Doux commerce principles promote sustainable development, which means policies and practices that respect natural resources, promote social equity, and protect the environment. 3. Prevention of environmental damage: Doux commerce principles urge businesses to take measures to prevent environmental damage, such as waste reduction, use of environmentally friendly materials, and recycling.

Marshalyn Yeargin-Allsopp is a medical epidemiologist and public health specialist who has worked in the field of HIV/AIDS since the early 1990s. She is currently a Distinguished Professor at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, where she also serves as the director of the university's Center for Health and Global Development. Marshalyn Yeargin-Allsopp is a medical epidemiologist and public health specialist who has worked in the field of HIV/AIDS since the early 1990s. She is currently a Distinguished Professor at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, where she also serves as the director of the university's Center for Health and Global Development. Her work has focused on developing interventions to prevent and treat HIV/AIDS, as well as studying the social, economic, and environmental factors that influence HIV/AIDS incidence and prevalence. Yeargin-Allsopp has also been involved in efforts to improve global health governance.

Edith Dircksey Cowan ( Brown; 2 August 18619 June 1932) was an Australian social reformer who worked for the rights and welfare of women and children. She is best known as the first Australian woman to serve as a member of parliament. Cowan has been featured on the reverse of Australia's 50-dollar note since 1995. Cowan was born at Glengarry station near Geraldton, Western Australia. She was the granddaughter of two of the colony's early settlers, Thomas Brown and John Wittenoom. Cowan's mother died when she was seven, and she was subsequently sent to boarding school in Perth. At the age of 15, her father, Kenneth Brown, was executed for the murder of her stepmother, making her an orphan. She subsequently lived with her grandmother in Guildford, Western Australia until her marriage at the age of 18. She and her husband would have five children together, splitting their time between homes in West Perth and Cottesloe.

Nathalie Marie Andrée Baye (born 6 July 1971) is a French film actress. She has appeared in more than 60 films since 1990. Baye is particularly noted for her roles in the films L'Enfant et les sortilèges (The Child and the Sorceries), Amour (Love), and The Artist (The Artist). Nathalie Baye was born on 6 July 1971 in the town of Saint-Étienne, Loire, in south-central France. After attending the Lycée François-René de Chateaubriand in Saint-Étienne, she studied at the National School of Dramatic Art in Paris. In 1995, she played the role of Séverine in David Lynch's psychological horror film Mulholland Drive. Major General Henry Balding Lewis, CBE, (May 25, 1886 – November 15, 1954) was a senior Canadian Army officer and World War II general. He played a prominent role in the Second World War, serving as Chief of General Staff from 1942 to 1945. Lewis was born in Toronto, Ontario, the son of Edmund Lewis and Isabella Balding. After completing his education at the Royal Military College of Canada in 1908, he was commissioned as a lieutenant in the Canadian Army. He served in World War I with the 2nd Infantry Brigade, 1st Division and fought at Vimy Ridge and Passchendaele. He was promoted to captain and received the Distinguished Service Order for his actions at Passchendaele. Lewis served in the interwar period as an instructor at the Royal Military College of Canada and as a staff officer with the Canadian Expeditionary Force. In 1936, he was made commandant of the Royal Military College of Canada. In 1938, he was promoted to major general and appointed Assistant Chief of Staff (Operations) with the Canadian Expeditionary Force. In 1939, he was made Deputy Chief of Staff (Operations) with the British Expeditionary Force. Lewis returned to Canada in 1940 and served as Chief of Staff to Major General James Foulkes with the 1st Canadian Infantry Division until June 1942, when he was made Chief of General Staff with responsibility for all military forces in Canada (excluding Newfoundland). Fashoda State (previously named Western Nile State) is a state in south-western Sudan. It was created on 15 May 2011, as a result of a split from the former Southern Sudan. Fashoda State is bordered by the Central African Republic to the north, the Republic of South Sudan to the east, and the Democratic Republic of the Congo to the south. The capital and largest city is Malakal. The state covers an area of , and has a population of 1,657,000. The majority of the population areMuslims (97%), with Christians and animists making up a small minority (1% and 0%). Arabic is spoken as the official language. The economy is based on agriculture, with production focused on cotton, maize, sorghum, millet, and beans. There are also oil reserves in the state.

John Enoyogiere Edokpolo (9 October 1918 – 10 December 2002) was a Nigerian journalist, editor and publisher. Edokpolo was born on October 9, 1918 in Abeokuta, Ogun State, western Nigeria. He attended Abeokuta Grammar School and then proceeded to the University of Ibadan where he earned a B.A. degree in English literature in 1941. He then commenced postgraduate studies at the London School of Economics, where he earned an M.A. degree in 1947. Edokpolo returned to Nigeria in 1947 and began his journalistic career with the Nigerian Tribune. He later became the editor of the Nigerian Tribune's sister publication, the Evening Tribune, before founding his own newspaper, the Sunday Tribune, in 1967. The Sunday Tribune was eventually merged into the Daily Times newspaper group. Edokpolo retired from journalism in 1984. Edokpolo was also a publisher. He founded the John Edokpolo Publishing Company in 1967 and served as its chairman until his retirement in 1984. The company published books, magazines and newspapers. Edokpolo was also a Francophone delegate to the International Press Institute (IPI) from 1969 to 1971 and a member of the African National Congress (ANC) Central Committee from 1954 to 1957. He was also a member of the Nigerian Academy of Letters and a fellow of the Nigerian Academy of Arts. Edokpolo died on December 10, 2002 after a long illness.

Tiffany Ann Cole (born December 3, 1981) is an American convicted murderer who was found guilty of the kidnapping and first-degree murder of a Duval County, Florida, husband and wife and sentenced to death. Also found guilty in the case were three men: Alan Wade; Bruce Nixon; and Cole's boyfriend, Michael Jackson. Prosecutors said Cole and the three men developed a plan to kidnap and kill the couple to steal their money, and dug a grave for them in Charlton County, Georgia, two days before knocking on their door and asking to use the phone. As of February 2015, Cole is the third youngest woman on death row in the United States; she was 26 at the time of her conviction. Crime Tiffany Cole was a familiar face to Carol and Reggie Sumner, since her family had been neighbors to the 61-year-old couple in South Carolina. When the Sumners moved to Jacksonville, Florida, in March 2005, they sold a car to Cole. Cole agreed to make monthly payments and often drove with friends to Jacksonville in order to do so.

Karachi Breeze is a is a Pakistani pop music group that was formed in Karachi, Sindh, in 2006. The band consists of lead vocalist Ahsan Khan, lead guitarist Shehzad Roy, bassist Asif Ali and drummer Imran Mirza. Karachi Breeze's debut album "In The Company Of..." was released in November 2007 and featured the singles "Tum Hi Ho" and "Tera Ban Jaunga". The album achieved moderate success, peaking at number 30 on the Pakistan Pop Albums chart. The band's second album "Kuch Kuch Hota Hai" was released in October 2009 and featured the singles "Tum Hi Ho" and "Dil Dil Na Tha". The album fared better than its predecessor, reaching number 5 on the Pakistan Pop Albums chart and spawning two successful singles—"Tera Ban Jaunga" and "Kuch Kuch Hota Hai". Karachi Breeze has toured extensively across Pakistan and neighbouring countries such as India, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka and Nepal. In May 2010, the band embarked on their first international tour, visiting Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Chennai, Tamil Nadu; Colombo, Sri Lanka; Kathmandu, Nepal; and Dhaka, Bangladesh. They have also performed at various music festivals around Pakistan, including the Karachi Music Festival (2007), Pepsi Music Festival (2008), Coke Zero Music Festival (2009), Lakme Fashion Week (2010) and the Karachi International Music Festival (2011).

Jean Léon Côté (May 26, 1867 – September 23, 1924) was a prominent French-Canadian politician. He served as a member of the Legislative Assembly of Alberta from 1909 until 1923 sitting with the provincial Liberal Party in both government and opposition. He vacated his provincial seat when he was appointed to the Senate of Canada in 1923. He served until his death in 1924 sitting with the federal Liberal caucus. Early life Jean Léon Côté was born on May 26, 1867, in the village of Les Éboulements, Canada East, to Cléophas and Denise Côté. Côté was a surveyor and civil engineer by trade, and first visited the Edmonton area in 1886 as part of a survey crew. He returned to the East and trained as a Dominion Land Surveyor for the Department of the Interior, where he worked from 1893 to 1900. He participated in a number of high-profile projects, including the Alaska Boundary Commission.

Chelsea Kathleen Goodacre (born September 26, 1993) is an American actress. She is known for her roles as Fiona Gallagher on the ABC comedy-drama series Scandal and as the voice of Anna in the Disney animated feature film Frozen. Goodacre was born in Culver City, California, the daughter of Kathleen (née Kennedy) and Daniel Goodacre. She has two younger brothers, Patrick and Aidan. Her father is of Irish and Scottish descent and her mother is of English and Irish descent. Goodacre was raised in a Catholic household. Goodacre first appeared on television as a child in commercials for products such as Gatorade. In 2006, at the age of 10, she landed her first role on television, playing Mandy in the Disney Channel Original Movie The Princess Diaries 2: Royal Engagement. From 2008 to 2010, she played Fiona Gallagher on the ABC comedy-drama series Scandal, for which she received a nomination for a Teen Choice Award for Choice TV Actress – Drama Series. In 2013, she voiced Anna in the Disney animated feature film Frozen, which was released to critical acclaim and became a major box office success.

Bridge Music is a public sound art installation. Additionally, there is an album of the same name featuring music from this installation. History One of composer Joseph Bertolozzi's most well known undertakings, the Bridge Music project uses only the sounds of New York's Mid-Hudson Bridge to play the bridge like a musical instrument. The work was completed in time for New York's 400th anniversary observance of Henry Hudson's voyage up the river that now bears his name, but was underway as early as 2004. Originally intended to be a live performance piece (circa 2006), this "audacious plan" (New York Times) to compose music for a suspension bridge using the bridge itself as the instrument brought Bertolozzi wide local and international attention. When funding fell through for a live performance, Bertolozzi took the audio samples he had used to compose his works for the bridge, and used them to put together a studio album. The installation features audio from the album, and allows listeners to hear the project on the bridge itself. In 2016, a documentary film by Andrew Porter captured "Bridge Music" and its back-story.

Shahin Musayev Kheyreddin oglu was the Prime Minister of Azerbaijan from 1992 to 1993. He was also the Chairman of the Supreme Soviet of Azerbaijan from 1990 to 1992. Shahin Musayev was born on November 12, 1941, in the village of Ashtarak, Azerbaijan. He graduated from Baku High School in 1959 and from the Baku Institute of Oil and Gas Engineering in 1964. He worked as an engineer at the Azerbaijan Oil Company from 1964 to 1988. In 1988 he was appointed chairman of the State Committee for Work with Foreign Economic Countries. Musayev became Prime Minister of Azerbaijan in 1992, after serving as chairman of the Supreme Soviet of Azerbaijan from 1990 to 1992. He served as Prime Minister until he was replaced by Ayaz Mutalibov in March 1993. Musayev then served as Minister of Industry and Trade until his resignation in December 1994. He is currently a member of the Board of Directors at SOCAR.

Traditional trades (known also as traditional building trades, traditional crafts, traditional tradespeople, or traditional occupations) are a wide range of skilled manual labor occupations that are no longer commonly practiced in the modern world. These trades were once the backbone of many economies and supported a large and diversified workforce. Today, many of these trades are in decline because of technological advancements and the globalization of the economy. However, there are still many traditional trades that remain popular and prosperous. These include carpentry, plumbing, roofing, electrical work, and car repair. Traditional trades can be very rewarding careers if you have the necessary skills and training. If you want to get into a traditional trade, you will need to learn about the trade and its requirements. You will also need to obtain certification or licensure from your state or local government.

Dr. A. Chellakumar is an Indian politician and Member of parliament. He was elected to the Tamil Nadu legislative assembly as an Indian National Congress (INC) candidate from Anna Nagar constituency in the 1991 election and as a Tamil Maanila Congress (Moopanar) (TMC) candidate from T. Nagar constituency in the 1996 election. He was unsuccessful in winning the Villivakkam constituency in 2001. and in the 2011 election he attempted once again to gain the T. Nagar seat. His candidacy in 2001 was as a TMC member and in 2011 it was for the INC. He was runner-up on both occasions. Although he had joined the TMC breakaway group in 1996 when factionalism beset the INC due to a decision to ally with the All Indian Anna Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam (AIADMK) in the state, Chellakumar subsequently fell out with TMC founder G. K. Moopanar. His career then stalled for some years until, seen as a neutral figure with the INC, into which the TMC had re-merged, he was one of three people appointed as a secretary to the Tamil Nadu All India Congress Committee in 2013.

The Australasian Anti-Transportation League was a body established to oppose penal transportation to Australia. Beginning in Van Diemen's Land (Tasmania) in the late 1840s, it had branches in Adelaide, Melbourne, Sydney, and Canterbury (New Zealand). The Colonial Office abandoned transportation to eastern Australia in 1852. Development Transportation to New South Wales (then, the colony covering the eastern Australian mainland, modern New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland) had ceased in 1840 and the number transported to Van Diemen's Land increased sharply. A two-year suspension of the transportation of male convicts to Van Diemen's Land was implemented in May 1846. It was the intention to resume transportation under new arrangements but that decision was conveyed to the local colonial administrator, William Denison in the following terms: "it is not the intention that transportation should be resumed at the expiration of the two years"; the words "under the present system" were omitted. The dispatch, taken to mean what it said on its face, was made public before the imperial authorities corrected their error.

Timofiy Bilohradsky (also Belogradsky, Pelogradsky; ; ca. 1710 — ca. 1782) was a lutenist, composer and kobzar-bandurist of Ukrainian ethnicity, active in St. Petersburg and Königsberg. Little is known about his childhood. He is thought to have been born in or near the city of Cherkasy in Ukraine and that he learned to play the kobza and lute at the Hlukhiv Music Academy in Ukraine. He had an excellent voice and great musical aptitude. In 1725 he was invited to St Petersburg to sing in the Imperial Church Capella. In 1733 Tsarina Anna sent Bilohradsky to Dresden in the retinue of the ambassador Count Keyserlinck to perfect his lute playing under the tutelage of Silvius Leopold Weiss - the most important lutenist-composer of the 18th century. He also studied voice with Faustina Bordoni-Hasse, and castrato Domenico Annibali. Bilohradsky eventually became one of the highest trained musicians in the Russian Court Capella.

Astle died of chronic traumatic encephalopathy in 2002 at the age of 59 . West Brom are commemorating the launch of the Jeff Astle Foundation . The Baggies are wearing a replica of their 1968 FA Cup winning kit .

Yvette Bonny (born 1938) is a Haitian Canadian pediatrician. She arrived in Canada in 1962 where, unusually for a black immigrant, she become established as a doctor. In April 1980, she performed the first bone marrow transplant on a child in eastern Canada. As head of the paediatric bone marrow transplantation unit at Montreal's Hôpital Maisonneuve-Rosemont until 1998, she performed all the transplants herself. From 1972, Bonny was also a professor in the department of medicine at the Université de Montréal. She has received many awards and distinctions including the Order of Canada and the Queen Elizabeth II Diamond Jubilee Medal. Biography Born in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, on 20 July 1938, Yvette Bonny always wanted to become a medical doctor like her grandfather. After she had graduated from the department of medicine at the University of Haiti, in 1962 she arrived in Montreal, Canada, to continue her studies. She specialized first in paediatrics at the Sainte-Justine Hospital. She had then hoped to return to Haiti but in view of the deteriorating political situation there, her parents encouraged her to stay in Canada. She therefore decided to extend her studies to haematology, receiving fellowships at the Hôpital Saint-Antoine in Paris and at the Royal Victoria Hospital in Montreal.

Brooke Christa Shields (born May 31, 1965) is an American actress and model. She is perhaps best known for her role as Cindy Brady on the television sitcom The Brady Bunch from 1969 to 1974. Shields was chosen as "America's Most Beautiful Teenager" in the 1970 edition of the title, and won the title again in 1972 and 1973. She was also a Playmate of the Month for the January 1974 issue of Playboy magazine. Shields began her acting career in television commercials, but achieved wider recognition for her role as Cindy Brady on The Brady Bunch. She reprised her role for The Brady Bunch Movie (1978) and The Brady Bunch Reunion (1995). In 1994, she made her Broadway debut in the play Sweet Charity. Shields has since appeared in a variety of films, including Pretty Woman (1990), Forrest Gump (1994), Father of the Bride (1991), What Women Want (2000), and Black Swan (2010). Shields has been married three times, to actor Matt Dillon from 1987 to 1990, to singer John Travolta from 1991 to 1991, and to businessman Casey Kasem from 1997 to 1999. She has two children, daughter Madeline from her first marriage, and son Presley from her second marriage.

Khutzeymateen Inlet (also spelled K’tzim-a-Deen in the Tlingit language, or Ketchikan Inlet) is an inlet on the western coast of the island of Alaska in the United States. It is located on the north shore of Chatham Island, and is about long and wide. The inlet has a sheltered bay with a number of small islands, and it opens out onto the Gulf of Alaska. The name Khutzeymateen Inlet is derived from the Tlingit language word "khutzeymateen", meaning "place where one can see a great many eagles". The inlet was first explored by Europeans in 1786, when Spanish explorer Don Juan Pérez sailed into it on his way to explore the Alaska Peninsula. The first recorded landing in the area was by Russian fur traders in 1795. The inlet was used as a trading post by the Russians and later by American traders. The first permanent European settlement at Ketchikan, founded by American trader George Vancouver in 1811, was located near the outlet of Khutzeymateen Inlet. The area around Khutzeymateen Inlet has been heavily mined for coal since the early 1900s. The coal mines have caused significant environmental damage, and have been closed down several times due to protests by environmentalists. The most recent closure took place in 2001. The climate around Khutzeymateen Inlet is mild year-round, with average temperatures ranging from 10 to 25

Ramaz Nikolaishvili (born 17 June 1965) is a Georgian politician who served as the Minister for Regional Development and Infrastructure of Georgia from 2010 to 2012. Early years Nikolaishvili was born on June 17, 1965 in Tbilisi, Georgia. From 1983 to 1990, he studied at Georgian Technical University graduating with a degree in Civil Engineering. He later studied at and graduated from Tbilisi State University with master's degrees in Finance and Credit, Economics and Law in 1997 and 2003, respectively. In 1994-2000, he worked in managerial positions at Operative Division of the Tax Inspection of Georgia. In 2000-2003, he was the Deputy Head of Special Task Division of Special Legion. From 2003 through 2004, Nikolaishvili was the Deputy Chief of Information and Analysis Department of Financial Police of the Ministry of Finance of Georgia and in 2004-2005, head of its Statistics and Information Services. In 2005-2007, he worked as the head of Main Division of Investigation Department of Financial Police, in 2007-2008, as head of Main Division of Investigation Department of Revenue Service.

Bernard Blomfield Riley (21 July 1912 – 4 August 1978) was an Australian politician. He was born in Cairns to mill manager Bernard Rocks Riley and Isabelle Marion Murphy. He was educated at The King's School in Parramatta and then attended Oxford University, where he received a Bachelor of Arts in 1934 and a Master of Arts in 1951. Called to the bar at Gray's Inn in 1935 and in New South Wales in 1936, he worked as a barrister. On 15 December 1941 he married Stephanie Marguerite Day, with whom he had two children. In 1960 he was appointed Queen's Counsel. From 1968 to 1973 he was a Liberal member of the New South Wales Legislative Council; he resigned in 1973 to become a judge of the Federal Court of Bankruptcy. In 1977 he was appointed to the Federal Court, but he died in Sydney the following year.

Ding Junhui (; born 1 April 1987) is a Chinese professional snooker player and the most successful Asian player in the history of the sport. Throughout his career, he has won 14 major ranking titles, including three UK Championships (2005, 2009, 2019). He has twice reached the final of the Masters, winning once in 2011. In 2016, he became the first Asian player to reach the final of the World Championship. Ding began playing snooker at age nine and rose to international prominence in 2002 after winning the Asian Under-21 Championship and the Asian Championship. At age 15, he became the youngest winner of the IBSF World Under-21 Championship. In 2003, Ding turned professional at the age of 16. His first major professional successes came in 2005 when he won the China Open and the UK Championship, becoming the first player from outside Great Britain and Ireland to win the title.

Ivan Berlyn (1867 – 11 December 1934) was a Russian-born American artist and printmaker who is considered one of the leading figures of the American Impressionist movement. He was also known for his woodblock prints and paintings of urban scenes. Ivan Berlyn was born in 1867 in Moscow, Russia, to a wealthy family. He began his artistic training at the Moscow School of Painting, Sculpture and Architecture, but left to study at the Royal Academy of Fine Arts in Florence, Italy in 1887. Upon his return to Russia, he continued his studies at the Imperial Academy of Arts in Saint Petersburg, graduating with honors in 1892. Berlyn first came to prominence as a painter and printmaker in Russia in the late 1890s. In 1899, he exhibited his paintings and prints at the World's Fair in Paris. The following year, he settled in the United States and became a naturalized citizen. He continued to live and work in New York City until his death there on December 11, 1934. Ivan Berlyn is best known for his paintings and prints of urban scenes, which capture the bustling energy of mid-20th century New York City. His work has been exhibited at museums around the world, including the Museum of Modern Art (MoMA) in New York City and the Art Institute of Chicago. He was awarded the Gold Medal for Fine Arts by the New York City Board of Aldermen in 1922.

Frontex says the EU's border agency is not coordinating search and rescue efforts. The UK says search and rescue operations in international waters are "an unintended 'pull factor' The EU has been criticized for not doing enough to help the migrants.

Gareth Vaughan Bennett, also known as Garry Bennett (born 25 October 1961) is a retired Anglican priest in the Church of England. Bennett is best known for his work as a missionary in the Democratic Republic of the Congo and his work with children and young people. Gareth Bennett was born on 25 October 1961 in Wimbledon, London, England. He was educated at Ampleforth College and Christ's College, Cambridge, where he earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in theology. He was ordained into the Church of England in 1987. Bennett spent most of his priesthood working as a missionary in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. He has been involved in a number of humanitarian projects, including working with children and young people. In 2002, he was awarded the prestigious Albert Schweitzer Prize for his work with young people. Bennett retired from full-time ministry in 2013.

Kenneth Cartwright Patty (December 2, 1891 – March 27, 1967) was a Virginia lawyer who served as the 27th Attorney General of Virginia. Patty was an assistant attorney general before Governor Thomas Stanley appointed him after the resignation of his boss, J. Lindsay Almond. Almond was member of the Democratic political organization led by Senator Harry F. Byrd, and he stepped down to run for Governor during the Massive Resistance crisis in Virginia. Patty's tenure at that position ended after Albertis Harrison, elected during that same 1957 election, took office. Personal life Kenneth Patty was born in Parrottsville, Tennessee, where his father, Rev. William Monroe Petty, served at Harned's Chapel. His mother, the former Minnie Bushong, bore at least 3 sons (one of whom, Graydon Patty, became a minister like his father) and 3 daughters. An ancestor served in the American Revolutionary War. The family subsequently moved to Tazewell, Virginia. Patty attended Washington and Lee University Law School, graduating in 1918. Patty married Ruth Friend Lacy (1892-1967) and had a daughter.

Chung Seo-woon (1924–2004) was a Korean comfort woman during World War II. She was the first Korean woman to be recognized as a victim of war rape by the United Nations. Chung Seo-woon was born in 1924 in the village of Namyangju, Gyeonggi Province, in what was then the Japanese Empire. At the time of her capture, she was a 19-year-old high school student. After being taken prisoner by the Japanese military in 1942, Chung was forcibly recruited into the Japanese military's Comfort Women Program, which dispatched Japanese women to occupied areas to provide sexual services to Japanese soldiers. Chung was repeatedly raped by Japanese soldiers throughout her time as a Comfort Woman. After being liberated by Allied forces in 1945, Chung sought help from the United Nations War Crimes Commission. In 1948, she testified at a Tokyo trial of six Comfort Women defendants, and became the first Korean woman to be recognized as a victim of war rape by the UN. Chung later published her autobiography, "Comfort Woman", which brought attention to her experience as a Comfort Woman and helped spur public discussion about Japan's wartime sexual violence. She died in 2004.

Helen U. Esuene (born 23 November 1949) is a Nigerian-born British actress and singer. Esuene was born in Ibadan, Nigeria, on 23 November 1949. Her family moved to the United Kingdom when she was five years old, and she was educated at the Katherine Harris School for Girls in West London. Esuene began her career as a child actor, appearing in such films as The Guns of Navarone (1961) and The Lion in Winter (1968). She made her stage debut in the musical production of Oliver! in London's West End in 1971. Esuene began her professional singing career in 1974, when she released her debut album, Helen U. Esuene. The album spawned two UK Top 40 singles, "Love Is All Around" and "Save My Love for You". In 1977, Esuene starred as the title character in the UK television series Helen. The series ran for three seasons and was followed by a series of successful spin-off films. Esuene also starred in the TV series Blanche's Sister (1978) and The New Adventures of Robin Hood (1981). Esuene made her feature film debut in the comedy film Up the Creek (1986), and has since appeared in such films as The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert (1994), Big Daddy (1999), Venus & Mars (2011), and The Hundred-Foot Journey (2014). She has also appeared on television in such programmes

Hastings is a city and the county seat of Brown County, Nebraska, United States. The population was 3,912 at the 2010 census. It is part of the Hastings, Nebraska metropolitan area. Hastings was founded in 1876 when the Fremont and Elkhorn Railroad was extended to that point. The city was named for Robert Hastings, one of the original railroad investors. Hastings became a center for grain and livestock marketing and has since developed into a regional manufacturing center. The city is also home to a number of colleges and universities, including Hastings College of Law, Hastings University of the Health Sciences, and the University of Nebraska–Hastings. Hastings is located at (41.460826, -96.435690). According to the United States Census Bureau, the city has a total area of , all of it land. As of the census of 2010, there were 3,912 people, 1,663 households, and 1,012 families residing in the city. The population density was . There were 1,859 housing units at an average density of . The racial makeup of the city was 92.5% White, 3.2% African American, 0.7% Native American, 1.1% Asian, 0.1% Pacific Islander, 0.6% from other races, and 2.3% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 2.5% of the population.

Michael Hamilton Jameson (London 15 October 1924 – Los Angeles, California 14 December 2005) was an English author, journalist and film critic. Jameson is best known for his work as a film critic for "The Observer" and "The Sunday Times". He wrote extensively on Italian neorealist cinema, and is considered a leading authority on the films of Federico Fellini. He also wrote extensively on Hollywood cinema, and was a regular contributor to "The New York Times" review section. Jameson was born in London, the son of an Irish doctor. He attended Eton College and Trinity College, Cambridge. After serving in the Royal Navy during World War II, he began his career in journalism as a copy boy on "The Daily Telegraph". He then worked for several years as a film critic for "The Observer" and "The Sunday Times". In 1974 he became film critic for "The New York Times", where he remained until his retirement in 1996. Jameson was also a writer of books on cinema, including "Eccentric Cinema: A Collection of Critical Essays" (1982), "Cinema: A History" (1990), and "A Hundred Years of Movies" (1996). In 1992 he was awarded an honorary doctorate by Trinity College, Cambridge. Jameson married the actress Patricia Neal in 1951; they divorced in 1970. During her father 's presidential campaign and subsequent two terms in the White House , Chelsea was well known for her tight curls . In her interview , published days after her mother 's presidential candidacy announcement , she also addressed America 's ` need ' for female politicians .

Double victory for Oxford as both men and women 's teams won races . Women competed on same course as men and on same day for first time . Up to 300,000 expected to line the banks of the Thames for historic race . Oxford men 's rowing team claimed their fourth win in five years .

Stanley Seymour Applebaum (March 1, 1922 – February 23, 2019) was an American composer, arranger, musician and conductor. He arranged the orchestration on many pop hit records, most notably in the early 1960s, including The Drifters' "Save the Last Dance for Me"; Ben E. King's "Spanish Harlem" and "Stand By Me"; Brian Hyland's "Sealed with a Kiss"; and Neil Sedaka's "Breaking Up Is Hard to Do". Life and career Applebaum was born in Newark, New Jersey, United States. He started playing piano aged 7, after a doctor suggested it would help heal a broken finger, and began taking lessons. By the age of 12 he had started writing arrangements for his school band, and played at local weddings and events, and in clubs. He wrote arrangements for Cootie Williams, Lucky Millinder, and others, before serving in World War II in Germany, where he joined the US Army band. After leaving the military, he joined music publishers Edwin H. Morris & Co, and began composing. His reputation as an arranger grew, and he worked with bandleaders such as Benny Goodman, Harry James and Charlie Ventura, as well as Jimmy Durante.  He is co-credited as writer of the Billy Eckstine and Sarah Vaughan hit "Passing Strangers". Mort Palitz of Jubilee Records asked Applebaum to arrange songs on a 1958 album, Scotch Mist, by Marilynn Lovell, and he also orchestrated Al Martino's 1959 album Swing Along.

Tulsa County Sheriff 's Office reserve deputy Robert Bates faces a charge of second-degree manslaughter for the April 2 shooting of Eric Harris . In an interview on the Today show on Friday , he described his shock and remorse at the shooting and how he never intended to kill anyone . He demonstrated that he kept his Taser near his chest and his gun on his right side - but insisted the mix-up could have happened to anyone . Bates said he had completed all proper training and was not allowed to ` play cop ' just because he had donated equipment to the sheriff 's office .

Satyam Computers Services was at the center of a massive $ 1.6 billion fraud case in 2009 . The software services exporter 's chairman , Ramalinga Raju , admitted inflating profits . Satyam had been India 's fourth-largest software services provider .

Prof Thomas Walmsley FRSE (1889–1951) was a Scottish anatomist who made significant contributions to the understanding of the human body. Born in 1889 in Glasgow, Walmsley attended the University of Glasgow where he gained a BSc in 1912 and an MD in 1916. He then worked as a doctor for a number of years before joining the University of Edinburgh as a lecturer in 1919. In 1931, he moved to the University of Cambridge where he served as Professor of Anatomy and Physiology until his death in 1951. Walmsley made significant contributions to the understanding of the human body, particularly in his work on the structure and function of the nervous system. His work helped to develop theories on how nerve cells communicate with each other, and it also helped to establish how diseases such as epilepsy are caused. Walmsley was also highly influential in the development of medical ultrastructural techniques, and his work helped to elucidate the molecular basis of many diseases.

Mathias Joseph Alten (February 13, 1871 – September 7, 1954) was a German mathematician who made seminal contributions to the theory of differential equations and complex analysis. He was also a renowned theorist of relativity, and developed the Alten–Noether theorem. Alten was born in Münster, North Rhine-Westphalia, Germany on February 13, 1871. He studied at the universities of Bonn, Göttingen and Berlin, receiving his doctorate from Berlin in 1898. He became a professor at Göttingen in 1907 and at Berlin in 1916. In 1933 he emigrated to the United States, where he became a professor at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. He retired in 1948 and died on September 7, 1954. Alten is best known for his work in differential equations and complex analysis, which included the development of the Alten–Noether theorem. He also made significant contributions to relativity theory, including the Alten–Kirchhoff–Lemaitre theory of general relativity and the Alten–Born–Jordan equation of general relativity.

Community food security (CFS) is a relatively new concept that captures emerging ideas about the central place of food in communities. At times it refers to the measure of food access and availability at the community level, and at other times to a goal or framework for place-based food systems. It builds upon the more commonly understood concept of food security, which refers to food access and availability at an individual or household level (in health and social policy, for instance) and at a national or global level (e.g., in international development and aid work). Hamm and Bellows (2003) define CFS as “a situation in which all community residents obtain a safe, culturally acceptable, nutritionally adequate diet through a sustainable food system that maximizes community self-reliance and social justice” (p. 37).  CFS involves social, economic, and institutional factors, and their interrelationships within a community that impact availability and access to resources to produce food locally. It takes into account environmental sustainability and social fairness through measures of the availability and affordability of food in that community relative to the financial resources available to purchase or produce it. CFS' Global Scale In industrialized countries, income-related food security is measured at both the individual and household levels whereas in non-industrialized countries it is most often measured in terms of under-nutrition and malnutrition through anthropometric measurements.  Indicators of individual food insecurity include limited food selection, suboptimal nutrient intakes and severe nutrient inadequacies. Household food insecurity measures food intake of adults and children as a group within the home in relation to household income and food cost expenditure. Markers of vulnerability to food insecurity in Canada and U.S. include low income, reliance on welfare, lone motherhood, lack of home ownership, and Aboriginal status.

Around 200,000 people were deported to the Nazi camp in northern Germany during World War Two . British soldiers took over the camp on April 15 , 1945 and found tens of thousands of dead bodies . Their intervention came just two months after diarist Anne Frank , who was held at the camp , died .

Keith Freeman (born December 11, 1963) is a Canadian musician, best known as the drummer for the Canadian rock band Rush. Freeman has been the drummer for Rush since 1983 and has played on all of their studio albums, as well as numerous live albums and DVDs. He has also recorded several solo albums, and is a frequent collaborator with other artists, playing drums on records by Tom Petty, The Tea Party and Lucie Silvas. Born in Lindsay, Ontario, Freeman started playing drums at the age of eight. After being accepted into the Berklee School of Music in Boston, Massachusetts, he played with several Boston-area bands before joining Rush in 1983. Freeman has been a regular member of the band ever since, and has appeared on all their studio albums except 1992's Fly by Night. In 2003, Freeman was diagnosed with a rare form of lymphoma and underwent chemotherapy and radiation treatment. He returned to full-time drumming in 2005 and continues to play with Rush regularly. Freeman has won several awards throughout his career with Rush, including two Juno Awards (for Best Rock Album for Moving Pictures in 1990 and Vapor Trails in 2007), three Grammy Awards (for Best Rock Performance by a Drummer for The Spirit of Radio in 1998, 2112 in 2002 and Clockwork Angels in 2011), and two Canadian Music Awards (for Group of the Year for Rush in 2001 and Drummer of the Year in 2010). He is also a two-time winner of the prestigious Drummer Magazine Drummer of the Year

The Make-Up is an American post-punk band from Washington, D.C. formed in 1995, consisting of ex-Nation of Ulysses frontman Ian Svenonius on vocals, James Canty on guitar and organ, Steve Gamboa on drums, and Michelle Mae on bass guitar. The Make-Up were joined in late 1999 by a fifth member, Alex Minoff (of the groups Golden and Extra Golden), who played guitar with the group until the band's dissolution in early 2000. The Make-Up combined garage rock, soul, and a self-styled liberation theology to make a new genre they called "Gospel Yeh-Yeh". This style led to an emphasis on live performances and interaction between the band and their audience, incorporating the audience into the performances as a "fifth member", creating what one reviewer described as ""highly energetic and participatory live shows". Parallel to the band's gospel musical stylings, the Make-Up produced music under a communism-influenced political philosophy that they saw as counter to the capitalist form of modern rock and roll and pop music.

Rev. Samuel Austin Moffett (1864–1939, , Hanja: 道州蘭森 宣教士) was an American Protestant missionary and educator in Korea. He served as a professor at the University of Seoul from 1901 to 1907, and later served as the president of the American Presbyterian Mission in Korea from 1907 to 1919. Moffett was born on October 9, 1864, in , Hanja: 道州蘭森, in what is now the Republic of Korea. He was one of six children born to missionaries who had worked in Korea since the 1850s. Moffett's father, James Moffett, was a theologian who had served as pastor of a Presbyterian church in Shanghai before coming to Korea. Samuel Moffett attended the Monroe School in Shanghai before enrolling at the University of Michigan in 1883. There, he studied theology and education. Moffett was ordained into the Presbyterian ministry in 1886. He began his missionary work in 1887, when he became a teacher at a Presbyterian school in Incheon. In 1901, Moffett was appointed professor of Christian education at the University of Seoul. He served in this position until 1907, when he was appointed president of the American Presbyterian Mission in Korea. Moffett helped to rebuild the Korean Presbyterian church after it had been destroyed during the Japanese occupation of Korea (1910–1945). He also played an important role in revitalizing Korean education during this time. Moffett retired from his missionary work

Silent Screams are an English metalcore band formed in Coventry, West Midlands, England, in 2007. The band currently consists of lead vocalist Joel Heywood, guitarists Ozzi Osman and Sam Varney and drummer Adam Mallabone and bass-player and vocalist Tom Craig. The band released two EP: Ghosts on 2008, and Hope Is the Assurance of Fools on 2009; and two studio albums: When It Rains on 2011, and Hope for Now on 2014. History The band released a self-produced EP "Ghosts" in 2008. In 2009, the band released their second EP "Hope is the Assurance of Fools", produced by Matt Hyde (As I Lay Dying, Gallows and Funeral for a Friend), in an edition of 1000 copies. In 2011, the band signed with the label Ghost Music to release their debut album with the producer Joey Sturgis (The Devil Wears Prada, Asking Alexandria, Miss May I). The album When It Rains was released on 24 October 2011.

A characteristic of Homer's style is the use of epithets, as in "rosy-fingered" Dawn or "swift-footed" Achilles. Epithets are used because of the constraints of the dactylic hexameter (i.e., it is convenient to have a stockpile of metrically fitting phrases to add to a name) and because of the oral transmission of the poems; they are mnemonic aids to the singer and the audience alike. Formulae in epic poetry from various Indo-European traditions may be traced to a common tradition. For example, the phrase for "everlasting glory" or "undying fame" can be found in the Homeric Greek as / and Vedic Sanskrit as / . These two phrases were, in terms of historical linguistics, equivalent in phonology, accentuation, and quantity (syllable length). In other words, they descend from a fragment of poetic diction (reconstructable as Proto-Indo-European ) which was handed down in parallel over many centuries, in continually diverging forms, by generations of singers whose ultimate ancestors shared an archetypal repertoire of poetic formulae and narrative themes.

Ruth Tringham (born 14 October 1940) is a British author and artist. Ruth Tringham was born in 1940 in London, England. She attended the Slade School of Fine Art, University of London, graduating with an Honours degree in 1962. She then travelled to India, where she studied at the Guindy School of Art. After returning to England, Tringham began her career as a painter, exhibiting her work at the Royal Academy of Arts, London and the Paris Salon. She also worked as a teacher at the Slade School of Fine Art for many years. In 1984, Tringham published her first novel, A Life Apart. The book was well-received and won the Somerset Maugham Award. Tringham has since written several other novels, including The Truth About George (1988), The Memory Keeper's Daughter (1990), and The Painter (1994). Her books have been published in twenty languages and have been translated into more than twenty-five. Tringham has also continued to paint and exhibit her work throughout her career. In 1998 she was awarded a commission by the Queen to create a series of paintings for the Royal Collection. Her most recent paintings were exhibited at the Royal Academy in London in 2016. Tringham is also a prolific artist. Her work is in many public and private collections around the world, including the Victoria and Albert Museum in London, the National Gallery of Australia in Canberra, and the Musée d'Ors

Mark Schoofs is an American Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist and author who has written about national politics, current events, and media. He is a senior writer for Politico magazine. Schoofs was born in Washington, D.C., in 1965. He graduated from the University of Michigan in 1987 with a degree in political science, and he worked as a reporter for The Michigan Daily while he was an undergraduate. He later worked as a national correspondent for The Wall Street Journal and as a senior national correspondent for Politico. Schoofs has written about national politics, current events, and media, including articles about the 2016 presidential election, the Trump administration, the opioid crisis, and the media industry. In 2017, he won the Pulitzer Prize for Explanatory Reporting for his coverage of the 2016 presidential election and the Russian interference in it.
