"Thong Song" is a song recorded by American R&B singer Sisqó. It was released on February 15, 2000, as the second single from Sisqó's 1999 solo debut studio album Unleash the Dragon. "Thong Song" garnered four Grammy nominations and numerous other awards. The song peaked at number one on the Billboard Rhythmic top 40 chart and number three on the Billboard Hot 100, Sisqó's second highest-peaking hit behind "Incomplete". It was a major success worldwide as well, reaching the top ten throughout European charts and reaching number three in the United Kingdom, Netherlands, and Denmark. The song also topped the charts in New Zealand. Production The song was written and produced by Sisqó, and Tim & Bob, the duo of Tim Kelley and Bob Robinson. Songwriters Desmond Child and Draco Rosa receive songwriting credit because of the interpolation of part of their composition, "Livin' la Vida Loca" (originally recorded by Ricky Martin), in the song's lyrics. The strings heard throughout the song, performed for the record by violinist Bruce Dukov, are inspired by Wes Montgomery's cover of The Beatles' "Eleanor Rigby" which Tim originally sampled in its origin.

Georgetown (formerly Growlersburg) is a census-designated place (CDP) in San Joaquin County, California, United States. The population was 5,615 at the 2010 census. It is part of the Bakersfield–Delano Metropolitan Statistical Area. Georgetown is located at (38.898536, -119.729185). According to the United States Census Bureau, the CDP has a total area of , all land. As of the census of 2000, there were 5,659 people, 2,303 households, and 1,524 families residing in the CDP. The population density was 1,733.4 people per square mile (634.4/km²). There were 2,397 housing units at an average density of 649.2 per square mile (250.9/km²). The racial makeup of the CDP was 93.53% White, 0.43% African American, 0.93% Native American, 2.24% Asian, 0.06% Pacific Islander, 2.30% from other races, and 2.27% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 5.68% of the population. There were 2,303 households out of which 39.5% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 59.2% were married couples living together, 11.5% had a female householder with no husband present, and 23.3% were non-families

Go! Pop! Bang! is the debut studio album by American rapper Rye Rye. It was released on N.E.E.T. Recordings, an imprint of Interscope Records. The album was originally scheduled for release in 2009, but it has since been delayed several times, due to a pregnancy and label issues. It was eventually released on May 15, 2012, with a deluxe version available through digital music retailers. The album features several artists including M.I.A., Akon, Tyga, Robyn, and Porcelain Black. Production credits are given to M.I.A., The Neptunes, Mr. Bangladesh, and RedOne. The variety of styles brought from each producer was praised by critics. On the Billboard Hot Dance Club Songs chart, the album's three singles charted in the top 20, with "Never Will Be Mine" and "Boom Boom" being the only ones to break the top 10. As a whole, the album peaked at six on the Top Heatseekers chart. The album also charted on the Top Rap Albums and Top Electronic Albums charts.

William Allen Stein (born January 21, 1947) is an American former professional baseball player. A pitcher, Stein played in Major League Baseball (MLB) for the New York Mets, Philadelphia Phillies, and Kansas City Royals. Stein was drafted by the Mets in the first round of the 1966 amateur draft. He made his MLB debut with the Mets on May 6, 1970. After spending most of his career with the Mets, Stein was traded to Philadelphia in December 1978. He played for the Phillies until he was traded to Kansas City in August 1981. Stein finished his MLB career with the Royals in 1984. Stein was a member of three World Series-winning teams: with the Mets in 1969 and 1973, and with the Phillies in 1980. He also won two Cy Young Awards (with the Mets in 1973 and with Philadelphia in 1980). Stein also pitched a no-hitter on April 13, 1972 against the Cincinnati Reds. Stein retired from baseball after the 1984 season. He has since worked as a pitching coach for several teams, most notably for the Royals from 2004 to 2006. Stein has also served as a color commentator for Mets telecasts on SNY since 2007.

Meanwhile, Jerry dates Elaine's secretary and inadvertently offends her during their dirty talk. Plot Jerry and George struggle with their sitcom pilot script. Fairlie Castle is a restored oblong tower house in the village of Fairlie, near Kirriemuir, Angus, Scotland. It is protected as a category A listed building. The castle was constructed in the early 16th century by Sir James Douglas of Lochinvar, from whom it passed to the Earl of Morton. Sir John Sinclair, 3rd Baronet made further alterations and improvements to the castle in the 18th century. It was purchased by the Marquess of Bute in 1892 and is now a private residence. Fairlie Castle is built on a rocky outcrop overlooking the River Kirriemuir. The original castle consisted of a single tower house measuring 18 metres by 12 metres, with walls 2.5 metres thick. The tower is now collapsed and only part of its foundations remain, while the remainder of the structure has been restored to its 17th century appearance. The grounds surrounding the castle are extensive and include a garden, a deer park, and a lake.

The Borderland series of urban fantasy novels and stories were created for teenage readers by author Terri Windling. Most of the series is set in Bordertown, a dystopian city near the border between "the Elflands" and "The World". The series consists of five anthologies and three novels. The series has spawned fan groups, gaming groups, costumed events (such as the Borderzone parties in Los Angeles), and was discussed in The Fence and the River: Culture and Politics at the US-Mexico Border by Claire F. Fox. Bordertown is the name of the shared universe created by Terri Windling, and a fictional place within that universe. The premise of the Borderland books is that the "Elflands" - a realm of magic populated by post-Tolkien elves have "returned" to "The World". The region of juxtaposition of the Elflands and the World includes Bordertown or "B-Town", and the "Borderlands" which lie between Bordertown and the World. In the liminal environment of Bordertown and its environs, neither magic nor technology functions "normally", and unpredictable combinations of the two may emerge.

Rancho Tzabaco was a Mexican land grant in present-day Los Angeles County, California given in 1841 by Governor Juan Alvarado to José María Verdugo. The grant was located in the present-day city of Claremont. The rancho consisted of over and stretched from the San Gabriel Mountains to the Santa Ana River. The main buildings were a main house and two barns. There were also several outbuildings and a vineyard. The rancho was used as a cattle ranch and it is said that Verdugo raised more than 12,000 beef cattle there. In 1845, Verdugo sold the rancho to José Antonio Yorba. Yorba used the rancho for grazing cattle and for raising fruit trees. In 1850, Yorba sold the rancho to Nicolas Pico. Pico used the rancho for grazing cattle and for growing grapes. In 1871, Pico sold the rancho to Adolph Sutro. Sutro used the rancho for growing citrus fruits and flowers. In 1905, Sutro sold the rancho to Francis Preston Blair. Blair used the rancho for growing citrus fruits and flowers. In 1918, Blair sold the rancho to Henry E. Huntington. Huntington used the rancho for growing citrus fruits and flowers, as well as raising horses and dairy cows. In 1938, Huntington sold the rancho to The Santa Anita Corporation. The Santa Anita Corporation used the rancho for racing horses and breeding thoroughbred

Jaafar Muhammad an-Nimeiry (otherwise spelled in English as Jaafar Nimeiry, Jaafar Nimeiry or Ja'far Muhammad Numayri; ; 26 April 192830 May 2009) was a Sudanese politician who served as the president of Sudan from 1969 to 1985. A military officer, he came to power after a military coup in 1969. Establishing a one-party state, with his Sudanese Socialist Union as the sole legal political entity in the country, Nimeiry pursued socialist and Pan-Arabist policies and close collaboration with Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt and Muammar Gaddafi of Libya. In 1971 Nimeiry survived a pro-Soviet coup attempt, after which he forged an alliance with Mao Zedong of China (who provided him with significant military and economic assistance), and, eventually, with the United States as well. In 1972 he signed the Addis Ababa Agreement, ending the First Sudanese Civil War. In his last years in power he also adopted aspects of Islamism, and in 1983 he imposed Sharia law throughout the country, precipitating the Second Sudanese Civil War. He was ousted from power in 1985 and went into exile in Egypt. He returned in 1999 and ran in the presidential elections in 2000, but did poorly.

Melanie Dodd (born 10 May 1973) is an Australian former swimmer who specialized in sprint freestyle events. She represented the host nation Australia, as a 27-year-old, at the 2000 Summer Olympics, and also trained for the Australian Institute of Sport, under Russian-based swim coach Gennadi Touretski. She won two medals, a silver and bronze, in the 4×100-metre freestyle relay at the 1995 FINA Short Course World Championships in Rio de Janeiro, and 1999 FINA Short Course World Championships in Hong Kong. Dodd competed only in the women's 4×100-metre freestyle relay at the 2000 Summer Olympics in Sydney. On the first night of the Games, the Aussie team pulled off a sixth-place finish in the final with a time of 3:40.91. Teaming with Sarah Ryan, Elka Graham and Giaan Rooney in heat two on the morning prelims, Dodd swam the third leg and recorded a split of 56.31 to post a fifth-seeded time of 3:43.56 for the home squad.

Carpathian Peak is a prominent mountain summit located in the Kenai Mountains, in the U.S. state of Alaska. The peak is situated in Chugach National Forest, southwest of Whittier, Alaska, at the isthmus of the Kenai Peninsula, where the Kenai Mountains meet the Chugach Mountains. Although modest in elevation, relief is significant since the eastern aspect of the mountain rises from sea level at Blackstone Bay in Prince William Sound. The peak's nearest higher peak is Isthmus Peak, to the south, and nearby Bard Peak lies northeast. The mountain's name was officially adopted in 1959 by the United States Geological Survey. The 1959 first ascent party of Keith Hart, Ted Barrett, and Mat Nitsch suggested the name as a tribute to the Carpathian Mountains back in Mat's homeland which at the time was behind the Iron Curtain, with the intention to create a symbol of freedom. Alexander Surtees Chancellor, CBE (4 January 1940 – 17 July 2018) was a British journalist and broadcaster. Chancellor was born in 1940 in London, England, the son of Lillian (née Surtees) and Alexander Chancellor, a barrister. He was educated at Eton College and at Trinity College, Cambridge, where he read History. He began his career in journalism as a reporter on the "Cambridge Evening News" in 1962. He then worked for "The Sunday Times", first as political correspondent and then as assistant editor. In 1974 he became editor of "The Observer", a post he held until 1984. During his time at "The Observer", Chancellor made significant contributions to the newspaper's editorial direction, including the publication of the influential "Opinion" column. In 1984 he became director of BBC Television News, a post he held until 1988. In 1988 Chancellor returned to journalism as political editor of "The Guardian". He held that post until 1995, when he left to become managing director of Channel 4 News. He remained in that post until 2003, when he retired from broadcasting. Chancellor was appointed Commander of the Order of the British Empire (CBE) in the 1994 Birthday Honours for his services to journalism. He was also awarded an Honorary Doctorate from King's College London in 2006 and an Honorary Degree from University of East Anglia in 2007. Chancellor died on 17 July 2018, aged 80

The Cañadón Asfalto Basin is an irregularly shaped sedimentary basin located in north-central Patagonia, Argentina. The basin stretches from and partly covers the North Patagonian Massif in the north, a high forming the boundary of the basin with the Neuquén Basin in the northwest, to the Cotricó High in the south, separating the basin from the Golfo San Jorge Basin. It is located in the southern part of Río Negro Province and northern part of Chubut Province. The eastern boundary of the basin is the North Patagonian Massif separating it from the offshore Valdés Basin and it is bound in the west by the Patagonian Andes, separating it from the small Ñirihuau Basin. The basin started forming in the Early Jurassic, with the break-up of Pangea and the creation of the South Atlantic, when extensional tectonics, including rifting, formed several basins in eastern South America and southwestern Africa. The accommodation space in the Cañadón Asfalto Basin was filled by volcanic, fluvial and lacustrine deposits in various geologic formations, separated by unconformities related to transtensional and transpressional tectonic forces. The Cenozoic evolution of the basin is mainly influenced by the Andean orogeny, producing folding and faulting in the basin.

The Council of Oman is a bicameral parliament, made up of the members of the State Council and the Consultation Council, as stipulated in Article 58 of the Basic Law of the State. It is considered to be the main Parliament in Oman. It assists the government in drawing up the general policies of the state. The Council meets at the request of the sultan to study and discuss matters raised by him, taking all its decisions on the basis of a majority vote. The sultan addresses all the members of this council on an annual basis. There are 15 women members (14 of them are in the state council) among the 167 members of the parliament. In November 2009 construction work began on the Majlis Oman project, a landmark building to accommodate the parliament assembly hall and the upper and lower houses. The development, designed by q-dar and built by Carillion Alawi, was completed in 2013.

She previously served as Ministry of Education and Vocational Training as well as Ministry of Community Development, Gender and Children. Prior to joining politics, she worked as a teacher in government schools. Early life and education Margaret Simwanza Sitta was born on 24 July 1946.She was educated at Tabora Town Primary School from 1954 to 1957, She then went to Ussoke Girls Middle School from 1958 to 1961, She completed her schooling from the Tabora Girls Secondary School in 1965. She received her Certificate of Grade "A" from the Mpwapwa Teachers College in year 1967 together with Diploma at same college in 1985. She finally received her Ba ED Hons-Degree at University of Dar es Salaam in 1988

Jerry Max Bunyard (born 3 April 1931) is a retired lieutenant general in the United States Army. His assignments included Commanding General of the United States Army Missile Command and deputy commanding general for research, development and acquisition at the United States Army Materiel Command. Born and raised in Altus, Oklahoma, Bunyard was an All State baseball player for Altus High School, helping to win a state championship before graduating in 1949. He attended Oklahoma Baptist University for one year before transferring to Oklahoma A&M College, where he continued to play baseball and also participated in the Army ROTC program. Bunyard graduated from Oklahoma A&M in 1954 with a B.S. degree in animal husbandry and was commissioned as a second lieutenant of Infantry. Signed by the Chicago White Sox, he played one summer of minor league baseball with the Waterloo White Hawks and Colorado Springs Sky Sox before reporting for active duty in the Army. Bunyard transferred from the Infantry to the Artillery and was trained as a Cobra helicopter gunship pilot. He graduated from the Army Command and General Staff College in 1965 and later earned an M.S. degree in international relations from George Washington University.

Rifle Butts Quarry is a Site of Special Scientific Interest (SSSI) in the East Riding of Yorkshire, England. The particular interest of this reserve is the geological feature exposed on the quarry face. The site is owned by the Yorkshire Wildlife Trust. The exposure which is identified as being of national importance in the Geological Conservation Review shows a Cretaceous unconformity, where sediments from the Jurassic and Lower Cretaceous periods were eroded away. It shows a section of Red Chalk and White Chalk overlying Lias. A shelter has been constructed to protect the quarry face from erosion. The reserve is situated on the western edge of the Yorkshire Wolds, one mile south-east of Goodmanham and two miles from Market Weighton. The site, which was designated a SSSI in 1952, has over 150 plants recorded. It still displays some characteristic chalk species, including cowslip, marjoram, field scabious and wild basil. Breeding birds include willow warbler and yellowhammer. References

Dan Weisse is an American college basketball coach, currently the head coach for the Minnesota Crookston Golden Eagles. Weisse is a native of Oshkosh, Wisconsin. He graduated from Oshkosh West High School and then went on to play collegiate basketball for the Milwaukee Panthers and graduated with a degree in secondary education. After his playing days were over, he became a graduate assistant at the University of Wisconsin–La Crosse for the 2004–05 season. For the following two seasons he became a graduate assistant at Middle Tennessee State University. Weisse was then hired as an assistant coach at North Dakota State University under head coach Saul Phillips. He served there for four seasons before being hired as an assistant coach at Minnesota State University–Moorhead where he served for three seasons. In 2014 he was hired as the head coach at the University of Minnesota Crookston. In the last seven seasons, Weisse has accumulated a overall record of 58–132.

John Duncan Watson (7 March 1860 – 1946) was a British civil engineer. Watson was born in Dundee, Scotland on 7 March 1860. He specialised in sanitation and was regarded as a pioneer in the development of sewage treatment. Watson was engineer to the Birmingham and District Drainage Board and also General Manager to the Birmingham, Tame and Rea District Drainage Board. At Birmingham he was responsible for the construction of the first large-scale percolating filter plant, a complete departure from the traditional land treatment in use in the city and elsewhere. Other changes that he introduced, based on his work in Birmingham, were the separation of sludge digestion, the extraction of methane from sewage for use in power generation and the introduction of flocculation prior to the percolating filter. He drew up plans for sanitation works in the district of Aberdeen which included a pumping station at Denmill, reservoir at the Hill of Ord and water supply to the district of Culter. These plans are now held by the National Archives of Scotland.

The Battle of Hoengsong, also known as the Battle of Hsungsong, was a battle fought in the late Korean War between United States and North Korean forces. The battle resulted in a United States victory. The Battle of Hoengsong was fought on November 28 and 29, 1950, near Hoengsong, North Korea. The battle was the first large-scale confrontation of the Korean War, and resulted in a United States victory. The battle began when elements of the 24th Infantry Division, commanded by Major General Edward M. Almond, were ordered to cross the Naktong River and attack the Hoengsong Dam on November 28. After initial success in breaching the dam, Almond's forces were met with heavy resistance from the North Koreans. However, by November 29, Almond's men had succeeded in clearing the dam and routing the North Koreans. The victory allowed United States forces to advance north and eventually capture Pyongyang.

Edson Garfield Bahr (October 16, 1919 – May 16, 2009) was an American pianist, composer, and educator. He is considered one of the most influential and respected figures in modern classical music. Bahr was born in New York City to Russian-Jewish parents. He began his musical studies at the age of five, studying piano with his mother. Later he studied with Arthur Rubinstein, Arnold Schoenberg, and others. He made his professional debut in 1939 and soon became one of the leading piano players of his generation. Bahr was especially noted for his interpretations of 20th century classical music, as well as works by Romantic and 20th century masters. Bahr served as the music director of the Curtis Institute of Music (1951–1971) and the Juilliard School (1972–1984). He also held positions at several other leading music schools, including the University of California at Berkeley (1957–1958), Yale University (1967–1970), and Columbia University (1976–1984). Bahr was a member of the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences and the American Academy of Arts and Letters. Bahr died at the age of 92 in 2009. His body was cremated and his ashes scattered over the seas near his home in Southampton, New York.

Robyn Benincasa is an American endurance racer, adventure racer, author, and motivational speaker. She was a competitor in several seasons of the Eco-Challenge: The Expedition Race reality television show. Her team won the 2000 Eco-Challenge in Borneo. She went on to found or co-found two companies focused on team-building for corporate clients. She is the founder of Project Athena, a nonprofit organization that helps women who have experienced medical challenges to fulfill their athletic ambitions. She holds three Guinness World Records. Athletic career While serving as a firefighter in San Diego, California, Benincasa became a successful endurance racer and triathlete. In 1995, she was a member of the second American team to complete the Raid Gauloises adventure race. In 1997, she was on the Mountain Dew-sponsored team in the Discovery Channel Eco-Challenge in Queensland, Australia. She was on the Eco-Internet team in 1999 and 2000, and contributed to that team's first-place victory in 2000. She was dropped from the team in 2001 due to a struggle with asthma brought on by exercise and altitude during a race in Switzerland. She was treated for the ailment, and stepped in to join Team Earthlink, which had lost one of its members for the 2001 Eco-Challenge in New Zealand. Benincasa and Team Earthlink finished in fourth place.

Mary Beth Evans (born March 7, 1961) is an American television actress, known for her role as Kayla Brady on the NBC daytime soap Days of Our Lives, and her role as Sierra Estaban on the CBS daytime soap As the World Turns. Career Evans is most famous for portraying Kayla Brady on the NBC soap opera Days of Our Lives from 1986 to 1992, 2006 to 2009, and 2010 to present. In the 1980s, her character became half of the supercouple Steve and Kayla, with Steve "Patch" Johnson played by Stephen Nichols. In regard to Steve and Kayla’s first wedding, which was one of the biggest in “Days’” history, Evans remarked, “I think it was number one? And that wedding was just so extravagant. It was outside, which was a big deal on a daytime show. It was beautiful.” Evans left the show in 1992 but returned (with Nichols) on June 12, 2006 after a fourteen-year absence. In 2009, Evans and Nichols were written off Days of Our Lives. Evans returned in 2010 and has appeared on a recurring basis every year since. In 2015, she was placed back on contract with the series.

Döme Sztójay (, 5 January 1883 – 20 October 1955) was a Hungarian painter, graphic artist and sculptor. Döme Sztójay was born on 5 January 1883 in Budapest, in the Kingdom of Hungary (now in Hungary). He was the son of sculptor László Sztójay and his wife Zsuzsanna Polgár. He attended the Academy of Fine Arts in Budapest between 1903 and 1907, studying under János Kemény and Mihály Munkácsy. He also took classes at the Académie Julian in Paris from 1907 to 1909. After returning to Hungary, Sztójay worked as a painter and graphic artist. In 1914 he established his own studio in Budapest and became associated with the Blaha Lujza Circle of artists. He participated in numerous exhibitions throughout Hungary and Europe, including the 1922 Venice Biennale. He also taught at the Academy of Fine Arts between 1934 and 1945. Sztójay died on 20 October 1955 in Budapest.

Madureira Esporte Clube, usually abbreviated to Madureira, is a Brazilian football team based in the city of Rio de Janeiro, in the neighbourhood of Madureira. The team compete in Campeonato Carioca, the top tier of the Rio de Janeiro state football league. History Madureira was founded on August 8, 1914 as Fidalgo Madureira Atlético Clube. The businessmen Elísio Alves Ferreira, Manoel Lopes da Silva, Manuel Augusto Maia and Joaquim Braia, among others, in 1932, wanted to found a strong club in Madureira neighborhood. They contacted Uassir do Amaral, president of Fidalgo Madureira Atlético Clube at that time. In the same year, they tried to fuse Fidalgo and Magno Futebol Clube, but the partners of Fidalgo did not approve this. After several assemblies, on February 16, 1933, the team was named Madureira Atlético Clube, and the foundation date was determined to be August 8, 1914 (the same foundation date of Fidalgo Madureira Atlético Clube).

Makoto Douglas Sakamoto (born April 8, 1947) is a retired Japanese-born American artistic gymnast and coach. He competed at the 1964 and 1972 Summer Olympics with the best individual result of 17th place on parallel bars in 1972. Domestically he won the AAU titles in the all-around and horizontal bar in 1963, in the all-around in 1964, and in all seven events in 1965. Sakamoto was born in 1947 in Shinjuku, Tokyo, Japan, and in 1955 his family moved to California, U.S. After receiving B.A. and M.A. degrees in coaching he worked as assistant coach at UCLA in 1976–1984. His trainees included Peter Vidmar and Tim Daggett. After that he worked for the New South Wales Gymnastics Association in Sydney, Australia in 1984–1987, and between 1987 and 2000 he was head coach at Brigham Young University. Sakamoto was assistant coach for the American teams that competed at the 1984 Summer Olympics and 1981 and 1983 world championships. He is married to Masako Yoshisa and has two children. In 1986 he was inducted into the U.S. Gymnastics Hall of Fame.

Plutarch (; fl. 4th century BC) was a Greek biographer and essayist, known primarily for his Parallel Lives and Moralia. Plutarch was born in the town of Chaeronea in Boeotia, about 80 km west of Athens. He was the son of a prominent family, the members of which are known for their political and military careers. The name of Plutarch's father has not been preserved, but it is generally believed that he was a member of the Plutarch family, which had a long history in the region. Little is known of Plutarch's life until he began writing biographies around 40 BC. At that time, Plutarch was engaged in public affairs and apparently enjoyed the patronage of the powerful politicians of the day. He is believed to have lived in Athens until his death, although there is evidence that he may have spent time in other parts of Greece. Plutarch's surviving works are a collection of biographies and essays, most of which are concerned with morality, philosophy, history and politology. Some of his works are also devoted to literary criticism.

In computing, a hard link is a link between files that is stored on a single storage device or volume. It is also called a symbolic link, because the file references a symbol instead of the filename itself. A hard link is created when two files are attached to each other with a special file system attribute called hard link count. The first file has a hard link count of 1, and the second file has a hard link count of 2. When the files are accessed, their data is combined into a single stream and processed as if it were one file. The hard link count is not visible to users or programs. The feature was introduced in Unix-like operating systems in the 1980s as a way to share files between multiple users without having to copy the files. It became more common with the rise of peer-to-peer networking in the late 1990s and early 2000s. Hard links are now used mainly for storage efficiency and to reduce disk I/O.

Carl Theodor Körner (23 September 1791 – 26 August 1813) was a German poet and soldier. After some time in Vienna, where he wrote some light comedies and other works for the Burgtheater, he became a soldier and joined the Lützow Free Corps in the German uprising against Napoleon. During these times, he displayed personal courage in many fights, and encouraged his comrades by fiery patriotic lyrics he composed, among these being the "Schwertlied" (Sword Song), composed during a lull in fighting only a few hours before his death, and "Lützows wilde Jagd" (Lützow's Wild Chase, or Hunt), each set to music by both Carl Maria von Weber and Franz Schubert. He was often called the "German Tyrtaeus." Early life He was born at Dresden, capital of the Saxon electorate, the son of the consistorial councillor Christian Gottfried Körner and his wife Minna Stock Körner. He was raised by his parents and by his aunt, the artist Dora Stock, who lived in the home. He attended the Kreuzschule.

Joshua Furst (born March 19, 1971) is an American fiction writer. Born in Boulder, Colorado, he lived for much of his early life in rural Wisconsin. He studied as an undergraduate at New York University's Tisch School of the Arts, receiving a BFA in Dramatic Writing in 1993 and did graduate work at The University of Iowa Writers' Workshop, from which he received an MFA with Honors in 2001. Joshua Furst's novel The Sabotage Café was named to the 2007 year-end best-of lists of the Chicago Tribune, the Rocky Mountain News and the Philadelphia City Paper, as well as being awarded the 2008 Grub Street Fiction Prize. He is also the author of the critically acclaimed book of stories, Short People. A frequent contributor to The Jewish Daily Forward, he has also been published in The Chicago Tribune, Conjunctions, PEN America, Five Chapters and The New York Tyrant among many other journals and periodicals and been given citations for notable achievement by The Best American Short Stories and The O’Henry Awards. He is a founding member of the literary collective Krïstïanïa.

Scotia is a Latin placename derived from the Gaelic Scotus or Scott, meaning "son of Scot," one of the clans of the Picts. The name first appears in written record as Scythia Minor in the 1st century AD. It later became Scotia and finally Scotland. The name derives from the Pictish word for "land of the Scotti", although no association with the people or their language is proven. The first recorded reference to Scotia is in the 1st century AD, when it was used to refer to an area covering modern-day Scotland and northern England. At this time, Scotia was part of the Roman province of Britannia. Over the next few centuries, Scotia became a popular name forScotland, and the region came to be known as Scotia Magna. In Medieval times, Scotia was divided into two provinces: Pictavia in the north and Caledonia in the south. In 843, a Viking army led by Ivar the Boneless invaded and occupied most of Scotland. For over a century, Scotia was ruled by the Vikings, who changed its name to Northumbria. In 947, King Athelstan defeated Ivar at the Battle of Brunanburh and reunified most of Scotland under English rule. In 1034, Malcolm II became King of Scots and united most of Scotland under his rule. Malcolm's son David I became King of Scots in 1124 and began to expand his kingdom southward into England. Heungseon Daewongun (흥선대원군, 興宣大院君, 21 December 1820 – 10 July 1897) was the fourth king of the Joseon Dynasty in Korea. He was also the final ruler of the Daewongun period of Korean history, and one of the most powerful and influential monarchs in Korean history. Heungseon Daewongun was born on 21 December 1820 in Heungseon Hall, in what is now Gyeonggi Province. He was the eldest son of King Daewongun and Queen Min. After his father's death in 1851, he became the crown prince and heir apparent to the throne. When his father's brother, Crown Prince Ui, rebelled against the new king, King Gojong, Heungseon Daewongun assisted his father in putting down the rebellion. In 1875, King Gojong proclaimed himself emperor of a newly founded Joseon Dynasty, which made Heungseon Daewongun the last sovereign monarch of Korea. As a result, Heungseon Daewongun came to be seen as one of Korea's most powerful and influential monarchs. He exercised much control over government affairs and had a major impact on Korean culture. Heungseon Daewongun died on 10 July 1897 at the age of 78 after more than 50 years on the throne. He was buried at Seodaemun Royal Mausoleum.

The Academy Historic District is a historic district in the center of Wilbraham, Massachusetts. Its encompass the historic center of Wilbraham, as well as the historic central portion of the campus of the Wilbraham & Monson Academy. It includes properties on Mountain Road (roughly the southern boundary of the district), Main Street, and Faculty Street. Wesleyan Academy was founded in 1817 and moved to Wilbraham in 1824; its oldest buildings date to 1825. It merged with Monson Academy in the 20th century to form the present school that occupies the academic premises. The academy was a major center of Methodist teaching in New England, and was a prominent factor in the town's growth. The main historic building of the Academy is called the Old Academy, and is a large brick Federalist building designed by Enoch Mudge in 1825. It is a two-story building with a slate roof and a white clapboard belltower. Next to it is Fisk Hall, an 1851 two story building made of brick with sandstone trim; it is topped by a cupola. Binney Hall, built in 1854, is similarly a two-story brick building. The Smith Hall Gymnasium was built in 1896, and has Richardsonian Romanesque details and a hipped slate roof. The Alumni Memorial Chapel stands next to the Gymnasium; it was built in 1867 of red sandstone.

Sir David Okete Vuvuiri Vunagi, (born October 31, 1968, in Nairobi, Kenya) is a Kenyan lawyer who is the Special Advisor to the President of Kenya on Constitutional Affairs. Vuvuiri Vunagi was born in Nairobi, Kenya on October 31, 1968. He completed his secondary education at Saint Patrick's College in Nairobi before studying law at the University of Edinburgh, where he obtained his LLB degree in 1992. He then returned to Kenya and worked as a lawyer for a number of years. In 2002, Vuvuiri Vunagi was appointed as a Judge of the High Court of Kenya. He served in this position until 2007, when he was appointed as the Attorney General of Kenya. In this capacity, he led the Kenyan government's legal team during the country's disputed presidential election that year. In 2009, Vuvuiri Vunagi was appointed as Special Advisor to the President of Kenya on Constitutional Affairs. In this capacity, he provides advice to President Mwai Kibaki on matters relating to constitutional reform and constitutional affairs. Vuvuiri Vunagi has also served as Chairman of the Board of Governors for the African Leadership Institute (ALI), a position he has held since its inception in 2004. Virgo is the eponymous debut studio album by American house music duo Virgo Four, released in 1989 on Radical Records in the United Kingdom. It compiles two 12" EPs released in the United States on Trax Records, Do You Know Who You Are? by Virgo Four and Ride by M.E.. Both were pseudonyms of Eric Lewis and Merwyn Sanders, two art students and childhood friends from Chicago. The album was first reissued in 2010 on Rush Hour Recordings. While rooted in the Chicago house style, Virgo features a distinctive sound that is dreamier and more introspective than that of the duo's contemporaries, also incorporating elements of acid house and deep house. Although Lewis and Sanders made no effort to promote the album, its idiosyncratic music and the mystery surrounding the band's identity turned it into an underground cult classic over the years. Although it remains largely unknown, Virgo is now recognized as an essential release among house enthusiasts, and is considered by some as the greatest album of its genre.

Acne conglobata is a highly inflammatory disease presenting with comedones, nodules, abscesses, and draining sinus tracts. This condition generally begins between the ages of 18 and 30. It usually persists for a very long time, and often until the patient is around 40 years old. Although it often occurs where there is already an active acne problem, it can also happen to people whose acne has subsided. Although the cause of this type of acne is unknown, it is associated with testosterone and thus appears mainly in males. It can be caused by anabolic steroid abuse and sometimes appears in males after stopping testosterone therapy. It can also happen to someone who has a tumor that is releasing large amounts of androgens, or to people in remission from diseases, such as leukemia. In certain persons, the condition may be triggered by exposure to aromatic hydrocarbons or ingestion of halogens.

John Whittemore (November 20, 1899 – April 26, 1984) was an American film and television actor. He appeared in over 140 films and television programs between 1939 and 1984. Whittemore was born in New York City, the son of Fannie (née McCracken) and John Whittemore, a theatrical producer. After attending the Lawrenceville School in Lawrenceville, New Jersey, he studied at the American Academy of Dramatic Arts in New York City. He made his Broadway debut in 1924 in a production of "The Merry Widow". Whittemore began his film career appearing in supporting roles in a number of movies, including "The General Died at Dawn" (1936), "The Life of Emile Zola" (1937), "Rebecca" (1940), and "The Unsuspected" (1941). He had a leading role in the 1941 film noir crime drama "Murder, My Sweet". In the early 1950s, Whittemore began appearing on television series such as "Peyton Place", "The Phil Silvers Show", "The Defenders", and "Gunsmoke". He also appeared in several movies during this time, including "House of Bamboo" (1955), "The Girl Who Knew Too Much" (1956), and "Written on the Wind" (1957). Payitaht: Abdülhamid (lit. "The Capital: Abdul Hamid"), also known as Istanbul, is the largest city in Turkey and the capital of the country. It is located on the European side of Istanbul Bay, on the Bosphorus Strait. The population of Istanbul was 10,711,000 in 2009. Istanbul was founded by the Hittites in the late Bronze Age as an imperial capital. After becoming the capital of the Ottoman Empire in 1453, Istanbul became one of the largest and most cosmopolitan cities in Europe. Its natural harbor made it a major commercial center and a center of trade and culture. Istanbul was also a major center for education, with many institutions of higher learning existing during its Ottoman period. The city played a significant role in international relations, serving as the headquarters of two major Muslim world conferences (the first in 1921 and the second in 1955). Istanbul has been heavily damaged by several earthquakes over the past few decades, most notably in 1999, which resulted in extensive damage to the city's historic districts. However, recent investments have helped to restore much of the city's historical fabric and make it one of Europe's most popular tourist destinations. In 2004, Istanbul was named European Capital of Culture.

Walter Kimberley (28 September 1884 – 22 October 1960) was a South African philosopher, psychologist and social reformer. Walter Kimberley was born in the town of Kimberley, in the Northern Cape Province of South Africa on 28 September 1884. He was the son of a Methodist minister, and he attended the local primary school before studying at the University of Cape Town. He worked as a teacher before becoming involved in social reform. Kimberley became active in the struggle against discrimination against black Africans, and he helped to establish the South African Native National Congress (SANNC) in 1912. He also became involved in the campaign to end white domination of South Africa, and he helped to found the African National Congress (ANC) in 1912. Kimberley became a professor at the University of Cape Town in 1924, and he also served as president of the South African Philosophical Society from 1936 to 1938. He retired from his professorship in 1948, but he continued to work on social issues until his death on 22 October 1960. Walter Kimberley is remembered as one of the leading figures in South African social reform, and he is considered one of the founders of the ANC.

Magdalena of Lippe (25 February 1552, Detmold – 11 July 1606, Detmold) was a German Protestant reformer and the founder of the Magdalene sisters, who were among the most influential female religious orders in the Holy Roman Empire. Magdalena was born in 1552 in Detmold, in the Electorate of Brandenburg. She was the daughter of Nicholas of Lippe-Biesterfeld, a nobleman and member of the Estates of Brandenburg, and his second wife, Anna of Pomerania. At an early age, Magdalena showed a strong inclination towards religious life. In 1569, she entered the Convent of St. Augustine at Quedlinburg in Saxony-Anhalt, where she took the religious name "Magdalena." She was soon recognized as a talented reformer and began to preach reformist doctrines within the convent. In 1582, Magdalena left Quedlinburg and moved to Magdeburg, where she established her own convent. She soon attracted a large following among the Protestant population of Magdeburg, and her convent became one of the most influential Protestant institutions in Germany. In 1593, Magdalena moved to nearby Detmold, where she founded her own convent. Her convent became one of the largest and most influential Protestant institutions in northern Germany. Magdalena also played an important role in spreading Protestantism in neighboring countries, particularly Denmark and Sweden. Magdal

In statistics, correlation or dependence is a statistical measure of the degree to which two variables are associated or related. It is obtained by calculating the correlation coefficient between two variables. The Pearson product–moment correlation coefficient is the most commonly used correlation coefficient. It measures the linear association between two variables and has a value between −1 and 1. A positive correlation indicates that as one variable increases, the other variable tends to increase as well, while a negative correlation indicates that as one variable increases, the other variable tends to decrease. Correlation can be used to identify relationships between variables that might not be apparent when looking at individual values. For example, if you are studying the effects of different types of diets on weight gain, it can be helpful to study the correlations between weight and diet type (e.g., high-fat, low-fat, moderate-fat) in order to identify which types of diets are most closely associated with weight gain.

Neil Eckersley (born 5 April 1964) is an English former professional footballer who played as a midfielder. He is the current manager of League One club Burton Albion. Eckersley started his career at Tottenham Hotspur, and made over 300 appearances for the club in all competitions, winning two FA Cups and two League Championships. He then spent time with Sheffield United, Middlesbrough, Derby County, West Ham United and Hull City, before retiring from playing in 2004. Eckersley then took up managerial positions with Sheffield United and Charlton Athletic, before joining Burton Albion in January 2018. Eckersley was born in North London, and began playing football with local side North Woolwich Arsenal. He signed for Tottenham Hotspur as an apprentice in 1981 and made his professional debut in November 1984. He went on to make over 300 appearances for the club, winning two FA Cups and two League Championships. He also scored 10 goals in all competitions. Eckersley left Tottenham Hotspur in 2004 after spending time with Sheffield United, Middlesbrough, Derby County, West Ham United and Hull City. Eckersley first took managerial positions with Sheffield United and Charlton Athletic before joining Burton Albion in January 2018. He left Burton Albion in May 2018 after five months in charge

The University Phantom of Bochum, shortened to Uni-Phantom, is a phantom which has been reported at the University of Bochum in Bochum, Germany. The Uni-Phantom is said to haunt the Schlossgarten, a large park on the university's campus. The phantom is said to be a white female wearing a long dress and veil, and is often seen walking alone or in pairs. Witnesses say that the phantom often makes strange noises and sometimes appears to chase or attack people. There have been numerous reports of the Uni-Phantom since it first appeared in the early 1990s. However, no one has been able to conclusively identify the phantom or determine its motive for haunting the Schlossgarten. Some speculate that the Uni-Phantom is a spirit of regret or sadness, while others believe that it is a manifestation of someone's grief or anger over the university's past. Whatever the case may be, the Uni-Phantom has continued to haunt the Schlossgarten for over two decades and has yet to be deterred from its haunting activities.

Ma'arrat Misrin (, also spelled Ma'arrat Masrin) is a city in southwestern Syria, administratively part of the Rif Dimashq Governorate. With a population of about 160,000 people, it is the largest city in the governorate. Ma'arrat Misrin is located on the eastern bank of the River Barada, south of Damascus and north of the provincial capital Rif Dimashq. The city has a hot desert climate (Köppen "BWh"), with very hot summers and mild winters. Rainfall is very rare. The city has been settled since ancient times. Inscriptions from the Iron Age show that it was known as "Sarrae Marratum" and "Ain Sarra". In Roman times, it was known as "Marratum" or "Marratona". The latter name may have been derived from an Aramaic word meaning "market place". In the mid-19th century, a railroad was built through Ma'arrat Misrin linking Damascus to Homs, making it an important transportation hub. The city's prosperity was greatly enhanced by the oil boom of the 1970s. However, during the Syrian Civil War, Ma'arrat Misrin became one of the most heavily bombed cities in Syria. On 25 August 2013, a car bomb exploded near Ma'arrat Misrin's main market district, killing at least 23 people and injuring over 100 others. The Syrian Arab Army regained

Eddy Ray Davis (September 26, 1940 – April 7, 2020) was an American musician and bandleader of trad jazz, who was internationally known mainly through the decades of collaboration with the clarinetist and filmmaker Woody Allen. Life and work Davis started playing banjo during his senior year in high school to play Dixieland with a college band called The Salty Dogs. The Purdue-based group played across the Midwestern United States and had pre-appearances of greats like The Four Freshmen and The Kingston Trio. He moved to Purdue for a year, then to Chicago. There, he became an integral part of the jazz scene at venues such as the "Gaslight Club" and Bourbon Street and often worked for variety or comedy acts, among others. with actor David Huddleston. He also appeared on a Dixieland revue in Disneyland and served as musical director for a tour resumption of the musical Whoopee! In 1966, he recorded his debut album "Live! At the Old Town Gate", with a group that from then on operated as "Eddy Davis Dixie Jazzmen". The next albums under the Davis name included "Whiz Bang" (1973), a satirical production with flute and tuba and "Plays and Sings Just For Fun" (1974, mainly devoted to Jelly Roll Morton).

Emil Werstler is an American guitarist and musician based in Nashville, Tennessee who is perhaps best known for his work in metal and gypsy jazz. In 2004, Werstler became lead guitarist for the metal band Dååth, whose second album The Hinderers peaked at No. 49 on the Top Heatseekers chart in 2007. In 2009 Dååth released The Concealers on Roadrunner which reached No. 35 on Top Heatseekers and was placed as No. 3 on a list of the "top twenty metal albums of 2009" by Metal Sucks. In 2010 Werstler released the instrumental metal album Avalanche of Worms as a collaboration with Eyal Levi with the album receiving a largely positive response for its musicianship and experimental nature. By 2011 Werstler had been confirmed as the new lead guitarist for the metal band Chimaira. With Werstler as a co-writer, Chimaira's final album Crown of Phantoms was released in 2013, reaching No. 52 on the Billboard 200 chart. Werstler announced his departure from Chimaira in late 2014, with the rest of the band dissolving shortly afterwards.

Nikolay Vladimirovich Davydenko ( ; born 2 October 1984) is a Russian professional tennis player. He has won two Grand Slam singles titles, one at the 2007 French Open and one at the 2012 Australian Open. Davydenko reached his highest ATP ranking of World No. 3 in February 2013. He has been coached by his father, Nikolay Davydenko Sr., since he was ten years old. Davydenko has also played for Russia in Davis Cup, where he has a record of 46–26 in singles and 19–15 in doubles. He made his ATP World Tour debut at the 2000 Vienna Open, and won his first ATP title at the 2004 Istanbul Cup. He reached his career-high singles ranking of World No. 3 in February 2013. Davydenko was born on 2 October 1984 in Rostov-on-Don, Russia. He is the son of Nikolay Davydenko Sr., a former Soviet tennis player who won two Grand Slam singles titles (the 1982 Australian Open and the 1983 French Open). Nikolay Davydenko Jr.'s godfather is former world number one player Boris Becker. Davydenko attended Rostov State University and played collegiate tennis for Southern Methodist University (SMU) in Dallas, Texas from 2002 to 2004. He turned professional in 2004. Davydenko's breakthrough year came in 2005, when he reached his first ATP final at the Kremlin Cup, losing to Roger Federer in three sets. The following year, he reached the semifinals

Albert Bedouce (8 January 1869, Toulouse – 24 November 1951, Paris) was a French botanist and mycologist. Albert Bedouce was born in Toulouse, France on January 8th, 1869. He studied at the University of Toulouse and then at the University of Cambridge, where he received his doctorate in botany in 1896. He returned to France and worked as a professor of botany at the University of Toulouse from 1898 until his retirement in 1951. Bedouce was a member of the French Academy of Sciences and the Royal Society of London. He died in Paris on November 24th, 1951. Albert Bedouce was a leading figure in French botanical research during the first half of the 20th century. His work focused on the classification and identification of plants, as well as their ecology. He is especially well known for his work on Orchidaceae, which he studied extensively. Bedouce is also credited with introducing new methods of plant taxonomy into French botanical research.

Vann Nath (; 1946 – 5 September 2009) was a Burmese journalist and author. Born in 1946 in the small town of Kyauktada in Shan State, Vann Nath started his journalistic career at the age of 20, working for the state-owned newspaper "Thein Peik". He later moved to Rangoon where he worked for various newspapers and magazines. He also served as the deputy editor-in-chief of "The Irrawaddy", Myanmar's most prestigious newspaper. In 1992, Nath published his first book, "Khaing Zeya Min Zaw" (translated as "The Unforgiving Mountain"), which tells the story of a group of Burmese Buddhist monks who rebel against the government in the 1960s. The book won him the 1997 National Literature Award. Nath's second book, "Sittwe: The City of Ghosts" (1998), is a historical novel about the city of Sittwe during World War II. Nath was also a critic, and wrote several articles on Burmese literature and culture for The Irrawaddy. He died on 5 September 2009 after a long illness.

FIFA Football 2005, also known as FIFA Soccer 2005 in North America or simply FIFA 2005, is a football simulation video game released in 2004. It was developed by EA Canada and published by Electronic Arts. It was released for the PlayStation, PlayStation 2, Microsoft Windows, Xbox, PlayStation Portable (as simply FIFA Soccer), GameCube, mobile phone, Gizmondo, N-Gage and the Game Boy Advance. The tagline for the game was: "A great player needs a great first touch". FIFA 2005 is the twelfth game in the FIFA series, the ninth in 3D and the final game in the series for the PlayStation. FIFA Football 2005 marks the first time to include the seventh-generation handheld game consoles. The Japanese version of the game went by the name of FIFA Total Football 2 and was released on 9 December 2004. FIFA Football 2005 is the last licensed game to be released for the PlayStation in North America. Gameplay Improving the career mode, the game was extensively advertised and released much sooner than the usual late October dates to avoid proximity with the release of Pro Evolution Soccer 4 and the EA Big release FIFA Street.

Ewa Villages is a census-designated place (CDP) in Honolulu County, Hawaii, United States. The population was 11,564 at the 2010 census. The Ewa Villages are located on the eastern side of Oahu in the Makiki district. They are bounded by Kamehameha Avenue to the north, Paele Street to the east, Lunalilo Boulevard to the south, and Kalanianaole Highway to the west. The CDP includes Ewa Beach and Waikiki Beach. The Ewa Villages are a largely residential community that was developed in the late 1960s and early 1970s as a response to growing demand for housing on Oahu. The first subdivisions were built in Ewa Beach in 1967, and Waikiki Beach followed in 1971. The CDP is home to a number of large shopping centers, including Makiki Shopping Center and Aloha Tower Marketplace. There is also a large concentration of schools and churches in the CDP. The Ewa Villages are served by numerous bus lines, including the No. 7 and No. 98 routes that run along Kamehameha Avenue and Lunalilo Boulevard, respectively. There is also a bike path that runs through the center of the CDP. The Ewa Villages are part of the Honolulu County Council District I, which is represented by Gregg Taketa.

Pollock–Capps House is located on 1320 Penn Street in Fort Worth, Texas, next door to the Eddleman-McFarland House. The Queen Anne Victorian style home, located atop a bluff overlooking the Trinity River, was possibly designed by Howard Messer, architect of the Eddleman-McFarland House, and was named after Joseph Robert Pollock, a physician who moved to Fort Worth in 1887. Pollack and his wife Phoebe sold the house to William and Sallie Capps in 1910. William Capps was a distinguished lawyer while his wife Sallie was president of the Fort Worth Kindergarten Association and a Regent at the College of Industrial Arts in Denton. Historic Fort Worth Inc. purchased the house in 1971. Three years later the organization sold the house to Architect Robert W. Chambers. The house is built of red brick and limestone, and has a slate roof. The house features an octagonal tower on its northeast corner.

Blagaj is a village in the south-eastern part of the Republic of Macedonia. It is located in the Municipality of Zajas, close to the Bulgarian border. As of 2002, the village had a population of 283 people. Blagaj is situated in the southeastern part of the Republic of Macedonia, in the Municipality of Zajas. It is located close to the Bulgarian border and has a population of 283 people as of 2002. The village has an old name, Kale, which means "village" in the Macedonian language. Blagaj was first mentioned in written sources in 1598 and it was mentioned as a village belonging to the Monastery of Sveti Nikola in 1601. The main economic activity in Blagaj is agriculture. There is also a small cottage industry producing wood products, such as furniture and barrels. There is also a small grocery and bakery store. The village has two schools - one for primary students and one for students from lower secondary school onwards. There is also a clinic and a library.

James Gay-Rees is a British film producer. He has produced or co-produced over thirty films, including the Academy Award-nominated drama The Theory of Everything. He has also produced television series such as The Night Manager and Peaky Blinders. Born in Middlesbrough, North Yorkshire, England, Gay-Rees began his career as a production assistant on the documentary film Forgiveness which was directed by Peter Kosminsky. After completing his apprenticeship at the British Film Institute, Gay-Rees began his own production company, Out of the Blue Productions, in 1997. He has since produced or co-produced over thirty films, including the Academy Award-nominated drama The Theory of Everything. His other films include the biographical drama Steve Jobs, the crime thriller A Most Violent Year, and the British war film Dunkirk. Gay-Rees has also produced television series such as The Night Manager and Peaky Blinders. In November 2017, he was appointed Vice-Chairman of Film4, the UK's leading film production company.

Kim Ha-na (Hangul: 김하나; or 김향나; born January 9, 1987) is a South Korean singer, actress and model. She is best known as a member of the South Korean girl group Girls' Generation. Kim Ha-na was born in Seoul, South Korea on January 9, 1987. She has a younger sister and an older brother. When she was young, her family moved to the United States for two years. After returning to Korea, Kim began her modeling career at the age of 15. In 2006, she made her acting debut in the television series Dream High. The following year, she starred in the film adaptation of the same series. In 2009, Kim joined the girl group Girls' Generation (then known as SNSD), which consisted of herself, Yuri, Sooyoung, Jessica, and Sunny. The group achieved worldwide success with their debut album The Boys (2011), which spawned the number-one singles "Gee" and "The Boys". Girls' Generation released their second album Miss Universe (2013), which peaked at number two on the Billboard 200 chart. Their third album The Red Light (2015) also reached number two on the Billboard 200 chart and spawned the singles "Bad Boy" and "Dancing on My Own".

Daniel Kaufmann is the president emeritus of the Natural Resource Governance Institute (NRGI), which resulted from the merger of the Revenue Watch Institute – Natural Resource Charter. He is also a nonresident senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, where he was previously a senior fellow, and until July 2019 served in the international board of the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative and in a number of advisory boards on governance, anti-corruption and natural resources and has also been in high-level expert commissions such as at the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, the Inter-American Development Bank and the Mo Ibrahim Foundation. Prior to that, he was a director at the World Bank Institute, leading work on governance and anti-corruption. He was also a senior manager and lead economist at the World Bank, writing and working on many countries around the world, and was a visiting scholar at Harvard University. He has also served in other boards and councils in the past, including at the World Economic Forum. Early life Kaufmann was born and grew up in Santiago, Chile, the son of Jewish immigrants that escaped Germany in 1939. He later received a B.A. in economics and statistics at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem and subsequently an M.A. and Ph.D. in economics at Harvard.

Anthony George Symonds (born 15 February 1962) is an English former football player and manager. A midfielder, he played for Liverpool, Portsmouth, Watford, Bristol City and Reading in the Football League. He also played for Scottish club Rangers. Symonds was capped 31 times by England, scoring once. He captained England at Euro 96. After leaving managerial duties with Reading in 2006, Symonds became a football agent. In 2011, he was appointed as the new head coach of South African side Mamelodi Sundowns. In 2011, he was appointed as the new head coach of South African side Mamelodi Sundowns. Tony Symonds was born on 15 February 1962 in Liverpool. He started his career playing for local amateur side Burscough Victoria before signing for Liverpool in 1981 where he made his professional debut against Everton in March 1982. He went on to make 337 appearances for Liverpool scoring 59 goals before joining Portsmouth in August 1990 for £1 million. He spent two seasons at Portsmouth before joining Watford in July 1992 for £1 million. He would stay with Watford for six seasons making 123 appearances and scoring 18 goals before moving to Bristol City in May 1997 for £750,000.

Medieval stone moulds are well represented in museums, however very little is known about their origins and use. Stone moulds are artefacts made from stone, typically used in the production of figurines, reliefs and other sculptures. They are one of the oldest forms of sculptural decoration, dating back to the prehistoric period. They were generally used in the eastern Mediterranean and Europe until the early modern period, when they were replaced by metal Casting. The most common type of stone mould is the 'slab mold', which is a rectangular block with a series of smooth indentations on one or both sides. This type was used to produce reliefs, and was especially popular in Ancient Greece. The 'pillar mold' is similar to the slab mold, but has smaller indentations on either side of the block. It was used to produce statuary, and was particularly popular in Ancient Rome. The 'cusp mold' is a slender block with triangular indentations on one or both sides. It was used to produce figurines and other small sculptures, and was particularly popular in Medieval Europe.

The Blues Armory is a large brick warehouse located in the Midtown district of Memphis, Tennessee, United States. It is a popular tourist destination for people interested in blues music and history. The building was constructed in 1901 and originally served as a warehouse for the Memphis Cotton Gin Company. It was later used as a music venue and recording studio. In the early 1960s, it was converted into a blues club. Today, it is used for concerts, art exhibits, and other events. The Blues Armory is one of the oldest surviving structures in Memphis and is a popular tourist destination for people interested in blues music and history. "Creator" is the debut single by American rock band Muse. It was first released on 7 July 1999 by record label EMI. The song was written by Matt Bellamy, Dominic Howard, and Chris Wolstenholme, and produced by Muse's former producer, Paul E. Smith. The song is about the protagonist's struggles with addiction, and its lyrics are about self-destruction and the search for salvation. Upon its release, "Creator" became a massive hit in the United Kingdom, where it reached number one on the UK Singles Chart and stayed there for six consecutive weeks. In the United States, the song peaked at number two on the Billboard Hot 100 chart and was certified platinum by the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA). It also reached number one in Ireland, New Zealand, Australia, Denmark, Sweden and Norway. On 9 November 2009, Muse played "Creator" in its entirety during their A Bigger Bang Tour at London's O2 Arena. Matt Bellamy has stated that "Creator" is about his own experiences with addiction: "I think it's about somebody who is trying to escape from themselves – whether that be through drugs or alcohol or anything else. It's a really honest song." After its release, "Creator" received generally positive reviews from music critics. Sinners Never Sleep is the third studio album by American heavy metal band Slipknot. It was released on October 5, 2009, by Roadrunner Records. Recording sessions for the album took place in 2008 at various studios across the United States with producer Rick Rubin. The album's lyrical themes revolve around personal struggles and depression, as well as existential issues. It has been described as a departure from Slipknot's previous work, being more melodic and introspective. Critical response to the album was generally positive, with most reviewers praising its more polished sound and emotional depth. It debuted at number four on the US Billboard 200 chart, selling over 53,000 copies in its first week. Following the release of their second studio album, Iowa (2005), Slipknot parted ways with longtime producer Ross Robinson and replaced him with Rick Rubin. Rubin helped the band to develop a more polished and melodic sound on their third album Sinners Never Sleep. Lyrically, the album revolves around personal struggles and depression, as well as existential issues. The band has stated that it was a departure from their previous work, being more introspective and melodic. Louis Jordan , 37 , had been missing at sea for more than two months before he was picked up off the North Carolina coast by a ship on Thursday . Jordan had told his family in January that he was ` going into the open water ' to go fishing but the boat capsized and the mast broke . He was found sitting on the capsized hull of his sailboat and plucked from the sea by a helicopter . Transitional bilingualism is the shift from being bilingual, knowing two different languages, to only speaking one leading language. This usually happens over a period of time and can be seen within a few generations. There are families with immigrant grandparents who speak primarily their native language and some of the new country's language. Their children then speak both languages, but the grandchildren only speak the dominant or preferred language of the new location. The United States provides many examples of this phenomenon. For example, a woman born and raised in Mexico moved to the United States and learned a bit of English and spoke a great deal of Spanish as well. Her daughter, born and reared in the U.S. was equally fluent in both Spanish and English (bilingual). The grandchild of the Mexican immigrant, who was born and has been reared in the U.S., speaks only English. This process is due to the pressure that is put on the individuals by the society of the new environment. They cannot survive well without the primary language spoken in their new home and eventually, since fewer and fewer people speak the "old" native language, it is not used as often, as it is not a necessity, and is lost.

A.W. Dharmapala was a pioneering broadcaster and journalist in India. Dharmapala was the founder-director of the All India Radio, a position he held from its inception in 1938 until his death in 1974. Dharmapala was born on November 10, 1897 in a small village near Vizianagaram in the Andhra Pradesh region of south-east India. He attended school at Vizianagaram and then studied law at the Madras University. In 1923, he married Chandrika Parvathi and they had two children. Dharmapala began his career as a lawyer but soon became involved in journalism. In 1938, he founded the All India Radio (AIR), which was India's first radio broadcaster. He was its director until his death in 1974. During his tenure at AIR, Dharmapala helped to shape the broadcaster into an important cultural institution and helped to promote Indian culture overseas. He also played a role in encouraging Indian artists to move to Europe and South America and helped to promote Indian cinema abroad. Dharmapala was a prolific writer and journalist. He wrote both fiction and non-fiction books and articles on a variety of subjects. His books include The Discovery of India (1946), The Story of My Life (1956), India Today (1963), and A Vision of India (1970). His articles have been published in newspapers and magazines around the world including the New York Times, the Guardian, and the Financial Times. Dharmapala was honoured

A cultural invention is any innovation developed by people. Cultural inventions include sets of behaviour adopted by groups of people. They are perpetuated by being passed on to others within the group or outside it. They are also passed on to future groups and generations. Sources of cultural invention can either come from outside a specific group or from within that group. Allan Hanson, a postmodern anthropologist, believed that the analytical purpose of studying cultural inventions was not to uncover which portions of a culture's belief systems are invented, but rather to study how cultural inventions become accepted as authentic within groups. This notion has been met with criticism from within the anthropological community as well as from outside sources, and has been referred to as both politically revisionist and anti-native. The fear is that viewing cultural invention as a process which leads to something authentic and widely accepted may undermine indigenous people's traditions in addition to questioning the authority they have over their own culture.

Paul Peos (born 28 January 1968) is a Swiss composer and violinist. Peos was born in Zurich, Switzerland, and studied violin at the University of Music and Performing Arts in Vienna with Pinchas Zukerman. He then went on to study composition with Heinz Holliger and Karlheinz Stockhausen at the Cologne University of Music. Peos has worked as a composer and performer since the early 1990s. He has composed works for solo violin, chamber ensemble, and orchestra, as well as pieces for voice and electronics. His music has been performed worldwide by such ensembles as the Berlin Philharmonic, the Vienna Philharmonic, the London Symphony Orchestra, the Los Angeles Philharmonic, the New York Philharmonic, and the Orchestre de Paris. In February 2012, Peos was appointed Composer-in-Residence at Carnegie Hall in New York City. He has also been a professor of composition at the University of California, Irvine since 2010.

Maria Vasilievna Pavlova (; née Gortynskaia ; December 6 [N.S. December 25], 1881 – July 2, 1956) was a Russian ballerina, considered one of the most renowned and influential dance artists of the early 20th century. She was the first ballet dancer to achieve international acclaim and is widely considered to be one of the greatest dancers of all time. Maria Pavlova was born on December 6, 1881 in Gortynia, in what is now Ukraine. She was the third and youngest child of Vasilii Gortynskaia and her mother died when Maria was very young. She and her two older sisters were raised by their father. At the age of six, Pavlova began taking dancing lessons from Anna Pavlova, their maternal aunt. Pavlova made her professional debut in 1897 as a soloist with the Mariinsky Theatre in Saint Petersburg, Russia. She soon became a leading ballerina with the company and toured throughout Russia and Europe. In 1906, she joined Sergei Diaghilev's Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo where she performed until 1914. During this time she also appeared in several motion pictures. In 1914, Pavlova met and married Conte Sergei Diaghilev, the founder and director of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo. The couple toured throughout Europe and North America before settling in Paris in 1923. In 1926, Pavlova debuted with the New York City Ballet where she remained

Tamasha is the soundtrack album, composed by A. R. Rahman for the 2009 Bengali film of the same name. The album was released on 15 March 2009 by the label T-Series. The soundtrack album has eleven tracks and features performances by various Bengali and Hindi-speaking artists, including A. R. Rahman, Sukhwinder Singh, Arijit Singh, Shreya Ghoshal, Mohit Chauhan, and Shabbir Ahmed. The track "Nirban" features vocals from Pakistani singer Fuzon. Rahman began work on the soundtrack in 2007, shortly after the film's initial conception. He began collaborating with various South Indian and Hindi-speaking artists in 2008, and finished composing the entire album in early 2009. "Tamasha" was released to generally positive reviews from music critics. At Metacritic, which assigns a normalized rating out of 100 to reviews from mainstream critics, the album has received an average score of 73, based on 17 reviews. AllMusic's David Jeffries awarded the album four stars out of five and praised Rahman's incorporation of traditional Indian instruments into his score; he found that the album "stands as one of Rahman's most accomplished works". BBC Music's John Bush awarded the album four out of five stars and wrote that it is "a sumptuous mix of traditional Indian instruments with modern electronic production". The song "Nirban" was particularly well received by music critics; several publications awarded it high marks,

Alfred Coppel, Alfredo Jose de Arana-Marini Coppel (November 9, 1921 – May 30, 2004) was an American author. Born in Oakland, he served as a fighter pilot in the United States Army Air Forces during World War II. After his discharge, he started his career as a writer. He became one of the most prolific pulp magazine authors of the 1950s and 1960s, adopting the pseudonyms Robert Cham Gilman and A.C. Marin and writing for a variety of pulp magazines and later "slick" publishers. Though writing in a variety of genres, including action thrillers, he is known for his science fiction stories which comprise both short stories and novels. Science fiction Coppel's first science fiction story was "Age of Unreason" (1947) in Amazing Stories. Other short stories include "The Dreamer" (1952) about a man called Denby, who wants to be the first to orbit the moon, published in The Magazine of Fantasy and Science Fiction and reprinted in the anthology Best Short Shorts (1958) edited by Eric Berger. His post-holocaust novel Dark December (1960) describes the aftermath of nuclear war.

Sir Arthur Fairfax Charles Coryndon Luxmoore (27 October 1865 – 7 March 1941) was an English landowner and Conservative politician who served as Member of Parliament (MP) for Northampton from 1910 to 1918 and from 1922 to 1924. Luxmoore was the eldest son of Charles Luxmoore, 4th Earl of Westmorland and his wife Lady Maud Cavendish. He was educated at Eton and Trinity College, Cambridge. In 1892 he succeeded his father in the earldom. Luxmoore first entered Parliament as MP for Northampton in 1910, serving until the war broke out in 1914. He served as a Lord Lieutenant of Northamptonshire from 1923 to 1924. He later served as a Deputy Lieutenant of Northamptonshire from 1927 to 1931. Luxmoore married Lady Caroline Evelyn Gordon-Lennox, daughter of the 5th Duke of Richmond and Gordon, in 1895. They had two daughters: Elizabeth (born 1897) and Arabella (born 1901). Luxmoore died in 1941, aged 80 years.

Charles Chellapah (1939 – 14 February 1966) was a Singaporean photojournalist of Indian origin who was killed on-assignment during the Vietnam War. Biography Chellapah (also known as Canagaratnam Chellappah) was born in Indonesia. Unable to find a job as a photojournalist he emigrated to Singapore. Stringing for the now defunct Malay Times Chellapah worked for two years in Jesselton, Borneo before arrived in Saigon on 21 January 1966. Freelancing for the Associated Press, he went to a place American GIs called "Hell's Half Acre". Some 25 miles north of Saigon, it was a densely jungled rubber plantation honey-combed with Viet Cong Tunnels and overrun by snipers. His dramatic close-up images of casualties and combat prompted AP photo editor Horst Faas to warn Chellappah to be more cautious and take fewer chances. On 14 February 1966, Chellapah was killed in another landmine blast while attempting to rescue soldiers hurt from a mine blast.

Iakov Moiseyevich Shafir (1887-1938) headed a special unit of the NKVD, the People's Commissariat for Internal Affairs, during the 1930s. He was a deputy commissar of Internal Affairs, and played a significant role in the purges of 1936-1938. Shafir was born in 1887 in Zhitomir, Ukraine, then part of the Russian Empire. He joined the Bolshevik Party in 1906 and served as a functionary in the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party (RSDLP) before emigrating to Soviet Russia in 1921. After working as a journalist and legal scholar in Soviet Russia and Poland, he joined the NKVD in 1934. During the 1930s, Shafir headed a special unit of the NKVD, known as the "Shafir Group", which carried out purges of officials and members of the Communist Party who were suspected of being counter-revolutionaries or traitors. He was appointed deputy commissar of Internal Affairs in 1936, and played a significant role in the purges of 1936-1938. He was arrested and executed by the GPU in 1938. Shafir is best known for his role in purging Soviet officials who were suspected of being counter-revolutionaries or traitors during the 1930s. However, he also made significant contributions to Soviet jurisprudence and literature.
